DOC.HEAD: Chernobyly Hero Pilot Honored in Seattle Memorial Service
LaserPhoto SE6
DOC.TEXT: A heroic Soviet helicopter pilot who developed leukemia after helping entomb the burning Chernobyl nuclear reactor did not die in vain, his widow said at a memorial service Thursday. Galina Grischenko spoke of the treatment her husband, Anatoly Grischenko, received at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, where he died Monday at age 53. ``I think that this example of good cooperation will help all others who have suffered in the Chernobyl disaster,'' Mrs. Grischenko said, speaking through an interpreter. About 50 hospital officials, friends of Mrs. Grischenko and well-wishers attended the service at a funeral home. Grischenko was among the pilots who flew helicopters over the damaged, highly radioactive Chernobyl nuclear plant for three days after the 1986 disaster, dropping huge loads of sand and wet cement to encase the burning reactor. He and several others in the operation were designated heroes of the Soviet Union, that country's highest honor. Grishchenko suffered acute radiation sickness after the disaster and was found to have leukemia last year. Because the only bone marrow transplant center in the Soviet Union could not treat him, he was flown to Seattle on April 11. A bone marrow transplant was performed at the cancer center later that month. Doctors reported encouraging progress after the transplant, but Grishchenko's condition worsened when a months-old lung infection flared up and he had to undergo surgery June 12. He was placed on a respirator June 15, and died Monday night. ``The term `hero' is well applied to him,'' Dr. Richard Vanderjagt said at the memorial service. ``It is sometimes used loosely but certainly not with regards to him,'' said Vanderjagt. ``I really do feel that Anatoly was a great hero.'' Dr. John Hansen, an associate director of the Hutchinson center, said Grishchenko has helped focus renewed attention on Chernobyl. ``There is a lot to be done about the Chernobyl disaster,'' Hansen said. ``And of course, there is a lot to be done about world peace.'' Grishchenko's body was to be flown back to Moscow this weekend, accompanied by Mrs. Grishchenko and the pilot's Soviet physician, Dr. Eugenia Margulis.

DOC.HEAD: NY Demonstrators Protest Yugoslavian Action
With AM-Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of ethnic Albanians from Yugoslavia staged a protest Thursday against the forced dissolution of the government in their region of the country, calling it a prelude to civil war. The protesters, gathered in front of the United Nations, said authorities in Yugoslavia's largest republic, Serbia _ which controls their region of Kosovo _ had arrested the leaders of the ethnic Albanian democracy movement. About 500 demonstrators, who temporarily blocked traffic on First Avenue, chanted ``USA!'' and ``Democracy!'' Some held up the red flag of their region, whose provincial assembly on Monday declared it would secede from Serbia. The demonstration followed the suspension Thursday by Serbian authorities of all elected and other officials in Kosovo's local government. Several leading ethnic Albanian officials and journalists were removed from their jobs at Kosovo's radio, television and the Albanian-language Rilindia publishing house, which publishes a daily newspaper. The decision to dissolve Kosovo's legislature and government was approved unanimously by all three chambers of Serbia's parliament. It came in the wake of a declaration Monday by 114 ethnic Albanian deputies in Kosovo's provincial assembly to secede from Serbia, according to television reports in the Serbian capital of Belgrade. One of the protesters, Zaide Gjonbalaj, 15, lived in Kosovo until last year. ``A lot of people got killed, they (the Serbs) just hate our guts and think we're animals. It's worse than war,'' said Gjonbalaj, who lives in the borough of Brooklyn. She said she remembered army troops last year in the capital city of Pristina throwing tear gas at school children, including her. ``There will for sure be a civil war,'' said Shefcet Karacica, of the borough of the Bronx. ``They're beating children in front of their mothers and fathers and they're sending in troops.'' Din Derti, vice chairman of the Albanian-American Civic League, a Washington-based human rights group, said relatives reported that Yugoslavian police were beating citizens and making mass arrests. An Albanian-language, Manhattan-based radio station, the Voice of Freedom, was interviewing writer Rexhep Qosja from his home in Pristina on Thursday when his telephone line suddenly went dead. The radio station later contacted the writer's wife and learned he had been arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Probe Focuses on Charge of Errant Rocket That Injured 18
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with revised injury count of 18, and that four hospitalized now all in stable condition; picks up 5th graf, ```All I ...'
DOC.TEXT: Investigators on Thursday focused on the charge that propelled an errant rocket into a crowd watching the town's July Fourth fireworks display, injuring 18 people. The six-inch rocket went off course, skidded hundreds of feet and showered the tightly packed gathering of about 10,000 people with burning debris after the rack that held it tipped over Wednesday night, authorities said. ``It was like a cannon shot into the crowd,'' Fire Chief Bernard Lach said. ``There was a big white flash and then a lot of commotion.'' Four people, including a 3-year-old boy, were hospitalized with burns. All were listed Thursday in stable condition. The others suffered minor injuries, and were treated at a hospital and released. ``All I can gather is the rack blew up and tipped over on its side,'' said Ken Lupoli, who set up the fireworks display. David Paige, who heads the state Department of Public Safety's Division of Fire and Building Safety, said, ``The damage to the rack and the condition of the rack causes us to focus on the lift charge. We're concentrating on what happened to make the rack dislodge.'' The lift charge is made up of black powder that is placed beneath the rocket. It propels the rocket through a tube into the air, Paige said. The display _ which also marked the town's 250th anniversary _ was held on a baseball field. The fireworks racks were set up in left-center field, and people sitting on blankets and lawn chairs in far right field were hit by the rocket. ``It appears everything met state regulations, but we're still investigating,'' Paige said. The accident occurred during the finale of a 45-minute display. People were about 300 feet from the launch site, Lach said. State regulations require that they be at least 200 feet away. Lupoli, a subcontractor who uses fireworks supplied by Vitale Fireworks Display Co. Inc. of New Castle, Pa., had put on similar displays in Torrington for several years and had never had any problems, city Fire Marshal Ron Corey said.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Consumes Part of Landmark Gilley's Bar
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT size of building to 70,000 square feet, sted 140,000.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HTP1
DOC.TEXT: A fire Thursday damaged part of Gilley's, the landmark country-western bar shut down more than a year ago after a legal dispute. Fire officials were investigating the cause of the blaze in this Houston suburb, which damaged parts of the 70,000-square-foot building, said Fire Chief Jay Boyner. A damage estimate was not immediately available. Several firefighters were treated at the scene for heat exhaustion, and one suffered a minor cut and was taken to a hospital for treatment, authorities said. Gilley's, which was featured in the movie ``Urban Cowboy,'' was closed more than a year ago following a legal dispute between country singer Mickey Gilley and former partner Sherwood Cryer.

DOC.SECOND: PM-AP on TV-Piece of Cake, 1st Ld-Writethru,0851
DOC.HEAD: `Piece of Cake' _ Or How to Prepare for the Battle of Britain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st Elsewhere in Television item of b0227 sent July 5 to rephrase CBS reference
DOC.TEXT: ``Piece of Cake,'' the PBS miniseries on ``Masterpiece Theater'' for the next six Sunday nights, is the compellingly watchable tale of a RAF fighter squadron during the first year of World War II. That's not to say the London Weekend Television production doesn't have its flaws. But they're not significant enough to hamper an American audience's enjoyment of a fine cast, great aerial photography and a good story. ``Piece of Cake'' _ RAF slang for a task as pleasant as it is easy _ opens in 1939, when Germany invaded Poland, Great Britain declared war on Germany and nobody did anything in particular. It was sitzkrieg, or ``phony war,'' and Germany consolidated its gains on the Continent before pushing the Allies out of France. It was more than a year before Hitler launched the air war that became known as the Battle of Britain. So we have time to learn about the gallant lads of Hornet Squadron before they defend their homeland from the Luftwaffe. Days after war is declared, their squadron leader dies in a four-foot tumble from his cockpit. Then, in their first combat, they're scrambled up against a flight of incoming planes and shoot down a fighter. Their donnish and impious intelligence officer, ``Skull'' Skelton _ wonderfully played by Richard Hope, the upmarket mobster of ``Bellman and True'' _ notes an unusual circumstance: There isn't a German fighter base within 400 miles. They've splashed one of their own. Things seem to improve a bit with the arrival of Squadron Leader Rex Ramsey (Tim Woodward), a very wealthy, very public school, very bullying, upper-class nob who runs the squadron like his private gentlemen's flying club. He transfers the squadron to France, installs it in a chateau with an excellent wine cellar and concentrates on teaching its members how to fly in tight formations _ the tactical air doctrine of the day. The British didn't know the doctrine was outmoded until the German pilots proved it by whipping them. The squadron leader's popularity plummets when the other pilots realize his insistence on formation flying is getting them killed. Rex's main antagonist is Flying Officer Chris Hart (Boyd Gaines), an American veteran of the Spanish Civil War who joined the RAF to fight fascism. His American notions of equality, and his air combat experience with the Nazis, immediately put him into conflict with Rex. Another memorable character is the utterly nasty ``Moggy'' Cattermole (Neil Dudgeon), a dashing pilot and cruel, philandering bully who's got to be seen to be appreciated. ``I've lost my hands!'' radios a pilot after being raked by enemy fire. ``That was careless of you, old chap,'' replies Moggy. You'll be rooting for the Luftwaffe. No fighting force in history deserved its apotheosis as much as the Royal Air Force for its heroic defense of Britain in World War II, and ``Piece of Cake'' took its share of flak from British audiences. The British didn't like how the miniseries violated the image of gallant chaps sitting about with lashings of tea and cakes, then winging their battered kites up to have a go at bashing the filthy Jerries. ``Piece of Cake'' also took heat from military historians for using the Spitfire fighter plane. The Spitfire, they noted, was not operational in significant numbers until mid-1940. It was the doughty Hawker Hurricane fighter that bore the brunt of the fighting until then. Producer Andrew Holmes explained the lapse: ``There are, sadly, only two Hurrricanes flying today in the world and they hardly form a squadron. But fortunately, there are a dozen or so Spitfires.'' It's a forgivable lapse, since the gull-winged Spitfire is one of the prettiest warplanes ever to take to the skies. When a half-dozen Spits claw up into the air, it approaches poetry, and director Ian Toynton's aerial unit captures the cruel, balletic beauty of 300-mph dogfights. ``Piece of Cake'' is a treat.

Elsewhere in television... IF IT'S FRIDAY, THIS MUST BE THE FINAL LEG: The network anchors, who thanks to satellites go traveling at the drop of a summit conference, all covered the annual Communist Party Congress in Moscow this week. CBS' Dan Rather, who obtained an interview Monday with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, headed home Thursday. CNN's Bernard Shaw will wrap things up today. ABC's Peter Jennings and NBC's Tom Brokaw went to London for the NATO summit conference Thursday and tonight. SUB-ANCHOR WATCH: Those checking the ``NBC Nightly News'' for signs Jane Pauley is being eased in as Brokaw's co-anchor might have been confused this week. Faith Daniels anchored the non-Moscow part of Brokaw's broadcasts Monday through Wednesday. Pauley was scheduled to subanchor the non-London segments Thursday and again tonight.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Car Dealer Must Give Car To Winner Of 1988 Hole-In-One Contest
DOC.TEXT: A car dealer must make good on an offer of a $15,000 car to the winner of a hole-in-one contest, a state appeals court has ruled. Rex P. Callicott thought he won the car at the 15th annual New York Institute of Food Technologists Inc. annual golf and tennis outing on June 6, 1988. The institute had an agreement with Garfield Chrysler-Plymouth Inc. to sponsor the event, and sent out thousands of fliers announcing ``Hole-in-one _ Car,'' according to court papers. A new Chrysler Lebaron, with a $15,560 sticker price, was stationed on the ninth hole of the Edgewood Country Club that day. Callicott was given the keys to the car at that evening's awards banquet, but the dealer refused to give him title to the car, claiming the tee-off point on the hole was 12 yards less than the distance marked on the course scorecard. A trial court, however, said the assertion that the tee markers were too close was unsubstantiated, and the appellate division of state Superior Court agreed Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Dozens Arrested As Haitians Demonstrate in Front of Store
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0407 to fix slugline. INSERTS 1 graf after 12th graf to UPDATE with officers still on scene; picks up 13th graf, `Reyes said ...'
DOC.TEXT: Police in riot gear arrested about 50 people at a demonstration Thursday by Haitian-Americans at a shopping center where last week a Haitian immigrant was allegedly beaten by Hispanic employees. The incident occurred at the Biscayne Plaza Shopping Center when police began trying to disperse the crowd, which swelled from about 50 to 100 demonstrators, said Officer George Law. About 160 officers _ outfitted with nightsticks, shields and helmets with face guards _ were called to the scene north of downtown near Little Haiti, police said. ``We told them to disperse and they failed to, so we moved in,'' said police spokesman Roberto Navarro. ``A community can't hold someone hostage like that.'' Four of those arrested were in stable condition late Thursday at Jackson Memorial Hospital after treatment for minor facial cuts, scrapes and bruises, said hospital spokesman Don Del Vecchio. Three were being held in the hospital's prison ward; a fourth was undergoing treatment in the emergency room. The rest of those arrested were taken to the Dade County Jail on charges including assault, resisting arrest, disorderly conduct and failure to disperse. The protests in front of the Rapid Transit Factory Outlet store began June 29 after a dispute between the store owner and a Haitian-American customer over alterations for a pair of pants. The customer, Abner Alezi, claimed he was beaten. Alezi, 44, and several others were later arrested for trespassing when they returned to the store to complain. When store owner Luis Reyes tried to open the store on Saturday, more than 1,000 Haitians turned out in a peaceful protest. The store then remained closed until Thursday. Police Chief Perry Anderson said his department had tried to mediate the dispute. ``We are being extremely tolerant,'' Anderson said. ``There have been rocks and bottles thrown. For two days the owner of the store has been held hostage. We have been very, very tolerant.'' At least 40 officers remained at the store late Thursday. Reyes said he planned to reopen his store Friday. ``We are here to do business and to set a principle that not us, not any merchant and not the city of Miami Police Department will be intimidated by something like this,'' said Reyes, a 65-year-old Cuban-American. ``The violence will not take over.'' The fracas left protesters' shoes, coats and hats strewn across the rainy parking lot. The confrontation at the shopping center followed tension between blacks and Hispanics over the recent visit of South African anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela. Demonstrators had complained about the alleged beating at the store and the snub of Mandela by Cuban-American leaders after the African National Congress leader refused to disavow his support of Cuban President Fidel Castro. But they also cited what they said was preferential treatment given to Cuban immigrants over Haitians, contending that Cubans are given freedom while Haitians are detained or sent home.

DOC.HEAD: `Father Teresa' Aiding Victims of Pakistan Ethnic Strife
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: When the streets of Pakistan's largest city explode in gunfire, Abdul Sattar Edhi rushes out into the urban battlefield. With the siren on his beatup mini-van blaring, he weaves through the streets on a mission of mercy, picking up the the dead, the dying and the wounded. A resurgence of ethnic and political violence has claimed more than 400 lives in Karachi and Hyderabad, 150 miles to the north, in the past month. ``When I go out on the streets of Karachi, I feel very sad,'' Edhi said of the bloodshed, which has transformed this once tranquil city on the sun-baked Arabian Sea into camps of heavily armed gangs. Edhi, 62, operates the Edhi Welfare Foundation, a $5 million a year charity he founded 30 years ago using a battered pickup truck as a one-man free ambulance service. Steadily he built it into one of the subcontinent's biggest and best-organized social service networks, boasting a fleet of 615 ambulances, a rescue helicopter, dozens of blood banks and shelters for mental patients, heroin addicts, battered wives, orphans, runaways and anyone else his staff finds wandering without help or hope. ``I was born a Moslem, but true religion is the service of humanity,'' said Edhi, a stalky man with a flowing white beard and a gruff voice. ``I'm just one man. I just want to help people.'' He is called saint, an angel of mercy, and his deeds have earned him the nickname ``Father Teresa,'' the counterpart of the tiny Roman Catholic nun who has spent her life working with the destitute and dying in the slums of Calcutta, India. His telephone rings at all hours. He is ready for any emergency, always carrying a packed bag with a small satchel that contains a change of clothes _ gray baggy pants and a matching shirt _ rubber sandals, glasses, a toothbrush and a near-toothless comb. Although his work reaches every part of Pakistan, the heart of his operation is Karachi, a city crowded with 9 million people, mostly poor and illiterate. Born in the western Indian state of Gujarat, Edhi immigrated to Pakistan during the 1947 partition that ended British colonial rule of the subcontinent. And in many ways, Edhi's simple lifestyle mirrors Mohandas K. Gandhi, the Mahatma or ``great soul'' who led that freedom struggle. Edhi and his wife, Bilquis, live in a stark room sandwiched between an office and a narrow room with only a wooden table where the bodies of Karachi's unwanted and unclaimed are laid out for burial. Edhi's bed is a wooden plank resting on a steel frame. His wife has a mattress, her only concession to comfort. Mrs. Edhi, mother of four children, looks around the room at the two-burner hot plate, a wooden table and a cupbord crammed with their possessions. ``This is my paradise,'' she said. The walls outside the dilapidated building are lined with fuzzy photographs resembling wanted posters, pictures of beggars who died in the alleyways around town. ``There are so many people lost and alone in this world,'' he sighed. ``They die alone and no one cares. So we take their pictures and hope that maybe somebody will know them.'' Edhi has buried a small city over the past three decades, washing more than 60,000 unidentified bodies and wrapping them in traditional white shrouds. In less than three hours, three bodies arrived for burial. He had already washed and prepared two earlier in the day. ``Where else would they go?'' he asked. While Edhi cares for the dead, his wife looks after the living, setting up adoptions. ``I have seen so many children die. They were thrown in garbage cans, in gutters. So I thought I'll give them to the people who want them,'' she said. She and her husband have set up homes for battered wives and centers to treat the city's 1 million heroin addicts. They also established a home for the handicapped and a girls' orphanage in two donated mansions in Karachi's affluent Clifton area, where Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto maintains a home. ``He is helping everyone,'' said Farhad Naz, a social worker in Karachi. ``Without him these women would have nowhere to go.'' In this desperately poor and troubled country, Edhi's work fills the widening gap created by the government's inability or unwillingness. He does it solely with private donations. ``When my mother died, I promised that as long as God gave me energy, I would work to help the poor and the sick,'' said Edhi, who has a sixth-grade education. ``I was not educated so when I started my efforts were small, simple and practical. But the public like it and now they give me money. My work is still simple, but it's no longer small.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Washed Down Storm Drain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs with five found alive; picks up 5th graf, `We were ...'
DOC.TEXT: Five young adults exploring a storm drain were found alive after being washed away by runoff from a thunderstorm Thursday night, authorities said. The five, who were among eight people 18 to 25 years old who were exploring the drain, were located about 350 yards inside the drain about 11:30 p.m., said Fire Department spokesman Brad Stewart. ``They're all alive,'' Stewart said. One of the eight, John Shaffer of Charleston, said he and two friends were able to escape the drain. ``We got washed down the tube,'' said Shaffer, 21. ``We got a quarter of the way down and the water got so high. We tried to get out and we got washed out. ``We were just exploring there,'' he said. ``It wasn't raining when we went in, but then the water came in.'' The storm dumped up to 1{ inches of rain in a two-hour period in the area, the National Weather Service said.

DOC.HEAD: Tanglewood Music Center Celebrates 50 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AB1
DOC.TEXT: In 1940, 17-year-old Lukas Foss packed his bags and headed for the Berkshires, eager to check out a new school that offered fledgling musicians a chance to get their hands on a real orchestra. ``Everybody knew about it,'' recalls the composer, one of a string of distinguished alumni returning this summer to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Boston Symphony Orchestra's training school. ``We very rarely got a chance to conduct an orchestra. At Tanglewood you would. It was something that everybody knew and everybody wanted right from the start,'' he said. That 1940 season at the Tanglewood Music Center founded by the great BSO director Serge Koussevitzky glittered with the names of 20th-century music: Foss and Leonard Bernstein as students, composers Aaron Copland and Paul Hindemith among the teachers. For Foss, who has been composer-in-residence at Tanglewood for two years, there's an element of nostalgia to this year's celebration. ``I don't think I ever thought as a student that I would be back as the Paul Hindemith and conducting the BSO. This is very special,'' he said. The 1990 season is the last of four in a celebration of Tanglewood's founding. This year's observance begins with a gala concert Friday night featuring the premiere of an overture ``Celebration,'' written by Foss for the occasion. Seiji Ozawa, who studied at the center in 1960, will lead the BSO in a program of Stravinsky, Verdi and Puccini. Other former students scheduled to appear this summer include Bernstein, Charles Dutoit, conductor of the Montreal Symphony Orchestra, and Zubin Mehta, conductor of the New York Philharmonic. Some things have changed in 50 years, Foss said. ``In those days it was very different because the teacher really launched your life. They didn't call it a career either, they called it your life, your work. Nowadays they call it your career and your manager does all that,'' Foss said. Today's students ``enroll here very often or not to do what they call networking,'' Foss said. ``The students are much older now, there are no 17-year-olds.'' The shift has its good and bad sides, said Foss. Career-driven musicians are motivated to work hard, but if they come for career purposes instead of wanting to learn something, that's not so good, he said. Recalling his days at Tanglewood, Foss said he worried Koussevitzky by signing up for classes under the Russian-born conductor and Hindemith. But when Koussevitzky suggested Foss take a lighter load, the teen-ager asked for an audition to show he could handle it. ``After the audition, he said, `If you want, you will have.' He was a wonderful, father-like figure to me,'' Foss said. Foss said he proved a difficult pupil. ``Hindemith once wrote to Koussevitzky and said he will not teach me again because, `Lukas wants to know but he doesn't want to follow.' Koussevitzky said, `That's wonderful,''' Foss recalled. This week, an army of lawn mowers rolled over the wide, sloping lawns of the Tanglewood estate, readying the green expanses for the onslaught of the thousands of people who descend each weekend from New York and Massachusetts to hear the BSO and celebrity guests. The history of Tanglewood, a country estate in the Berkshire hills town of Lenox, dates back to 1937, when the BSO first began giving its popular weekend concerts. The festivals continue, this weekend featuring violinist Itzhak Perlman. Concert-goers pay $16 to $58 for tickets to the 4,000-seat Tanglewood Shed, a semi-open structure, or $10 to sit on the vast lawns in front of the Shed. Across the lawns is the world of the music center where a group of 100 or so Tanglewood Fellows meet in July and by the end of summer have created an orchestra of their own. At the end of this summer, the orchestra will tour Europe under Bernstein's direction. ``It's a fun place to be,'' Foss said. ``It's not like some drudging kind of concert work, but of course the more talented the person is, the harder he works. ``Mainly, you see, what Tanglewood has, it has very wonderful people in charge. It has the right people leading it, the right people teaching and that's really the secret of its success.''

DOC.HEAD: Asylum-Seeker Tells of Hard Times, Hope for Better Life in West
With PM-Albania, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Despite working three jobs, a 28-year-old Albanian asylum-seeker says he ``just can't make a living'' in his Communist homeland and wants to go anywhere that offers the promise of a better life. He is one of the nearly 600 Albanians who have sought refuge in foreign embassies in Tirana this week in a desperate bid to flee the country. The 28-year-old, interviewed Thursday by telephone by Hungarian state radio, is holed up with 11 other Albanians in the Hungarian embassy _ one of a dozen foreign embassies in Tirana where Albanians have sought asylum. ``I came here because I just can't make a living,'' he said. ``I am 28, I have a wife and two children. I work as a bricklayer, as a driver and as a lathe operator,'' the man said, speaking in his native Albanian. His comments were translated into Hungarian. It was not clear from the interview whether his family had fled with him to the embassy. He did not explain why he chose to seek refuge in the Hungarian embassy. ``I make 400 leks (about $57 dollars a month),'' said the asylum-seeker, who was not identified by name. He said rent and electricty cost more than 50 leks a month, a 2.2 pounds of bread cost four leks, a quart of milk three leks, and a kilogram of sugar eight leks. ``Everything is very expensive here, or rather we earn very little,'' he told the radio. ``It is impossible to make a decent living.'' With the fall of Communist leaders in Hungary and most other Eastern European countries, Albania remains the last bastion of orthodox Communism in Europe. Its leaders have begun to implement some cautious reforms, such as allowing citizens to apply for passports to travel abroad. But the 28-year-old asylum-seeker said that even if he were granted a passport under the new regulations, he doesn't have enough money to pay for a trip abroad. ``Even if they would now give me a passport, I do not have the money for plane fare, but I promise to work very hard and pay it all back,'' he said. The Albanian told Hungarian radio that he would like to go to Italy, West Germany or the United States. ``Anywhere, just away from here.''

DOC.HEAD: Congress Nearing Completion of Bill to Require Double Hulls
DOC.TEXT: House and Senate negotiators are a few pen strokes from requiring double hulls on oil tankers, but industry officials say preventing oil spills carries a high price tag _ and some risk. With shipyards already receiving orders to build an extra layer of steel around the outside of oil tankers, Congress moves into the final stages of negotiations next week over provisions of a major oil spill bill that has been 15 years in the making. Already set are key provisions to increase penalties for shippers found liable for spills and to establish Coast Guard oil spill response centers along U.S. coasts. The bill also establishes a $1 billion cleanup fund through a five-cent tax on each barrel of oil produced in or imported to the United States. Environmentalists hail the double-hull requirement as an environmental safety net capable of preventing some of the major oil spills that have soiled coasts from Alaska to Rhode Island. ``Double hulls work,'' said Clifton Curtis, an ocean specialist with the environmental group Friends of the Earth. ``The evidence shows that they do add an important additional protection against spills occurring and they reduce the amount of oil that is released.'' Oil interests, while resigned to a law requiring double hulls, warn that it comes with a price tag: $30 million per ship _ a cost increase that will likely trickle down to consumers' wallets. Concessions won from Congress to allow time to build double-hulled ships are an attempt to keep those costs under control. ``We've been pointing out the cost figures since the issue first emerged,'' said Bill Taylor of the American Petroleum Institute, a Washington-based industry group. ``Whatever adjustments that have been made from the original legislative proposals reflect the tremendous costs involved.'' Although details remain to be worked out, sources said the final bill will require that new tankers and oceangoing barges weighing over 5,000 gross tons have double hulls, which consist of a second layer of steel and an air space between the sea and the cargo. Older vessels would have to be either phased out of operation or refitted with second hulls. ``At this point the double hull requirement is a foregone conclusion,'' said a House staff aide who spoke on condition of anonymity. Refitting the 153 U.S.-flagged tankers with double hulls would cost nearly $4.6 billion, or $30 million each, Taylor said. The same amount would be added on to the cost of building new tankers, meaning a 15 percent cost increase. The roughly 900 foreign-flagged tankers that call in U.S. ports would cost $20 million apiece to refit at lower-cost foreign shipyards, Taylor said. In addition to the added cost, shipping interests contend it is uncertain whether double hulls work. The National Academy of Sciences is working on a study expected to detail some of the weaknesses of double hulls. The Senate wants to give the secretary of transportation authority to review that study along with other data to see if alternatives to double hulls would work as well or better. Ernie Corrado, president of the American Institute of Merchant Marine Shipping, said preliminary results of the study show that gases trapped between the hull walls could cause an explosion and a breach in the outer wall could allow water in the cavity between the hulls, capsizing the vessel. ``It's not simply a question of economics, it's a question of safety,'' said Joe Farrell, president of the American Waterways Operators, a trade association representing coastal shippers, including oil barge haulers. The oil spill legislation has been debated in Congress for 15 years, but efforts to pass it out were stepped up after the Exxon Valdez spill of March 24, 1989. The super tanker ran aground on Bligh Reef in Alaska, spilling 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound.

DOC.HEAD: Town's Future Unclear After Oil Bust
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Main Street is quiet except for a few children riding their bikes, dodging the many holes and bumps their town can't afford to fix. For two years, this community of 1,100 has been on the verge of becoming the first in North Dakota history to declare bankruptcy. Outside town, on the edge of the scenic Badlands, an oil well reminds residents of better days as well as Belfield's uncertain future. ``It's pretty much at a standstill,'' said George Kessel, 77, who was born and raised here. ``Everybody's hanging on, waiting for things to get better.'' Oilfield worker Driggers ``Bob'' Tyndall has been in town for just three weeks, but he's been reading and hearing about Belfield's prosperous past and troubled present. ``When it was up, it was booming, it was alive,'' Tyndall said. ``But look at it now _ it's dead.'' In the late 1970s, Belfield's future looked as promising as the state's oil industry. Oil workers poured into the unprepared town, forcing officials to sell $2.1 million worth of bonds in the early 1980s to pay for water, sewers and housing. Its population swelled by almost 300. But by 1986, oil prices had dropped and Belfield was stuck with more than $1 million in unpaid property taxes owed by unemployed workers who left. City officials ruled out new taxes for people already complaining of skyrocketing costs. Instead, they hoped to work out deals with the bondholders that would pay off part of the debt or set up a payment plan. Today, the town's debt totals almost $1.9 million, and no deals are in sight. ``We were hoping we could avoid bankruptcy, but as time is going by and no clear-cut decisions are made ... we're going back to the idea that bankruptcy is going to happen,'' said former Mayor Phil Dolyniuk, who stepped down in April. ``It's going to be a battle. The next four years are going to be very difficult.'' Attorney Albert Hardy told bondholders in a February letter that city services such as water, sewer and streets were curtailed ``to the point where the health and well-being of the people remaining in Belfield may be at risk.'' Dolyniuk said Thursday that he doesn't expect any health problems, although he noted that Belfield's landfill is getting full and the town may have problems paying to get its waste shipped elsewhere. The number of full-time municipal workers has declined from seven in 1984 to four today, and the town police bought a used car last time they needed one. The town has lost a grocery store and a car dealership, although it has gained a service station and a Dairy Queen. Residents have formed a group called the Community Development Corporation to give the town a moral and financial lift. The group and others helped raise money to repair a swimming pool that had been closed for years. It also put up signs along U.S. 85 to attract travelers and turn a small conservation dam nearby into a recreation center. A new 24-page brochure was written to tell business prospects about Belfield's history, recreation and climate. Some of the efforts seem to be paying off. Arcus Environmental Inc. last month announced plans to hire 50 people for a plant that turns hazardous waste into fuel. Belfield officials are wooing a dentist so people won't have to drive 20 miles to Dickinson to get their teeth fixed. And Mayor Susan Heck is cautiously _ very cautiously _ optimistic. ``If we maintain, I think we'll be lucky,'' she said. ``We just take it a step at a time. It's gradually coming around.'' ``Nobody expects a big oil boom again,'' said Duane Indergaard, owner of Belfield's Fort Houston Museum. ``It's too early to tell. It's just too early to tell how Belfield's going to be.''

DOC.HEAD: Pickers, Grinners Frolic All Night
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Come Saturday, the moon will be full and so will Ted Walker's farm. Hundreds of pickers, fiddlers and crooners will gather on Walker's rural spread near Nashville to pay tribute to Luna from nightfall to sunrise at another Full Moon Bluegrass Party, a 13-year-old tradition. The parties have attracted crowds of 1,000 to 1,500 people and have seen well-known musicians such as Chet Atkins and Wynonna Judd sitting in with carpenters, accountants and housewives for impromptu jam sessions. ``The full moon just brings out something special in people,'' Walker said. ``They're up tempo and the moon is up tempo and everything is full energy.'' John Hedgecoth, foreman at a Nashville guitar manufacturer, rests up so he can stay up late to play banjo with the big boys. ``Spectators show up early and stay `til about midnight, and some of the musicians will brave the crowd,'' he said. ``But the serious musicians wait until about 11 p.m. to show up and the really good jam sessions start then and go all night.'' ``It's a great party. A very folksy-type atmosphere, the quality of the music,'' said Kelly Mullins, who works in Vanderbilt University's publications department. Instruments range from banjos and guitars to spoons and washboards. The singing ranges from great to terrible, says Walker, a Nashville lawyer when he's not throwing bluegrass parties. ``I'm a terrible singer, but they put up with me _ because it's my party,'' he said. The full moon parties started in August 1977 when Walker and some friends decided to have a jam session in the country, where the moonlight is brighter than in the city. They picked his homestead in Williamson County about 20 miles southwest of Nashville. They enjoyed themselves so much, they did it again the next full moon, and the tradition was on. Fiddlers and frolickers used to gather at nightfall any day the full moon rose from April to October. This year, the parties will be held only on warm, weekend nights that coincide with the full moon. ``I guess I'm getting old,'' said Walker, 48. But partyers will continue to jam through the night. ``Every full moon is followed by a day off,'' he said. The gatherings have gotten so big that Walker hires a parking crew and a cleanup crew and keeps everyone in touch with beepers and cellular phones. Walker realized in 1980 that the party's size had truly gotten out of hand _ a rowdy stranger told him to go home and not come back. That was when he started charging $5 admission. He later boosted it to $10, at musician John Prine's suggestion that it should be easier to make change. Musicians get in for free. ``I'm talkin' about bonafide bluegrass musicians, who I've either seen personally or heard of by reputation,'' Walker said. ``It's not for just the casual player, maybe for people who are one step above that.'' Groups form and re-form with different members in different spots all night long, but the theme is always the same: have fun and play that ``fast-drivin' music.'' ``It's kind of like having a buffet of music,'' Walker said. ``If you can't find something you like, you have no business out there. But if you like bluegrass, you'll find plenty to like.''

DOC.HEAD: When Harold Is Bad, Things Are Very, Very Bad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: In this summer of Steinbrenner and Zodiac shootings, it's this name that elicits maximum fear and loathing among thousands and thousands of New Yorkers: Harold. Harold will hold up 110,000 people this summer. He is a $100 million commuter headache, the alias for a massive modernization of the switching system that directs 650 Long Island Rail Road and Amtrak trains beneath the East River each day. What does Harold mean to the 110,000 daily riders on the nation's largest commuter railroad, the LIRR? Try systemwide delays, overcrowded trains and elimination of some service. Overall, commuters should expect ``fairly rotten service'' for the next nine weeks, predicted Sheldon Schachter, chairman of the LIRR Commuters Council. Work began Monday and runs through Sept. 4. ``You know about Harold? It's a nightmare,'' said Andy Donnelly, a Manhattan financial analyst, shortly after his train arrived 15 minutes late Thursday morning at Penn Station. Donnelly, of Huntington, has traveled back and forth from Long Island most weekdays since 1986. But the arrival of Harold has persuaded him to put those days behind him, Donnelly said. ``My solution is I'm moving into the city, Upper East Side,'' said Donnelly. ``I'm not going to deal with it this summer.'' There's already enough to deal with: the heat, George Steinbrenner's systematic destruction of the Yankees, a gunman selecting victims based on their birth signs. But now there's Harold, short for the 80-year-old Harold Interlock System. Round-the-clock work on the antiquated system will replace track, switches and signals in Harold, bringing it into the '90s. But until the work is finished ... ``Did you ever have a bad day, one of those days where nothing goes right? Well, picture a whole summer like that,'' said Schachter, who has traveled between Rockville Centre and Manhattan for two decades. State consumer watchdog Richard Kessel warned the LIRR could become like the heavily congested Long Island Expressway, which is often more parking lot than parkway. ``It's going to be traffic jams on the rails,'' Kessel said. Harold derives its name from the days before the city had numbered streets, said LIRR spokeswoman Susan McGowan. Before becoming 39th Street, the road nearest the tower was Harold Street. ``Who the original Harold was, we don't know,'' said McGowan. ``It's a mystery.'' Everybody knows about Harold now. Posters about the Harold problems _ featuring a nifty little logo with a train switching signal as the ``o'' in ``Harold'' _ are plastered on bulletin boards, walls and pillars throughout Penn Station. ``Penn Service Suspended,'' read the most severe notices, alerting reverse commuters that morning rush hour service from Manhattan to Long Island is history until after Labor Day. These 5,000 riders are left to their own creative devices for rush hour transportation. Fourteen employees at CMP Publications in Manhasset have kicked in to rent a van each day that will carry them to the office and home. Matt Sheerin, an employee at CMP, decided to try another option. ``I've given up and bought a car,'' said Sheerin, a Manhattan resident and the proud new owner of a 1981 Honda. Using the LIRR, Sheerin's commute was about 60 minutes; taking the subway to the LIRR in Queens takes 90 minutes; driving in this week ran 35 minutes. ``I think one of the things the LIRR overlooked is the off-peak riders,'' said Sheerin. ``They'll end up losing riders, and I'm one of them. I won't be back _ unless my car gets stolen.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: With Cold War Over, US Agenda for Hemisphere Changes
DOC.TEXT: President Bush gave an important but little noticed speech on hemispheric policy last week. What set it apart from virtually every other presidential initiative for the Americas over the past two generations was that it had nothing to do with fighting communism. This week Bush is attending the first post-Cold War NATO summit. And last week's speech showed that with East-West tensions in decline, he now has the luxury of giving priority to the hemisphere's economic troubles as opposed to security concerns. Bush said that to bolster the hemisphere's newly emerging democracies, there is need for more trade and investment and additional debt relief. The speech was a departure from past initiatives, which had the underlying rationale of keeping Marxism out of the hemisphere. The list is long. There was the CIA-initiated coup in Guatemala in 1954, the American-sponsored invasion of Cuba in 1961 and the creation of the ambitious social and economic development program called the Alliance for Progress that same year. There was the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, the U.S. military intervention in the Dominican Republic in 1965 and the efforts to undercut Chile's leftist government from 1970-73. Hemispheric policy during the Reagan years was devoted largely to combating leftist forces in Central America. The Caribbean Basin Initiative of the early 1980s was partly a response to leftist gains. Bush's new proposal is aimed at reversing the economic decline that afflicted much of Latin America during the 1980s. He offered some debt relief and promised to open the United States to more hemispheric exports if U.S. goods are granted the same treatment. The ultimate aim, he said, is a ``free trade system that links all of the Americas _ north, central and south _ and we look forward to the day when not only are the Americas the first fully free democratic hemisphere, but when all are equal partners in a free trade zone stretching from the port of Anchorage to the Tierra del Fuego.'' A long, hard effort lies ahead, but Susan Kaufman Purcell of the Americas Society believes it is well worthwhile. She points out that U.S. exporters could benefit greatly from a market encompassing 435 million people. Ms. Purcell says Latin Americans have been worried about being ignored as a result of the end of the Cold War. As a result, she says, there is a new receptivity among Latin Americans for closer ties with the United States. ``A hemispheric free trade zone is therefore an idea whose time has come,'' Ms. Purcell writes. The Washington Post editorialized last Friday that Bush's proposal could bring immense benefits to Latin American countries, where closed economies and protection of monopolies have created ``great wealth for a few people at the top and great poverty for the rest.'' ``Opening up these economies will be bad for the monopolies but very good for the middle class and the people trying to climb into it,'' the Post said. Reaction to the Bush proposal has been almost universally favorable in Latin America. The contrast in attitudes toward the United States during the 1980s is considerable. Those were the days when Reagan administration tried mightily to enlist hemispheric support behind its policy of arming the Nicaraguan Contras, but to little avail. With Nicaragua no longer an issue and communism less of a concern to Washington, many believe the prospects for a productive U.S.-Latin American relationship seem brighter than at any time in years. The Inter-American Dialogue, a gathering of 50 leaders from throughout the Americas, said Bush's initiative ``is welcome, timely and potentially significant. Indeed, it could mark a turning point in inter-American relations _ if it is now turned from a broad vision to concrete and joint actions.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for The Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Sex Scandal Distant Dark Cloud for Local Hero Barney Frank
LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: The Washington sex scandal that vaulted openly gay U.S. Rep. Barney Frank to national notoriety is a remote worry for the local hero firmly entrenched among voters in this bastion of New England liberalism. His widely publicized involvement with a homosexual prostitute remains an embarrassment, but he faces no serious opposition in his bid for a sixth congressional term and refuses to dwell on his admitted indiscretions. He called his relationship with male prostitute Stephen Gobie a ``stupid mistake,'' but said it shouldn't interfere with his work. ``Talking about my personal angst does not have any bearing on the policies I'm elected to carry out,'' he said Thursday in an interview at his office in West Newton Square in suburban Boston. The House ethics committee is expected to release its report soon on his association with Gobie, but back home during the congressional recess it's political business as usual for Frank. Frank admitted paying Gobie for sex and letting him move into his home, but denied allegations he knew Gobie was operating a prostitution ring under his roof. The congressman greets visitors and the news media dressed in a rumpled blue T-shirt and casual pants, but is far from laid back. ``All right, `I'm ready,'' he grunted. Pleasantries fall by the wayside, Frank explained later, because ``I do a lot of things at one time and I like to do them fast.'' Frank is one of only two openly gay members of Congress and represents some of the most liberal communities in the country's most liberal state, but the only stereotype that applies is that of a veteran politician. He is never far from the telephone, and blends charm with firm stands on issues such as affordable housing, health care, education, and reducing the defense budget. Frank, 50, seems a shoo-in to win his sixth term in November. The only serious Republican contender, James Nuzzo, recently dropped out of the race for personal reasons. Republican John Soto, his only other opponent, recently called for Frank to take an AIDS test and is not supported by party leaders. After the relationship was disclosed by The Washington Times, Frank acknowledged hiring Gobie for sex in 1985. He said he later hired Gobie as an aide and driver and paid him with personal funds. Gobie has claimed that he based his prostitution ring at Frank's Capitol Hill apartment, with Frank's knowledge. Frank denied that allegation and said he fired Gobie in August 1987 after learning of the prostitution ring. Members of the House Ethics Comittee are reportedly split over how severely to punish Frank, with some favoring a light sanction such as a letter criticizing his behavior. But any mild sanction is expected to be challenged on the floor of the House. Rep. William E. Dannemeyer, R-Calif., has promised to push for an expulsion resolution and others reportedly will introduce resolutions for reprimand or censure. Frank said he minimized damage from the scandal by telling the truth. ``It was better than I expected,'' Frank said. ``The important thing was that I explained what happened. ``If all it was that I hired a prostitute, people will think simply that you showed pretty bad judgment. If you lied and if this is a pattern, that would be bad.'' Outside, residents confirmed Frank's salvaged popularity. ``Personally, I like Barney Frank,'' said Bill Andrews, 43. ``I think he's been straightforward and honest. I think he's done good work. And as far as that whole thing, he's satisfied all the questions I had with what he's said.'' Frank said he is working on a book for Random House that will focus on his pet philosophy that, while liberal issues are popular, liberalism is not. ``We let the right look as if they're pro-America,'' said Frank. ``Liberals should start talking more about what's good about America rather than saying how badly flawed it is.''

DOC.HEAD: South Korea Plans To Exchange Newspaper Correspondents With Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: South Korea plans to exchange news media correspondents with the Soviet Union even before the two countries normalize relations, government sources said today. One source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the exchange may take place this fall. Government sources said officials of the two countries will meet later this month to discuss related matters, including the number of correspondents to be exchanged and their activity and security. Despite a lack of diplomatic relations, South Korea and the Soviet Union have steadily expanded contacts. Some speculated that they might agree to start formal relations before the end of this year. Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev met with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo in San Francisco last month and agreed to work toward normalizing their relations. The Soviet Union is a close ally and arms provider for Seoul's rival, communist North Korea.

DOC.HEAD: After Fifteen Years, Domestic Terrorists Still Baffle Police
DOC.TEXT: Almost every week since mid-May, bombs blamed on leftists have rocked the Greek capital. But while terror groups have been wiped out elsewhere in Europe, Greece has failed to arrest a single suspect. Most of the bombings in Greece are believed to be the work of a shadowy group called November 17 or of other groups inspired by them. November 17 _ which takes its name from the day in 1973 when the right-wing military junta crushed a student rebellion _ first surfaced in December 1975 with the assassination of Athens CIA station chief Richard Welch. The United States has called November 17 one of the deadliest terrorist groups in Europe. In the past 14 years, the group has assassinated 14 people, including three U.S. officials. Despite promises to crack down on terrorism, successive Greek governments _ both conservative and socialist _ have failed to arrest a single homegrown terrorist. Experts say November 17's success in evading arrest depends mainly on their own ruthless efficiency, small membership, and a police force that appears to have been unprepared to deal with urban terrorism. Premier Constantine Mitsotakis, whose conservative New Democracy Party won a slender victory in April's election, has a personal reason to want to do better than his predecessors in stamping out terrorism. Last year, November 17 assassinated his son-in-law Pavlos Bakoyannis. ``If there is any danger to Greece it is from terrorism,'' the conservative politician warned Parliament in January. Terrorist attacks here in the mid-1980s with Arab involvement led to claims that Greece was soft on terrorism. In the past two years, there have been no international terrorist incidents. But November 17 and similar domestic groups remain active, even though they have failed to create a broad climate of terror. ``Our problem is domestic terrorism, and that means November 17,'' a top state security official said in a recent interview. ``They are trying to create the impression that there is widespread terrorism and ... they encourage other groups to copy them,'' said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. November 17 has claimed responsibility for only two of seven recent bombings. The other attacks have been claimed by a previously unknown group calling itself Popular Rage. No one has been seriously injured in the attacks. Various reasons are put forth for Greece's failure in combating terrorism. Conservatives suggest that during the 1981-89 socialist administration the state security apparatus was indecisive. ``As soon as there is systematic work, the necessary political will, and cooperation with all other countries of the world (terrorism) will be confronted,'' Mitsotakis' daughter, Dora Bakoyannis, said in an interview. She was elected to her slain husband's seat in Parliament and is one of the premier's closest aides. The latest state budget has increased funding by 27 percent for the Public Order Ministry. More money and material have been promised to the anti-terrorist units, and the government has pledged to work with foreign intelligence agencies. The conservatives want to wipe out any impression left from the eight-year socialist administration of Andreas Papandreou that Greece is lax in fighting terrorism. The United States issued a highly publicized travel advisory in 1985, warning its citizens that Athens airport was unsafe after Arab terrorists hijacked a TWA jet shortly after it left the Greek capital. In 1987, the United States accused Greece of allowing the notorious Abu Nidal organization to operate a logistics office in Athens, allegedly in exchange for immunity from terrorist attacks. The socialists threatened to call off negotiations on a new defense pact with the United States, and Washington withdrew the accusation. But subsequent refusals to extradite Palestinians wanted in Italy and the United States made Greece appear to be a haven for terrorists, and may have deprived Greek security services of foreign intelligence material, a foreign diplomat said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Mitsotakis has said that the Palestinian sought by the United States on charges of planting a bomb on an American airliner in 1982 will either be extradited or tried in Greece. The blast over Hawaii killed one person and wounded 15. Some experts have suggested that part of the problem in fighting domestic terrorism is the bad reputation gained by the security services from 1967 to 1974 when they supported the military junta. November 17 has played on the police links with past repression, trying to present itself as a latter-day Robin Hood-type group that chooses selective targets and won't harm common people. Its long messages to newspapers, emblazoned with a red five-pointed star, offer a mixture of intellectual arguments and revolutionary jargon. It urges armed struggle as the only means to overturn what it calls a corrupt society. An opinion poll published early last year indicated that almost 6 percent of those polled would consider voting for November 17 in an election.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers Union Accepts Non-Traditional Teacher Certification
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest teachers union abandoned its resistance to allowing engineers, scientists and other midcareer professionals into the classroom while they study to become teachers. The 2 million-member National Education Association had opposed so-called alternative certification programs because it said recruiting non-teachers to combat faculty shortages undercut traditional licensing programs. The policy adopted Thursday during the first day of the union's four-day convention won passage because it established standards like mandatory bachelor's degrees, supervision by certified teachers and enrollment in teacher accreditation courses, officials said. ``I'm not in favor of blanket alternative certification,'' said Rosanne Bacon, president of the Massachusetts Teachers Association, a former opponent of such teacher recruitment efforts. ``This proposal sets up clear, high standards for teachers coming in on a non-traditional route. It carefully opens access to the teaching profession,'' she said. The policy statement said alternative-route certification can attract sorely needed minorities and experts in math, science, foreign languages and special education. Rising teacher shortages in recent years prompted officials to begin luring professionals from fields outside education, but teachers objected to allowing them into the classroom before they completed teacher certification programs. According to the NEA, there will be a demand for 1.3 million new teachers by 1994. In a survey of 191 of the nation's largest school districts, 48 percent reported a shortage of teacher applicants. A new study by the National Center for Education Information found that 33 states are implementing alternative routes _ up from 23 less than two years ago. Eight states hired such instructors in 1983. Not everyone agreed with the vote. Bernard Anderson of Reno, Nev., said non-traditional certification routes mask the real issues behind the nationwide teacher shortage. ``Had they raised teacher salaries, then we would have been able to attract people with proper credentials into our profession,'' said Anderson, speaking for the Nevada delegation of about 70 teachers. The NEA document is the first official support by the entire union for the concept. It takes a middle ground between outright opposition to alternative certification and those who feel that any college graduate can teach school. ``The National Education Association remains committed to ensuring that there is a fully licensed, qualified teacher in every classroom _ but recognizes that there may be more than one way to prepare such teachers,'' the policy statement said. NEA President Keith Geiger said the union succeeded in getting the policy adopted mainly because it emphasized those taking alternative routes would have to meet strict standards. The policy statement stresses that the objective of both a traditional and non-traditional route is ``to rigorously prepare an individual to obtain a standard, full teaching license.'' ``A non-traditional route does not lead to an alternative license,'' the document said. Standards listed in the NEA policy include: _Programs must be conducted in conjunction with a state-approved college or university teacher education program. _Every candidate should have at least a bachelor's degree. _Candidates must receive substantial training in how to teach before beginning classroom work. _Candidates working in the classroom must be supervised by a fully-licensed, trained mentor and be evaluated frequently. _To become fully licensed, the candidate must meet the same state requirements as those required of traditional-route teachers.

DOC.HEAD: Korean War Unit Remembers Defeat 40 Years Later
DOC.TEXT: Forty years ago this week the young men of the U.S. Army's Task Force Smith were sent in search of the North Korean army with the order to ``stop the enemy where you find them.'' Task Force Smith found its enemy on a hillside 22 miles south of Seoul. After fighting for seven hours against overwhelming odds with weapons incapable of stopping tanks, the unit was overrun. Gen. Carl E. Vuono, the Army's current chief of staff, said the object lesson in the story of Task Force Smith is that the unit symbolized an Army paralyzed by the rapid demobilization and deep budget cuts that followed World War II. The story could be repeated, he said, if the Army of 1990 is cut too quickly and deeply in search of a ``peace dividend'' as East-West tensions relax. ``That Fifth of July was one of the worst days of my life,'' said Floyd R, Martin, 79, of Tucker, Ga., who on that day was an Army major and executive officer of Task Force Smith, a hurriedly assembled force of two infantry companies and an artillery unit. ``I just couldn't believe we were forced off that hill, and we were very reluctant to leave that hill,'' Martin said Thursday night. ``I could not believe that would happen to us. We were pretty dejected at the end of that day.'' ``But we just didn't have what we needed to do the job,'' Smith said as 15 or so former comrades milled around him at a unit reunion, retelling the stories of battle and retreat. Task Force Smith, named for its commander, Lt. Col. Charles Bradford Smith, was the first U.S. fighting force to enter combat in the Korean war. What was missing in the unit was just about everything it needed. Pulled with little notice from occupation duty in Japan, the officers and men of Task Force Smith say they had inadequate training. When the sun rose on July 5 and they looked down on a miles-long column of North Korean infantry in trucks and 33 Soviet T-34 tanks, the 400-plus soldiers discovered other shortcomings. They had been issued exactly six artillery rounds powerful enough to pierce the armor of such tanks. Their bazookas were too light to do the job, their rockets simply bouncing off the armor. Their radios failed and could not be used to call for help or artillery support. They had little or no intelligence about the enemy. There was no medical evacuation system and when the order came to withdraw, 30 of the most seriously injured had to be left behind. And when Task Force Smith broke for cover, chewed up by North Korean automatic fire with heavy casualties, no maps had been issued to tell them where they were or where friendly forces might be found. ``I did not know that those bazookas would not knock out a tank,'' Martin said. ``All we could do is scratch the paint on the tanks and annoy the tankers,'' said Carl Bernard, 64, a platoon leader in Task Force Smith and like Martin, a retired Army colonel. Although many of those present said they would not have believed it when they stumbled off their hill in defeat four decades ago, Gen. Vuono was present to give their keynote address and to hail them as a symbol of counterproductive cost-cutting. ``You did all that your nation had a right to expect, but you were the victims of those who believed there was little need for trained and ready military forces in peacetime,'' he said. The Army is ready to cut back, he said. ``But precipitous cuts of more than about 35,000 active soldiers in any single year will fracture the combat capability that may be required to defend our nation's vital interests,'' Vuono added. Martin said he agrees. The moral of Task Force Smith, he said, is: ``Never again send people into combat ill-prepared and without proper weapons.''

DOC.HEAD: Six Injured When Amtrak Train Collides With Tractor-Trailer Rig
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `The injured ...' to CORRECT that 4 Amtrak employees sent to hospital. picks up 5th graf, `Debbie Hare ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MRD1
DOC.TEXT: An Amtrak train collided with a tractor-trailer rig Thursday, sending eight people to hospitals, authorities said. ``The train's whistle was blowing the whole time and, Lord, it sounded like a bomb when they hit,'' said Nila Williams, who saw the crash from a window at the Torch Truckstop where she worked. She said it appeared the train struck the truck's trailer rather than the cab. The injured were treated at Meridian hospitals and released, officials said. Four Amtrak employees and two passengers were treated at Jeff Anderson Regional Hospital; another passenger and the truck driver were treated at Riley Memorial Hospital. Debbie Hare, spokeswoman for Amtrak in Chicago, said the injured included the engineer and an assistant engineer. She said as many as 20 passengers had requested medical attention. The New York-bound train, the Crescent, remained upright and only the engine and the first set of wheels on the second of eight cars had derailed, Hare said. She said the truck was carrying railroad crossties. The train's manifest showed 170 passengers were aboard when the train left New Orleans but the number could have changed before it reached Meridian, Hare said. Hare said passengers remained aboard undamaged cars, which were pulled back into Meridian's Amtrak station. She said the passengers were to be taken by bus to Birmingham, Ala., to board another Amtrak train for the remainder of their journeys. The accident occurred at a crossing off U.S. 11, shortly before 11 a.m.

DOC.HEAD: Farms Doing Better, But Numbers Declining, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: A profile of U.S. agriculture shows farmers are moving toward the 21st century with a financial condition much improved from a few years ago. But the report issued Thursday by the Agriculture Department also further nailed down an old trend showing that farm numbers are still declining and that big superfarms continue to grow. ``The proportion of farms that are financially vulnerable today is half that of 1985,'' the report said. ``Farmland prices have stabilized and are beginning to rise.'' The number of farms in the United States ``continued to decline throughout the 1980s as they have, almost unabated, since 1935,'' the report said. According to the 1987 census of agriculture, there were just over 2 million farms, down 7 percent from 1982, when the previous census was taken. Small farms, although fewer in number, increased as a proportion of total farms. Mid-sized farms declined both in number and their share of the total. ``The number of large farms continued to increase,'' the report said. ``This trend shows little prospect of reversing in the near future.'' The analysis by USDA's Economic Research Service was based on an annual report to Congress on the status of family farms. ``Virtually all farms in the United States are family-owned businesses,'' the report said. ``Fewer than 3 percent of all farms are organized as corporations, most of which are family held.'' Only 0.3 percent are corporations owned and operated by people other than a family. Single families own 87 percent of all farms, and multifamily partnerships operate the remainder. ``Because almost all farms are owned and operated by one or more families, we did not define family farm for this report,'' the agency said. Thomas A. Carlin, one of the editors, said ``a snapshot of the farm sector'' shows that most U.S. farms are small, non-commercial and usually family-owned and -operated. Non-commercial units were defined as those having gross farm sales of less than $40,000 a year. ``Small, non-commercial farms produce a minor share of total U.S. food and fiber,'' Carlin said in the report's overview. ``They are typically located near more densely settle urban areas where non-farm employment opportunities abound.'' The small farms often operate at a loss, with farm expenditures exceeding commodity sales, government payments and other farm-related income. ``Family well-being for these small farms depends primarily on off-farm income, and their average total income in most years is commensurate with that of all U.S. families,'' Carlin wrote. Most of the nation's food and fiber is produced by ``very large commercial farms'' that are highly capitalized, Carlin said. Owners of such large farms typically control several million dollars of land, machinery and other assets. ``Many of the largest farms produce fruits, vegetables and horticultural specialty crops, crops not covered by federal price and income support programs,'' he said. Farming is the dominant occupation for families operating large holdings, and annual income in most years is above that of the U.S. average. Families with large operations do report off-farm income, but that is typically from interest, rent or dividends rather than from a job paycheck. With some exceptions, most big farms are located away from major urban centers, in areas conducive to large-scale operations. ``The number of mid-sized commercial farms ... continues to shrink,'' Carlin said. ``Most of these farms produce food and feed grains that are included in federal commodity programs.'' Thus, he said, mid-sized farms get more than half of all direct government payments. Operators are usually employed full time on the farm, but often someone else in the household works off the farm. Copies of the report, ``The U.S. Farming Sector Entering the 1990s, AIB-587,'' can be ordered for $11 per copy from ERS-NASS, P.O. Box 1608, Rockville, Md. 20849-1608. Or call toll-free 1-800-999-6779.

Beef consumption is rising slowly in Japan, but an Agriculture Department trade report says high prices are discouraging all-out dining on steaks and roasts. The item in AgExporter magazine said recent Japanese government figures put per capita beef consumption at 5.4 kilograms, or 11.9 pounds, in 1988-89, up 8 percent from the previous year, reflecting larger imports. ``Beef consumption in Japan is still well below U.S. consumption of 31.7 kilograms (69.9 pounds),'' the report said. ``One deterrent to even faster increases in beef consumption is the high prices of beef.'' Recently, the report said, some Tokyo supermarkets were selling U.S. frozen tenderloin steaks for $15 per pound, chilled tenderloin steaks from fed Holstein steers for $20 per pound, Australian chilled tenderloin blocks for $12 per pound and fed Holstein round for $13 per pound. That would be at least two to four times the retail prices paid by American consumers for comparable cuts of beef. James V. Parker, U.S. minister-counselor for agricultural affairs in Tokyo, said Japanese consumers apparently are waiting for trade liberalization next year, when they expect beef prices to drop sharply. ``However, consumers are likely to be disappointed, according to some importers, because of the tariff increase to 70 percent and the likelihood of further depreciation of the yen against the dollar,'' he said. Currently, the landed price of beef in Japan is about the same as what it will be under liberalization. Parker said Japan now charges a 25 percent tariff on beef plus a surcharge of roughly 50 percent for the domestic livestock industry. That is only slightly above the 70 percent tariff that will take effect with liberalization on April 1, 1991. However, Parker said competition among Japanese distributors and retailers may reduce beef prices.

DOC.HEAD: Only One Health Worker for Every 500 Peasants in China
DOC.TEXT: Medical care in rural China is so lacking that 500 people share a single health worker who probably has never had professional training, an official report said today. By contrast, six health workers serve every 1,000 urban residents, the English-language China Daily said in a report. Furthermore, 63 percent of the medical staff in hospitals at the township level ``have never received regular professional education,'' the paper quoted Huang Yongchang, of the Ministry of Public Health, as saying. In an attempt to narrow the gap between urban and rural health care, the Public Health Ministry has launched a program to emphasize the training of medical personnel in the countryside, Huang said.

DOC.HEAD: Dick Tracy Cartoon Series Accused of Stereotyping
DOC.TEXT: Dick Tracy is taking heat from Asian and Hispanic groups, who say his sidekicks in a 29-year-old cartoon series are offensive stereotypes. The series has been broadcast weekdays at 8 a.m. for the last four weeks on Disney-owned KCAL-TV Channel 9 to coincide with the release of Disney's film, ``Dick Tracy.'' The characters considered objectionable are ``Jo Jitsu,'' a buck-toothed, squinty-eyed, crime-fighting assistant who can't pronounce the letter r, and ``Go Go Gomez,'' a heavily accented Hispanic who spends a lot of time taking siestas and saying things like ``Ay, chihuahua.'' ``I thought this was no longer acceptable in the public media,'' said Raul Ruiz, a Chicano studies professor at Cal State Northridge. ``This city is composed of human beings and all of us have differences; what this does is point out that differences are not necessarily positive.'' Ron Wakabayashi, executive director of the Los Angeles City Human Relations Commission and a member of the Japanese American Citizens League, said he is dismayed by the depictions. A team of KCAL executives have begun reviewing the series and episodes deemed offensive will not be broadcast, Jim Saunders, KCAL vice president and station manager, said Thursday. An employee in the station's programming department screened the series before the promotional broadcast began four weeks ago, and found it suitable for television, Saunders said. Since the concerns have been raised, Saunders said, ``we are rescreening them all.'' Saunders said the station had received only one private citizen complaint about the cartoons. The cartoon series is distributed by Sachs Finley Programming. Shelly Hirsh, president of programming at Sachs Finley, said the company is concerned about a possible unfavorable reaction to the ``Dick Tracy'' cartoon series. ``We're monitoring it in other stations around the country,'' Hirsh said. The cartoons also are available in video stores through Paramount Home Video. A spokseswoman for the video company said the cartoons had been screened and so far there were no consumer complaints.

DOC.HEAD: Forensic Expert Says Cocaine Traces Found
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Court resumes 9 a.m. EDT with arguments over admitting Farrakhan, Stallings; will be led
DOC.TEXT: Traces of cocaine were found last month on business cards recovered from the coat pockets of one of Marion Barry suits, an FBI forensics expert testified at the mayor's trial. The testimony Thursday was designed to bolster the government's assertions of frequent drug use by the mayor, who is accused of 10 counts of cocaine possession and one count of conspiracy. He also is on trial for three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his alleged involvement with drugs. ``There were traces of cocaine on each of the three groups of business cards'' found in the pockets of Barry's coat, testified FBI agent Thomas Lynch. The coat was seized by the FBI in the mayor's Jan. 18 arrest at the Vista International Hotel in an FBI sting. Meanwhile, lawyers for Nation of Islam Minister Louis Farrakhan and Imani Temple Bishop George Stallings, an excommunicated Catholic priest, were to argue today before U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson that the two should be admitted to Barry's trial. A federal appeals court refused Thursday to order that Farrakhan and Stallings be admitted, but sent the matter to Jackson for further consideration, saying the two could not be barred simply because they advocate a particular viewpoint. Jackson barred the two last week, saying their presence would be ``potentially disruptive'' and intimidating. On Thursday, Lynch testified that the scientific tests on the business cards were not conducted until mid-June. There was no explanation for the delay. Lynch also testified that crack cocaine was recovered from a small pocket of Barry's suit. The FBI had supplied crack to ex-model Rasheeda Moore for the sting operation against Barry. Moore testified that Barry put some of the crack in his pocket just before his arrest. In other testimony, prosecution witness Carole Jackson testified that Barry sat on the side of a bathtub snorting cocaine through a straw in the summer of 1986. That was around the time the mayor was announcing ``Operation Clean Sweep'' to rid the city of drugs. Jackson testified that she, Barry, Moore and another man used cocaine in the bathroom of an apartment. Jackson said she was ``absolutely positive'' she watched the mayor take cocaine ``into the nose through a straw,'' and that later in the evening Barry made ``several sexual advances'' that she declined. Minutes before Jackson's testimony, the prosecution played a videotape of Barry on Sept. 26, 1986, announcing a police undercover operation that targeted drug users as well as pushers. Those who complain about undercover police officers selling drugs to drug users are ``crybabies,'' Barry said in announcing the operation. ``We want every drug buyer to know'' that their dealer might be a police officer, said Barry. Three and a half years later, Barry was caught in the sting operation at the Vista. He is arguing that he was the victim of entrapment.

DOC.HEAD: Royal Newlyweds Make Pilgrimage to Shrine
DOC.TEXT: Royal newlyweds Prince Akishino and Princess Kiko today made a pilgrimage to Japan's most sacred Shinto shrine, where they paid homage to the sun goddess in a centuries-old tradition. Thousands of flag-waving Japanese turned out to welcome the couple married one week ago. Reports had said the two wanted to honeymoon in Thailand, but the imperial palace prevailed upon them to make a series of ceremonial visits to sacred sites instead. Attended by priests in flowing white robes, Prince Akishino, formerly known as Prince Aya, presented a sacred branch to the sun goddess Amaterasu at a simple wooden altar, and he and his bride bowed low. Akishino, 24, is second-in-line of succession to his father, Emperor Akihito.
