The royal newlyweds were dressed in formal Western clothing, the prince wearing a morning coat and carrying a silk top hat and Princess Kiko in an olive green gown with white hat and gloves. The shrines of Ise, on the central Japan coast about 200 miles southwest of Tokyo, are the most sacred to followers of Shinto, Japan's indigenous religion. Myth says Japan's imperial family is descended from the sun goddess enshrined here. Princess Kiko, 23, a graduate student in psychology and the daughter of a college professor, is only the second commoner to marry into Japan's royal family. Akishino's elder brother, Crown Prince Naruhito, 30, has yet to marry. The newlyweds were traveling next to Nara, an ancient Japanese capital, where they were to visit the tomb of Japan's first emperor, Jimmu, who according to legend ascended the throne in 660 B.C. Their honeymoon will end Sunday in Tokyo, when they will pay their respects at the tomb of the late Emperor Hirohito, Akishino's grandfather.

DOC.HEAD: Architects Group Agrees to End Alleged Anti-Competitive Practice
DOC.TEXT: The American Institute of Architects is agreeing to a consent decree settling a government lawsuit that charged it unlawfully restrained competition among its members for design services. The civil antitrust suit, which the Justice Department filed simultaneously in federal court with the proposed consent decree, accused the AIA of trying to prohibit its 54,000 members from engaging in competitive bidding, giving discounts and providing free services. The consent decree will force architects to compete to provide customers not only the best design but also the best price for their services, Justice Department spokesman Frank Kelly said Thursday. The department's complaint charged that national officers of the Washington-based professional society endorsed and promoted a 1984 policy statement of the AIA's Chicago chapter that barred architects from submitting bids, giving discounts or providing free design services. The Chicago chapter's statement said it was unethical for architects to submit price quotations where price was the ``sole or dominant consideration in the selection of an architect,'' according to U.S. District Court papers. The complaint charged that the AIA entered into a conspiracy between September 1984, when the Chicago statement was issued, that lasted at least through February 1985 to restrain price competition. The proposed consent decree, which was submitted for court approval following a 60-day comment period, requires the AIA to implement an elaborate antitrust compliance program to educate its members about the law.
DOC.HEAD: Government Levies Record Fine In Fatal Mining Explosion
DOC.TEXT: The operator of a Kentucky mine where 10 workers died in an explosion last year has to pay more than $500,000 in fines, the largest penalty ever assessed by the government in a mine disaster. Pyro Mining Co. said it would appeal the fine, which was levied Thursday by the Labor Department's Mine Safety and Health Administration. The penalty stemmed from 121 alleged violations of federal safety laws. ``We're just not making any comment at all beyond the fact that we're surprised by the size of the penalty. The appeal is in process and we will continue that,'' said James Greenlee, executive vice president of Evansville, Ind.-based Costain Coal Inc., which owns Pyro Mining. The Labor Department contends Pyro managers knew explosive methane gas was accumulating in the mine four days before the explosion but failed to take action. ``We consider the violations in this case so flagrant and indicative of the company's negligence that this fine is warranted,'' William J. Tattersall, assistant labor secretary for mine safety, said of the record fine. Before Thursday, the largest penalty ever assessed for a mine accident stemmed from a 1976 blast that killed 26 workers at the Scotia mine near Oven Fork, Ky. In that investigation, the Blue Diamond Coal Co. was assessed $266,000.
DOC.HEAD: Federal Lab Says Its Has Found Nearly All Of $45 Million In Missing Items
DOC.TEXT: The Lawrence Livermore Laboratory says it has accounted for all but a fraction of the more than $45 million in equipment that had been reported missing. In a statement released Thursday by the Department of Energy's San Francisco office, officials said that as of Tuesday the lab could account for all but 2 percent of the items noted as missing by the General Accounting Office. ``We have located about 98 percent of all the missing property,'' said Carol Powell of the DOE in San Francisco. ``We don't expect we'll ever achieve 100 percent.'' A statement by the nuclear weapons research and development facility laboratory in Livermore, Calif. said that the only equipment still missing had an acquisition value of about $4.5 million and a current value of about $2 million. The GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, released a report Tuesday saying that as of mid-January, the Livermore laboratory was missing more than $45 million worth of equipment. The study said there were 27,538 missing items, ranging from typewriters to computers, and that the missing equipment represented 16 percent of the Livermore inventory. Livermore said the laboratory continued its inventory efforts after the GAO study ended in January and that all but a fraction of the missing items have been found.

DOC.HEAD: Police Seek to Halt Wild Driving
DOC.TEXT: Alarmed over reckless driving and escalating accidents, police said today they will file attempted murder charges against a city bus driver and a trucker who failed to heed orders to stop. In one case, a policeman trying to cite a city bus driver for swerving out a designated lane had to leap onto the bumper of the bus to escape injury. Another policeman tried to issue a speeding ticket to a truck driver and the driver roared off with the policeman dangling from the vehicle, police said. Government statistics released today said 35 people died every day last year. The number of deaths per 10,000 cars last year was 47, compared with 2.6 in the United States, the statistics said. Drivers' licenses can be obtained without ever driving in traffic and many drivers are new and inexperienced.

DOC.HEAD: Air Controllers, Electrical Workers To Join General Strike
DOC.TEXT: Air traffic controllers and electrical workers pledged to join a general strike by supporters of the ousted Sandinista leadership that threatens to paralyze the country. President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has declared the strikes illegal and accused the leftist Sandinistas of trying to undermine her government's economic recovery program. The Sandinistas, who spearheaded the walkouts that began Monday, accuse Chamorro's 2-month-old conservative government of breaking a promise not to fire public employees. They also accuse the government of violating the constitution by denying union leaders a say in making economic policy. Sandinista-led strikes in May won government employees a 100 percent salary increase and other concessions from Mrs. Chamorro's administration. Banking, postal and telephone services were disrupted and hundreds of government employees held sit-in strikes in public buildings. About 3,800 telephone and post office workers walked out Wednesday night, virtually halting operator-assisted international calls. Nicaragua has no direct dialing. Telex service continued normally, however. About 12,500 bank employees and 3,500 more at the Agriculture Ministry walked out on Thursday. The banks were opened by managers, but there was no service. Customs and the ministries of foreign affairs, labor, construction, transportation, commerce and finance were also struck, as were most of the country's universities. The air traffic controllers said they planned to stop monitoring all flights as of this morning, and the workers at the state power monopoly threatened electricity cuts. Thousands of farm workers, whose title to their lands could be affected by the new government's policies, were also reported to be on strike. Labor leader Lucio Jimenez claimed a total of 80,000 workers had walked off their jobs nationwide, but estimates of the number of strikers by the Sandinista-led unions have often been exaggerated in the past. Jiminez was among seven Sandinista strike leaders briefly detained by the government Wednesday. Since taking office April 25, Mrs. Chamorro has been trying to whittle the government's top-heavy bureaucracy, cut expenditures, and eliminate a host of subsidies from urban transportation to basic foods. Her administration also sharply devalued the currency and has been trying to do away with state controls on the economy imposed by the Sandinistas when they seized power in a 1979 revolution that overthrew rightist dictator Anastasio Somoza. The Sandinistas were defeated in the Feb. 25 elections by Mrs. Chamorro's 14-party coalition. Government economists say a decade of Sandinista rule left Nicaragua saddled with a huge foreign debt, a treasury that is almost broke, an annual inflation rate of 36,300 percent, and agriculture and industry in near shambles. The Sandinistas blame Nicaragua's economic woes in large measure on the decade-long U.S.-backed Contra insurgency and U.S. economic sanctions.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Release Jailed Reporter After Source Identified
DOC.TEXT: A judge declined to release a television reporter held in jail for contempt of court despite the apparent public disclosure of the source the reporter has refused to identify. Bexar County Sheriff Harlon Copeland said Thursday the source was a cousin of a capital murder suspect that KMOL-TV reporter Brian Karem interviewed by telephone from the county jail last year. However, the disclosure had no immediate effect on Karem's status. He has been in the Bexar County Adult Detention Center since June 27 serving a six-month term for contempt of court. Prosecutor Beth Taylor said the district attorney's office wants the disclosure from Karem. ``He still has to produce a piece of paper of his sources. We need to see that,'' she said. Larry Macon, Karem's attorney, filed a motion to dismiss the contempt-of-court finding, but State District Judge Pat Priest told Macon in chambers that the motion was meaningless. The judge said only Karem's statements, not those of another person, could relieve the contempt-of-court finding, according to Cathy Granados, Priest's court coordinator. ``That's not going to happen in my lifetime,'' Karem said after the sheriff's annoucement in a telephone interview from jail. ``I have a promise between myself and that source. That source has not absolved me of my promise,'' he said. ``I'm sure as hell not going to be intimidated by a judge, or by a prosecutor or by a defense attorney.'' A formal hearing will be set for the dismissal motion, Granados said. Jane Kirtley, executive director of The Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press in Washington, said following Copeland's revelation that the only reason Karem is still in jail is to punish him. ``Once you've got the name of the source, you don't have to keep the journalist jailed, unless you're just offended that the journalist wouldn't buckle under to you,'' she said. ``At this point there's not even an arguable purpose to continue to jail him other than to punish him.'' Karem has repeatedly refused to say who arranged an interview with Henry David Hernandez, accused of killing a San Antonio police officer last year. In the interview, Hernandez said he shot the officer in self-defense. Defense attorneys and prosecutors say they have to know who arranged the interview to determine if the interview is admissible in his trial. Before about 60 reporters gathered at the jail to show support for Karem, Copeland identified the source as Deborah Ledesma, a cousin of Hernandez. Copeland said he learned the name last Friday through his own investigation and tried to tell the judge but was told Priest could not discuss the case with him. There is no Deborah Ledesma listed in San Antonio's telephone directory so she could not be immediately reached for comment. Hernandez and his brother, Julian, are charged with capital murder in the shooting of officer Gary Williams last March. A federal judge upheld Priest's contempt order two weeks ago and refused to extend a stay while Karem appealed the order in federal courts. Karem was jailed after a U.S Supreme Court justice also refused to extend the stay.

DOC.HEAD: Delay in Arrest of Officer Accused in Coverup of Jesuit Killings
DOC.TEXT: A high-ranking military officer accused of covering up the murder of six Jesuit priests remained in command of an elite infantry batallion nine days after a judge ordered his arrest. The priests' brutal slayings in November provoked an international outcry and calls from some in Congress for cuts in the millions of dollars of U.S. aid that keep El Salvador's government and military afloat. The officer, Lt. Col. Camilo Hernandez, said last week he would turn himself in when ordered to do so by Defense Minister Humberto Larios or by Col. Rene Emilio Ponce, head of the joint chiefs of staff. Ponce said the Defense Ministry did not receive a copy of the arrest warrant until Thursday, more than a week after it was issued. ``We will proceed with the detention of Lt. Col. Hernandez,'' Ponce said in a telephone interview. On Thursday, Hernandez was still on duty at the headquarters of the elite Belloso infantry battalion just outside the capital and security forces had made no effort to arrest him. The case, with its human rights implications, could be pivotal in in peace negotiations between the rightist government of President Alfredo Cristiani and leftist rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. The insurgents have demanded an end to military impunity in human rights cases as a condition for ending the 10-year-old civil war that has claimed an estimated 72,000 lives. ``That Lt. Col. Hernandez remains at his post is one more proof that military impunity is a concrete reality that must be eradicated. It is a demonstration of contempt for the judiciary,'' said Miguel Saenz, a member of the rebel's political-diplomatic commission, in a telephone interview from Mexico City. Though international human rights groups blame the armed forces or military-linked death squads for the abduction and murder of up to 30,000 suspected government opponents in the past decade, no officer has been tried for human rights abuses. Judge Ricardo Zamora of the 4th Criminal Court ordered Hernandez' arrest on June 26 for covering up the murder of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter. The priests were dragged from their beds and shot to death on Nov. 16 during a major rebel offensive in the capital. Right-wing extremists had long considered them subversive because they publicly maintained the civil war stemmed from social and economic injustice instead of outside communist aggression. Hernandez was the No. 2 officer of the Military College in November when the Jesuits were killed by an army detail based at the school. He allegedly ordered the burning of log books detailing troop movements. Hernandez denied the allegation in sworn testimony before the arrest warrant was issued. Lt. Col. Guillermo Benavides, commander of the Military College when the killings took place, has been charged with murder along with three lieutenants and five privates. All but one, a private who is a fugitive, are under arrest. Despite his arrest, Benavides was spotted at a military-owned beach resort earlier this year. After the sightings, he was confined to National Police headquarters, where he reportedly enjoys catered meals and visits from family and colleagues.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Higher
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,445.12, up 93.45 or 0.29 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Report: AIDS Virus Linked to 1959 Death
DOC.TEXT: Three medical researchers say a British sailor who died in 1959 had the AIDS virus, which would mean the disease was present in Britain more than 20 years earlier than had been thought. The researchers at the medical school at the University of Manchester reported their findings in The Lancet, a London-based weekly medical journal. The report, made available today, was based on tests on tissue preserved from the Royal Navy sailor's body. According to the report, the sailor had an immune deficiency that at the time could not be explained, as well as pneumocystis pneumonia, one of the opportunistic diseases now associated with AIDS. The discovery stemmed from the persistence of one of the three researchers, pathologist George Williams, who performed the original examination of the sailor's body. In a report in The Lancet in the 1960s, Williams described it as a unique case of pneumonia accompanied by overwhelming complications and secondary infections. When AIDS was recognized in the 1980s, Williams reminded his colleagues of the similarity and asked if they could reopen the sailor's case. By then, the sailor's only physical remains were samples of tissue stored in paraffin blocks. In their report in The Lancet, Williams, virologist Andrew Bailey and Gerald Corbitt reported that the HIV virus was found in tissue taken from the sailor's kidneys, bone marrow, spleen and pharyngeal mucosa. HIV, or human immunodeficiency virus, causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS. ``Taking into account the incubation time of several years between infection and development of the full-blown disease, the seaman would have contracted the virus in the early 1950s,'' the Times of London quoted Bailey as saying in an interview. The researchers said the earliest accepted case of human blood serum with antibodies indicating the donor was HIV-positive was a sample taken in Zaire in 1959. AIDS breaks down the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to a wide variety of infections and cancers. It is usually transmitted through sexual contact, blood transfusions or infected needles. There is no known cure. As of June 1, 1990, the World Health Organization counted a cumulative total of 263,051 cases of AIDS worldwide, but WHO estimates the true number to be closer to 700,000. The organization says 156 countries have officially reported at least one case of AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stock Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar edged down against the Japanese yen Friday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange bounced back. The dollar closed at 150.95 yen, down 0.05 yen from Thursday's close of 151.00 yen. After opening at 151.17 yen, the currency ranged between 150.80 yen and 151.30 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues gained 93.45 points, or 0.29 percent, losing the week at 32,445.12. The index shed 94.25 points on Thursday. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 87.12 points as of 3 p.m. (2 a.m. EDT), up from Thursday's 86.98. The yield stood at 7.165 percent, up from the previous day's 7.195 percent. Currency dealers said the dollar moved narrowly pending Friday's release of U.S. employment figures for June. Kozo Yoshida, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, said dollar buyers emerged in early trading to cover their short positions. ``But the dollar as a whole remained in a narrow range. It's rather difficult for it to move today,'' Yoshida said.

DOC.HEAD: North Korea Promises To Open Part Of Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: North Korea announced Friday that it will open a portion of its border with South Korea next month to encourage unification, a South Korean news agency said. Naewoe Press, a semi-official news agency specializing in communist affairs, said North Korea's Committee for the Peaceful Reunification of the Fatherland made the announcement in a broadcast monitored in Seoul on Friday. The North Korean announcement said the communist sector of the truce village of Panmunjom inside the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) will be opened Aug. 15 to allow free travel between the two Koreas. It was not immediately clear whether both North and South Koreans, or foreigners, would be permitted to freely cross the border. In addition, South Korea also controls any passage through the heavily guarded border. In Seoul, South Korean officials denounced the communist move as propaganda. Officials claimed it was aimed at encouraging South Korean radical groups to hold a unification rally at the border village on the country's national liberation day, which also is Aug. 15. ``The North Korean move also is insignifiant because it affects only its sector of Panmunjom, which is very small,'' said a senior Seoul govenment official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Panmunjom is an oval-shaped joint security area straddling a portion of the 155-mile border between the two Koreas. It is where military officials of both sides irregularly meet to discuss alleged armistice violations. The North Korean action would affect about 800 yards of the border. The North Korean annoucement came while officials of both sides were holding talks at Panmunjom village to discuss an accord that would outline terms for the first meeting between the prime ministers of the two Koreas. At a border meeting on Tuesday, the two Koreas agreed in principle to hold the first prime ministers' meeting, possibly in August in Seoul. They agreed to adopt a formal agreement on such talks July 26. It would be the first meeting between top officials of the two Koreas since the divison of their peninsula in 1945. The Korean border is tightly sealed and no one can cross the border without government approval, which is rarely given. The date announced for the border opening, Aug. 15, is symbolic to both Koreas. On Aug. 15, 1945, Korea was liberated from Japan after 35 years of colonial rule. North and South Korea are still technically at war because no peace treaty was signed after the 1950-1953 Korean war. The war began June 25, 1950, when North Korea sent thousands of troops across the 38th parallel into South Korea and ended with a cease-fire 37 months later. The conflict killed more than a million people, including 54,000 American soldiers.

DOC.HEAD: Murder Prompts Work-Release Policy to Limit Violent Inmates
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Florida inmates have been barred from work-release programs after a convicted murderer escaped from a community detail and allegedly stabbed a woman to death in a mall. The new prison policy means 50 percent of the entire prison population of 42,700 inmates will be held in the state's most secure prisons. About 40 percent, or 18,127, were in such prisons before the new policy was announced by Gov. Bob Martinez Thursday. Martinez said the old system was ``antiquated'' and allowed prison officials too much discretion in deciding whether hard-core criminals could get assigned to work details for community jobs, road work and prison industries. ``We can't stop every criminal from committing criminal acts,'' he said. ``But we can stop giving the worst of them the opportunity to walk the streets of our communities, where they have the greatest chance to escape and threaten law-abiding citizens.'' About 3,400 inmates now classified for minimum- or medium-security institutions will be shifted to more secure, so-called close-custody prisons, and it will be more difficult for violent or long-term inmates to get into work-release programs. Martinez blamed the old policy for Donald David Dillbeck's escape on June 22 from a catering detail out of the Quincy Vocational Center. Dillbeck, convicted of the 1979 murder of a Lee County sheriff's deputy, is charged with fatally stabbing 44-year-old Faye Lamb Vann on June 24 as she sat in her car at a Tallahassee mall. Three corrections officials were fired for letting Dillbeck into the program and onto the catering detail. ``The judgment was faulty, no question,'' Martinez said. ``But the discretion (allowed to corrections officials) led the fault to occur.'' Eight other prison officials involved in the Dillbeck case will not be fired, Martinez said, but remain on administrative leave pending possible department disciplinary action. The case became a political issue when former Sen. Lawton Chiles, a candidate in the Democratic primary for governor, blamed it on prison policies of Martinez, whose re-election campaign touts his law-and-order record. The old rules let those prisoners required to serve a specific sentence before being eligible for parole to be moved to less-secure custody status after they finished 40 percent of their mandatory sentences. Dillbeck, for instance, had served 44 percent of his 25-year-minimum term. The new policy requires that all such inmates serve the entire minimum portion of their sentences in close custody before they can be assigned to a work-release program. Inmates will be ineligible for work-release or other community jobs if they have been convicted of first- or second-degree murder unless they are within one year of release and have served all mandatory time.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Promise Release Of Peace Corps Volunteer and Japanese Aid Worker
LaserPhoto MLA1
DOC.TEXT: A statement purportedly from Communist rebels says a U.S. Peace Corps volunteer and a Japanese aid worker would be released this month but that guerrillas would not permit the groups to work on Negros island again. The New People's Army is believed holding Peace Corps volunteer Timothy Swanson, 26, of Cheyenne, Wyo., and Fumio Mizuno, 36, of the Japanese Organization For Industrial, Spiritual and Cultural Advancement in the rugged mountains of Negros island. Today, news organizations received a statement purportedly from ``Ka (Comrade) Efren,'' who identified himself as chief of the regional command on the island located about 300 miles southeast of Manila. There was no way to verify whether the statement came from the rebels. Reporters familiar with the Negros rebels said they were unfamiliar with the alias ``Ka Efren.'' Retired Roman Catholic Bishop Antonio Fortich, who has good contacts with the rebels, said he had heard unofficially that the two might be released soon but he had no confirmation. ``I would suppose they cannot hold them any longer,'' Fortich said by telephone from Negros. ``These two gentlemen have been very good and their have not committed human rights violations. Usually, the NPAs do not hold people like this.'' In the statement, ``Ka Efren'' said Swanson and Mizuno were ``invited'' to a ``dialogue'' because the rebels suspected their organizations were involved in the government's counter-insurgency. Swanson was abducted June 13 from his home in Patag, about 330 miles southeast of Manila. Mizuno was taken at gunpoint May 29 while inspecting a silkworm farm about 10 miles south of Patag. ``They are safe,'' the statement said. ``We will turn them over within the month, but an offensive by the enemy might endanger their lives.'' The statement said Swanson and Mizuno were unaware that their organizations were used to spy against the rebels. But the statement accused both groups of working for the government and rich landlords. ``We will prepare charges against their organizations,'' the statement said. ``After this, after we have aired our evidence, anybody who pursues these anti-people activities are consciously risking their lives,'' the statement said. The United States suspended Peace Corps operations in the Philippines last month and recalled all 261 volunteers because of reports the rebels planned to target members of the organization. U.S. officials said the decision was taken before they knew Swanson had been kidnapped. They learned of the incident after trying unsuccessfully to contact him about the pullout. The rebel statement described Swanson as ``American rah-rah boy, ready to spread goodwill, not knowing he was being used in an evil scheme.'' Philippine officials said that Swanson was one of seven Peace Corps volunteers on Negros. On Wednesday, about 200 Patag residents staged a rally in their mountain village urging the rebels to release Swanson. Villagers, including schoolchildren, teachers and others, carried placards asking the rebels to ``Return Tim Swanson,'' and ``We Love Tim.'' Swanson had lived in the area for two years and married a local schoolteacher on May 29, the day Mizuno was kidnapped. Swanson had been teaching agricultural and reforestation techniques to local residents.
Here, at a glance, are highlights of the NATO summit where 16 leaders are considering the future of the Western military alliance.
DOC.HEAD: Nuclear `Last Resort' Policy
DOC.TEXT: The NATO leaders agreed to endorse President Bush's proposal that the Western allies use nuclear weapons only as a last resort. The plan represents a fundamental change in the alliance's doctrine of ``flexible response,'' which is intended to leave potential aggressors uncertain about when NATO would use nuclear arms. The proposal met a mixed response, but was expected to be included in the communique that will be published at the end of the summit. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher expressed reservations about it, but her aides said she would go along with it. West German officials welcomed the proposal.
DOC.HEAD: NATO Invites Gorbachev to Address Alliance
DOC.TEXT: NATO leaders endorsed Bush's proposal to invite Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to address the North Atlantic Council, NATO's chief decision-making body, at Brussels, Belgium. Leaders of the six other Warsaw Pact nations also would be invited.
DOC.HEAD: Elimination of Nuclear-tipped Artillery Shells
DOC.TEXT: Bush pledged to eliminate 1,470 U.S. nuclear-tipped artillery shells, based mostly in West Germany, as Soviet troops withdraw from Central and Eastern Europe. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl agreed to reduce a united Germany's military manpower to ease concerns in Moscow.
DOC.HEAD: West Germans Seek A Formal End to the Cold War
DOC.TEXT: Kohl sought to have his fellow NATO leaders join with Warsaw Pact countries to declare a non-aggression agreement formally ending the Cold War. France opposes such a declaration, as does the United States.
DOC.HEAD: Aid to the Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Gorbachev's mounting domestic problems came up ``again and again'' during NATO's discussions, said West German spokesman Hans Klein. Kohl is pressing for direct Western aid to the Soviets bvt there was no discussion of that plan, a U.S. official said. Bush is leaning in favor of the idea.
DOC.HEAD: Overtures to Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: NATO leaders discussed the idea of allowing Hungary to participate in some non-military NATO deliberations. There have been indications Hungary wants to abandon the Eastern alliance. Diplomatic sources said Bush suggested that Eastern European diplomats be accredited to the alliance as a way of making overtures to emerging democracies.

DOC.HEAD: Protester Stops Work at King Museum
DOC.TEXT: A protester camped in front of the motel where Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated has stopped construction of a civil rights museum there. The Lorraine Motel where the civil rights leader was killed in 1968 is to become the centerpiece of a $9 million civil rights museum. But protester Jacqueline Smith describes the Lorraine as ``sacred ground.'' She contends it should become housing for the homeless, not a museum. Construction manager Anthony Vaccaro said Thursday he stopped the state-run project on Monday because Ms. Smith, a former resident and employee of the motel, is camped on a sidewalk that must be torn up for utility lines. The museum is scheduled to open on July 4, 1991. State architect Mike Fitts said last week he was seeking legal advice on getting rid of Ms. Smith. But Vaccaro said the state informed him this week that he is responsible for removing Ms. Smith since she was ``an existing site condition'' when the construction contract was awarded. ``Apparently nobody wants to take the blame for doing this,'' Vaccaro said. Ms. Smith has been living in a tent on the sidewalk in front of the motel since March 2, 1988. She has refused requests to move across the street where her protest could continue. Vaccaro said he expected to seek a court order by next week requiring law enforcement authorities to remove Ms. Smith. Sheriff's deputies carried Ms. Smith from the motel when it was shut down to make way for the museum. Since then, authorities have pretty much ignored her. Police spokesman John Bennett said city authorities expected the state to deal with Ms. Smith. ``We have never received a complaint from anybody regarding her presence down there,'' Bennett said. Site preparation and preliminary construction got under way last year, but Ms. Smith did not hinder that work. The major phase of museum construction began last month. A group of concerned citizens bought the Lorraine at a foreclosure auction in 1982 and spent the next couple of years convincing the state, county and city governments to finance the museum.

Jean Dabry, navigator for French pilot Jean Mermoz on several pioneering flights in the 1930s, died Wednesday at age 89. The cause of death was not disclosed. On May 12, 1930, Dabry and Mermoz completed the first non-stop flight between Africa and South America, crossing the South Atlantic from Senegal to Brazil in 21 hours, 14 minutes. Four years later, they completed the first commercial flight between Paris and Buenos Aires, Argentina.

Robert Lee ``R.L.'' Blaffer II, grandson of a Humble Oil founder and great-grandson of a Texaco founder, died Wednesday of an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound at age 30. His grandfather, Robert Lee Blaffer, was a pioneer in the early days of the Texas Spindletop oil field discovery in 1902. Fifteen years later, the elder Blaffer and three partners helped found Humble Oil & Refining Co., which became Exxon. Robert Blaffer married Sarah Campbell, daughter of Texaco founder William T. Campbell. Police were investigating the death in his condominium apartment as a suicide, said Sgt. D.D. Shirley. Friends said he wasn't employed.

David ``Sweeney'' Schriner, a member of two Stanley Cup hockey teams with the Toronto Maple Leafs in the 1940s, died Thursday after a long illness at age 78. The Russian-born Schriner began his NHL career with the New York Americans, winning the Calder Trophy as the NHL's rookie of the year in 1934-35. Schriner had 201 goals and 204 assists in 484 NHL games. He was a first-team all-star in 1936 and 1941 and a second-team all-star in 1937. In 1938-39, the left wing was traded for four players to Toronto, where he won Stanley Cups in 1942 and 1945. He retired after the 1945-46 season and went into the oil and gas business in his hometown of Calgary, Alberta. He was elected to the Hockey Hall of Fame in 1962.

Lud Shahbazian, The Hudson Dispatch's sports editor emeritus whose 70-year career included covering boxers from Jack Dempsey to Joe Frazier, died Thursday at age 88 of congestive heart failure. Shahbazian was hired as a sports cartoonist at the Dispatch in 1920. Two years later, he was named sports editor and remained in the post for 56 years. He retired as active sports editor in 1978. Shahbazian founded the New Jersey Boxing Writers Association, the New Jersey Racing Writers Association and the Ring 14 Boxing Association for writers and fighters. Shahbazian is survived by his wife, Josephine; a son, Haddon (Bob); three grandchildren; and a great-grandson.

Susan Tate King, whose World War II radio show, airing opposite ``Tokyo Rose,'' tried to encourage U.S. servicemen in the Pacific, died Sunday in her home at age 75. King's show, which ran for 18 months on the Armed Forces Radio, was aimed at boosting morale in the Pacific while the Japanese announcer tried to discourage them.

Bluesman Walter ``Lightning Bug'' Rhodes, who had played guitar with Wilson Pickett, Otis Redding and B.B. King, was found dead in a motel swimming pool Wednesday. He was 50. Armond Lenchek, a guitar player and manager for the Lightning Bug Rhodes Blues Band, said Rhodes apparently died of a heart attack. Rhodes' band was preparing a tour of Switzerland and an album was due for release in the fall, Lenchek said.

Paul Wynne, a television news reporter who turned the camera on himself and his battle with AIDS in ``Paul Wynne's Journal,'' died Thursday of the disease he chronicled. He was 46. Wynne hosted the KGO-TV weekly show that began airing in January. The show was suspended several weeks ago, when his illness prevented him from working. He died at the Fort Miley Veterans Medical Center in San Francisco. ``Paul Wynne's Journal'' won a local Friends of the Human Rights Commission Award in June.

DOC.HEAD: Champagne and Truffles, Maybe Caviar When Gorbachev Comes
DOC.TEXT: NATO leaders feasted on champagne and truffles at their summit celebrating the end of the Cold War. Maybe they'll dine on caviar when Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev shows up. It was supposed to be the summit of no surprises. Everyone was talking about troop cuts, modifying NATO policy to use nuclear weapons only as a ``last resort,'' and the future of the 16-nation alliance formed in 1949 at a time of East-West hostility. Suddenly, a buzz spread through the summit that President Bush had invited Gorbachev to address a future NATO meeting, and the man trying to fend off attacks at the Communist Party congress in Moscow became the man of the hour in London. Several observers quipped that Gorbachev probably wished he were here right now. ``It's a spectacular coup to show that NATO is open to relations with the Warsaw Pact,'' said British lawmaker Bruce George, a member of the House of Commons Select Committee on Defense who is writing Jane's NATO handbook.

Somehow, all 16 NATO leaders managed to keep the Gorbachev invitation a secret for days. Bush wrote letters to the summit leaders a week earlier with a list of U.S. proposals, including the Gorbachev invitation, which was quickly accepted. His letter to Francois Mitterrand addressed the French president as ``old chap,'' French officials disclosed Thursday.

Mitterrand not only lived up to his reputation for tardiness at international meetings but only narrowly missed arriving late twice in one morning. His late arrival at Lancaster House, site of the 1979 conference that paved the way for Rhodesian independence, delayed the start of the first summit meeting for about 15 minutes. For the NATO ``family portrait,'' British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher helped get the front row lined up on the grand staircase, with marks where each was to stand. Mitterrand was missing. But he arrived just before Danish Prime Minister Poul Schluter. Bush and Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney clapped when everyone was finally assembled.
It was a typical London summer day with drizzling rain and a chill wind blowing. Even Mrs. Thatcher, who abhors hot weather, told reporters: ``It's terrible, isn't it?,''

The summit leaders got one hour and 40 minutes extra to relax before dinner at Buckingham Palace with Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip. The summiteers finished the afternoon session early and motorcades were caught by surprise. Bush had to wait several minutes because the driveway was blocked by someone else's limousine. ``They can't get by with that car here,'' he said with some exasperation before his limousine appeared.

For two hours, the leaders savored the splendors of royal living. They sipped cocktails in The White Drawing Room with its marble and antique furniture, posed for pictures in the Music Room where many young royals have been christened, wandered through the Picture Gallery with its masterpieces of Dutch art, and dined in the crimson Throne Room behind the chair the queen used for her 1953 coronation. The queen, in a green chiffon and gold lame gown set off by a diamond necklace and earrings, sat between Bush and Mitterrand and the prince between Woerner and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The 52 guests, seated at five round tables, dined on poached sole with truffles, duck garnished with white peaches and cherries, and raspberry ice cream. There were five glasses _ for German white wine, French red, champagne, the queen's own private stock of port and water.
Some NATO officials were caught switching the TV monitors to the Wimbledon tennis semi-final. And Kohl said he was confident West Germany will defeat Argentina in Sunday's World Cup soccer final.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion at Chemical Plant Kills 12
DOC.TEXT: An explosion at an ARCO chemical plant killed 12 employees, a company spokesman said today.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.TEXT: Editors: An AP reporter and photographer are en route to the scene of the ARCO plant explosion. A writethru combining the bulletin series is in the works.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Blind Masseurs Protest Government Crackdown
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of blind masseurs shouting ``Protect our right to live!'' today protested a government crackdown on massage parlors. Riot police blocked a street protest by the estimated 400 men and women who tried to march toward downtown Seoul after a rally asking the government to end its curb on massage parlors. The protesters accused the government of clamping down indiscriminately on small massage parlors where many blind people work. They claimed there has been a loophole in the crackdown, with most deluxe or hotel massage parlors unaffected. They said massage has been the main means of livelihood for about 150,000 blind people. In response to public outcries against the nation's booming sex business, the government has begun regulating hotels, massage parlors, barber shops and saunas known for providing sex. Many massage houses in South Korea use parlormaids for prostitution, along with blind masseurs. Some hotels run massage parlors using women who are not blind for massage and sex. The blind masseurs also demanded the government ban massage by people who are not blind.

DOC.HEAD: High Temps, Thunderstorms Widespread
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures dipped today in the eastern half of the nation after record-high readings and a rash of thunderstorms. Rain and thunderstorms were scattered from the Atlantic Coast into the Midwest and Deep South late Thursday. Rainshowers and thunderstorms also ranged across northwest California and from southern Arizona into Colorado, Wyoming, the Idaho Panhandle and western Montana. Record highs were set or tied Thursday in several cities in the East and South. The 98 degrees in Atlantic City, N.J., tied a record set in 1949; Augusta, Ga., was 101, breaking a record 100 set in 1954; and Baltimore was 100, breaking a record 97 set in 1977. Thunderstorms packing heavy rain and high winds rumbled across broad sections of the Midwest and Northeast Thursday. Severe thunderstorm watches were posted in eastern Virginia, southern Maryland, southern Delaware and sections of West Virginia, Ohio and Kentucky and Indiana. The high temperature for the nation Thursday was 113 degrees at Lake Havasu City, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Hackman Advised to Exercise and Plan Diet
DOC.TEXT: Actor Gene Hackman has been told to exercise and improve his diet after he narrowly avoided a heart attack. Hackman was listed in good condition early today at St. Vincent Hospital & Medical Center, said nursing supervisor Marymae Zimmerman. ``He feels much relieved,'' said Dr. Herber Semler, the cardiologist who treated Hackman. ``The pain is gone. He is up and around and ready to make another movie.'' An artery leading to Hackman's heart narrowed dangerously and doctors had to reinflate it with a balloon catheter, Semler said a news conference Thursday. Semler said that if Hackman hadn't entered the hospital when he did, ``the artery would have completely shut down and he would have possibly had a heart attack.'' Hackman, 60, was admitted to the hospital Tuesday. Semler said the rest of Hackman's coronary arteries look good and the actor can return to an active life. He said Hackman is not overweight, doesn't smoke and has no history of medical problems. ``That's the interesting part _ we see this in otherwise healthy people,'' he said. ``The narrowing comes on as a natural process like gray hair. It could happen to anyone.'' However, Semler said he is recommending an exercise and diet plan for Hackman, who lives in Beverly Hills, Calif. Hackman had just finished filming a movie in Europe called ``Dinosaur'' and was vacationing on the Oregon Coast when he began suffering chest pain. He came to Portland and the pain expanded to include his arm. ``We think we got him just in the nick of time,'' Semler said. Hackman thought the chest pain was only indigestion, but felt it was a good idea to have it checked, said his publicist, Dick Guttman in Los Angeles. The son of a journeyman pressman, Hackman is a former truck driver and soda jerk who did not pursue acting until he was in his 30s. His most acclaimed role was as the rough-and-tumble narcotics cop Popeye Doyle in 1971's ``The French Connection.'' That performance won him an Academy Award. Among his other film credits are ``Bonnie and Clyde,'' ``I Never Sang for My Father,'' ``The Conversation,'' ``Hawaii,'' ``Lucky Lady,'' ``A Bridge Too Far,'' ``Superman,'' ``The Package,'' ``No Way Out,'' ``Target,'' ``Hoosiers'' and ``Mississippi Burning.'' Upcoming releases include ``Postcards from the Edge'' and ``Narrow Margin.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS Althorp item to CORRECT spelling of Althorp in 4th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Viscount Althorp, the NBC television correspondent and brother of the Princess of Wales, and his wife are expecting their first child in January. ``We are both delighted,'' Althorp, 26, said Thursday. Althorp and fashion model Victoria Lockwood, 25, were married last September at his family home near Northampton, 70 miles northwest of London. Lord Althorp, Charles Edward Maurice Spencer, is the brother of the former Lady Diana Spencer, who is married to the heir to the British throne, Prince Charles. Lord Althorp joined NBC in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Rise
DOC.TEXT: The dollar firmed against all key currencies except the British pound in European trading this morning. Gold was higher in quiet trading. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 150.95 yen, down 0.05 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 151.10 yen. ``The dollar has been firm since it hit the 149-yen level'' on Wednesday, said Toshio Takahashi, a dealer with the Industrial Bank of Japan. ``It seems the dollar is comfortable at a 150-151 yen level.'' Other dollar rates compared with Thursday: _1.6535 German marks, up from 1.6497 _1.4000 Swiss francs, up from 1.3990 _5.5480 French francs, up from 5.5357 _1.8605 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8582 _1,212.20 Italian lire, up from 1,210.25 _1.1645 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1627 The British pound was quoted at $1.7845, up from Thursday's late $1.7795. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $360.35 per ounce this morning, up from $359.75 late Thursday. Gold in Zurich was quoted at $360.20 bid, up from $359.50 late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped 21 cents an ounce today to close at $361.26. Silver bullion was quoted in London at $4.88 an ounce, unchanged from late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 24 Hurt in Bomb Blast Blamed On Right Wing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with 24 hurt, but most of injuries not serious. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `Police said...'
DOC.TEXT: Police blamed right-wing extremists for a powerful bomb that blew up today next to a downtown bus terminal used mainly by blacks, injuring at least 24 people. The blast on a busy street during morning rush hour sent concrete and debris hurtling through the air, a police spokesman said. ``There were rocks flying into the air. There was blood everywhere, people screaming and crying,'' said Nhlanhla Mbatha, who was waiting in a bus line when the bomb went off. ``It was only black people who got injured.'' Doctors said most of the 24 injuries were not grave. The independent South African Press Association said two people were hospitalized. Police said no group claimed immediate responsibility for the blast. But because the targets were blacks, they said suspicion fell on extreme right-wing white groups, who had threatened earlier this week to step up a bombing campaign. The groups oppose steps by President F.W. de Klerk toward dismantling apartheid laws that segregate whites and blacks. The bomb went off in an area where buses used by black people pick up and let off passengers. Thousands of blacks from townships outside Johannesburg pass through the area every day, on their way to work. Three mini-buses were rocked by the blast and riddled with debris, eyewitnesses said, and up to 15 vehicles were damaged. Witnesses said people caught by the blast stood in the street, frozen by fear and disbelief. Some of the injured were buying food in nearby shops when they were hit by flying debris, witnesses said. ``Everything was clouded with smoke. I saw about six people running toward me with shredded clothing and some with no shoes,'' said shopkeeper Isha Charassi. Police explosive experts were combed the area to ensure there were no other bombs. Several bomb attacks earlier this week in Johannesburg were aimed at whites involved in efforts to end apartheid, but they caused no injuries and minor damage. Right-wing groups claimed responsibility for those attacks. Police defused a large bomb Thursday in a black miners' union in the town of Oberholzer west of Johannesburg. The bomb made of six sticks of dynamite would have caused major damage if it had detonated, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Wounds Off-duty Policeman, 2 Others; Man in Custody
DOC.TEXT: A man randomly fired an undetermined number of shots on a church group, seriously injuring an off-duty police office and wounding two other people. The officer, Steve Checketts, was hit in the left arm and chest Thursday morning as teen-agers boarded buses for a church camp in the parking lot of a Mormon Church, police said. Checketts, 43, had told the man to drop his gun. The man then fired an undetermined number of rounds into the crowd of more than 100 girls and adults before he fled to a nearby house, said police spokesman Leo Speliopoulos. Checketts' condition was upgraded to serious from critical after surgery at John C. Lincoln Hospital. A woman who was hit on the left ankle and a teen-age girl who was grazed on her leg were treated and released. After a two-hour standoff, Clifton Phillip Jeter, 23, of Los Angeles was arrested and booked into a Maricopa County jail for investigation of eight counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon, Speliopoulos said. He said the five extra complaints came from people at whom the attacker pointed a firearm and who felt their lives had been threatened. Jeter had been charged with drug possession-for-sale and aggravated assault in Los Angeles in the past 12 months. Speliopoulos said Jeter did not cooperate during an interview with detectives. A motive could not immediately be determined, he said. ``It just appears to be a random shooting,'' Speliopoulos said. Karine Eliason, 48, a church leader who was going to the camp along with her 13-year-old daughter, said the fusillade lasted only about 20 seconds. ``I could tell the guy who was shooting was doing it randomly,'' Mrs. Eliason said.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``The fire is out of control. We're throwing everything at it we have _ tankers, bulldozers, people _ and it isn't working.'' _ Forester Bob Dick, as firefighters working 20-hour shifts battled a wildfire at Tok, Alaska.

``Today, standing in front of you and in front of the entire society, I have to say clearly that I see danger on the peaceful Polish road to democracy.'' _ Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, as he ousted all but one former Communist from his Cabinet.

``I just pray that a very special angel meets him at the gate and escorts him to paradise.'' _ Actor Martin Sheen, on the death of homeless advocate Mitch Snyder, victim of what police called an apparent suicide.

DOC.HEAD: Pleasure Cruise Has New Meaning on Detroit River
DOC.TEXT: Lace and spandex peel away readily aboard the Wayward Princess, a Detroit River cruise ship where men delight in discarded G-strings and women watch musclemen shed double-breasted suits. The 110-foot, three-decked vessel opened for a preview voyage Thursday with dozens of photographers and reporters getting the first peek at the sexy gyrations of one male and four female dancers. ``I'm doing it for the fun of it,'' said Jacques Beauchamp, who developed the nude-dancing cruises when his business of renting the boat for private parties waned. ``I think we are going to prove that it's just a good thing for the city of Windsor.'' Ontario strippers, unlike their Michigan counterparts, are allowed to remove all clothing in establishments where alcohol is sold. Windsor, a city of about 195,000 people, lies across the Detroit River from Detroit. It regularly attracts U.S. visitors to downtown clubs where women dance nude on stage or, for $5 a song, atop a box next to the table. Beauchamp had staged chartered strip shows on the Wayward Princess until Windsor officials revoked his license two years ago. The city grudgingly approved a license two weeks ago. ``Personally, I'd rather not see it,'' city licensing Commissioner Ronald Reaume said. ``But we're not there to license the morality of the situation.'' Beauchamp could face fines or imprisonment if the Wayward Princess crosses the river's international boundary, said Detroit police Officer Dan Smith. Neither Detroit police nor the U.S. Coast Guard could say what penalties are involved. Kara, a tall brunette with braces and a deep tan, opened the show Thursday with a dance to the song ``All Around the World.'' The 21-year-old Detroit-area woman, who didn't give her full name, strutted around the tiny stage in nothing but a G-string. The G-strings will drop on subsequent cruises. ``It's kind of exciting because it's the only boat in the world that's a strip bar ... where you can get totally nude,'' Kara said. Elizabeth Hall, an inspector with Windsor's License Division, was on the cruise Thursday, checking the dancers' licenses and telling one woman she couldn't perform until her paperwork cleared. The ship's maiden voyage for paying customers will be tonight. Beauchamp said he expected a capacity crowd of 325 passengers. Male strippers will perform on the lower level and female strippers on the second deck. The open-air top level, loosely termed the ``Friendship Deck,'' is designed for socializing. Zsolt Szanati, 22, immigrated to Windsor from Hungary three years ago. He worked several jobs before he discovered stripping. Nudity on the water will offer audiences an extra allure, he said. ``It is going to be more exciting for people on board,'' Szanati said.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Survive After Being Swept Away in Storm Drain
DOC.TEXT: Runoff from a severe thunderstorm swept eight people along a 10-foot-wide storm drain for several hundred yards, but they all survived with minor injuries. Authorities feared that five of the group had been swept into the Kanawha River because they were missing for about an hour Thursday night. But firefighters found them trapped inside the drain. ``They were very happy to see the firemen,'' said Fire Lt. Bryce Stotts. ``They just found them up there in the dark in water about 2 feet deep. They couldn't go anywhere.'' Three others in the group were swept out of the drain about 150 yards further down. Police Chief Ed Garnett said he did not know why the group had ventured into the drain. ``They're alive and that's what's important,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Warplanes Hit Two Palestinian Bases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE casualties, other details. Pick up 10th graf pvs, `Guerrillas armed...'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli warplanes blasted Palestinian guerrilla bases in Syrian-policed eastern and northern Lebanon today, wounding at least eight guerrillas, police said. In Israel, the military confirmed it raided two bases and said its planes returned safely. The targets of both attacks were bases of the Libyan-backed, Damascus-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command. A Lebanese police spokesman said four jet fighters rocketed the southern edge of the village of Sultan Yacoub in the eastern Bekaa valley this morning. Later, warplanes hit Tal Hayat, a guerrilla position just northeast of the Palestinian refugee camp of Nahr el-Bared refugee camp, he said. The spokesman, speaking anonymously in line with standing rules, said three guerrillas were wounded in Sultan Yacoub and five in Tal Hayat. The base in Sultan Yacoub houses an amunition depot, a training camp and communications center, and guerrilla naval forces are based in Tal Hayat, the spokesman said. The police spokesman said the Israeli warplanes scored ``direct hits'' on both bases, badly damaging them. The Israeli military said the bases had been used to launch attacks on Israel. Sultan Yacoub is about 24 miles north of the Israeli border, and Nahr el-Bared is more than 100 miles north of the border. In the first attack, the jets dropped delayed-action bombs, the last of which exploded more than three hours after the attack, the spokesman said. Guerrillas armed with assault rifles sealed off the southern edge of Sultan Yacoub, preventing reporters and photographers from approaching the base. The guerrilla group, led by Ahmed Jibril, was blamed for the Nov. 27, 1987, hang-glider attack on a northern Israeli army base that left six Israeli soldiers dead and eight wounded. On April 19, Israeli jets hit bases used by the group near Damour, south of Beirut, in two air raids. A day later, they struck bases of the pro-Iranian fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, in the Bekaa Valley, killing six people. The attack on Sultan Yacoub set an ammunition dump ablaze, and smoke engulfed the base, which includes a training camp and a communication center, the Lebanese police spokesman said. The guerrillas opened up with anti-aircraft guns as the jets zoomed in to strike the base, but missed their targets, the police spokesman said. By police count, 16 people have been killed and 31 wounded in Israeli air attacks since Jan. 19.

DOC.HEAD: Mazowiecki Fires All But One Ex-Communist From Cabinet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs with reaction from Solidarity lawmakers, prime minister saying more changes may be in works. Pickup 6th, `The prime...' ^By JOHN DANISZEWSKI
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki ousted all but one former Communist from his Cabinet today to counter criticism of his 10-month-old government's performance. But some Solidarity activists said the changes weren't sweeping enough. In a speech before Parliament that was broadcast nationwide, Mazowiecki said political battles in the non-Communist-led government were threatening the country's peaceful evolution to democracy. The prime minister announced the resignation of five Cabinet ministers, including three of the four former Communists who remained in the government as the price for Solidarity replacing the Communist regime in September. Prominent among those ousted was the interior minister, Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak, who is in charge of the police, and Defense Minister Florian Siwicki. Mazowiecki retained ex-Communist Marcin Swiecicki, the young foreign trade minister who has been instrumental in trade talks with the Soviet Union. Some Solidarity activists said they were not satisfied with the shake-up. ``These changes are not sufficient,'' said Bogdan Lis, a Solidarity senator from Gdansk. He urged the ouster of government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska and Cabinet director Jacek Ambroziak as well. The state news agency PAP said Mazowiecki met with Solidarity lawmakers immediately after his speech and told them more changes may be forthcoming. The prime minister suggested earlier parliamentary elections, which are currently scheduled for spring 1991. But he did not set a date. He also urged more rapid privatization of state enterprises. Under fire from the nation's farmers and from his former ally and mentor, Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, Mazowiecki's speech was high political drama. ``Today, standing in front of you and in front of the entire society, I have to say clearly that I see danger on the peaceful Polish road to democracy,'' Mazowiecki declared. ``The sense of responsibility for the country is getting weaker in political life,'' he said. ``Substantial arguments are being replaced by the language of brutal struggle, even in this hall.'' Mazowiecki's spokesman on Thursday said the speech should be considered a turning point in the history of the East bloc's first non-Communist government, which was seated Sept. 12 in a wave of national optimism. Lately, that hope has diminished. The government has had to grapple with a major rail strike, use police to break up two farm protests, and answer a steady stream of criticism from Walesa, believed to be mounting a campaign to take over the presidency from former Communist leader Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. Walesa aides said he had no comment after Mazowiecki's speech. The Solidarity leader has urged Mazowiecki to replace holdover Communists in the government and state-run industries, hold early elections and speed privatization of state enterprises. The prime minister responded to all three points in his speech. Besides Kiszczak and Siwicki, the third ex-Communist to be ousted from the Cabinet was Transport Minister Franciszek Wieladek. Agriculture Minister Czeslaw Janicki of the Peasant Party and Communications Minister Marek Kucharski of the Democratic Party also resigned. Appointed to succeed Kiszczak as head of the Interior Ministry was Krzysztof Kozlowski, a Catholic editor who has recently been serving as deputy interior minister. Taking over the Defense Ministry was Rear Adm. Piotr Kolodziejczyk. Artur Balazs, the former minister of rural life and a founder of the farmers union Rural Solidarity, will become agriculture minister. Wieladek was replaced by Ewaryst Waligorski, and no immediate replacement was announced for Kucharski.

DOC.HEAD: Surgeon: Jogger `Hung Onto Life By a Thread'
DOC.TEXT: The Central Park jogger had lost 80 percent of her blood, mostly from severe head wounds, and was close to death when she was admitted to Metropolitan Hospital, a surgeon testified. ``She hung onto life by a thread. I think it's close to a miracle that she survived,'' Dr. Robert Kurtz said Thursday at the trial of three youths charged with raping and nearly killing the woman. Color photographs of the woman's naked and bloodied body were shown to the jury for the first time since the trial opened June 25. Defense lawyer Robert Burns complained that presenting the pictures was unnecessary and inflammatory. Burns is representing Yusef Salaam, 16, who is charged along with Antron McCray, 15, and Raymond Santana, 16, with attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, assault, robbery and riot in the attack on the woman and two male joggers. Kurtz said the jogger had several skull fractures, a crushed cheekbone, a concussion, bleeding under the membrane that covers the brain, and swelling of the brain when she was brought to the hospital. ``Both halves of her brain at that point were wiped out and not functioning,'' Kurtz said. He said the woman could not breathe properly and had dilated eyes, which he said was a sign of impending death. Surgeons had to remove a huge blood clot that ``looked like she had a large grape on her outer ear,'' he said. The woman was attacked late on April 19, 1989, and brought into the hospital early the next morning. Doctors have called her recovery and her return to her job at an investment banking firm miraculous. The woman, now 29, has no recollection of what happened that night, prosecutors said. Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer has refused to say whether the woman will testify. The three defendants are being tried in an adult court, but if convicted they will be sentenced as juvenile offenders and face up to 10 years in prison. Three other youths are charged in the attacks and are due to stand trial on the same charges later this year.

DOC.HEAD: 2-Year-Old Paralyzed in Drive-by Shooting
DOC.TEXT: Brandon Lott watched with a 2-year-old's wonder as children twirled sparklers to celebrate Independence Day. Minutes later, he was paralyzed from the waist down, the victim of a drive-by shooting. The toddler was in serious but stable condition this morning at the pediatric intensive care unit of Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, said hospital spokesman Ron Wise. The bullet had shattered part of his spine. No arrests had been made by early today, said Sgt. Tony O'Brien. ``We were just sitting there watching fireworks when a car came by,'' said Brandon's mother, Dorothy Overland. ``They started shooting at the ... babies.'' ``I saw flashes of light, then it was `pow, pow, pow,''' said Alicia Jones, 20. ``At first I thought it was firecrackers, then everybody started diving for cover and running.'' Police Detective Maurice Landrum said no one enjoying the block party was a gang member. Brandon was one of at least five children wounded in shootings in the Los Angeles area since Monday.

DOC.HEAD: LONDON: in Europe.
DOC.TEXT:
14. As Soviet troops leave Eastern Europe and a treaty limiting conventional armed forces is implemented, the Alliance's integrated force structure and its strategy will change fundamentally to include the following elements: _NATO will field smaller and restructured active forces. These forces will be highly mobile and versatile so that Allied leaders will have maximum flexibility in deciding how to respond to a crisis. It will rely increasingly on multinational corps made up of national units. _NATO will scale back the readiness of its active units, reducing training requirements and the number of exercises. _NATO will rely more heavily on the ability to build up larger forces if and when they might be needed.
15. To keep the peace, the Alliance must maintain for the foreseeable future an appropriate mix of nuclear and conventional forces, based in Europe, and kept up to date where necessary. But, as a defensive Alliance, NATO has always stressed that none of its weapons will ever be used except in self-defense and that we seek the lowest and most stable level of nuclear forces needed to secure the prevention of war.
16. The political and military changes in Europe, and the prospects of further changes, now allow the Allies concerned to go further. They will thus modify the size and adapt the tasks of their nuclear deterrent forces. They have concluded that, as a result of the new political and military conditions in Europe, there will be a significantly reduced role for sub-strategic nuclear systems of the shortest range. They have decided specifically that, once negotiations begin on short-range nuclear forces, the Alliance will propose, in return for reciprocal action by the Soviet Union, the elimination of all its nuclear artillery shells from Europe.
17. New negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union on the reduction of short-range nuclear forces should begin shortly after a CFE agreement is signed. The Allies concerned will develop an arms control framework for these negotiations which takes into account our requirements for far fewer nuclear weapons, and the diminished need for sub-strategic nuclear systems of the shortest range.
18. Finally, with the total withdrawal of Soviet stationed forces and the implementation of a CFE agreement, the Allies concerned can reduce their reliance on nuclear weapons. These will continue to fulfill an essential role in the overall strategy of the Alliance to prevent war by ensuring that there are no circumstances in which nuclear retaliation in response to military action might be discounted. However, in the transformed Europe, they will be able to adopt a new NATO strategy making nuclear forces truly weapons of last resort.
19. We approve the mandate given in Turnberry to the North Atlantic Council in Permanent Session to oversee the ongoing work on the adaptation of the Alliance to the new circumstances. It should report its conclusions as soon as possible.
20. In the context of these revised plans for defense and arms control, and with the advice of NATO Military Authorities and all member states concerned, NATO will prepare a new Allied military strategy moving way from ``forward defense,'' where appropriate, towards a reduced forward presence and modifying ``flexible response'' to reflect a reduced reliance on nuclear weapons. In that connection, NATO will elaborate new force plans consistent with the revolutionary changes in Europe. NATO will also provide a forum for Allied consultation on the upcoming negotiations on short-range nuclear forces.
21. The Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE) should become more prominent in Europe's future, bringing together the countries of Europe and North America. We support a CSCE Summit later this year in Paris which would include the signature of a CFE agreement and would set new standards for the establishment, and preservation, of free societies. It should endorse, inter alia: _CSCE principles on the right to free and fair elections; _CSCE commitments to respect and uphold the rule of law; _CSCE guidelines for enhancing economic cooperation, based on the development of free and competitive market economies; and _CSCE cooperation on environmental protection.
22. We further propose that the CSCE Summit in Paris decide how the CSCE can be institutionalized to provide a forum for wider political dialogue in a more united Europe. We recommend that CSCE governments establish: _a program for regular consultations among member governments at the Heads of State and Government or Ministerial level, at least once each year, with other periodic meetings of officials to prepare for and follow up on these consultations; _a schedule of CSCE review conferences once every two years to assess progress toward a Europe whole and free; _a small CSCE secretariat to coordinate these meetings and conferences; _a CSCE mechanism to monitor elections in all the CSCE countries, on the basis of the Copenhagen Document; _a CSCE Center for the Prevention of Conflict that might serve as a forum for exchanges of military information, discussion of unusual military activities, and the conciliation of disputes involving CSCE member states; and _a CSCE parliamentary body, the Assembly of Europe, to be based on the existing parliamentary assembly of the Council of Europe, in Strasbourg, and include representatives of all CSCE member states. The sites of these new institutions should reflect the fact that the newly democratic countries of Central and Eastern Europe form part of the political structures of the new Europe.
23. Today, our Alliance begins a major transformation. Working with all the countries of Europe, we are determined to create enduring peace on this continent.

DOC.HEAD: Text of NATO Summit Communique
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS pvs 8th graf bgng, ``6. The member,'' to CORRECT, reading 35-nation Conference instead Council.
DOC.TEXT:
Here is the text of the final declaration issued Friday by NATO summit leaders:
London Declaration on a Transformed North Atlantic Alliance, issued by the Heads of State and Government participating in the meeting of the North Atlantic Council in London on 5th-6th July 1990.
1. Europe has entered a new, promising era. Central and Eastern Europe is liberating itself. The Soviet Union has embarked on the long journey toward a free society. The walls that once confined people and ideas are collapsing. Europeans are determining their own destiny. They are choosing freedom. They are choosing economic liberty. They are choosing peace. They are choosing a Europe whole and free. As a consequence, this Alliance must and will adapt.
2. The North Atlantic Alliance has been the most succesful defensive alliance in history. As our Alliance enters its fifth decade and looks ahead to a new century, it must continue to provide for the common defense. This Alliance has done much to bring about the new Europe. No one, however, can be certain of the future. We need to keep standing together, to extend the long peace we have enjoyed these past four decades. Yet our Alliance must be even more an agent of change. It can help build the structures of a more united continent, supporting security and stability with the strength of our shared faith in democracy, the rights of the individual, and the peaceful resolution of disputes. We reaffirm that security and stability do not lie solely in the military dimension, and we intend to enhance the political component of our Alliance as provided for by Article 2 of our Treaty.
3. The unification of Germany means that the division of Europe is also being overcome. A united Germany in the Atlantic Alliance of free democracies and part of the growing political and economic integration of the European Community will be an indispensable factor of stability, which is needed in the heart of Europe. The move within the European Community towards political union, including the development of a European identity in the domain of security, will also contribute to Atlantic solidarity and to the establishment of a just and lasting order of peace throughout the whole of Europe.
4. We recognize that, in the new Europe, the security of every state is inseparably linked to the security of its neighbors. NATO must become an institution where Europeans, Canadians and Americans work together not only for the common defense, but to build new partnerships with all the nations of Europe. The Atlantic Community must reach out to the countries of the East which were our adversaries in the Cold War, and extend to them the hand of friendship.
5. We will remain a defensive alliance and will continue to defend all the territory of all of our members. We have no aggressive intentions and we commit ourselves to the peaceful resolution of all disputes. We will never in any circumstance be the first to use force.
6. The member states of the North Atlantic Alliance propose to the member states of the Warsaw Treaty Organization a joint declaration in which we solemnly state that we are no longer adversaries and reaffirm our intention to refrain from the threat or use of force against the territorial integrity or political independence of any state, or from acting in any other manner inconsistent with the purposes and principles of the United Nations Charter and with the CSCE (the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe) Final Act. We invite all other CSCE member states to join us in this commitment to non-aggression.
7. In that spirit, and to reflect the changing political role of the Alliance, we today invite President (Mikhail S.) Gorbachev on behalf of the Soviet Union, and representatives of the other Central and Eastern European countries, to come to Brussels and address the North Atlantic Council. We today also invite the governments of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the Czech and Slovak Federal Republic, the Hungarian Republic, the Republic of Poland, the People's Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to come to NATO, not just to visit, but to establish regular diplomatic liaison with NATO. This will make it possible for us to share with them our thinking and deliberations in this historic period of change.
8. Our Alliance will do its share to overcome the legacy of decades of suspicion. We are ready to intensify military contacts, including those of NATO Military Commanders, with Moscow and other Central and Eastern European capitals.
9. We welcome the invitation to NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner to visit Moscow and meet with Soviet leaders.
10. Military leaders from throughout Europe gathered earlier this year in Vienna to talk about their forces and doctrine. NATO proposes another such meeting this autumn to promote common understanding. We intend to establish an entirely different quality of openness in Europe, including an agreement on ``Open Skies.''
11. The significant presence of North American conventional and U.S. nuclear forces in Europe demonstrates the underlying political compact that binds North America's fate to Europe's democracies. But, as Europe changes, we must profoundly alter the way we think about defense.
12. To reduce our military requirements, sound arms control agreements are essential. That is why we put the highest priority on completing this year the first treaty to reduce and limit conventional armed forces in Europe (CFE) along with the completion of a meaningful CSBM (confidence-building measures) package. These talks should remain in continuous session until the work is done. Yet we hope to go further. We propose that, once a CFE Treaty is signed, follow-on talks should begin with the same membership and mandate, with the goal of building on the current agreement with additional measures, including measures to limit manpower in Europe. With this goal in mind, a commitment will be given at the time of signature of the CFE Treaty concerning the manpower levels of a unified Germany.
13. Our objective will be to conclude the negotiations on the follow-on to CFE and CSBMs as soon as possible and looking to the follow-up meeting of the CSCE to be held in Helsinki in 1992. We will seek through new conventional arms control negotiations, within the CSCE framework, further far-reaching measures in the 1990s to limit the offensive capability of conventional armed forces in Europe, so as to prevent any nation from maintaining disproportionate military power on the continent. NATO's High Level Task Force will formulate a detailed position for these follow-on conventional arms control talks. We will make provisions as needed for different regions to redress disparities and to ensure that no one's security is harmed at any stage. Furthermore, we will explore broader arms control and confidence-building opportunities. This is an ambitious agenda, but it matches our goal: enduring peace in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Says Party Is on the Road to Ruin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Gorbachev comment, news conference of Russian delegates, other details and background. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin told Soviet Communists today they are following their Eastern European comrades down the path to ruin and could even be brought to trial by a society demanding punishment for their misdeeds. Yeltsin, the president of the Russian republic and populist rival of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, shook up the sleepy fifth day of the Communist Party congress with a blistering attack on the hard-liners who dominate it. Yeltsin is calling for more drastic market-oriented reforms to revive the faltering Soviet economy than those favored by President Gorbachev, the leader of the Communist Party. If the party does not change, ``inevitably, representatives of the apparatus will be dragged out of the bodies of legal power,'' he said. ``Such a party will be unable to hold onto its vanguard role, or even its representatives in the legislature.'' Citing a growing demand to nationalize party property, Yeltsin said: ``It's possible to imagine that a struggle will begin to bring to trial leaders of the party at all levels for damages they personally brought to the people and the country.'' The more than 4,600 delegates in the Kremlin's Palace of Congresses listened intently to Yeltsin, but he received only a smattering of applause.
