Gorbachev, asked later about Yeltsin's speech said: ``I expected more.'' Hammering home his point, Yeltsin told delegates: ``If you think there is a different possibility, look at the fate of the Communist Parties of Eastern Europe. They separated themselves from the people, didn't understand their role, and were left on the side of the road.'' The only way out, he said, is for the Soviet Communist Party to accept all the trappings of democracy that party leaders endorsed earlier this year. Yeltsin is a sympathizer of the Democratic Platform faction within the Communist Party. The group has indicated that if the Commmunist Party cannot be reformed, it will found its own party. In his speech, Yeltsin said many new parties are forming. Later, Yeltsin predicted the Democratic Platform would join an alliance of more democratic-minded political parties. On Monday, the first day of the 10-day congress, Leningrad reformer Yuri Boldyrev, called for nationalization of party property. Democratic Platform says taking back the party's vast holdings is a key issue for the group. Yeltsin parlayed his popularity among Russian citizens in May into election as president of Russia, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics. Since quarreling with Gorbachev in late 1987, Yelstin has been a constant critic of the Soviet leader and an advocate of faster reform. But the congress so far has been a forum for Gorbachev's hard-line critics. Yeltsin also has called upon the congress to change its name to the Party of Democratic Socialism. Party spokesmen said Thursday that idea will be brought to the congress floor for a vote, despite a poll indicating that 80 percent of the delegates were against changing the name. Ivan K. Polozkov, newly elected head of Russia's Communist Party organization, told reporters he was against changing the party's name. ``To replace the Communist Party is to change the sign on a firm that has hurt its own reputation, but its essence won't change,'' he said. ``The task is to renew the party and to show people it can fill an avant-garde role in society.'' Polozkov said he also supported Gorbachev's statement on Wednesday that the leadership should quit if it cannot make any improvements in Soviets' lives in the next two years. The congress comes at a time of crisis for the Soviet party. It is not in immediate danger of losing its dominance of the political scene, but its authority is low and there has been talk of a split. The congress is technically the highest organ of the Communist Party, empowered to set the party line, change the leadership and alter party structure.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says He's `Ready to Go' to NATO
With PM-NATO-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev indicated today he would accept an invitation from NATO to visit its headquarters, and a Foreign Ministry spokesman gave the alliance's latest session a glowing review. Gorbachev, speaking to reporters and delegates during a break in the Communist Party Congress in the Kremlin, said he had not received a formal invitation yet but ``I am always ready to go.'' NATO leaders, ending their summit in London today, approved a communique that proposed a mutual non-aggression pact with the Soviet Union and extended the unprecedented invitation to Gorbachev and other Warsaw Pact leaders to visit NATO headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, probably in December. Gennady Gerasimov, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, told reporters in Moscow the Soviet Union had followed the NATO summit with high expectations and ``we welcome the results of the session as a practical step to re-examine the philosophy of confrontation in Europe.'' He announced that the alliance's secretary general, Manfred Woerner, would come to Moscow on July 14 in ``a good continuation'' of the London forum. Gerasimov said NATO's moves away from military confrontation were an effective answer to several Soviet officers who have complained the country's foreign policy under Gorbachev has consisted mainly of one-sided concessions. ``The results of the NATO session show that our good example brings answering steps from NATO,'' he said, noting that Western moves thus bolstered Gorbachev's position at home as well as abroad. Ivan Polozkov, head of the Russian Federation's Communist Party, told reporters earlier today he supports the idea of Western aid for the ailing Soviet economy. ``I think we have no basis to refuse aid if it's proposed,'' said Polozkov, who is considered a leading hard-liner in the party. Gorbachev reportedly appealed for economic aid in a letter to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain at the NATO meeting. The issue of Western economic aid to the Soviet Union was not resolved at the London meeting, and is expected to be tackled at an economic summit of seven major industrial democracies that opens in Houston on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Fires Force Evacuation of Town of 900
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with highways reopened, new estimate of Tok fire size, fire diminishing overnight but storm threat today. Converts acreage to square miles. Picks up 20th graf, `The governor...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FB1
DOC.TEXT: More than 150 wildfires raced across Alaska's interior, forcing the evacuation of a town of 900 people and disrupting travel on highways choked by heat and smoke. Gov. Steve Cowper declared a statewide state of emergency, and called on the Alaska National Guard to help fight the fires that raged over 270 square miles of forest and open tundra. An elite firefighting team from California was being flown in later today. No injuries were reported. The biggest fire covered about 47 square miles near Beaver, about 110 miles north of Fairbanks, but no structures were threatened there. The greater threat was a wildfire that took only 24 hours to nearly double in size to at least 39 square miles today. Flames swelled up over trees and drew to within a quarter mile of the east edge of Tok, a town about 175 miles southeast of Fairbanks. Emergency workers Thursday afternoon went door to door urging people to leave their homes. The evacuation remained in effect early today. Authorities closed portions of the Glenn Highway, leading south to Anchorage, and the Alaska Highway, a main road from the Canada border, for the day Thursday. But the smoke hazard diminished overnight, and traffic resumed. State troopers said there was a steady line of cars passing through Tok early today. Many were tourists hauling campers who spent the night camped at the village airstip. More than 400 firefighters spent Thursday cutting firebreaks and dumping loads of chemical retardant on the crackling forests from airplanes flying through thick smoke. A fresh crew of about 150 arrived at Fairbanks early this morning. Sharon Wilson, an interagency fire spokeswoman in Fairbanks, said a shift in the wind helped firefighters keep damage to almost zero in Tok. Only a few abandoned buildings burned, she said, adding that today's work would center on widening breaks that are keeping fire from a neighborhood north of town. ``It's not moving now at any drastic rate,'' Wilson said. ``The fire tends to get more quiet at night, but the problem is, the forecast is for more hot and dry weather, and a possible thunderstorm.'' The fire burned mainly black spruce, birch, aspen and brush on the flat terrain around the town. Some Tok residents wore masks to filter out smoke. ``What's bothering us the most is breathing. There's burnt spruce needles falling out of the air,'' said one resident, Mellie Terwilliger. ``You can see but you go around with your lights on.'' Earlier reports that the town's Coast Guard navigational station had been burned were incorrect, said Sue Mitchell, a spokeswoman for the Bureau of Land Management in Fairbanks. The evacuated station, which provides electronic signals to guide aviators and mariners, only lost power, she said. Seventeen firefighter managers from California were expected to arrive at Tok later today. A similar team battled the Yellowstone National Park fire that claimed more than a million acres in the summer of 1988. On Thursday, state forester Bob Dick said: ``The fire is out of control. We're throwing everything at it we have _ tankers, bulldozers, people, and it isn't working.'' The governor, who flew over the region Thursday, said ``we had to get upwind of it before we could actually see it _ the fires are that massive.'' Most of the fires were blamed on heat, low humidity and a rash of lightning strikes. The fire danger was extremely high in much of Alaska, Mitchell said. Temperatures approached 90 degrees throughout much of the interior Wednesday. The heat dries out Alaska's forests and gives rise to late afternoon thunderstorms and wind gusts, Mitchell said. There were more than 1,800 lightning strikes in Alaska on Tuesday, and a record 2,192 on Sunday. On the Kenai Peninsula, however, drizzle and temperatures in the 40s and 50s helped firefighters curb a series of blazes that broke out near Ninilchik. All the blazes there were expected to be contained by Saturday. Nearly four dozen fires were being ignored by firefighting crews because of their limited ability to respond, Mitchell said.

DOC.HEAD: North Korea Says It Will Open Part Of Its Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to RECAST 1st graf, MOVE higher that North's plans appear to be largely symbolic. Pickup 5th graf pvs, `For a...'
DOC.TEXT: Communist North Korea said today it will open part of its border with South Korea next month to promote reunification, and it challenged the South to do the same, according to news reports. But officials in the capitalist South denounced the action as propaganda. The North's plans appeared to be largely symbolic, and it was unclear whether any citizens from the North would be allowed to cross into the South. It would be the first time either of the two Korean states had opened a portion of their border since the Korean War ended in 1953. Word of the North's move came from Naewoe Press, a semiofficial South Korean news agency specializing in Communist affairs. It said North Korea's Committee for the Peaceful Reunification of the Fatherland announced the plans in a broadcast monitored in Seoul today. ``For a successful progress of contact and visit between the North and the South, we will open the portion of our side ... and hope that the South side, too, will take a corresponding measure,'' the announcement said. But it said only those interested in promoting reunification would be allowed into the North. The North Korean announcement said about 800 yards of the border would be opened Aug. 15, the day in 1945 when Korea was liberated from Japan after 35 years of colonial rule. The North said the stretch of border to be opened was in the Communist sector of the truce village of Panmunjom, inside the Demilitarized Zone, about 35 miles north of Seoul. But no civilian can enter the area without approval from military authorities of both sides. South Korea's Defense Ministry said it had not been officially notified of the North's plans and would not comment on whether anyone would be allowed into the area during the border opening. It also was not clear whether North Koreans would be allowed to cross into the South during the opening. South Korean officials claimed the announcement was aimed at encouraging South Korean radical groups to hold a unification rally at Panmunjom. South Korean dissident groups immediately welcomed the North Korean announcement and asked the government to approve their plans to send up to 300 representatives to meet with North Koreans. A spokesman for an umbrella dissident group, Chonminyon, said the South Korean government's response had been negative ``but we will push ahead with our plans.'' A senior Seoul government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, also said the North's move was ``insignificant'' because it affected only a small section of the border. Panmunjom is an oval-shaped joint security area straddling a portion of the 155-mile border between the two Koreas. Military officials of both sides meet there to discuss alleged armistice violations. The announcement came as negotiations were being held to arrange for historic talks between prime ministers of the two nations, possibly in Seoul in August. The talks would be the highest-level contact between the Koreas since the division of the peninsula in 1945. A South Korean statement issued after today's talks said the prime ministers' meeting appeared ``certain to be held.'' On Tuesday, the two sides had agreed in principle to the meeting, possibly in August in Seoul. They agreed to adopt a formal agreement on the talks July 26. North and South Korea are still technically at war because no peace treaty was signed after the 1950-1953 Korean war, which began June 25, 1950 and ended with a cease-fire 37 months later. The Korean border is tightly sealed with more than 1.5 million troops deployed behind concrete bunkers and barbed wire on either side. There is no mail, telephone contact and no communications and travel between citizens.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, a0531,a0533; editing changes throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Western leaders agreed today to transform NATO's nuclear strategy, and President Bush said the alliance was offering a ``solemn commitment to non-aggression'' to the Soviet Union and the new democracies of Eastern Europe. At a news conference wrapping up a two-day NATO summit, Bush said there would be negotiations to limit a unified Germany's armies after the United States and the Soviet Union conclude a treaty reducing their conventional forces in Europe. ``Our alliance extends the hand of friendship,'' Bush said. ``We reaffirm that we shall never be the first to use force.'' He said ``NATO is changing,'' and that the Soviet Union should no longer regard the Western alliance as posing a military threat. In Moscow, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said he was ready to accept the NATO leaders' invitation to address a meeting of the Western alliance, probably in December. ``I am always ready to go,'' Gorbachev said during a break in a contentious Communist Party Congress at the Kremlin. The Soviet leader said he had not received a formal invitation. Soviet foreign ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said, ``We welcome the results of the (NATO) session.'' Bush renewed his support for Gorbachev's reforms but said he has ``big problems'' with direct U.S. assistance to the Soviet economy so long as Moscow spends $5 billion annually for Cuba and billions more on military modernization. Bush said ``perhaps'' there are ways to help the Soviet economy by extending financial credits before moving on to direct government loans. Diplomatic sources said Gorbachev wrote British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher during the NATO summit with an appeal for economic aid. From London, Bush was flying to Houston and next week's economic summit of the world's seven leading industrialized nations. The issue of direct Western aid to the Soviet economy is regarded as certain to dominate discussions in Houston. NATO leaders made a dramatic overture to the Soviet Union, expressed by Bush this way, ``We say to President Gorbachev, come to NATO.'' NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner was dispatched to brief Gorbachev next week. The NATO meeting was called to consider Western security needs in light of the virtual collapse of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact in Eastern Europe, whose member nations have thrown off communist control. The North Atlantic Treaty Organization was founded after World War II as a military counterweight to the Soviet military bloc in Europe. Even as he offered friendship to East European countries, Bush made it clear he is not ready to accept any of the former Soviet satellites into NATO. Asked whether he would oppose Hungary's application, Bush said, ``not forever.'' Woerner said the changes in NATO policy would ease the threat of war. ``At long last we have the chance to make for the first time in history military aggression in Europe materially impossible and also politically meaningless,'' he told reporters at a separate news conference. On nuclear weapons, Woerner said the NATO leaders said they will ``modify and adapt the tasks of their nuclear deterrent forces'' and offered to eliminate all nuclear artillery shells from Europe ``in return for reciprocal action by the Soviet Union.'' In another important development, the allies proposed that once a treaty is signed _ probably next fall _ on limiting conventional arms and military equipment, talks would begin immediately on reducing the number of U.S. and Soviet troops in Europe. ``With this goal in mind, a commitment will be given at the time of signature of the CFE treaty concerning the manpower levels of a unified Germany,'' said a closing communique. Bush said much the same in his news conference. The arms talks are being held between the NATO and Warsaw Pact nations to sharply reduce tanks, artillery and other non-nuclear weapons in Europe. The United States and the Soviet Union already have agreed to limit each side to 195,000 troops in the central region. The United States would maintain an additonal 30,000 in Britain and southern Europe. The commitment by West Germany to limit the forces of a united Germany was seen as a key move to reassure the Soviet Union. Western leaders want a unified Germany to be part of NATO, but Gorbachev is opposed. Overall, Bush described the NATO decision as a ``historic turning point'' and said, ``The London Declaration transformed NATO's nuclear strategy.'' In a written statement, the leaders proposed a mutual non-aggression pact with the Soviet Union and the other nations of the fading Warsaw Pact alliance. The 20-paragraph communique also: _Tightened the trigger guard on European nuclear missiles by stating they would be used only as a last resort. _Invited the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland, Bulgaria and Romania ``to come to NATO, not just to visit, but to establish regular diplomatic liaison.'' ``The walls that once confined people and ideas are collapsing,'' the NATO leaders declared. ``Europeans are determining their own destiny ... They are choosing a Europe whole and free.'' _Proposed the eventual elimination of nuclear artillery shells by ``reciprocal arrangement.'' Asked what message he wants Gorbachev to receive from the London meeting, Bush said: ``Here's an alliance that you should view, Mr. Gorbachev, as defensive, not threatening, and please convince your military and others in the Soviet Union of that fact.''
DOC.NOTE: MORE
Eds: Editing to update.
DOC.HEAD: LONDON: that fact.''
DOC.TEXT: Bush met British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher over breakfast and the president made clear he was satisfied with the communique. Mrs. Thatcher had expressed misgivings about the change in nuclear doctrine. But she agreed and in their final communique, the leaders said ``there are no cricumstances in which nuclear retaliation in response to military action might be discounted.'' The Houston summit is expected to tackle an issue left unresolved here _ whether the West will commit billions of dollars in emergency assistance to help salvage the Soviet Union's crumbling economy. The communique also proposed a permanent secretariat for the 35-nation East-West Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, as well as regular meetings between member heads of government. In a letter to Mrs. Thatcher at the NATO meeting, Gorbachev appealed for economic aid to salvage his troubled economic reform program, sources said. The letter made no mention of any figures, but Gorbachev said he was hoping for ``positive conclusions'' at both the London and Houston summits on the aid issue. West Germany and France have been pushing a $15 billion aid package from the West. Bush has been cool to the proposal, but appears to be softening his stand. Japan says it will oppose it. Gorbachev could use an infusion of Western cash to calm domestic unrest by putting a greater variety of foods and consumer items on Soviet store shelves and to reduce a balance-of-payments deficit that exceeds $2 billion. Half the total is owed to West German companies and creditors. The NATO communique was fashioned early today by foreign ministers of the 16 alliance nations and approved virtually intact by the heads of state at their midmorning concluding session. ``It was pretty much our draft,'' said Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater. White House national security adviser Brent Scowcroft said it was ``an agreement not to be the first to use force'' between individual nations rather than the two alliances. Otherwise, he said, it would give ``a kind of blessing and legitimacy to the Warsaw Pact that we didn't want to do.'' For nearly a quarter-century, NATO officially has reserved the strategic option of quickly unleashing nuclear weapons if NATO's conventional European defenses could not repulse an invasion by Soviet forces. That early-use doctrine is being set aside with a declaration that nuclear arms would be a weapon of last resort. However, the United States will have fewer nuclear weapons in Europe. Bush pledged to begin withdrawing the arsenal of 1,470 nuclear-tipped artillery shells, now based mostly in West Germany, as Soviet troops pull out of Central and Eastern Europe. In a corresponding move, West Germany agreed to reduce the military manpower of a reunited Germany to ease concerns in Moscow. German sources said Bonn is prepared to reduce the size of the joint armed forces to about 400,000, or nearly 150,000 fewer than the combined troops of West and East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Another Art Heist At the Louvre _ This Time Ancient Jewelry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to CLARIFY that the jewelry heist is not the latest art theft, only the latest to be discovered. Pickup 4th, `But the...'
DOC.TEXT: Curators checking the Louvre after the theft of a Renoir painting this week discovered that a dozen ancient necklaces, bracelets and earrings had been stolen from a display case, officials announced today. The officials said the second- and third-century jewelry was stolen from the department of Egyptian antiquities. It was discovered missing during an inspection by department curators on Wednesday. The announcement of the theft came one day after authorities took the unprecedented step of closing five Paris museums to individual visitors following art thefts at the Louvre and two other Paris musuems on the same day. But the director of the Museums of France, Jacques Sallois, said the jewelry theft occurred long before the paintings were stolen. ``The disappearance of these objects _ which are not of great value and are often seen on the market _ is certainly quite old,'' Sallois said. ``It is prior to that of the paintings.'' The jewelry was discovered missing during an inspection by curators, ordered after a Renoir was cut from its frame at the Louvre on Wednesday and two other paintings were stolen from two smaller museums. Police said it was possible that the same person or group robbed all three museums during a span of several hours, moving from one to another in the middle of the day. The city's major museums will remain open, but security will be tightened, said Sallois. Authorities plan to examine existing security systems and develop new ones similar to those used in banks. In addition to the Renoir, an 1816 painting by Paul Huet was stolen from the Carnavalet Museum, and an 1870 work by Ernest Hebert was stolen from a museum named after the artist. The Hebert was one of the five museums closed as of Thursday to individual visitors. The others _ also relatively small institutions focusing on the works or the collections of a particular individual _ are the Eugene Delacroix, Gustave Moreau, Jean-Jacques Henner and Ennery museums. From now on, group visits to these museums must be arranged in advance, Sallois said. Police have complained previously that museum officials were not aggressive enough or candid enough in dealing with security. Sallois, who took up his post only five weeks ago, vowed this would change and said art theft would no longer be a ``taboo subject'' for public discussion. The Louvre's director, Michel Laclotte, said the theft of Renoir's ``Portrait of a Seated Woman'' (1890-95) appeared to be the work of an ``especially clever'' professional. The work by Huet, a French landscape painter, was lifted off its hook Wednesday morning at the history museum in one of the oldest sections of Paris. The painting, ``Les Moulins de la Glaciere,'' was estimated to be worth about $14,500. The Louvre and Hebert museums are run by the national government. The Carnavalet is run by the city of Paris.

DOC.HEAD: Police Issue Sketch as `Dartman' Hits 46th Victim
DOC.TEXT: Police released a sketch of a man from descriptions given by 46 women who say they were hit by darts while walking on midtown Manhattan streets. Chief of Detectives Joseph DeMartino said the latest victim found a homemade dart dangling from ``the backside of her clothing'' when she returned to her office from a lunchtime shopping trip Thursday. Like 17 darts recovered from other attacks, it was made from a pin or needle with a paper stabilizer and probably was blown through a straw, DeMartino said. Police said women should not panic, because needles and pins recovered had not been doctored and showed no indication they could carry an infection. All the victims were women, usually wearing business clothes or skirts, DeMartino said. Thursday's victim was the first black woman to report an attack, he said. The police sketch of the Dartman, as New York's tabloids have dubbed the city's latest unusual criminal, shows a black man with a mustache and neatly trimmed beard. Police say he is 5-feet-6 to 5-feet-8, weighs 135 to 150 pounds and may wear glasses and carry a black bag. All the attacks have occurred on busy streets from 21st to 54th streets between Madison and Seventh avenues, an area encompassing the garment district, Times Square and Rockefeller Center. If arrested, the suspect might be charged with reckless endangerment, assault or possibly felonious assault if a serious injury resulted from a dart attack, DeMartino said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Vocalist Wins Tchaikovsky Gold Medal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to CORRECT that not first time for cello and vocals. Pickup 4th, `Alyssa Park...'
DOC.TEXT: American vocalists Deborah Voigt and Hans Choi today won top honors in the ninth international Tchaikovsky musical competition. Akiko Suwanai of Japan took first place in the violin section of the contest, West Germany's Gustav Rivinius won the gold medal for cello, and Soviet Boris Berezovski took first place for piano, contest officials said. The Tchaikovsky competition has been held every four years since 1958. Alyssa Park, a 16-year-old violinist from Lexington, Ky., came in third and received three medals, for third place, for most talented performer and for most artistic performer. ``I was very honored, but also very puzzled,'' she said later, noting the international jury awarded her medals for most artistic and most talented, but then only gave her third place. She admitted feeling some tension. ``But I just tried to treat it as a concert and play,'' she said. Ten Americans were among the 48 finalists competing for gold medals Thursday night. ``This is the superbowl of musical competition,'' said Daniel Pollack, a competitor in the piano competion in 1958 and now a jury member. Ms. Voigt, 29, a former apprentice with the San Francisco Opera Company, won the gold medal for best female vocalist. She lives in New York. Before the contest, Ms. Voigt said she wanted to win because the Tchaikovsky competition is the best known in the world and can give a singing career an immediate boost. ``The amount of publicity a singer can get here is more than I could pay.'' Choi, a former student at the La Scala opera company of Milan, Italy, got the gold medal for male vocalist. He has lived in the United States for two years and currently resides in Flushing, N.Y. During the competition, he said the biggest problem was language. ``I must sing in six languages, and I must sing perfectly in six languanges, because the judges come from so many countries.''

DOC.HEAD: Mitch Snyder Remembered as `Man of Action' for Homeless
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New material, editing throughout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Mitch Snyder, who was found hanged in the shelter he founded, was eulogized today as a ``man of justice'' who answered a moral call to help the nation's homeless. Snyder, 46, was discovered dead Thursday afternoon in a 1,400-bed homeless shelter in a ragged neighborhood a few blocks from the U.S. Capitol. Autopsy results were not made public but police called his death an apparent suicide. The Rev. Jesse Jackson told a memorial service at Bible Way Church that Snyder was a man who heard and answered a ``moral call'' to help the homeless. ``The fact that birds have a home, foxes have a home, and yet men and women, veterans of foreign wars, mothers and fathers, working poor people, have no place to lay their head. He found that to be a moral disgrace,'' Jackson told the mourners. Friends of Snyder who spoke with him Tuesday described him as despondent. ``He was really down in the dumps and we had a long talk about his personal situation,'' said a friend who asked not to be identified. Jackson called Snyder ``a man of justice, who taught us all that you can still regroup and get your life together.'' ``Don't you surrender, and don't you give up,'' Jackson told the crowd of about 600 mourners, many of whom lived at Snyder's shelter. A funeral is scheduled for Tuesday outside the shelter. The gray, three-story building where Snyder's body was found symbolized the cause in which he achieved national prominence and the tactics he used in his fight. His group _ the Community for Creative Non-Violence _ was given the rundown government building by the Reagan administration only after he staged a hunger strike in 1984 to demand federal aid and publicize the plight of the homeless. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee, which handles housing issues, called Snyder ``a man of action'' who at times became depressed by the problems of the homeless. He was a ``man on the edge _ at the cutting edge of the homeless and the street people and his own ethos and rationale for existence,'' said Gonzalez. A police statement called the death ``an apparent suicide by hanging.'' Spokesman Lt. Reginald Smith said a note containing ``suicidal references'' was found near Snyder's body. The Washington Post reported today that police believe he died Tuesday night or Wednesday, and that he had not been seen since Tuesday. ``It was a domestic situation, something to do with his girlfriend,'' one source said. ``The note indicates there were problems there.'' A second note, found in Snyder's room and written last spring, ``talked about this possibility, sort of outlined what he might do,'' said a police source who spoke on condition of anonymity. Carol Fennelly, Snyder's companion of 15 years and partner in running the shelter, read a statement on the building's steps amid the drops of an approaching thunderstorm. She said the community was ``greatly shocked and saddened.'' Moments later, she departed from the written text and said, ``Mitch always said good things happen when it rains. He was wrong today.'' Fennelly said last spring that the couple would marry in September. She did not return telephone calls seeking comment on the notes. Soon after the discovery of Snyder's body, scores of shelter residents lingered outside the shelter, some with tears in their eyes, others angry. Many blamed the relentless pressures Snyder faced in his fight for the poor. ``The man had done all he could do,'' said Richard Coles, 28, a former shelter resident who visited after hearing the news. ``He was under a lot of pressure, the day-to-day struggle.'' Shortly after word of Snyder's death spread, the shelter was visited by Jackson and Mayor Marion Barry. ``It's tragic, he's gone, we'll miss him,'' said Barry, whose drug possession and perjury trial is under way at the federal courthouse nearby. Actor Martin Sheen, who portrayed Snyder in a 1986 television movie and later spent an evening on a sidewalk grate with him to call attention to homelessness, said he was devastated by the news of the activist's death. ``It's hard to come to grips with,'' Sheen told the Star-Banner in Ocala, Fla., where he was filming a movie. ``I just pray that a very special angel meets him at the gate and escorts him to paradise.'' Last spring, Snyder refused to let Census Bureau workers into the shelter to count its residents, calling the government's effort ``grandstanding.'' He was criticized by other homeless advocates for his stance. In recent weeks, he came under pressure from some volunteer staff aides at the shelter to fire other workers who they said were engaged in illegal activities such as drug use. Snyder grew up in New York City. He remembered his father ordering him to keep his car windows closed when he drove in the Bowery ``to keep out the bums.'' Snyder worked selling washing machines and vacuum cleaners and as a job counselor before quitting and leaving his wife and two children in 1969. He later was sent to the federal prison in Danbury, Conn., for auto theft. While there, he met antiwar priests Daniel and Philip Berrigan, who were serving time for destroying draft records. Snyder moved to Washington in 1973, as the Vietnam war was winding down. He was arrested Christmas Day that year, trying to climb the White House fence.

DOC.HEAD: University Fears Damage to Public Trust More than Health Risk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st-2nd grafs with 1 graf to recast. Picks up 3rd graf, `About 20...'.
DOC.TEXT: The possible exposure of 120 people to a fatal leukemia virus was ``an unacceptable break in procedure'' but probably didn't put anyone at serious risk, University of Pennsylvania officials said. About 20 veterinary students and staff and 100 visiting preschool children unknowingly handled 14 newborn lambs that had been inoculated with a slow-acting virus, HTLV-1. The human T-cell lymphotropic virus can cause a lethal form of leukemia in people but does not grow in sheep. ``It was an unacceptable break of procedure,'' said Penn's vice provost for research, Barry Cooperman. He said many of the veterinary school researchers expressed concern that allegations of misconduct would damage the public perception of science and hinder research efforts. ``The university's concern is that the public puts its trust in us,'' he said. ``We owe the public scrupulous responsibility in conducting experiments.'' Penn officials investigating the violation are now waiting for test results of blood samples from those people exposed to the animals to determine if they were infected, according to Cooperman. The exposure occurred sometime in April when the lambs were inoculated but not separated from the rest of their flock at Penn's 600-acre New Bolton Center in suburban Chester County. Both the school's Environmental Health and Safety Office and the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee had specified that the inoculated lambs should be isolated from the rest of the flock. ``It was a serious breach of responsibility,'' said Dr. Aron B. Fisher, chairman of Penn's animal care committee. Cooperman said officials investigating the problem did not learn until early June that the veterinary students had worked with the lambs and that children from the Kennett Square Cooperative Preschool had visited the site and played with the animals. Because HTLV-1 is transmitted only through blood, mother's milk and sexual intercourse, school and health officials believe it is unlikely that anyone was infected. ``The risk to children is essentially nil,'' said Cooperman. ``And to our own people, a minimal risk.'' The experiment, which was approved by a faculty committee, was conducted by Jorge F. Ferrer, 58, a senior Penn researcher. Ferrer, whose research has been suspended pending the outcome of the inquiry, has 15 days to respond. Cooperman said the school completed a preliminary investigation June 22 and will begin a full-scale inquiry soon. He refused to comment on the initial findings. Ferrer's telephone number is unpublished and he could not be reached for comment. His attorney, John M. Myers, did not return telephone calls. Cooperman said Ferrer was trying to grow the virus in the lambs to see if he could produce a protein that might help fight the virus in people.

DOC.HEAD: Court Orders Home, Car, Cash Returned to Brezhnev's Daughter
DOC.TEXT: A court has ordered a country house, Mercedes car, furniture, a weapons collection and thousands of dollars in cash returned to Galina Brezhnev, daughter of the former Soviet leader, a newspaper said today. The property and cash were seized when Ms. Brezhnev's husband, Yuri Churbanov, was imprisoned in December 1988 for accepting bribes. Ms. Brezhnev filed suit in a Moscow court arguing she inherited the car and money from her father, Leonid Brezhnev, according to Komsomolskaya Pravda, the Young Communist League's newspaper. Brezhnev ruled the Soviet Union from 1964 until his death in 1982. The court apparently agreed the property and cash were owned by Ms. Brezhnev rather than her husband. The paper said the court ordered the government to return a country house worth $108,474, a Mercedes given to Brezhnev by an unidentified foreign government, furniture and chandeliers. Also seized was a weapons collection worth $200,000, stuffed animals valued at $137,011 and $111,000 in savings. ``If it were not for the loud name of the plaintiff, I wouldn't even remember the case,'' the unidentified judge said in the article. ``Under the law, Galina Brezhnev was within her rights, since most of the property belonged to her and not her husband, and the Supreme Court had no right after sentencing Yuri Churbanov to confiscate it.'' The paper did not say when the decision regarding Ms. Brezhnev's property was made. Ms. Brezhnev's flamboyant lifestyle shocked Moscow during her father's tenure. The Soviet press has accused her of speculating in diamonds, and she has been linked to a bribery scandal involving a Moscus circus performer. Churbanov was fired from his job as first deputy interior minister in 1984. Four years later he was convicted of accepting $150,000 in bribes and sentenced to 12 years in a labor camp.

DOC.HEAD: Germanys Begin Negotiations on Final Merger
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 8th pvs, `This week...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with strikes today. Pickup 9th, `East German...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BER1
DOC.TEXT: Officials from the two Germanys began negotiations today on the final phase of unification, and Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere of East Germany said Berlin should be the new German capital. Meanwhile, in southern Leipzig, farmers said they would dump 2,640 gallons of milk on the streets Monday to protest the loss of business following the economic merger of the German states, the ADN news agency said. Elsewhere, a bomb threat forced the evacuation of East Germany's Parliament while lawmakers were in a session unrelated to the East-West talks. No bomb was found, and the lawmakers returned after about 30 minutes. De Maiziere led the East German delegation in talks today on combining the political systems of the German states. An economic treaty went into effect Sunday that united the German economies. Officials have spoken of all-German elections as early as December. In an interview with ADN, de Maiziere said the pact should give East Germans the same rights as West Germans. He also said the treaty should make Berlin the capital of a united Germany. West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble led the West German delegation. Also today, 100,000 metal workers held one-hour ``warning strikes'' to demand higher wages and job protection, said union spokesman Detlef Kuchenbecker. About 10,000 marched through East Berlin to press their demands. Prices have soared in this new free-market society following the economic merger and metal workers have held strikes daily at various plants. East German stores have stocked their shelves with more expensive West German products, forcing up prices. There have also been widespread reports of price gouging by East German stores. De Maiziere and other officials have criticized the price rises. The costs of some foodstuffs varied by 100 percent from one region to another. ``There's no way that can be justified merely by higher transportation costs or overhead,'' de Maiziere told legislators Thursday. ADN reported price rises of 400 percent to 600 percent in northern Mecklenburg and Pomerania regions and said there were long shopping lines in southeastern Dresden. ``There are cities in the GDR (East Germany) where the average price levels are way above those in West Germany,'' said Economics Minister Gerhard Pohl. ``We need certain guarantees that GDR citizens ... won't be exploited.'' Several thousand metalworkers struck at seven plants near Leipzig, where pay talks deadlocked two days ago, according to ADN. The union wants East Germany to adopt the West German system of stipulating salary scales and job descriptions in huge collective contracts by which all the workers in a specific industry are bound. In southwestern Erfurt, 9,000 workers rallied outside their union headquarters as contract talks began, ADN said. The negotiations later collapsed, the agency reported. Workers are demanding that pay levels be brought up to West German standards by next year. The average East German earns less than half the average West German salary. Rents are being kept low to help compensate during the transition from 40 years of socialism to capitalism. But unemployment is expected to surge into the millions as East Germany faces stiff competition from West Germany. East Germany's Communist regime was overthrown last autumn.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says Kenya Should Not Persecute Opposition
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials said today they were distressed by the recent detention of pro-democracy activists and urged the government not to persecute opposition figures. Charles Rubia and Kenneth Matiba, both former Cabinet ministers, were among at least 11 people detained Wednesday and Thursday. Since May they have led a loose alliance of lawyers and church leaders seeking legalized opposition in this one-party state. The U.S. State Department, in a statement released by the U.S. Embassy in Nairobi, said: ``In recent weeks, we have made clear our hope that Matiba and Rubia and others who may speak out against the government would not be persecuted.'' ``We believe very strongly in the principle of public expression of dissent and the right of peaceful assembly,'' the statement said. ``We are obviously distressed to see this action by the Kenyan government.'' The U.S. Embassy on Thursday delivered a note to Kenya's Foreign Ministry expressing the Bush administration's ``interest and concern'' over the situation, an embassy spokesman said. Rubia and Matiba had urged the government to allow opposition activists to hold a public rally on Saturday. But President Daniel arap Moi has called the pro-democracy supporters traitors and subversives, and he told citizens not to attend any rallies. The president says that multiparty politics would create ethnic strife among Kenya's 40 tribes and lead to tribal warfare. The opposition accuses the government of corruption and election rigging.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Converge on Yellowstone Blaze
With PM-Fires-Alaska, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hastily assembled firefighters today battled an 80-acre blaze in Yellowstone National Park. ``We are sending in as many people as we can spare this morning,'' said Marsha Karle, a park spokeswoman. Personnel from Yellowstone and nearby Grand Teton National Park who are qualified to fight fires were pulled off other jobs, she said. She said the fire, the largest so far this season in the park, was reported Thursday afternoon and probably resulted from lightning. The blaze is on Mount Washburn, near Dunraven Pass on the park's Upper Loop Road, about eight miles from the nearest visitors' facilities. Park officials have said that Yellowstone's policy is to fight all wildfires aggressively while its fire management plan, suspended after the devastating fires of 1988, is being revised. The previous policy, which came under wide criticism, was to let fires caused by nature burn unless they endangered human life or property.

DOC.HEAD: `Iron Lady' Remains True to Form
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Thatcher comment, inserting 2 grafs after 4th graf, In the, and subbing 6th graf pvs, Their heads
DOC.TEXT: The Iron Curtain may be down, but Margaret Thatcher's still the Iron Lady. True to form, Britain's prime minister was the least eager among the NATO summit participants to lower the West's voice or guard in the wake of Kremlin reforms and the collapse of the Soviet Union's satellite regimes in Eastern Europe. She delivered stern warnings about dismantling arsenals too soon and balked at President Bush's proposal that the alliance stiffen its policy restraint on the use of theater nuclear weapons. In the end, she agreed to the new ``last resort'' strategy, her aides said, because it still means that Moscow can never be sure that nuclear weapons wouldn't be used to respond to Soviet aggression in Europe. Mrs. Thatcher called the summit outcome ``good for NATO and good for Mr. Gorbachev.'' The NATO leaders' final communique said ``there are no circumstances in which nuclear retaliation in response to military action might be discounted.'' NATO has long openly reserved the nuclear option in the face of potentially overpowering Warsaw Pact conventional forces. The agreement to confine that option to the last-resort category was reaced by foreign ministers of the 16-nation NATO alliance early Friday, diplomatic sources said. Their heads of government approved the shift as part of their closing communique today. As drafted by the ministers, the document also included an invitation for the seven-nation Warsaw Pact, led by the Soviets, to sign a non-aggression pact with the Western alliance. Her aides said Mrs. Thatcher feared the ``last-resort'' language could mean ``losing the sense of the unknown which is essential to deterrence at all levels.'' But she finally was satisfied that ``the language that was worked out will keep the sense of mystery,'' said one British official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Some observers noted that Mrs. Thatcher would have had a tough time trying to block the policy shift in any case. The U.S. proposal was strongly backed by West Germany, soon to be an even more powerful European force as part of a united Germany. However, Mrs. Thatcher struck a series of warning notes through the crucial meeting, saying that while things have changed dramatically in Europe, glasnost and the collapse of satellite communist governments shouldn't mean the winding down of NATO. The prime minister, dubbed the Iron Lady by the Soviets in the Cold War era, reeled off statistics about continued Soviet weapons production during a closed session of the leaders on Thursday, her aides reported. ``To remind people of this might put me in danger of being called a Cold War warrior,'' a British official quoted her as saying. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Mrs. Thatcher then added that ``she could not be called a Cold War warrior but she certainly could be accused of being very cautious on defense.'' She was just as forceful in open session. ``NATO has defended peace with freedom and justice but it has never threatened anyone,'' she said. ``The cornerstone of that sure defense must remain, for we do not know what the future holds, but its architecture may change in the new situation.'' But she also acknowledged Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's need for reassurance. ``Our former adversaries need our help and also our assurance that their own security is not threatened by the changes taking place,'' she said. She believes her forthright approach is the one best understood by Gorbachev. Behind the tough words, Mrs. Thatcher is, however, looking to cash in on the peace dividend. Her government is undertaking a major overhaul of its defense spending, and already has canceled an order for 33 Tornado warplanes to trim $1 billion off this year's $37.7 billion defense budget.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Senator Says Iran, Saudi Arabia Helping Separatists
DOC.TEXT: Iran and Saudi Arabia are providing military and financial support to Moslem militants fighting for independence from India in disputed Kashmir, a U.S. senator said today. Sen. Alan Cranston, a senior member of the Foreign Relations Committee, indicated that Iranian and Saudi help to the separatists was maintaining the flow of arms and trained fighters across the Pakistan-Indian frontier. ``My impression is that Pakistan has greatly reduced, and perhaps ended, its assistance to those wanting to cross the border,'' Cranston told reporters. ``But I believe there are others engaged in this process.'' The California Democrat said he understood that Iran and perhaps some Afghans were training Kashmiri insurgents and that Saudi Arabia was giving financial aid to help the separatists counter a harsh Indian crackdown. In a meeting with the senator later, Indian Prime Minister V.P. Singh took issue with Cranston's claim that Pakistan was scaling down its help to the militants. Pakistani aid ``had actually shown a sharp increase in the last couple of months. This help was the main obstacle to the improvement of relations with Pakistan,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Aftab Seth quoted Singh as telling Cranston. He said Cranston was given documents supporting India's claim of growing Pakistani help, but he declined to elaborate. Indian sources said the flow of arms across the frontier was ``several times greater'' in the last two months than it had been earlier in the year. Seth declined to comment on the reported aid to the separatists by Iran and Saudi Arabia. But he said, ``If that is his (Cranston's) perception, he must have solid and concrete evidence to draw his conclusions.'' Pakistan and India both claim the entire Kashmir region, but it is divided between them. Two of the three wars they have fought since gaining independence from Britain in 1947 began over Kashmir. More than 650 people have died since tensions began growing in January. Jammu-Kashmir is the only one of the 25 states in Hindu-dominated India with a Moslem majority, although the nation is officially secular. Two more people were reported killed today during clashes between Indian security forces and the militants. One 60-year-old woman was shot in the head when closed a window, witnesses said. Cranston said he been assured that Amnesty International, the London-based human rights group, will be allowed to investigate allegations of abuses by Indian troops in Kashmir. Until now India has resisted any outside inspection as an infringement of its sovereignty. The government still appears divided on how much freedom Amnesty officials would have. Cranston, who visited Kashmiri refugee camps during a three-day trip to Pakistan, said Indian troops were clearly guilty of human rights violations during the seven-month rebellion. Although the threat of an India-Pakistan war over Kashmir has eased recently, he said, any conflict carried the risk of a nuclear confrontation. ``My impression is that neither side possesses a nuclear bomb, but both have the capability to produce a small number of nuclear weapons in a number of weeks if it wants to,'' he said. ``If war goes on for some time, nations are likely to deploy whatever weapons they have to win.''

DOC.HEAD: After 41 Years Of Glaring At Moscow, NATO Turns A Corner
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Bush quotes, inserting 2 grafs after 5th graf pvs, But propelled
DOC.TEXT: The NATO alliance isn't about to call it quits, but it's reaching out to Moscow with a less menacing countenance. Formed in 1949 to contain the Red Army, the alliance suddenly finds itself in search of a mission _ and with the prospect of fewer American soldiers, tanks and nuclear weapons at its disposal. Its rival military bloc, the Warsaw Pact, is unraveling; Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is ready to withdraw tens of thousands of troops and tanks from Europe. NATO ended a two-day summit today with a new strategic doctrine. Nuclear weapons will remain in NATO's arsenal, along with a threat to use them in the event of a ground war in Europe. But, propelled by President Bush, the pivotal figure at the two-day meeting, the allies have scrapped the threat of early first use. Bush, asked what message Gorbachev should take from the action, said: ``Here's an alliance that you should view, Mr. Gorbachev, as defensive, not threatening, and please convince your military and others in the Soviet Union of that fact.'' ``Our alliance extends the hand of friendship,'' Bush said. ``We reaffirm that we shall never be the first to use force.'' The West now views a Soviet invasion of Europe as far less likely than when the theater nuclear doctrine was formulated 25 years ago. So nuclear weapons, under the new vernacular, will become a deterrent of unlikely last resort. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher fought to keep NATO from tempering its nuclear posture, but her holdout ended Thursday night when the 16 foreign ministers agreed to keep the threat _ however diminished _ in the books. So radical is the change sweeping Europe the Western allies decided to solicit a non-aggression agreement from the Warsaw Pact; to invite Gorbachev to visit the North Atlantic Council in December; to begin dismantling 1,470 U.S. nuclear-tipped artillery shells once the Soviets withdrawn troops from Central and Eastern Europe. The withdrawal is being negotiated between NATO and the Warsaw Pact in Vienna, along with a more modest U.S. pullout. The artillery shells are targeted mostly on East Germany, which by December may be part of a united Germany and NATO itself. Gorbachev, remember, still heads the Soviet Union and what used to be called the Soviet Empire. Opening NATO's door to even a Gorbachev speech is an act of high symbolism. Similarly, liaison is being established with Hungary and any other interested Warsaw Pact members who want to approach Europe's future in concert with NATO at least as much as with Moscow. ``We will show that NATO has a new dimension of cooperation with the Soviet Union and with the new democracies of Eastern Europe,'' Bush told the 15 other Western leaders meeting in a chandeliered room in Lancaster House. What a difference from the rhetoric of just years ago. ``I am not in favor of anything that would artificially perpetuate bloc-to-bloc relations when this no longer reflects the reality,'' said French President Francois Mitterrand. Backing Bush's call for a formal end to the longstanding hostility between the two alliances, the French leader said he would go further, and seek ``a solemn declaration renouncing aggression or first use of force.'' That is a little more than Bush and most of the other allies are willing to offer. Similarly, the United States is not yet prepared to pull all its nuclear weapons from Europe. For the time being, at least, some 700 Lance missiles with battlefield nuclear missiles will remain, with most of them in West Germany. And the Bush administration is planning to produce a new air-to-surface missile called TASM, and also will divert some sea-launched cruise missiles to the West European nuclear arsenal. But with the cancellation of new Lances by Bush in May, and now the promise to scrap nuclear-tipped artillery shells, the trend in Europe cannot be misread.

DOC.HEAD: Province Tense After Dissolution of Government, Parliament
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with opposition statement, Slovenian protest. Edits to recast lead, trim. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Serbian authorities clamped a lid today on Kosovo, the troubled southern province it administers, detaining two ethnic Albanian opposition leaders and deploying police. Tension was high in Kosovo a day after Serbia dissolved the local legislature and government in Pristina, the province's capital. The crackdown followed Monday's vote by Kosovo's legislature to secede. Police patrolled Pristina, 150 miles south of Belgrade, and heavy security was reported elsewhere in the province today. ``Yesterday's decisions ... are both illegal and unconstitutional,'' said Jusuf Budzovi, a member of the opposition Democratic Forum, at a news conference in Pristina. ``Kosovo is now a special zone in Europe in which nothing except the police can function,'' Budzovi said. He spoke before a building housing the Forum's offices, which were sealed off by Serbian police. Yugoslavia is a loose federation of six republics and two nominally autonomous provinces. Kosovo, 90 percent of whose 1.9 million inhabitants are ethnic Albanian, has progressively lost control of its affairs to Serbia. At least 60 ethnic Albanians in Kosovo have died in clashes with the security forces since Kosovo's autonomy was severely limited in March 1989. Serbs consider Kosovo, the country's least-developed region, the cradle of their medieval kingdom. They have accused ethnic Albanians of pressuring remaining Slavs to move out to pave the way for independence. Under the crackdown, Serbian authorities took Albanian-language programs on Pristina radio and television off the air Thursday. They replaced management and leading journalists at broadcast media and the main provincial newspaper. Serbian authorities accused the Albanian-language media of preparing to broadcast and print calls for a general uprising by ethnic Albanians. But the Albanian-language Rilindija daily appeared on the stands today, Yugoslavia's state Tanjug news agency said. ``Kosovo was yesterday subjected to a coup by the Serbian authorities,'' said a commentary in Rilindija. Riot police surrounded the television and radio buildings today and were preventing visitors from entering the Rilindija publishing house, sources said. The journalists' union from Yugoslavia's westernmost republic of Slovenia, sharply denounced ``the measures being implemented against journalists of Albanian origin in Kosovo.'' Serbian Interior Minister Radmilo Bogdanovic said disciplinary measures would be taken against an undetermined number of ethnic Albanian policemen who refused to participate in the clampdown. Two prominent ethnic Albanian politicians, Ibrahim Rugova and Zekeria Cana, contacted from Belgrade said today they were detained overnight by state security police. The latest moves by the Communist leadership of Serbia are generally seen as an effort to strip the last vestiges of self-government Kosovo had under a 1974 constitution, until the charter was amended in March. Ethnic Albanians, who want free elections and a multiparty system, say the issue has been used by the republic's Communist leader Slobodan Milosevic to gain popular support for his hard-line policies. Serbia's leadership has proposed a new state constitution that would abolish Kosovo's autonomy. The elimination of Kosovo's parliament under a new Constitution would make ethnic Albanians a small minority in the Serbian legislature. The republic of Slovenia and Croatia this spring held the nation's first free local elections in 45 years and three other republics plan ballots later this year. Hard-line Serbia opposes Western-style democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Michigan Anti-Abortion Group Says Files Petitions on Parental Consent Law
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs with petitions submitted. Picks up 3rd graf, `Lawmakers earlier...'
DOC.TEXT: An anti-abortion group filed petitions today that it says have enough signatures to force lawmakers to draft legislation requiring minor girls to get a parent's permission to end a pregnancy. Right to Life of Michigan submitted petitions with 333,187 signatures to the Board of State Canvassers. The Michigan Constitution requires about 192,000 valid signatures to put the parental consent measure before the Legislature. Lawmakers earlier approved a law that would have required girls 17 and under to get a parent's or judge's approval before having an abortion. Gov. James Blanchard vetoed the measure and the Legislature failed to override his veto. If the canvassers rule there are sufficient signatures, the Legislature would have 40 days to approve the measure, or it automatically would go on a statewide ballot. If lawmakers approve the measure, it would become law exempt from a gubernatorial veto. ``Both houses have voted twice on it already because there were two different versions. And a majority of the state House and Senate have signed the petitions,'' Barbara Listing, president of Right to Life of Michigan, said Thursday. Pro-choice groups say the parental consent measure would hurt young people and hinder communication between parents and children. Last month, the U.S. Supreme Court upheld a Minnesota law requiring minor girls seeking abortions to notify a parent or seek judicial approval.

DOC.HEAD: Top Dog for the Underdog, Mad Dog to the Establishment
With PM-Mitch Snyder Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 9th graf, bgng, Now Mitchell ... to reflect that time of death is uncertain
DOC.TEXT: In a grubby field jacket, with burning eyes, Mitch Snyder knew how to use his hunger as a weapon. He stared down a president and got him to turn over a decaying federal building for a homeless shelter. That took a 51-day fast in 1984. CBS cameras were about to capture the showdown for ``60 Minutes.'' The presidential election was two days off. Ronald Reagan capitulated. Snyder got the Navy to alter plans to name a new nuclear submarine Corpus Christi, after the city in Texas. He said no warship should bear the name ``the body of Christ,'' and the Navy changed it to the USS City of Corpus Christi. That took 11 days of self-deprivation. It took 30 days without food to get the Department of Health and Human Services to release surplus food to the homeless. But frail, scornful, confrontational Mitch Snyder had failures, too. He walked out of a marriage, leaving behind two small children, forcing his wife onto welfare. He said he couldn't stand his life of selling Electrolux vacuum cleaners and Maytag washing machines. And 10 days ago, Snyder failed to keep the city of Washington from slashing funds for the homeless and gutting a law ensuring a night's shelter to everyone in need. The law had been Snyder's triumph. He persuaded voters to enact it in an initiative six years ago. ``This law was strangling us,'' said a city councilman, H.R. Crawford. ``We are broke.'' The new amendment, which awaits the mayor's signature, would require homeless people to go though a screening process before being approved for shelter. Now Mitch Snyder has suffered his ultimate failure. He has killed himself. His body was found Thursday. His motives are far from clear. Police sources suggest private demons _ not policy issues _ compelled Snyder to give up living. Snyder, 46, was known everywhere. He described himself as liberator of the destitute. He was the hero of a TV movie, ``Samaritan: The Mitch Snyder Story.'' Its star, Martin Sheen, called him ``a saint.'' He led congressmen and Hollywood celebrities to a night of sleeping on the street. He hobnobbed. This spring his life took new twists. He announced he would enter a Trappist monastery to renew his relationship with God, ``to do simple work like baking bread.'' A month later, a change in plans. Carol Fennelly, Snyder's companion for 15 years, said she and Snyder would marry in September on the street in front of the 1,400-bed shelter that had been the focus of Snyder's work, the place that Snyder had forced from a reluctant Reagan. The wedding ceremony was to have been performed by Daniel Berrigan, the anti-Vietnam war priest. Berrigan and his brother, Philip, introduced Snyder to activism in prison in Danbury, Conn. The Berrigans were there for destroying draft records. Snyder was there for stealing a car out West. That, he once explained, had been back in his Jack Kerouac days of finding himself. After prison, Snyder abandoned his old life. He drifted to Washington, activism, hunger strikes. He became top dog at the Community for Creative Non-Violence, turning it from a religious antiwar group into a noisy shelter for the roofless poor. His former wife, Ellen Daly, described him in an interview with The Washington Post in 1988 as driven, unhappy. ``I was married to him, I lived with him, I slept with him, I had children by him, and yet there's parts of him I really don't know,'' she said. After seeing him portrayed on television, the sons, Ricky and Dean, made contact. They visited Snyder at the shelter. They once helped serve Thanksgiving dinner there. Snyder's first act of defiance in Washington occurred on Christmas Day, 1973. He climbed the White House fence, apparently intent on confronting President Nixon. He had no more luck in 1978 persuading the Rev. James English, pastor of the fashionable Holy Trinity Church in Georgetown, to give the homeless money intended for church repairs. English told The Washington Times that Snyder said, ``I know how to deal with you,'' picketed, brought the homeless into the sanctuary during services, staged a ``sleep-in'' in the convent gardens, fasted. The congregation stood firm; it was the starving Snyder who, from a hospital bed, gave in. More recently, he outraged other homeless advocates by refusing to allow census workers into the shelter.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Studying Ways to Combat Poverty
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is engaged in a long-term study of ways to combat poverty, and it is unlikely that any new proposals will result before the end of the year, officials said today. ``This is a long-term process,'' Deputy White House Press Secretary Stephen Hart said. ``No decisions have been made. Certainly no final decision on what options should be considered by the president have been made.'' Douglas J. Besharov, a scholar at the conservative American Enterprise Institute, said, ``I think they are in the process of a long-term examination of what could be done. They just are not going to propose anything this year.'' Besharov was among a group of outside experts on poverty summoned to the White House for a meeting in September. ``It could well go into next year before any final decisions are made,'' said an administration official who spoke on condition he not be identified. ``You may see in the shorter term some decisions that give an indication of what direction we are headed in, but there will be no final decisions for quite some time.'' Besharov said that in the short term the administration believes that ``what is important is to improve the programs that are in place now.'' ``We had a major welfare reform bill passed just two years ago that is just now being implemented by the states,'' he said. ``It is very important that this be given a chance to do something.'' ``The president is just not coming forward and saying, `I have a new program that will solve all the problems.' Although that may disappoint people, that is probably the wisest thing to do at this stage,'' he said. However, Isabel V. Sawhill of the Urban Institute, an expert on poverty who also took part in the September meeting, said, ``It looks like they went through a lot of effort and came up with a mouse. I am frankly quite disappointed that they could not agree on an over-all strategy.'' ``There were a lot of good ideas put forward, both from people who were consulted externally and also generated internally within the administration, and I think it was a serious and worthy effort, but it seems to have fallen victim to some combination of ideology and budgetary pressures.'' Besharov said proposals from the administration that were considered included: having the government help residents of poor areas establish ``management corporations'' that would fight crime, improve schools and repair housing; allocating a larger proportion of federal aid to high-poverty areas; and providing financial subsidies to job contractors to steer people from high poverty areas to job openings.

DOC.HEAD: Oliver North Makes Fourth Grand Jury Appearance
DOC.TEXT: Former White House aide Oliver L. North made his fourth appearance today before a grand jury that is continuing to investigate the Iran-Contra affair. The retired Marine lieutenant colonel who served as a National Security Council staff officer during the Reagan administration testified behind closed doors at the U.S. Courthouse. The grand jury, which was empaneled in May, is being used by independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh to determine if other Reagan administration officials participated in efforts to deceive Congress about the sale of U.S. arms to Iran and the covert military assistance to the Nicaraguan Contras, sources say. North, who is appealing three Iran-Contra convictions, was accompanied by defense attorneys who waited in the hallway outside the grand jury room. The former White House aide, who coordinated a secret arms resupply operation for the rebels after Congress shut off U.S. aid, testified three times last month. The grand jury has also heard testimony from North's former boss, John M. Poindexter, who was sentenced last month to six months in prison for lying to Congress about the Iran-Contra affair. Poindexter, who is appealing his conviction, spent nearly six hours testifying before the grand jury last month and is expected to be called back for more questioning. The grand jury is also performing a final assessment of the roles of then-President Reagan and then-Vice President Bush in the Iran-Contra affair.

DOC.HEAD: Rocket Kicks Off Annual 9-Day Running of Bulls Fiesta
DOC.TEXT: Thousands roared as a rocket fired at midday Friday kicked off the annual weeklong running of the bulls fiesta made famous by author Ernest Hemingway. The traditional ``chupinazo'' rocket shot up from the balcony overlooking the jammed main square of this northern city, whose usual 200,000 population is estimated to have doubled for the fiesta. Dressed in the traditional all-white outfit outfit with red bandanna and sash, Councilwoman Elena Modrego shouted ``Viva San Fermin!'' in honor of the city's patron saint and the festival's namesake. The fiesta served as the setting for Hemingway's 1926 novel ``The Sun Also Rises'' and the book's success immediately began to draw thrill seekers from around the world. The fiesta revolves around the daily morning run of six bulls from a pen through cobblestoned streets for a half-mile to the city bull ring. Hundreds of people, mainly young men, test their mettle by running ahead of the bulls and the six steers that accompany them. The runs were to begin Saturday and go on every day at 8 a.m. through July 14. The bulls are killed in afternoon bullfights. The partying continues around the clock for the week after the rocket is fired, with natives and visitors drinking, dancing in streets and singing in honor of San Fermin. The festival began in 1324 but was halted at times because of plagues and wars, the last in 1936-39. Since 1591, bulls have gored 52 people to death. Thirteen runners have died since 1924, when Hemingway saw his first run, according to official records.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnamese Fisherman Finds Ancient Sunken Treasure
DOC.TEXT: A fisherman's net snagged a sunken wooden ship filled with 300-year-old porcelain pieces off Vietnam's Con Dao island, the official Vietnam News Agency reported Friday. The 31-year-old fisherman discovered the ship in water about 40 yards deep and about 125 miles southeast of Ho Chi Minh City, it said. It did not say when that happened. The report said the 1,719 articles aboard included table sets, flower vases, plates and pans worth millions of dollars. Archeologists have not yet identified the ship, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Record Price for German Painting
DOC.TEXT: A diptych by 16th century master Lucas Cranach fetched $8.6 million, a record for a German painting, Christie's auction house said Friday. The painting was purchased by an anonymous bidder who participated in the auction by telephone, Christie's said. The two panels bore portraits of two Electors of Saxony, 6-year-old John Frederick the Magnanimous and his father John the Steadfast. The diptych was part of a group of art works from a castle at Wildenstein in Switzerland. The previous high price for a German painting was $2.7 million for a winter landscape by Caspar David Freidrich, sold at Christie's Monaco in 1987. The previous high for a Cranach was $638,000 for a portrait of a girl, sold in New York in 1983, Christie's said.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Use More Firebombs Despite Tought Law
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators have hurled about 260,000 firebombs in the past year, injuring 383 policemen and destroying 32 vehicles, police said Friday. No comparable figures were given, but police said radical students, dissidents and other demonstrators used more firebombs despite a law that took effect July 7, 1989, to punish firebomb users. Of 1,001 people arrested for hurling firebombs since the law took effect, at least 32 were given sentences and imprisoned, police said. They said the others were released or were on trial. In South Korea, firebomb throwers can be sentenced to less than three years in prison. Government officials said firebomb users would be punished sternly to end violent demonstrations.
End of Washington Testing.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Reportedly Refuses to Take Doe to His Home Province
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with official in Washington denying that Doe asked to go to home province. Pickup 5th graf pvs, `Doe's remaining...'
DOC.TEXT: Liberian President Samuel Doe asked the United States to ferry him and 100 troops to his home region of Grand Gedeh, but the U.S. government has refused, diplomatic sources said today. Doe was believed to have about 3,000 loyal troops from his Krahn tribe in the area, 300 miles northeast of the capital. In Washington, a senior administration official denied that Doe had made any such request. The official, insisting on anonymity, said Doe suggested to U.S. diplomats in Monrovia earlier this week that he would like to stop off in his home region but made no formal request for U.S. help in getting there. The United States has offered to help Doe leave the country, and the U.S. envoys made it clear to him that the offer of transportation applies only to international travel, the official said. The question of U.S. transportation for troops loyal to Doe has not arisen, the official said. Transporting Doe and 100 soldiers to Grand Jeddah effectively would enable the president to launch his own campaign against the rebels. But the diplomatic sources in the Ivory Coast, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said the United States refused to help relocate Doe in the country. Doe's remaining forces in the capital, Monrovia, have been surounded by rebels. Charles Taylor, the leader of the rebel National Patriotic Front, said Doe must leave the country before he will accept a cease-fire. A senior rebel leader in the United States rejected a reported plan by six West African states to send a peacekeeping force to Liberia that would remain there until free elections could be held. Tom Woewiyu said from East Orange, N.J., ``Under no circumstances will the Patriotic Front allow troops of any kind to step on Liberian soil.'' ``If it was not necessary to impose a peacekeeping force on the murderous and cannibalistic regime of Doe, why is it necessary to impose it on us? It's being done under a camouflage of protecting tribesmen. The real intent ... is to keep the flames of popular revolt from spreading throughout Africa.'' Doe reportedly has set as a condition for his resignation assurances that his Krahn people will be protected against any revenge attacks by the National Patriotic Front, who draws its members from the Gio and Mano tribes. The 6-month-old guerrilla campaign to overthrow Doe has degenerated into a tribal war. Doe's forces killed hundreds of Gio and Mano civilians in an unsuccessful effort to halt the insurgents' advance. The rebels have been accused of killing Krahns and other civilians in revenge. Diplomatic sources in Freetown, Sierra Leone, in contact with Monrovia by radio, said the rebels were moving slowly and had not entered Monrovia from the surrounding suburbs. The diplomats said the city's streets remained deserted today except for bands of soldiers looting and robbing. Rebels have cut all roads into Monrovia and also have occupied the port. Since Monday morning all international telephone and telex lines into the city also have been cut. Foreign journalists in the city, sending their stories by radio telex, have reported widespread looting by government troops, operating under cover of a dusk-to-dawn curfew. Soldiers also have frequently robbed the few people who have risked going out on the city's streets. The president and his 500-man presidential guard were in the heavily fortified presidential mansion. The peacekeeping plan came from a six-nation mediation committee set up by the Economic Community of West African states. Representatives of the countries _ Nigeria, The Gambia, Mali, Togo, Sierra Leone and Guinea _ met in Freetown but adjourned today pending the expected arrival of a rebel delegation. Although Woewiyu criticized the plan for a peacekeeping force, he said he would go to Freetown. This, coupled with the rebels' inability to live up to their boast that they would take Monrovia within 12 hours of launching their attack, could mean they lacked the firepower to oust Doe from his stronghold. Woewiyu, repeating earlier statements, said the United States was responsible for the peacekeeping proposal. ``They are not convinced it will be to their benefit that (the) National Patriotic Front under Mr. Taylor takes control of the country,'' he said. A State Department official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said in Washington: ``It's not our role to assist Charles Taylor to come to power in Liberia. Our position is that there needs to be a political settlement to this conflict. We have tried to facilitate that by lending our support to various negotiation efforts.'' The State Department has said it has reservations about Taylor's commitment to democracy.
This is a test from AP communications End test. RLP

DOC.HEAD: Motorcycle Ride Puts Bride in Hospital
DOC.TEXT: A bride who got onto her husband's Harley Davidson while still wearing her wedding gown spent the night in a hospital after it got caught in the motorcycle's back wheel. Denise Hudson and her husband, Lee, planned to ride to Raleigh, N.C., for a Grateful Dead concert after getting married July Fourth at a park. But the train of Mrs. Hudson's full-length gown got caught and dragged her under the bike. Mrs. Hudson, 28, suffered a broken pelvis and a concussion. ``She's skinned and sore. It could have been worse,'' said Hudson, 30, who received minor cuts and bruises. Paramedics had to cut the cream-colored gown to pieces to free her. Mrs. Hudson will have to spend the next few days in Grand Strand General Hospital, and the next few weeks recovering from her injuries. ``We can always have another honeymoon,'' her husband said.

DOC.HEAD: Baby Born Quickly in Pop-Up Camper
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Andra is cq.
