DOC.TEXT: Andra Diane Brunson's birth in the middle of the night was so fast her dad didn't have time to switch on the lights _ in the family's pop-up camper. ``By the time my husband got from the head of the bed to the foot of the bed, the head was out,'' Carol Brunson said of early Wednesday's birth. Mrs. Brunson, her husband, Ronnie, and her four young sons were sleeping in the 16-foot camper behind a friend's house in San Marco about 4 a.m. Wednesday when she began having labor pains five to seven minutes apart. She woke her husband and said, ``The baby's really hurting.'' He told her to try to go back to sleep. When she woke him again about an hour later, the baby was ready to be born. Brunson, a roofer who moved his family to Jacksonville from Charleston, S.C., a few weeks ago, handled the entire delivery in the dark. ``As it turned out, I didn't have time to flip on the light,'' he said. Mother and daughter were doing fine at Baptist Medical Center.

DOC.HEAD: Neighbors Wonder if Missing Boa is Hungry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Alice is cq
DOC.TEXT: Alice, the 8-foot boa constrictor, hasn't been home since last weekend and neighbors are wondering _ is Alice getting hungry? Alice normally eats once a week and it's been that long since the male snake's last meal, a rat, said Deputy Police Chief Richard Faulkner. ``You know what it's going to do out there. It's going to grow,'' said Carole Stevens, whose cat is locked inside until Alice turns up. Alice got loose after a friend of its owner took it outside last Saturday, police said. The friend fell asleep and Alice slithered away. ``I saw these two people outside looking in my trees. I thought maybe they lost a bird,'' said Stevens, who lives near snake owner Linda Pyorala in the Country Cousin Mobile Home Village. When Stevens learned Alice was missing, she called police. Pyorala declined to comment about her missing boa.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana House Approves Lethal Injections For Condemned Killers
DOC.TEXT: The Louisiana House voted 86-3 Friday to change the state's method of executing killers from electrocution to injection. Louisiana has executed 19 inmates by electrocution since the 1976 U.S. Supreme Court ruling allowed states to resume use of the death penalty. The state Senate had already passed the bill but will vote on it again to concur in minor House amendments. The measure then goes to Gov. Buddy Roemer. One of the three opponents, state Rep. Peppi Bruneau, said he wasn't swayed by the argument that lethal injection is more humane that electrocution. ``Why should we be concerned about doing it in a quote-unquote humane manner?'' asked Bruneau.

LONDON (AP)_ Here is a transcript of President Bush's press conference at the conclusion of the two-day NATO summit.
President Bush: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher for hosting this splendid meeting. And I want to express my appreciation also to Manfred Woerner, not only for his kind remarks just now, but for his outstanding leadership in NATO, and in this alliance, which is at a turning point in its history. I'm pleased to announce that my colleagues and I have begun a major transformation of the North Atlantic Alliance, and we view it at a historic turning point. NATO has set a new path for peace. It's kept the peace for 40 years, and today charted a new course for stability and cooperation in Europe. We're, as you know, issuing a document, the London Declaration, and it makes specific proposals and established directions for the future in four key areas. First, the London Declaration transforms our relationship with old adversaries. To those governments who have confronted us in the Cold War, our alliance extends the hand of friendship. We reaffirm that we shall never be the first to use force against other states in Europe, and we propose a joint declaration between members of the alliance and member states of the Warsaw Pact, which other CSCE states could join in, in making a solemn commitment to non-aggression. We say to President Gorbachev, ``Come to NATO!'' We say to all the member states of the Warsaw Pacts, ``Come to NATO,'' and establish regular diplomatic liaison with the Alliance. And second, the London Declaration transforms the character of NATO's conventional defenses. We can start, and must start by finishing the current CFE talks this year, Once CFE is signed, we would begin follow-on negotiations to adopt additional measures, including measures to limit manpower in Europe. With this goal in mind, a commitment will be given when the CFE treaty is signed concerning the manpower levels of the armed forces of a united Germany. We will also seek in the '90s to achieve further far-reaching measures to limit the offensive capability of conventional armed forces. We'll charge our strategy for conventional defense. We agreed to move away from NATO's current strategy of forward defense to a reduced forward presence. We agreed, in addition, to make the principle of collective defense even more evident by organizing NATO troops into multinational corps. And third, the London Declaration transforms NATO's nuclear strategy. For 23 years we've had a nuclear strategy called ``flexible response,'' developed to meet a danger of sudden, overwhelming conventional attack. As that danger recedes, we've agreed to modify flexible response. Nuclear deterrence has given us an unprecedented period of peace, and it will remain fundamental to an unprecedented period of peace, and it will remain fundamental to our strategy. But by reducing its reliance on nuclear weapons, NATO in the new Europe will adopt a new strategy making its nuclear forces truly weapons of last resort. This new strategy will require different forces. We've decided that once negotiations begin on short-range nuclear forces, we are prepared to eliminate all NATO nuclear artillery shells from Europe in return for reciprocal action by the Soviet Union. We agreed that this review should report its conclusions as soon as possible. And fourth, the London Declaration transforms the Alliance's vision for the CSCE, and the structure for building a Europe whole and free. We know the CSCE process, bringing together North America and all of Europe, can provide a structure for Europe's continued political development. And that means new standards for free elections, the role of law, economic liberty, and environmental cooperation. And we agreed today on six initiatives to give life to CSCE's principles and realize its potential. As you can see, the London Declaration will bring fundamental change to every aspect of the Alliance's work. This is indeed a day of renewal for the Atlantic community. For more than 40 years we've looked for this day, a day when we have already moved beyond containment with unity on continent overcoming division. And now that day is here and all peoples from the Atlantic to the Urals, from the Baltic to the Adriatic can share in its promise. I'd be glad to take some questions. Helen? Q. Mr. President, with the end of the Cold War, the draw-down in forces, the eventual denuclearization of Europe, are you now ready to give some economic help, and with what other allies want, to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe so that they can get back on their feet, as we did in World War II _ with Germany and Japan? A. Well, We have given substantial help to certain countries in Eastern Europe. I have had a discussion, not here at NATO, but with Mr. Gorbachev and others at different times about support for the Soviet Union. We are most interested in helping them go forward with their reforms. But there was no decision taken certainly to send money to the Soviet Union. I have some big problems with that one. I think the American people do. But there are ways that we can assist in this transformation, in this reform that is taking place in the Soviet Union. Q. But you're not opposed to other countries giving it? A. No, if the Germans decide they want to do that, that's their business, but I have made very clear to those who have spoken to me about this at this juncture, we have some serious problems and I have not been under any false colors about that at all. Terry? Q. President Gorbachev has imposed a two-year deadline on himself and the communist leaders for reversing their country's economic tailspin. Does your reluctance to give the Soviets any financial aid complicate his chances fOr success in meeting that deadline? A. I hope not, because, as you know, not only have I spoken very fondly and enthusiastically about what he's trying to do in terms of reform, but I have spoken about him personally and about our interest in seeing him succeed. And he's got some extraordinarily difficult problems, but I don't think that our position on financial aid at this time should _ hopefully, it will not complicate his standing. He deserves support for this reform. Q. Do you view Western aid for the Soviet Union now as subsidy for its military regime? A. Well, I'll tell you, we've got some problems that I've been very frank with concerning the Soviets and one of them is a great percentage of their GNP going into the military; another is some regional problems that perhaps are unique to the United States, but things that concern me _ spending $5 billion a year in Cuba, for example, to sustain a totalitarian regime that is highly critical of the Soviet Union from time to time. So we have regional problems, we have some reform probvlems that should take place before financial support can be given, but perhaps there are ways that we can assist them as we go forward with credit or other matters before we go to direct government loans.

DOC.HEAD: Nude Man Demonstrates for Nature
DOC.TEXT: A man demonstrating at the State Capitol in support of nature did it au naturel. The naked demonstrator climbed atop a wall flanking the capitol steps and covered it with a red and blue banner proclaiming ``Nature's Forum.'' He sat there in the rain for 20 minutes Thursday, until state police arrived with a ladder. Then he descended peacefully. ``I thought it would be a good way to get people's attention,'' said David Hughes, 29, of Los Angeles. ``It's just time,'' Hughes said. ``Spiritually, people need to come together.'' His stunt didn't promote spiritual harmony with everyone. ``Mister, I don't know what you're trying to do, but defacing our state isn't the way,'' shouted Dustin Cox, 16, of Salem. ``I'm not sure it really makes a point,'' said Erin Rose of Salem. ``I think it's kind of silly when people try to draw attention to themselves.'' But Karl Bien, 41, of Cottage Grove, applauded the act. ``Anything you have to do to bring people's concern to the environment is great,'' Bien said. State Police Lt. Bob Smit said statutes against disorderly conduct and indecent exposure might apply against Hughes, who was taken to the Oregon State Hospital for up to five days of evaluation.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Christian Science Trial, 3rd Ld - Writethru, a0593,0800
DOC.HEAD: Christian Science Couple Gets Probation in Death of Son
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf to UPDATE with father's reaction; SUBS 8-9th grafs, bgng `After a...', with 4 grafs to CORRECT couple's current home town to Brentwood, N.Y., sted New York; add quote from Christian Science spokesman. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Medical experts...'.SUBS 13th graf, `Special Prosecutor...', to add quote from prosecutor.
DOC.TEXT: A couple were sentenced to 10 years' probation today for allowing their son to die while treating him with Christian Science healing methods rather than taking him to a doctor. David and Ginger Twitchell were ordered to take their surviving children for regular medical checkups as a part of their probationary sentence for manslaughter. ``We've always tried to obey the law ... and will try to obey the judge's instructions,'' Twitchell said after leaving the courtroom. ``We'll try to balance the law and the judge's instructions with our trust in God.'' Suffolk Superior Court Judge Sandra Hamlin rejected a prosecution request that the couple be automatically jailed if they violate any term of the probationary sentence. Instead, if there is a violation, a hearing would be held and punishment would be decided upon then. The Twitchells, both 34 and lifelong Christian Scientists, faced up to 20 years in prison. Hamlin had indicated Thursday, however, that she did not believe the couple should be behind bars for the 1986 death of their 2{-year-old son, Robyn. The couple were found guilty of manslaughter Wednesday; their lawyer has said they would appeal. Under terms of the probation, Hamlin said that American Medical Association standards should be followed for checkups of the Twitchells' three surviving sons and any children they might have in the future. If there was any sign of serious illness, they were to take their children to a doctor. The judge said she would continue jurisdiction of the case and wanted monthly probation reports. After a two-month trial, a jury found the Twitchells, former Boston residents now living in Brentwood, N.Y., guilty of involuntary manslaughter. The key issue in their trial is one continually debated by legal scholars: Where should the government draw the line on freedom of religion? Nathan Talbot, a spokesman for the Boston-based Christian Science Church, said today's sentencing was ``the state's effort to impose its own view.'' ``It's an effort to re-educate Christian Scientists into the state's view of what healing ought to be,'' he said. Medical experts applauded the verdict, saying it would protect children. ``No religion is going to be allowed to be a defense against abuse and neglect,'' said Dr. Michael Grodin, a pediatrician and medical ethicist at Boston University. ``The bottom line is we have to have standards for protecting children.'' But Laurence Tribe, a constitutional law expert at Harvard, said the decision reflects a ``fundamental unfairness'' because the Twitchells thought they were protected by a 1971 state law that exempted spiritual healing from child abuse statutes. The prosecution argued that the statute _ which states that children will not be considered neglected or abused when ``treated by spiritual means alone'' by an ``accredited practitioner'' _ did not exempt the couple from manslaughter laws. Special Prosecutor John Kiernan said the case was not an attack on religion, but sent the message that parents must protect their children. ``This is not a contest between medicine and religion, rather it is a marriage of the two,'' he said after the sentencing. The Twitchells were found to have caused Robyn's death by relying solely on Christian Science spiritual healing to treat his five-day illness. The boy died April 8, 1986. An autopsy showed he suffered from a bowel obstruction. Lyons, the defense attorney, said his planned appeal would be based on the judge's failure to consider or instruct the jury on the spiritual healing exemption and for allowing a ``mocking and sarcastic trial of Christian Science doctrine to occur.'' The Twitchells were not allowed to explain their beliefs to show the jury they acted reasonably in response to Robyn's symptoms, he said. The trial received national attention in part because it was held in Boston, the headquarters of the Christian Science Church. The church has long taught that sickness and disease can be healed by prayer alone. Church officials have said the verdict will not deter them from practicing their religion, and expressed hope it will be overturned on appeal. Since 1980, there have been seven prosecutions of Christian Science parents. Five have been convicted, one acquitted and one case was thrown out, according to child rights activist Rita Swan, a former Christian Scientist who actively seeks such prosecutions.

DOC.HEAD: Thieves Steal Ancient Jewelry From Louvre
DOC.TEXT: A dozen pieces of ancient Roman jewelry were stolen from the Louvre Museum, officials said Friday. It was the latest in a series of art thefts that has prompted an overhaul of security in Paris museums. The second- and third-century earrings, bracelets and necklaces were discovered missing Wednesday, the same day a Renoir was cut from its frame at the Louvre and two other works taken from two small museums. But the jewelry, found missing in an inventory check ordered after the Renoir theft, was removed long before, said Jacques Sallois, director of the Museums of France. ``The disappearance of these objects, which are not of great value and are often seen on the market, is certainly quite old,'' Sallois said. ``It is prior to that of the paintings.'' Shaken by thefts carried out in broad daylight, officials have announced a series of measures to tighten security at Paris museums. The Interior Ministry is assigning a special police unit to work with museum security personnel, systematic inventories are to be carried out, and five small museums have been closed indefinitely to individual visitors. ``We're not going to put a war machine behind each painting or object, but we're going to study procedures, types of behavior that can help us to tighten security,'' Sallois said. Louvre Director Michel Laclotte said the museum would shut at least four rooms. ``We're trying to study with architects ways to seal off certain spaces that are too open,'' he told reporters. ``In a palace like the Louvre, you can't just close doors.'' Officials estimated the worth of the stolen jewelry at about $910 and said that, above all, it had historic value. Experts said the stolen paintings, a landscape and two portraits, all small formats, were considered of limited market value. The most valuable of them, Renoir's ``Portrait of a Seated Woman,'' was estimated to be worth a few hundred thousand dollars at most, a relatively small sum today for a well-known artist's work. ``Works of great value are less negotiable,'' Laclotte noted. He declined to say whether there were suspicions the thefts were linked. Also stolen Wednesday were an 1816 landscape painting by Paul Huet from the Carnavalet Museum, and an 1870 portrait by Ernest Hebert from a museum named after the artist. Laclotte, speaking to reporters, denied that the four consecutive thefts amounted to a ``security crisis.'' He said the Louvre devotes $1.8 million of its annual budget to security and had the best in human and electronic sciences at its disposal. But he said museums cannot become impregnable bastions. ``All security measures are at the detriment of the art works,'' Laclotte said. ``Banditry is there. It is international.'' At least a dozen works have been stolen from French museums over the past year.

Here are quotes from leaders at the NATO summit that ended Friday.
President Bush, addressing the NATO leaders' decision to use nuclear weapons only as a last resort: ``I'm pleased to announce that my colleagues and I have begun a major transformation of the North Atlantic Alliance, and we view it at a historic turning point. NATO has set a new path for peace. It's kept the peace for 40 years, and today charted a new course for stability and cooperation in Europe.''
Bush: ``Our alliance extends the hand of friendship ... We reaffirm that we shall never be the first to use force ... NATO is changing.''
Bush, discussing the NATO leaders invitation to Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to visit NATO: ``We say to (Soviet) President Gorbachev, come to NATO.''
In response to the invitation, Gorbachev said in Moscow: ``I am always ready to go.''
Bush, discussing his reluctance to give direct economic aid to the Soviet Union: ``'ll tell you, we've got some problems that I've been very frank with concerning the Soviets and one of them is a great percentage of their GNP going into the military.''
The NATO leaders' communique: ``The walls that once confined people and ideas are collapsing ... Europeans are determining their own destiny ... They are choosing a Europe whole and free.''
British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher: ``NATO has defended peace with freedom and justice but it has never threatened anyone.'' ``The cornerstone of that sure defense must remain, for we do not know what the future holds, but its architecture may change in the new situation.''
A British official, quoting Mrs. Thatcher who has expressed reservations about disarming NATO too quickly: ``To remind people of this might put me in danger of being called a Cold War warrior.''
French President Francois Mitterrand, expressing reluctance to eliminate his country's nuclear arsenal immediately: ``When others have disarmed, those countries with enormous superiority with regard to weaponry, then we will. It is as simple as that.''
NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner: ``At long last we have the chance to make for the first time in history military aggression in Europe materially impossible and also politically meaningless.''

DOC.HEAD: It Took FBI Hour and A Half To Find Crack Pipe
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Combines pvs; edits to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The FBI had to search frantically to find the crack pipe and overlooked some of the cocaine used in the videotaped sting against Marion Barry, an FBI agent testified today at the mayor's drug and perjury trial. FBI agent Frank O. Steele said he found the crack pipe an hour and a half after Barry's arrest at the Vista Hotel on the night of Jan. 18. It was stuck inside an eyeglasses case that former model Rasheeda Moore had put in a dresser drawer. A second crack pipe was found in the glasses case as well. Both devices had been supplied by the FBI to Moore for the sting operation. Steele's testimony came on cross-examination by lawyers for Barry. The defense replayed segments of the FBI videotape to suggest ineptitude by the bureau. Steele also testified that he checked Barry's coat pockets for the pipe the night of the arrest. A week later, an FBI evidence technician found crack cocaine from the sting in a pocket of the mayor's coat. Steele said he had overlooked the pocket. It was a small slit pocket on the inside of the garment. Seconds after Barry was arrested, a law enforcement officer agent opened the dresser drawer containing the eyeglasses case, but closed it again without checking, the FBI videotape of the sting showed. Barry's lawyers replayed the section of the tape showing the agent opening the drawer, apparently searching for the pipe. Earlier in the day, the trial judge said Nation of Islam Minister Louis Farrakhan and Imani Temple Bishop George Stallings will be permitted to attend the trial as long as they ``observe the proprieties of the court.'' Last week, U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson refused to allow the two in as spectators, saying their presence would be potentially disruptive and was likely to be intimidating. He reversed himself after a court of appeals said spectators cannot be barred merely because they advocate a particular political or religious point of view. Farrakhan and Stallings sought to attend the trial on passes given to Barry. Stallings broke away from the Washington Archdiocese of the Roman Catholic Church a year ago, calling it hopelessly racist. He was later excommunicated and founded Imani Temple. Farrakhan has ``never been a disruptive force,'' said Chicago attorney Louis Myers, general counsel to the Nation of Islam. ``I felt that was insulting,'' Myers told the judge, referring to Jackson's comment last week about disruption and intimidation. American Civil Liberties Union attorney Arthur Spitzer renewed a motion for Jackson to vacate his orders of last week relating to Farrakhan and Stallings. The judge did so without hearing any arguments. ``I am prepared to grant the relief,'' said Jackson. Spitzer and Myers assured the judge that Stallings and Farrakhan would observe court decorum. ``The judge tried to establish that you can't walk into the middle of a public trial and disrupt it,'' said John Aldock, a private attorney representing the judge in the matter. ``We want to send a signal to any court of law, any other judge in America who desires to do something similar ... we will beat them,'' said Myers. The appeals court refused to order that Farrakhan and Stallings be admitted, sending the matter back to Jackson to hear arguments from the two black leaders. Barry is accused of 10 counts of cocaine possession and one count of conspiracy. He also is on trial on three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his alleged involvement with drugs.

DOC.HEAD: California Intensifies Effort to Control Problem Flies
DOC.TEXT: A war on a bothersome insect called the ash whitefly is being broadened with squadrons of tiny, stingless wasps from the Mediterranean. The flies have no natural enemies in California and are a nuisance to residents and a potential threat to the agriculture industry, the state Department of Food and Agriculture said. They were first detected in California in August 1988 in Los Angeles County and have since been spotted in 17 counties and as far north as Sacramento. The tiny insects suck out plant juices, infesting a variety of trees and shrubs including apple, apricot, citrus and pear. They can defoliate trees and clouds of the insects have driven residents from their back yards. Now tiny Encarsia wasps, imported from Israel and Italy, are being released and will be monitored to see how well they control the ash whiteflies. The wasp controls the ash whitefly population by laying its eggs inside fly larvae. After the wasps' eggs hatch, they eat their way out of the larvae, killing the pest. Pesticides are not considered practical for use against the whitefly because the pest's numbers are so large and it dwells on the undersides of leaves. Six southern California counties have been targeted for widespread release of the wasps, said Peter Stoddard, senior environmental research scientist with the state Department of Food and Agriculture. Additional counties will get the wasps later this summer. One of the initial sites chosen for release of the wasps was the Fullerton Arboretum on the edge of the California State University, Fullerton campus, just southeast of Los Angeles. Hundreds of wasps were released there Thursday. Wasps for future release are being reproduced at the University of California, Riverside, and the rate of reproduction will determine how quickly other sites will receive them, Stoddard said. A tiny ladybird beetle imported last year from Israel also is being studied as a possible weapon against the fly. California also is waging a battle against the Mediterranean fruit fly, using the pesticide malathion.

DOC.TEXT: A. Yes. And then I'll be over, Brit. Q. Mr. President, with the threat receding the way your communique describes, do you think it's inevitable that at some point in the next few years the Europeans will decide it's better that American troops just go home? And what can you say to American taxpayers to convince them that it's worth continuing to pay the bill to have them in Europe.? A. Well, I don't think the American troops will stay against the will of the host country. I don't want to see American forces deployed where American forces are not wanted. I don't want to see Soviet forces deployed where Soviet forces are not wanted. And I expect the same would be true of other nationalities' forces as well. But I don't foresee that day, because I think the Alliance has spoken rather eloquently about the need for a common defense and all the members of the Alliance are united in their view that a US force presence is stabilizing and very, very important. So I don't see that day looming up on the horizon. Q. But do you fear that American taxpayers support for that continuation might be eroding? A. Well, I see some attacks on this and I think this NATO declaration should help in that regard, but I view it as my responsibility to make clear to the American taxpayer why it is in our interest to help keep the peace. And that's exactly what these forces are engaged in. Yeah, Brit. And then we'll go _ Q. Mr. President, in light of the stress that's been placed here on the continued cohesion within this Alliance, sir, would it not be a major breach of that cohesion if a country like West Germany were to provide direct aid to the Soviet union in light of the deep concerns which you have expressed about such aid from the West? A. No, I don't feel that's _ (to another member of the press.) Excuse me. I'll be back. I don't feel that that's a breach of Alliance cohesion. The Germans have their own bilateral relationship with the Soviet Union and it doesn't concern me one bit. I've not made one single effort to try to have the Germans look differently at that question. Q. Mr. President, would it not than be possible that aid from our ally, West Germany, would at least arguably or indirectly flow to a country like Cuba? A. Well, if you want to say that anything that goes to the Soviet Union facilitates aid to Cuba, I suppose we could say the same about our trade. But that isn't _ I don't think that would be a fair charge to make against the Germans. Yes? Yes, John. Excuse me. Q. Tonight, in an interview to be broadcast in the united States, Fang Lizhi, the recently released Chinese dissident, says you owe him a dinner. He couldn't make it to the one you threw in Beijing, and he would like to be invited to the White House for dinner. Would you do that? and I have a follow up. A. Well, he's _ he is here in this country. I thought he wanted to stay out of the public eye. I thought he himself said so, so you've got a little different information than that. We'll just defer the rest of your question. Go ahead, what's your follow up? Q. If I can follow up, if you do meet him, he is going to complain that you have a double standard for human rights, that you have one standard for the Soviet Union, where you complain about human rights violations, or have in the past _ at least, pre-Gorbachev _ and that you don't complain so much about human rights violations, you're not as tough with the Chinese. He complains about sending Brent Scowcroft and Larry Eagleburger, at cetera. What would you say to him? A. I'd say that he's wrong. He's got a little time warp here, because we spoke out at the NATO meeting; indeed, I think we took the lead at the last _ at a meeting in Europe _ I guess it was the G-7 meeting, not NATO _ where we took the lead in expressing our joint indignation in terms of the abuses of human rights at Tiananmen Square. We've kept certain sanctions on China. I am heartened that Fang Lizhi is free, and free now to say what's on his mind like this. So I would _ I would say that if he feels that way, he's simply not expressing the facts as they are. I don't agree with that. I notice some of my critics in the United States Congress say that, and I think they are just as wrong as they can be. Yes, Lesley? Q. Mr. President _ Whoops _ back to the declaration. You are inviting the Warsaw Pact countries to come to NATO as observers. What if they want to become members of NATO _ Hungary, for instance, or even Poland? Are you saying, by inviting them to ``just be observers,'' that you do not look favorably on them becoming full members? A. I am saying NATO views this as an open invitation, and who knows what will happen in terms of membership down the line. That's not in the cards right this minute. We are just coming out of a adversarial environment, varying _ I think there is varying degrees of enthusiasm for what you are talking about amongst the members of the Warsaw Pact at this juncture, so I'd say it's premature. Q. Well, would you oppose _ would you oppose any country, for instance, Hungary, becoming a member of NATO? A. Not forever. But at this juncture, I support the NATO doctrine. Q. Mr. President, in your communique, you talk about nuclear weapons becoming truly weapons of last resort. You say the fundamental strategy of the Alliance is being transformed there. As part of this review, are considering going back home and taking another look at some of the strategic nuclear modernization programs that you have supported, looking at some of the very expensive weapons programs that some say should be a bonus, a part of the peace dividend? A. Not as a result of anything that's transpired here in NATO, no. We are interested in strategic arms agreements with the Soviets. The Soviets, as we all know, have indeed modernized their forces. We are on the horns of a dilemma in that question, you might say, because we have not to the degree they have. But that was not a consideration here at NATO, nor has anything transpired here that will make me go home with a different approach to strategic arms. Q. Will you proceed _ if I may follow up, sir, you'll proceed across the board with strategic modernization, your commitment to that? A. I will proceed _ yeah, I will proceed in negotiating with the Soviet _ Soviets to achieve a strategic arms agreement. Yes, sir? Q. Mr. President, how much did the threats to perestroika and reforms in the Soviet Union play in the changes you've announced today in NATO? A. You mean, is what's going on at the Congress? None, in my view. I mean, I think this _ I think what's contributed to the NATO _ the changes in our approach, NATO, are the changes that have taken place, particularly since our last meeting, in terms of Eastern Europe and in terms of the Soviets' willingness to withdraw forces, hopefully through a CFE agreement. So, I don't think that _ I don't think anything was short _ that there was short-term thinking as a result of the debates that are going on in Moscow this very day. Q. Well, If I could follow up then, what kind of message do the changes announced today send to Gorbachev?
