DOC.HEAD: Police Begin Homeless Crackdown; Five Arrested
With PM-Mitch Snyder, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with arrest total put at five. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `The march...'. Jack Howard, woman, is cq in 14th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested five people this morning as the city began enforcing a ban on sleeping in parks in an effort to empty a downtown plaza where more than 200 people have camped out for two years. Authorities said Keith McHenry, an activist who is one of the most vocal critics of the homeless removal plan, was arrested before 6 a.m. after about 20 officers began clearing the tree-shaded Civic Center plaza. Four other people, all unidentified, were arrested later. Police encountered no violence, Sgt. John Goldberg said. As an alternative to arrest for violating the public sleeping ban, police offered vouchers for admittance to two new city shelters. Thursday evening, a group of 50 activists and homeless people at the Civic Center decided to accept the city's offer. The group noisily marched seven blocks to one of two new shelters, where a worker told them all the rooms were filled. City officials said the homeless could obtain vouchers for free shelter elsewhere, but the group returned to the plaza _ a park surrounded by mostly government buildings. ``There's no room,'' said a homeless woman, Lima Rashida. ``We have no place to go but back to the Civic Center.'' Police had been under orders to begin making arrests at midnight, but after the homeless marchers were faced with no shelter space, officers on the scene did not immediately intervene. Of the five people arrested later in the morning, three were booked on misdemeanor counts of illegal lodging and interfering with police, and McHenry and one other person was cited with illegal distribution of food, police said. The march came after a peaceful candlelight vigil mourning the death of Mitch Snyder, a homeless activist in Washington, D.C., who was found hanged Thursday in what police said was an apparent suicide. The homeless people in the plaza said they paid for a red, white and blue wreath by selling jewelry and other personal items. Police Capt. Dennis Martel said the plaza transients ``don't have the option to stay here anymore. We are encouraging them to go to the shelters. We're handling this in a sensible, humane fashion.'' All this week, vouchers for rooms have been handed out, but many of those living in the park expressed no interest. ``I'm safer in this park than in one of those `hotline' rooms,'' said a woman who identified herself as Jack Howard. She pledged to stay in the plaza until police begin moving the homeless out. The ``hotline'' rooms are hotel rooms the city has available. Howard says occupants are often bothered by crack dealers, rats and mice. As a woman, Howard does not have access to the two male-only ``multi-service shelters'' the city took over this week. The shelters, operated for the city by church groups, combine shelter with such services as drug and alcohol treatment and job counseling. ``We have to have compassion because a lot of these people have had a lot of misfortune in their lives,'' said police officer Harry Soulette as he walked around the plaza. ``We want to help them.'' Being turned away from the shelter reinforced what homeless activists have said since the plan was revealed by Mayor Art Agnos _ that the city simply doesn't have enough beds. Homeless advocates also charge that the ``cleanup'' program forced 215 people already staying in one of the two shelters out on the streets to make way for the displaced Civic Center homeless. In protest, the Coalition on Homelessness said it plans to ``flood the system,'' bringing in homeless people from other areas to the Civic Center to overwhelm the new shelters, said a group leader, Josh Brandon. The city's plan unfairly targets the homeless at the Civic Center, while others throughout the city desire shelter as well, he said. ``We simply want to give people who want to get off the streets the opportunity to get off the streets,'' Brandon said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Steps Down from School Desegregation Case
DOC.TEXT: The federal judge who presided over court-mandated efforts to desegregate Pulaski County public schools for eight years stepped down Friday. In an order in which he announced his decision to leave the case, U.S. District Judge Henry Woods lamented the plight of black students in the county and criticized the federal appeals court for stifling his orders. Woods, 72, said he was leaving because he was unable to successfully implement a plan to bring educational equity to the children of the county under the restrictions imposed by the appeals court. ``Perhaps the application of a fresh mind and the perspective of another judge can find hope in a situation which I perceive as hopeless,'' he said. Woods will continue to hear his full slate of cases. ``It has been my intention to oversee a progressive educational plan to serve the children of these districts into the 21st century. Such a plan would bring peace to a community long plagued with a worldwide reputation for racial problems in its public schools,'' Woods said. ``However, I have steadfastly resisted the notion of peace-at-any-price.'' Woods' decision follows a ruling Monday by a three-judge panel of the 8th U.S. Circuit of Appeals ordering the release of portions of the $129 million settlement of the state's liability in the case. Woods presided over the case involving a federal suit filed in 1982 by the Little Rock School District against the Pulaski County and North Little Rock districts, and the state Department of Education. The Little Rock district sought consolidation with the other districts in the county to achieve racial balance. Woods criticized Monday's order, noting that the three Pulaski County districts have maintained that they are not required to spend the money solely for desegregation purposes. He said the districts will have received and spent ``tens of millions of dollars'' by the time the full order of the court is issued in the fall. ``The district court will be left ... trying to implement a long-term desegregation plan, yet to be announced, with insufficient funds remaining to implement any meaningful plan,'' he said. The appeals court this week also hinted it would limit the metropolitan supervisor's post _ the office Woods set up to direct the districts' desegregation efforts _ to merely monitoring those efforts.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-NATO Summit Rdp Bjt
Groups Demonstrate for Summit Audience
DOC.TEXT: Pick an issue, and there will a demonstration to match it during the economic summit. AIDS. Racial issues. Abortion. Trade. Summits are magnets for demonstrators, and at least five groups have obtained parade permits. Another 17 have registered for rallies. State and local law enforcement has been strengthened to monitor the demonstrators. Police officers will work 12-hour shifts. The Ku Klux Klan says it has organized 200 to 300 members for a march and rally on Saturday that ends at a statue of Sam Houston in Hermann Park. ``We're sending a message that the white racist movement is alive and well and is growing throughout America,'' said Texas Grand Dragon Charles Lee. ``We think Bush and his cronies have betrayed the American people with the open border policy and by letting taxpayers' money go outside the country.'' The Human RACE _ Racial Acceptance Class Equality _ planned a ``Human Summit'' on the steps of the City Hall as a counter-demonstration to the KKK event. The KKK members will be bused from the suburb of Humble at Houston expense, a decision that has infuriated some. Officials from Cure AIDS Now, a health care advocacy group for people suffering from acquired immune deficiency syndrome, oppose city financing of the KKK rally. ``The Klan has a right to march and make a statement, but the city should not be providing a $50,000 bus ride for the group under the guise of security,'' Cure AIDS Now executive director Bob Kunst said. ``That money should be used to keep people alive with a Meals on Wheels program for people with AIDS.'' Kunst said his organization has set up a week's worth of activities, including a parade and all-day rally and downtown street dance on Sunday. Another AIDS advocacy group, ACT UP, plans a more vocal counter-demonstration to the KKK at a Saturday rally. ACT UP, which caused a stir at an AIDS convention in San Francisco last month, also plans to ``zap'' a Catholic cathedral; protest several pro-life activities; demonstrate at the arrivals of Bush and the other world leaders; and ``zap'' the summit's closing gala at the Wortham Center for the Performing Arts. In real Texas style, country singer Willie Nelson is spearheading a cattle drive to dramatize opposition to proposed changes in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. ``This whole administration is a big corporate-minded administration,and they're not that concerned about the small family farmer, whether he's American or Japanese,'' Nelson said. Environmental groups plan the Envirosummit starting Saturday with guided tours of Houston's environmental sites. Clean Water Action, one of the groups, plans a ``Bush's Boston Harbor'' tour of the Houston Ship Channel on Sunday, featuring the environmental hazards posed by refineries and other industrialists fronting the channel. Then there was the broccoli summit Friday morning near the Rice University campus that will be home to the world leaders. Broccoli growers donated 40 tons of broccoli to local food banks in a continued jab at President Bush, who turned his personal dislike of the vegetable into a minor cause celebre last spring.

DOC.HEAD: Court Awards Brezhnev's Daughter Mercedes, Dacha and Cash
DOC.TEXT: A court awarded the flamboyant daughter of former Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev a luxury car, country house and thousands of dollars in cash and collections that were confiscated from her husband, a newspaper said Friday. The court said the cash and valuables rightly belonged to Galina Brezhnev and not to her husband, Yuri D. Churbanov, who was convicted in December 1988 of accepting bribes. He was sentenced to 12 years in a labor camp and had his property confiscated. Ms. Brezhnev herself has been accused in Soviet news accounts of speculating in diamonds and has been linked to a bribery scandal involving a gypsy performer in the Moscow circus. She often was seen driving the Mercedes car of her father, who died in 1982, through the streets of Moscow. ``The case was banal,'' the Komsomolskaya Pravda newspaper quoted the Moscow district judge as saying. ``There were no telephone calls or threats, nothing that could sway the trial.'' ``If it were not for the loud name of the plaintiff, I wouldn't even remember the case,'' he was quoted as saying. ``Under the law, Galina Brezhnev was within her rights, since most of the property belonged to her and not her husband, and the Supreme Court had no right after sentencing Yuri Churbanov to confiscate it.'' The newspaper did not identify the judge. It said the court had ordered the government to return a country house worth $108,474, a Mercedes car given to her father by an unidentified foreign government, furniture and chandeliers, a collection of weapons worth $200,000, stuffed and mounted animals valued at $137,011 and $111,000 in savings. Churbanov was fired from his job as first deputy interior minister in 1984 and tried in 1988. He was widely believed to have been given the job because of his marriage to Brezhnev's daughter. Brezhnev ruled the Soviet Union from 1964 until his death, and now is widely blamed for allowing the country to slide into stagnation.

DOC.HEAD: Communist North Korea Offers to Open Small Stretch of Border
DOC.TEXT: Communist North Korea on Friday offered to open a small stretch of its border to promote unification with South Korea, but its capitalist rival dismissed the gesture as insignificant. The Communist overture came as the prime ministers of the two nations prepared to hold historic talks, perhaps as early as August. North Korea announced it would open the northern sector of Panmunjom, a border village, on Aug. 15, according to Naewoe Press, a semi-official South Korean news agency that specializes in Communist affairs. North Korea said the opening, about 800 yards long and 500 yards wide, was aimed at promoting unification of the Korean peninsula and urged South Korea to do the same, according to Naewoe. ``For successful progress of contact and visits between the north and the south, we will open the portion of our side ... and hope that the south side will take a corresponding measure,'' the agency quoted the Communist government as saying. The opening, however, would not permit foreigners to travel inland, past the perimeter of Panmunjom, a truce village that straddles part of the 155-mile border between the two Koreas. The village is jointly controlled by North Korea and a United Nations Command, comprising the United States and 15 other countries that fought with South Korea in the 1950-53 Korean War. No civilians may enter the area from either side without approval. South Korea's Defense Ministry said it had not been officially notified of the north's plans and would not comment on whether anyone would be allowed to cross the border. But a government spokesman said on condition of anonymity that North Korea's move was ``insignificant'' because it affected only a small, restricted section of the heavily fortified border. Other officials said the move was aimed at dividing opinions in South Korea, where dissidents are pushing for free contacts with their Communist neighbors. The South Korean opposition welcomed the announcement. Dissidents asked Seoul to allow 300 people to meet with North Koreans at the border village Aug. 15, the day in 1945 that Korea was freed from Japanese colonial rule. But a spokesman for South Korea's umbrella dissident group, Chonminyon, said the Seoul response had been negative. The South Korean government bans unauthorized border talks with North Korea. After a five-month suspension, South Korean and North Korean officials have been meeting to discuss an accord that would outline terms for the first talks between their prime ministers. On Tuesday, the Koreas agreed in principle to hold the prime ministers' meeting, possibly in August in Seoul. They agreed to adopt a formal accord July 26. Talks have been held sporadically between the two Koreas, but little progress had been made until recently. The border on both sides is heavily fortified and sealed, blocking exchanges of mail and transportation. North Korea is one of the last totalitarian Communist states, and sweeping changes in Eastern Europe and its socialist allies have made little impact. The two Koreas are still technically at war. No peace treaty has been signed since the three-year Korean War ended in 1953.

DOC.HEAD: Government Group Suggests Charging Calif. Motorists in War Against Smog
DOC.TEXT: Motorists in Southern California who run errands or commute alone during rush hour should be penalized financially, a smog-reduction task force recommended. ``Over 70 percent of our air pollution problem is caused by mobile sources,'' said Judy Wright, who led the group set up by the Southern California Association of Governments. ``There aren't many more smokestacks to go after, so we have to go after the mobile sources.'' Wright suggested that one way to penalize motorists would be through extra fees on a toll road or bridge if the driver is alone in the car. Stickers would show whether a vehicle was authorized to be on the road during specific hours. The driver could be fined if found driving during unauthorized times, she said. The task force suggested test projects in western San Bernardino County, which has many homes and relatively few jobs, and in Los Angeles County's South Bay area, which has lots of jobs, but few homes. Both areas are besieged by commuter traffic. The association set up the task force last year after another agency, the South Coast Air Quality Management District, issued a long-term plan for cutting smog. The recommendations won't go into effect for at least a year and perhaps longer, said association spokesman Mario Guerra. ``We probably won't see a lot happening for a while, but the proposals are important because they recognize that driving is a right, not a responsibility, and people need to realize that,'' Guerra said.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Drops Slightly to 5.2 Percent in June
DOC.TEXT: The nation's unemployment rate edged downward to 5.2 percent last month despite an ongoing slide in manufacturing and overall weakness in job growth, the government reported Friday. Fewer Americans looking for work _ not any rebound in sluggish economic activity _ accounted for the improvement over May's jobless rate of 5.3 percent, analysts said. ``It's not that more people are getting jobs, fewer guys are looking,'' said Elliott Platt, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. of New York. The economy added just 40,000 jobs to non-farm payrolls in June, the Labor Department said. However, that figure would be closer to 97,000 if the temporary census workers the federal government laid off in June were not included in the count, the agency said. For the first six months of 1990, private sector businesses have been adding about 110,000 jobs a month, or about half the 220,000 average jobs gain for the same period last year, the government said. ``There's no real zip in this economy, but you don't have the combination of recessionary forces to drag it into negative territory, either,'' Platt said. The report's evidence of continued softness, at a time when unemployment is still relatively low, provides a puzzling picture for the Federal Reserve, which has been under pressure to lower interest rates, analysts said. ``The Fed is in a quandary now. From the job creation side, it's a clear case for the Fed to ease. But with unemployment so low, it's a very tough call,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. Sinai said June's job growth figures demonstrate that the economy is ``as close to a recession configuration as we can get without being in one.'' Revised figures for May showed that about 155,000 new jobs were added that month, excluding census workers, up from the original report of just 19,000 jobs, the Labor Department said. Unemployment has been fluctuating within a tenth of a percentage point of 5.3 percent for more than a year after hitting a 15-year low of 5 percent in March 1989. The rate has managed to stay relatively low, despite weak job growth, because smaller numbers of Americans are entering the labor force, said Janet Norwood, commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. So far this year, only about 290,000 Americans have entered the work force, compared with the 1.5 million Americans who joined the labor force during the first half of 1989, Mrs. Norwood said. The labor force is defined as Americans who are working or actively seeking jobs. The nation's manufacturing sector, which has been on a downward spiral for months, continued its slide in June as factory payrolls fell by 31,000 jobs. It was the 14th time in 15 months that manufacturing jobs declined. Since reaching a post-recession peak in March 1989, about 335,000 factory jobs have been lost. The number of construction jobs fell in June for the fourth month in a row, reflecting continued weakness in the housing market, the government said. Construction payrolls, after seasonal adjustment, dropped 14,000. Meanwhile, the service sector, which has been providing most of the economy's steam over the past several months, added 83,000 jobs, including 40,000 in the health services industry. Retail trade businesses lost 7,000 jobs in June, bringing the monthly increases in the first half of this year in that sector to 15,000, half the average for 1989. General merchandise stores have been particularly hard hit in that sector, losing 50,000 jobs over the past year, Mrs. Norwood said. The number of discouraged workers _ people who want a job but have given up looking _ averaged about 900,000 for the April to May period, an increase of nearly 150,000 over the first quarter of 1990, the agency said. That increase brought the number of discouraged workers to its highest level since the end of 1988. Labor costs, which have been pushing up and are being blamed for fueling the nation's inflation problems, continued to increase. Average hourly earnings posted a 0.3 percent rise in June to $10.01, up from the $9.98 the average worker earned per hour in May. The average manufacturing work week was unchanged from May at 41.0 hours. Manufacturing overtime held at 3.8 hours in June. In a separate calculation of unemployment that counts members of the armed services stationed in the United States, the June jobless rate was 5.1 percent, down from 5.3 percent in May and the same as June's civilian rate.

DOC.HEAD: Top Dog for the Underdog, Mad Dog to the Establishment
With AM-Snyder Suicide, Bjt
An AP News Essay
DOC.TEXT: Like the grubby beggars on the streets thrusting out their plastic coffee cups, Mitch Snyder was a goad. Unlike them, he would not be brushed aside. He made the destitute of this city visible. He got a roof over their heads. He could be a nuisance. He could exasperate the city and the citizenry. He drove critics and allies to distraction by an insistent demand that the homeless be accorded the respect due humankind. Now that he is dead, it dawned on Washington _ Washington the community, not Washington the world capital _ what he meant to this city. The dispossessed will have to fend for themselves. And so will the possessed. The goad is gone. It will be up to people to see the helpless poor without him. By common estimate, 15,000 homeless people live on the streets and grates of Washington. One of Snyder's triumphs was the enactment of a 1984 law _ by the citizens, in an initiative, over the objections of officialdom _ compelling the city to guarantee them an indoor place to spend the night. Of that number, 1,200 found a spot in the shelter that Snyder, in his guerrilla warfare, wrestled from Ronald Reagan in 1984. He did that by fasting for 51 days. Snyder looked then like he was nearly dead. CBS cameras were about to capture the showdown for ``60 Minutes.'' The presidential election was two days off. Reagan capitulated and gave Snyder's outfit, the Community for Creative Non-Violence, a tumbledown federal building a few blocks from the Capitol for use as a shelter and $6 million to rehabilitate it. Rep. E. Clay Shaw, R-Fla., didn't like the show boating. He called Snyder ``a masochist who influences government by threatening to starve himself.'' Snyder had a genius for attracting attention. But no one ever accused him of capitalizing on the poor. He hobnobbed with celebrities, coming to their parties in the wrinkled clothes given to the shelter. He always needed a shave. He held public funerals for homeless people who died on the streets in the cold. He scavenged through dumpsters with members of Congress. Once, he got movie stars to spend a night sleeping on the street. He got Cher to dish out the mashed potatoes at Christmas dinner at the shelter. He got the Navy to alter plans to name a new nuclear submarine Corpus Christi, after the city in Texas. He said no warship should bear the name ``the body of Christ,'' and the Navy changed it to the USS City of Corpus Christi. That fast lasted only 11 days. But angry, scornful, confrontational Mitch Snyder had failures, too. He walked out of a middle-class marriage, leaving behind in New York City two small children and forcing his wife onto welfare. He said he could not spend his life selling Electrolux vacuum cleaners and Maytag washing machines. Eleven days ago, Snyder suffered his greatest defeat. He could not keep the city council from voting to gut the homeless shelter law or slashing spending on the destitute. The change, awaiting Mayor Marion Barry's signature, would require homeless people to go though a screening process before being approved for shelter. Washington has accustomed itself to the sight of people sleeping on the streets. The outrage and passion have diminished. There were suggestions that difficulties with Carol Fennelly, Snyder's companion for 15 years, led him to take his life. In his room at the shelter where he hanged himself, Snyder left behind a note discussing his failed love relationship with Ms. Fennelly, police sources said. He was 46. Maybe he was a victim of that disease of the upwardly mobile: burnout. He had been at it for 17 years.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Governor Vetoes Abortion Bill, But Holds Off Sending Veto Message
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Buddy Roemer kept his word today and vetoed a tough anti-abortion bill but held off delivering his veto message to the Legislature, an administration attorney said. Roemer can hold on to the veto message for two days after signing it, said John Kennedy, a special counsel to the governor. If the legislators don't get the veto message until Sunday, they would have only the rest of the day Sunday and all day Monday to consider it before they must adjourn for the year at midnight Monday. ``We're not ready to deliver the message just yet,'' said Kennedy. Throughout the legislative session that began in April, Roemer had said he would veto an abortion bill that didn't make exceptions for victims of rape or incest. The bill eventually passed by the legislature contained no such exceptions, and would send abortionists to prison for up to 10 years. It allows abortions only to save the life of the mother. Roemer's decision not to immediately issue the veto message left open the question of when anti-abortion supporters would be able to attempt an override. House and Senate leaders were waiting for the veto message to schedule debates on an override attempt. It takes a two-thirds vote in each chamber _ 26 of 39 senators and 70 of 105 representatives _ to override a veto. No Louisiana governor's veto has been overridden this century. Rep. Woody Jenkins, a key backer of the bill, had said Thursday that he planned to ask the House to debate and vote on an override on Saturday, assuming the veto message was received in time to do so. Should the House vote to override Saturday, Jenkins had said, he would then want the Senate to take up the issue Sunday or Monday. Roemer has said during the past week that he would give lawmakers ample time to consider and vote on an override.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Warns that Party Faces Confiscation of Property, Prosecution
LaserPhoto MOSB4
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin warned Communist Party traditionalists Friday that the price of their intransigence will be nationalization of party property and demands that they stand trial for ruining Soviet society. Yeltsin brought the wave of public indignation that propelled him to the presidency of the huge Russian republic to the fifth day of the 28th Communist Party congress at the Kremlin's Palace of Congresses. Reformers got their chance to fight back against the Communist traditionalists who dominated the first week of the congress and blamed Mikhail S. Gorbachev for the party's loss of popularity and ideological drift. ``It is an illusion to think that after all dissenters, all who do not wish to be drive belts and cogs of the apparatus, quit the party, it will retain all the property of the Soviet Communist Party and the associated authority,'' he said. ``It will not be so. If this is the case ... the people will start struggling for the full nationalization of the property of the party,'' Yeltsin said. ``The party will be bankrupt, obliged to repay its debts to the people, if only with its property.'' ``An effort might be made to prosecute party leaders at every level for the damage they personally have inflicted on the party and the people,'' he said. Yeltsin's warning was a prediction of a day of reckoning for the Communist Party, which nationalized property and violently repressed its enemies when it seized power under Lenin in 1917. Gorbachev, a frequent target of Yeltsin's populist demands for quicker and more comprehensive reform, was unimpressed by his speech. ``I expected more,'' he told reporters in a stroll outside the congress hall. Delegate Yuri Boldyrev of Leningrad had urged the nationalization of party property on the first day of the congress. Party officials estimate the value of the property at $8.2 billion. Leaders of Democratic Platform, a radical group that has declared its intention to split from the party, say one of the key tactical questions is how to lay a claim to some of the party's vast holdings of newspapers, the best buildings in cities all around the country, a huge fleet of cars and bank accounts. Yeltsin warned that Soviet Communists are blindly following their Eastern European comrades down the road to oblivion. ``If you think there is a different possibility, look at the fate of the Communist parties of Eastern Europe. They separated themselves from the people, didn't understand their role, and were left on the side of the road,'' he said. The only way out, he said, is for the Communist Party to fully accept all the trappings of the multiparty system that party leaders endorsed earlier this year. Yeltsin read rapidly and with little emotion from a prepared text. More than 4,600 delegates in the congress hall listened intently, but reflecting the traditionalist mood of the congress, gave him only a smattering of applause. Backing up Yeltsin's warning, a leader of the Democratic Platform reform group and an actor who is an outspoken supporter of Gorbachev also took the floor. Vyacheslav Shostakovsky, rector of Moscow's Higher Party School, urged the party to abandon its stifling ideology. ``No ideological cow will give us milk or meat,'' he said. Actor Mikhail Ulyanov accused traditional-minded Communists of trying to return to decades of repression. ``Hardly had our people begun to straighten up when voices rang out, blaming Gorbachev for letting the reins slip from his grasp, for allowing the country to be plunged into chaos and anarchy, and for the collapse of socialist ideals,'' he said. ``Deep in their minds, however, they're thinking how to return to the iron fist, regular columns and uniformity,'' he charged. Alexei Sergeyev, a leader of an orthodox Communist movement formed in Leningrad, accused Democratic Platform of being ``openly pro-capitalist,'' and charged that the Soviet government's economic program resembles its approach. Yeltsin has said he is ready to suspend his party membership if the party does not seriously reform itself at the congress. Walking out of the congress hall after his speech, the 59-year-old populist predicted Democratic Platform will leave the party and join an alliance of more democratic-minded political parties. At a news conference, Democratic Platform leaders said they would found their own party at a gathering this fall.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Proposes Voluntary Seafood Inspection Program
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Friday it is planning to enhance current seafood inspections with a voluntary program paid for by companies whose products could earn an official government seal. The new program would use industry controls and government inspections ``to provide additional assurances to consumers that fish and fish products are safe, wholesome and properly labeled,'' officials said. The program was proposed by the Food and Drug Administration and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The FDA has a seafood inspection program that requires examinations of processors, shippers, packers and repackers, labelers, warehouses and importers of fish and fish products. That program would continue separately. NOAA's National Marine Fisheries Service runs a voluntary, fee-for-service seafood inspection program, which uses a government inspection mark. That program would continue to provide grading services, but continuation of other parts of the program would depend on the extent to which companies switch to the new system, officials said. The new plan would be based on inspections at various critical points at which health risks, such as spoilage and bacterial growth, can be controlled, the FDA said. Companies would pay a fee for inspections and could earn an official mark or seal they could display on their product's label. The FDA said a two-month pilot study is scheduled to begin Oct. 1 to identify problems industry and government might have in implementing such a system. The agencies are looking for industry volunteers for the study. Public Voice for Food and Health Policy, a consumer group, criticized the plans, saying the government should instead strengthen its mandatory inspection system. ``It's like putting a Band-Aid on a festering sore,'' said Ellen Haas, executive director of the group. ``It's a totally inadequate response to a serious public health problem,'' she said. ``What consumers need is not a voluntary program paid for by those fish companies that chose to participate, but a mandatory, health-based inspection program such as ones being considered in Congress.''
Here, at a glance, are the highlights of the NATO summit that ended Friday.
DOC.HEAD: Endorsement of `Last Resort' Doctrine
DOC.TEXT: The NATO leaders endorsed an historic change in policy by pledging to use nuclear weapons only as a ``last resort,'' rather than maintaining uncertainty over when the arms would be deployed. The change is designed to reassure the Soviet Union that the Western alliance is not a poised military threat.
DOC.HEAD: Invitation to Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Western leaders invited Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to address a meeting of the alliance, probably in December. In Moscow, Gorbachev said he was always ready to go.
DOC.HEAD: Elimination of nuclear-tipped artillery shells
DOC.TEXT: NATO said it would get rid of nuclear-tipped artillery shells in Europe in return for a reciprocal arrangement by the Soviet Union.
DOC.HEAD: Reduction of Troops in Unified Germany
DOC.TEXT: Once the United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty to limit the number of troops in Europe _ probably next fall _ talks will begin to reduce the army of a unified Germany. Sources say the combined Germany will have a military force of no more than 400,000, down from about 565,000.
DOC.HEAD: Overtures to Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: The Western countries invited the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland, Bulgaria and Romania to establish regular diplomatic liaison offices with NATO.
DOC.HEAD: Aid to the Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: The summiteers praised Gorbachev's reforms, but offered no direct financial assistance to the Soviet Union. Diplomatic sources said Gorbachev had appealed for financial aid. President Bush said he was reluctant to give money to the Soviet Union until Moscow stops helping Cuba, among other things. But Bush said perhaps there was a way to help Gorbachev with credits and other guarantees.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Extends Hand of Friendship to Gorbachev but Differ on Aid
DOC.TEXT: s. LONDON (AP) _ The NATO allies pledged Friday to sharply reduce both nuclear and conventional defenses in Europe, extending ``the hand of friendship'' to Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the rest of Eastern Europe. Solemnly, President Bush and his 15 Western alliance partners assured the Soviet leader, who is under attack from left and right at the 28th Communist Party Congress in Moscow, that they hold ``no aggressive intentions'' and ``will never in any circumstance be the first to use force.'' In Moscow, Gorbachev said he was ready to accept the leaders' invitation to address a meeting of the Western alliance, probably in December. And Soviet foreign ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said, ``We welcome the results of the (NATO) session.'' But Gorbachev could take little comfort from Bush's comment that he had ``big problems'' with the idea of direct Western economic aid to the Soviet Union _ a subject likely to dominate the Houston economic summit where Bush and many of the other Western leaders were flying after the NATO meeting. In London, the allies agreed to shrink their arsenal of battlefield nuclear weapons _ in tandem with Soviet action _ and relegate them to highly unlikely last-resort use. They also said, in their windup communique, that ``once negotiations begin on short-range nuclear forces, the alliance will propose, in return for reciprocal action by the Soviet Union, the elimination of all its nuclear artillery shells from Europe.'' They also decided to field smaller and restructured ground forces, in the newest sign that NATO's 40-year job of containing potential Soviet-bloc aggression was nearing a successful end. One shift in NATO doctrine, away from a quarter-century threat to use nuclear weapons promptly if attacked, drew most of the notice. More subtle but also significant was the decision to abandon the strategy of massing troops up against the East-West frontier, switching to smaller mobile units further back. ``Allied leaders will have maximum flexibility in deciding how to respond to a crisis,'' the communique said. And, in a surprise move designed to allay one of Gorbachev's deepest concerns, the NATO allies agreed to set a limit on the size of Germany's military forces. That could mean a cut of more than 160,000 soldiers from the combined troops of East and West Germany after merger. However, despite Gorbachev's still-unsuccessful effort to pump life into the Soviet economy, Bush distanced himself from a plan devised by West Germany and France to provide Moscow with a bountiful package of direct financial assistance that could run into billions of dollars. ``I have big problems with that one,'' Bush said. ``I think the American people do,'' because of the Soviet Union's financial support of Cuba and because of its military spending at home. But the president said he would consider credits or technical help for the Soviets. The economic summit next week, bringing together leaders from the seven richest democracies in the world, will have Gorbachev's economic restructuring program at the top of the agenda. Bush said he hoped his resistance to direct U.S. assistance would not impede Gorbachev, who this week gave himself a two-year deadline to succeed. ``I have spoken very fondly and enthusiastically about what he's trying to do in terms of reform,'' Bush said at a news conference after the allied leaders adopted their history-making ``Declaration on a Transformed North Atlantic Alliance.'' The document's many concessions to Moscow, which won support even from cautious British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, reflected a joint judgment that ``the Soviet Union has embarked on the long journey to a free society.'' Together, the allies offered a pledge of non-aggression to each of the seven members of the Warsaw Pact. One of the innovative decisions taken at the summit was to establish liaisons to those that wish to establish closer political links to Western Europe. The gesture seemed tailored to Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Poland, all of which have adopted democratic governments while maintaining tenuous ties to Moscow. ``The London declaration transforms our relationship with old adversaries,'' Bush said. ``To those governments who confronted us in the Cold War, our alliance extends the hand of friendship.'' The communique also used the ``hand of friendship'' phrase. Even so, hundreds of short-range nuclear weapons will remain in NATO's arsenal. The purpose, Mrs. Thatcher said at a separate news conference, is that ``anyone who wanted to cross our borders could never be certain that nuclear weapons could not be used ... against him.'' Bush is planning the production of new air-to-surface nuclear missiles, and sea-launched U.S. cruise missiles are taking over the mission of nuclear-tipped artillery shells that will be withdrawn as Soviet troops and tanks leave Eastern and Central Europe. And French President Francois Mitterrand told reporters that his country had no intention of reducing its sizable nuclear arsenal until the Soviet Union and the United States take such steps. ``When others have disarmed, those countries with enormous superiority with regard to weaponry, then we will,'' Mitterrand said. ``It's as simple as that.'' The United States is in the midst of negotiations with the Soviet Union to cut long-range missiles, bombers and submarines. Separate talks between NATO and the Warsaw Pact in Vienna are aimed at reducing U.S. and Soviet troops and such non-nuclear arms as tanks and helicopters by the end of the year. Bush said he would be in touch with Gorbachev over the next few weeks. ``They ought not to view NATO as a threat and certainly ought not to view it as a roadblock to progress in arms control or withdrawal of conventional forces or whatever it might be,'' the president said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Bill Monroe, founder of bluegrass music, is making the move to the big screen. A film crew from Caporeale Studios of Cincinnati is in Nashville interviewing friends of the Grand Ole Opry great and gathering film footage for a documentary on Monroe's life. ``Bill's somewhere in the neighborhood of 80 years old,'' said studio official Tom McGrail. ``He's afraid he might not be around much longer, and he's looking at this as his legacy.'' Monroe, who turns 79 in September, will be filmed performing this weekend at the Long Hollow Jamboree, the Grand Ole Opry and at a bluegrass festival Saturday at the Opryland U.S.A. theme park. McGrail said his crew already has interviewed Ralph Stanley, Emmylou Harris and ``a bunch of other bluegrass luminaries.'' Others to be interviewed include Ricky Skaggs and Wynnona and Naomi Judd. ``Bill's a regular, old-fashioned radio cowboy,'' McGrail said. ``We've never seen him without his white hat. And he does a great stone face.''

Harry Connick Jr., who has been described by some critics as the new Frank Sinatra, says he's such a Sinatra ``freak'' that he has daydreamed of breaking into Ol' Blue Eyes' house. ``I just want to touch him,'' the singer, songwriter and pianist said in an interview with USA Weekend magazine. ``I just want to touch him. I just want to say, `Mr. Sinatra, you're the king.''' Another of the young performer's dreams: to sing ``Luck be a Lady'' on stage with Sinatra. But Connick, 22, who won a Grammy for the music to the movie ``When Harry Met Sally,'' is no Beatles fan. ``That music is for second-graders,'' he said.

Billy Joel has finished the Atlanta leg of his ``Storm Front'' concert tour, but the singer may have to make another Atlanta date _ in Fulton County Superior Court. Joel's former manager and one-time brother-in-law, Frank Weber, filed an $11 million lawsuit against the rock star claiming breach of contract in his firing. Joel sued Weber in September for $90 million, claiming Weber used the entertainer's money for interest-free loans, signed Joel's name to documents without consent and put the singer's money in high-risk investments despite instructions to invest conservatively. Weber's suit, filed Tuesday, contends Joel dismissed the manager without cause and that Weber is entitled to 20 percent of Joel's gross income because Frank Management planned the singer's Atlanta tour. Daniel A. Gecker, an attorney representing Weber, said he chose to sue in Atlanta because ``the Atlanta docket moves a lot faster than the New York courts do.'' A similar lawsuit was dismissed in Richmond earlier this year for lack of jurisdiction, he said. Jane Sanders, a New York attorney representing Joel, said: ``We view it as harassing tactics and a way to find a another judge to act in his behalf.''

Where can you buy official ``Do The Right Thing'' T-shirts and other memorabilia from Spike Lee films? Do you know? Do you know? Do you know? The answer: Spike's Joint, a store Lee plans to open July 22, one day before the debut of his latest film, ``Mo' Better Blues.'' The store will sell hats, buttons, T-shirts and other items from Lee's movies. It also will feature Lee's preferred headgear _ Brooklyn Dodgers' baseball caps. The store is far from New York's tourist attractions but only a block from the offices of Lee's 40 Acres and a Mule movie company in Brooklyn's Fort Greene section. Lee's previous sales experience includes pitching Air Jordan athletic shoes for Nike, in a commercial that let him reprise a line from the movie ``She's Gotta Have It.'' Do you know?

A policeman who thought he was stopping an underage driver's summer joyride found he had pulled over actor Gary Coleman. ``He was so small,'' said Undersheriff Santos Baca. ``He had a pillow he was sitting on.'' Coleman, 22, is only about 4-foot-7 as a result of kidney disease and other health problems. Baca saw the ``Diff'rent Strokes'' television star behind the wheel of a rental car he was driving Thursday on Interstate 25 just north of Albuquerque. ``I could barely see him in there,'' Baca said. The undersheriff said Coleman politely explained he was heading from Dallas to Denver to visit his parents. He showed Baca a Colorado driver's license that listed his occupation as actor. ``Right away he struck me as a funny guy because he asked me, `What are you a policeman or a fireman?' He wanted to know if he was speeding,'' said Baca, who amiably sent Coleman on his way.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version moved on financial wires
DOC.TEXT: Finally, some good news for Donald Trump. The cash-starved developer won a real estate tax fight with the city and saved $1.2 million on his 1989 taxes. Trump's 56-acre waterfront property on Manhattan's Upper West Side, assessed by the city at $44 million, was instead taxed at a rate $12.5 million lower after Trump made his case before the city Tax Commission. Trump was one of 19,306 taxpayers who won assessment battles with the city for 1989. The full list of the winners _ which included the Andy Warhol estate and Alex DiLorenzo, owner of the building that housed the Happy Land Social Club where 86 people died in an arson fire _ was released June 29. Trump, whose cash flow problems have been well documented, saved $1.2 million in taxes with the re-evaluation, the city Finance Department said. But that money went right back to the city Thursday, when Trump made a multimillion dollar semiannual property tax payment. Trump shelled out $2.2 million for his undeveloped West Side property, $1 million for Trump Tower and $900,000 for the Trump Parc condominiums.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Pledges German Troop Cut Commitment, Kohl Wants Missiles Out
DOC.TEXT: NATO leaders promised Friday to spell out by autumn plans for massive German troop cuts in a move hailed by Chancellor Helmut Kohl as an ``indispensable signpost'' on the path to German unification. The allied leaders' agreement to set such a timetable as part of the summit-ending communique was another dramatic effort to allay Soviet anxieties about the looming merger of two Germanys. Kohl, the chancellor of West Germany, also urged the withdrawal of short-range U.S. missiles from his country. The communique included a commitment to come up with a troop level for a unified Germany by fall. Those force levels will in turn become part of a new round of negotiations with the Soviets on reducing overall troop levels of both alliances. Bonn's defense minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, has agreed to cut more than 160,000 from the current combined forces of West and East Germany, down to 400,000. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher has said an even greater cut _ to 350,000 troops _ is acceptable. Kohl will discuss it during a July 15 visit to Moscow in an attempt to clear away Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's objections to NATO membership for the country expected to emerge later this year. The Soviets, who still mourn their more than 20 million dead in World War II, fear a united German military in central Europe. But Kohl, while insisting on NATO membership for a unified Germany, will point to the changes adopted at the two-day summit aimed at making the alliance less threatening to the Kremlin. The democratically elected governments in Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary, in fact, would prefer keeping the mammoth new German state with nearly 80 million people embedded in the Western Alliance, Kohl said. ``For many people, having a strong NATO roof over Germany is better than isolation,'' he told reporters in London. ``This is a wide-ranging offer,'' said Kohl of NATO's new stance. ``This is NATO offering a hand.'' Kohl called the commitment ``an indispensable signpost along the path leading to German unity.'' Seeking to appease West Germans who for years have chafed against nuclear missiles in their country, Kohl also called for the removal of 700 aging American short-range nuclear missiles from his territory. The Lance missiles are only capable of hitting neighboring Czechoslovakia and East Germany, both of which have undergone major pro-democracy reforms. Only a few months ago, Kohl secured a U.S. promise not to replace the missiles, which will become technically obsolete by 1995 anyway. The United States is also removing medium-range nuclear missiles from West Germany, and is willing to talk with the Soviets about ridding Europe of nuclear-tipped artillery shells. Most of the 1,470 American shells are in West Germany. Nonetheless, the chancellor urged the Americans to keep some forces in Europe, or, as he put it, to maintain ``an apartment in the European house.'' Kohl lavished praise on President George Bush, saying the U.S. president has a clear view of the changes in Europe. ``The chemistry is right'' between both men, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says He's `Ready to Go' to NATO Headquarters
With AM-NATO Sumit Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto MOSB9
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev indicated Friday he would accept an invitation to visit NATO headquarters, and a Foreign Ministry spokesman said the alliance summit had bolstered the Soviet leader's position at home. Gorbachev, speaking during a break in the Communist Party congress, said he had not received a formal invitation yet but, ``I am always ready to go.'' NATO leaders, ending talks in London Friday, approved a statement that proposed a mutual non-aggression pact with the Soviet Union and extended the unprecedented invitation to Gorbachev and other Warsaw Pact leaders. Leaders of the rival alliance were invited to visit North Atlantic Treaty Organization headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, probably in December. Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said in Moscow the Soviet Union welcomed the summit conclusions ``as a practical step toward re-examining the philosophy of confrontation in Europe.'' He said the session ``helps Gorbachev's position'' in the Soviet Union. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said in a statement carried by the official news agency Tass that the NATO summit's decisions were ``realistic and constructive.'' ``The decisions adopted move in the right direction and pave the way to a safe future for the entire European continent,'' he said. He welcomed NATO's appeal for a joint declaration with the Warsaw Pact saying the two sides are no longer opponents and pledging to refrain from the threat or use of force. Gerasimov said NATO's moves away from military confrontation were an answer to Soviet officers who have complained recently that the country's foreign policy under Gorbachev has consisted mainly of concessions. ``The results of the NATO session show that our good example brings answering steps from NATO,'' he said. Valentin Falin, a top party official for foreign affairs, was less enthusiastic. He told reporters that NATO was mainly at the stage of making promises hinging on future Soviet behavior. ``You can't build a house out of `if's,''' he said, adding that nonetheless, the NATO communique was a sign of progress. On Thursday, several military officers speaking at section meetings during the Communist Party congress blasted Gorbachev's foreign policy for weakening the country's defenses and letting Eastern Europe slip away. Major Gen. Ivan Nikulin, chief political officer of the Soviet Union's southern army group, warned that the Soviet Union was allowing an upset in the military balance of Europe. He rejected Gorbachev's idea of a ``common European home'' as a ``myth,'' and warned that one-sided Soviet concessions would lead to the Soviet Union being pushed out of Europe instead of joined with it. ``The successes of Soviet diplomacy on the international scene were mostly due to its ability to give in,'' the Interfax news service quoted one of Gorbachev's critics as saying. Falin said the officers opinions ``don't reflect the opinion of the majority of the armed forces and naturally don't play a definitive role in the formulation of the practical actions of the Defense Ministry.'' Gerasimov formally announced that NATO's secretary-general, Manfred Woerner, would come to Moscow on July 14 to continue the London forum. Gorbachev reportedly appealed for economic aid in a letter to British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher at the NATO meeting. Ivan K. Polozkov, head of the Russian republic's Communist Party, told reporters he backed the idea of Western aid for the ailing Soviet economy. ``I think we have no basis to refuse aid if it's proposed,'' said Polozkov, considered a leading hard-liner in the party. Falin, asked if he was worried the Soviet Union's image would be tarnished if it accepted Western aid, said he was not concerned. ``I think not one pearl will fall from our crown if we take the hand held out to us,'' he said. The issue of Western economic aid to the Soviet Union was not resolved at the London meeting, and is expected to be tackled at an economic summit of seven major industrial democracies that opens in Houston on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: France and Britain Agree _ For A Change
DOC.TEXT: Traditionally at international gatherings there's not much love lost between French President Francois Mitterrand and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. But at the NATO summit, nuclear weapons brought them together, both jealously guarding domestic arsenals and both uneasy about the alliance's decision to rely on the armaments only as a ``last resort.'' Mrs. Thatcher had qualms. But she went along with the decision announced at the end of a two-day summit Friday, saying it was acceptable because NATO kept the option of using nuclear weapons. But Mitterrand remained flatly opposed. He said the last resort concept ``seems to me to be totally contradictory to French strategy, which is not to take the initiative to use force, but to bring out whatever force is necessary when appropriate.'' ``Great Britain and France had similar positions,'' he said, adding that Mrs. Thatcher voted in favor of the strategy switch while he voted against it ``both because of strategic differences of opinion and because we are not part of the command.'' France's withdrawal of its forces from the NATO joint military command in 1966 is a sore point with Mrs. Thatcher and is usually good for a British jibe. Instead, at her end-of-summit news conference Friday, she merely noted wistfully that French forces remained outside the NATO command. The position wouldn't change, and ``we accept it,'' she said. Then she launched into lavish praise of France for, she said, persuading West Germany to deploy U.S. nuclear missiles in the early 1980s. ``The fact that she (France) had a slightly different position in NATO was used to advantage and she was able to do a certain amount of persuasion which ... may continue to be very helpful in the future,'' said Mrs. Thatcher. It was a far cry from frequent testiness between the British Conservative Party leader and the French Socialist. They met again at the NATO summit fresh from their latest spat at a meeting of the leaders of the 12-nation European Community in Dublin, Ireland, 10 days ago. In Dublin, Mrs. Thatcher played a prime role in getting a French-West German proposal for an immediate $15 billion in Soviet aid sidelined. She and Mitterrand also renewed exchanges over what he sees as her constant efforts to put the brake on European unity and what she sees as grandiose rhetoric from a country as eager to preserve its national identity as anyone else. Mitterrand said Mrs. Thatcher was isolated in Dublin although she got her way on the Soviet aid proposal. Mrs. Thatcher brushed this aside. When reporters asked her about reported crusty exchanges in closed session, she said: ``Ah, yes, President Mitterrand. ... We usually have something.'' In London, they found they had a lot in common. After the centuries-old shared history of friendship and rivalry, the two former colonial powers now share a status as the only nations in Western Europe with their own nuclear arsenals. And the two leaders share a wariness about letting down their military guard. Said Mitterrand of NATO's offer to Eastern European countries of a commitment to non-aggression: ``We will follow the political line but not the strategic line.''

DOC.HEAD: USDA Seeks New Milk Price Formula
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department said Friday it is seeking an alternative way of setting minimum prices paid dairy farmers under federal marketing orders. The department currently uses a base known as the Minnesota-Wisconsin, or M-W, price, an average of prices paid to farmers in the two-state area for Grade B milk used only for manufacturing products such as cheese, butter and non-fat dry milk. Daniel D. Haley, administrator of the department's Agricultural Marketing Service, said the M-W base price has been used since the early 1960s and is widely accepted as a measure of change in the supply and demand for milk nationally. But a continuing decline in the output of Grade B milk _ partly because of tighter sanitary standards _ is gradually making the M-W price unusable for setting milk prices, he said. Haley said the department's National Agricultural Statistics Service, which compiles the M-W price, questions whether it will be able to do so after mid-1992. The dairy industry has asked USDA to develop and test alternative methods, and a national hearing on all federal milk orders has been tentatively set for September, although no specific date and location have been announced. Haley said a separate hearing on the base price will be held later. Meanwhile, specific proposals can be sent by July 25 to: Director, Dairy Division, AMS, USDA, Room 2968-S, P.O. Box 96456, Washington, D.C. 20090-6456.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Group Sending Supplies To Help Iranian Earthquake Victims
DOC.TEXT: An American relief organization said Friday that it would send $4 million worth of medical supplies, food and clothing to help victims of last month's devastating earthquake in Iran. The group, Feed the Children, said the 40 tons of supplies would be shipped Sunday from Dulles International Airport near Washington to Mehrabad Airport in Tehran. In Iran, the Red Crescent _ Iran's Red Cross equivalent _ will receive and distribute the goods, said Sekita Ekrek, a spokeswoman for organization. Iranian officials estimate that nearly 40,000 people died and 60,000 were injured in the June 21 earthquake, which measured between 7.3 and 7.7 on the Richter scale. Estimates of the homeless range up to 500,000. Larry Jones, Feed the Children president and founder, said the American public initially was reluctant to give donations to Iran because that county is seen as an enemy. Iran is believed to have influence with the kidnappers who hold 16 Western hostages, including six Americans, in Lebanon. ``Because we don't have diplomatic relations, because of the hostage situation, they were reluctant to give,'' he said. ``People needed a little nudge to help give.'' He said donations started coming in after he made a televised appeal for aid. Feed the Children has been working with the Iran Quake Relief Committee, formed shortly after the earthquake, and the United Armenian Fund, founded after a destructive 1988 earthquake in Soviet Armenia. The United Armenian Fund is paying for a private cargo plane to transport the supplies to Tehran. The Iran Quake Relief Committee helped solicit donations and coordinate the effort with Iranian officials. Marty Youssefiani, spokesman for the Iranian Quake Relief Committee, said the three groups came together despite major ethnic, religious and political differences. ``For the first time, the community has put aside all its differences,'' he said. ``That's a remarkable, remarkable accomplishment.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bulgarian President Resigns In Face of Strong Opposition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 5th, `Students, who... and recasts 13th, `Socialist Premier...' with Lukanov now in charge. Pickup 14th, `The new...'
DOC.TEXT: President Petar Mladenov, whose political party of former Communists won Bulgaria's first free election in 58 years last month, submitted his resignation today, state media reported. Mladenov had been under mounting pressure to step down. Students and opposition parties, who led the calls for his resignation, accused him, among other things, of suggesting that tanks should be used to put down an anti-government rally outside Parliament late last year. Mladenov's letter of resignation was read on state television's 8:00 p.m. news program by a commentator. Students, who have been on strike for nearly a month, issued a declaration earlier today calling on Bulgarians to go on a 30-minute ``warning strike'' Saturday if Mladenov did not step down today, the state BTA news agency said. The resignation left Premier Andrei Lukanov, a member of Mladenov's Socialist Party, as head of the government. A replacement for Mladenov will likely be chosen when the new Parliament first meets on Tuesday. Demands for Mladenov's resignation came after experts assessed as authentic a videotape in which he was heard to suggest the use of tanks on a large anti-government rally outside Parliament on Dec. 14. In the videotape, broadcast on an election program by the main opposition alliance Union of Democratic Forces three days before runoff elections last month, Mladenov was heard to say ``Let the tanks come.'' No tanks were used. In his reaction to the experts' conclusion, Mladeonv said on state TV Wednesday night that the phrase was taken out of context and did not reflect his political career and convictions. The end of hard-line Communist rule in Bulgaria came not, as in Romania, Czechoslovakia and East Germany, through street protest, but in a Communist Party coup in which reform-minded comrades, including Mladenov, ousted party chief Todor Zhivkov. The Communists reorganized as the Socialist Party. Mladenov was appointed president, and after peaceful demonstrations by the fragmented but quickly growing opposition, the Socialists began negotiations that led to the June elections. In Sofia _ a Democratic Forces stronghold _ nearly everybody, including most Western diplomats, was shocked by the Socialists' 211-seat victory in the parliamentary elections. The Democratic Forces won 144 seats. Lukanov had said he wanted to form a broad coalition government that might have more chance of attracting sorely needed foreign investment. However, the opposition refused to help the Socialists solve the growing economic crisis created by their mismanagement. The new Parliament will serve a two-year term and write a new constitution. Most of the original demands of the students, who have been on strike since June 11, have been fulfilled. They include the resignation of a TV director accused of biased reporting and publication of alleged election irregularities. But according to BTA, the students drew up a new list of demands today. They have called for a date to be set for a public trial of Zhivkov, 78, who is in detention. He has been charged with misappropriation of state property, inciting ethnic hostility and grave abuse of power. About 1,000 students have been conducting a sit-in strike in front of the presidential building to press their demands for Mladenov's resignation. A students' strike committee statement called for a general strike on Monday, one day before the new Parliament is to hold its first session, if Mladenov had not resigned by then, BTA said. The Union of Democratic Forces also issued a statement earlier today calling on Mladenov to resign before Parliament opens Tuesday. Other smaller opposition groups and the mainstream Agrarian Party, a once docile ally of the Communists, also backed the students' demands, BTA reported. The former official trade unions, which now call themselves independent, also supported student demands, as did miners at the Balkan coalfield who support the opposition union Podkrepa, BTA said. On Thursday, the leader of the Union of Democratic Forces, Zhelyu Zhelev said in a statement that a head of state ``cannot permit himself to be dishonest before the people,'' BTA reported.

DOC.HEAD: x x x to Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: A. They send to him that, ``Here's an alliance that is purely _ that you should view, Mr. Gorbachev, as defensive and not threatening, and please convince your military and others in the Soviet Union of this fact.'' You see, from my discussions with Mr. Gorbachev and others, I've had the feeling that they have viewed NATO as much more threatening to them than I've ever looked at _ than the way in which I've looked at NATO. But, now, as a result of the actions that we've taken here, I think it should be clear to the Soviet military, to Mr. Gorbachev, to his adversaries, and to his friends inside the Soviet Union that NATO is changing. And, to the degree they had seen it as a threat to their shores or to their borders, they should look at it not as a threat to their borders or to their people. Any time you sit down with people from the Soviet Union, they tell you the fact that they lost from 20 to 27 million lives. It's ingrained in them. And they do it not as a defensive mechanism, but they do it because they feel very strongly about that. I hope that they will look at the changes that NATO has taken and say, ``Well, if NATO had been a threat to us, it no longer is a threat to us,'' and then I hope we can go forward to further document that spirit by mutual agreements on arms control. Yes, Jessie? Q. Mr. President, how are you going to communicate what's in this document to Mr. Gorbachev and the people there? Are you going to talk with him personally? Did the NATO leaders decide on some other method of communication with him to let him know what it means, what the communique means? A. Well, I'd _ the NATO leaders have decided that the Secretary General will be going there, and that will be a very good face-to-face chance to discuss these matters. I believe our Secretary of State is meeting soon with Mr. Shevardnadze. You can be sure that matters will be discussed then, and then I _ it's in all likelihood I will discuss it personally by telephone with Mr. Gorbachev. I think it's very important that the leader of the United States and the leader of the Soviet Union stay in touch. And, in fact, when he was here in Washington, we talked about more such contacts. So perhaps within the next couple of weeks I will be talking to him about what transpired, because I want to make the _ some of these points here again, particularly that he _ they ought not to view NATO as a threat, and certainly they ought not to view it as a roadblock to progress in arms control or withdrawal of conventional forces or whatever it might be. Yes, Margaret? You had your hand up. Q. Mr. President, what kind of tangible response would you like to see from President Gorbachev now to this, and I'm thinking particularly the issue of Germany and NATO? A. Well, I think, in terms of the question of Germany and NATO, I would like to see the tangible respose be an acceptance of the concept that a unified Germany in NATO is not only good, but that it certainly is no threat to them. And we've had long talks with Mr. Gorbachev about that, and perhaps this declaration will be the _ be a document that he can use to convince others that a unified Germany in NATO is in the interest of stability and world peace. So, that would be _ I think that is probably the most important message. And then I'd like to think that out of this he would feel more confident in going forward with _ with arms control, bringing the two-plus-four talks to a conclusion, and there's a wide array of other things as well. Way in the back. Yes, sir? Q. Thank you. Jerry Lewis, Israel Radio. Did the topic of the Middle East come up during your discussions in the margins of the NATO summit? And can you comment on press reports which indicate you might be considering resuming your dialogue with the PLO, and what conditions would you attach to such a resumption? A. The discussion of the Middle East in the NATO meeting did not come up. It may have been discussed in the corridors but it was not a discussion of the _ in the _ in the meetings at all, and I didn't have discussions in a NATO context about the Middle East. My position on the dialogue with the PLO is that one of the preconditions for discussion was a renunciation of terror. And I viewed the aborted attack on the shores of Israel by some Palestinian commandos as a terrorist act. So, we didn't cancel, we suspended the talks with the PLO. And I would like to think that Mr. Arafat could some way bring his Council, not only to denounce the terror _ that particular terrorist act _ but also to take some action against the person that perpetrated it, and then I think we would certainly give rapid consideration to renewal of the dialogue. I happen to think the dialogue has been useful. I don't think Mr. Arafat particularly agrees with that, and I'm quite confident that Mr. Shamir doesn't agree with that. but, nevertheless, we have _ that's the view of the United States. Yes, Ellen? Q. Mr. President, Mikhail Gorbachev is already under fire from conservatives for essentially giving away Eastern Europe. Are you at all concerned, sir, that by inviting him to speak today only further undermines him? And I have a follow-up. A. No, I'm not _ not only do I think we're not undermining him, but I would think that would send a signal that NATO has no hostile intentions to the Soviet Union. So I would hope nobody at home would consider this an effort to undermine Mr. Gorbachev, nor would it be _ nor would it have the effect of undermining a man who has clearly tried to move forward, who has presided over the Soviet union at a time when this fantastic change towards democracy and freedom has taken place in Eastern Europe. And you're seeing that same kind of quest for change, democratic change, and economic change inside the Soviet Union. So I don't think it would have the effect that the question suggests. Q. If he accepts your invitation, sir, will you attend that meeting, or would it be an occasion for some sort of a superpower summit? A. It has the _ this _ the level of the Gorbachev meeting at NATO has not been determined, and I would be guided by what the other NATO members think is appropriate. But others have _ you know _ the level at which Mr. Gorbachev would speak to NATO has not been set. If it was a head-of-state level, why of course I would attend. Others have addressed NATO at varying levels. Yes, right in the middle. Q. Having attended quite a number of these things, of these NATO conferences, I'd like to ask a question, Mr. President, which I asked just two meetings ago. Is this to some extent a celebration of the victory of NATO in the Cold War? The Cold War is over, and NATO has won. Or don't you agree with the idea that NATO has won the Cold War? A. Excuse me, back up now. I _ I've tried to avoid code words, and the Cold War being over is something that I'd rather not _ not comment on. I _ I don't think we're dealing in terms of victory and defeat. We're dealing in terms of how do we stabilize and guarantee the peace and security of Europe. So to the degree a chief of state or head of government dwells on the kinds of rhetoric that you understandably ask about, I think it is counterproductive. Does that answer it? Q. Well, would you say that NATO has, to a great extent, caused Gorbachev to be; that the whole changes in Eastern Europe have to some extent been caused by what's been going on in Western Europe for the last 40 years? A. Well, I would say to some degree that the changes in Eastern Europe and in the Soviet Union have been because they have seen the success of market economies, they have seen a craving for freedom and democracy on the parts of people. And to the degree NATO countries contributed to that proper perception, so be it. I think _ I like to think that _ I'm convinced that NATO's solidarity during the last 40 years has guaranteed the peace for Europe. And when you look back at history, it is a long peace, given some of the conflagrations on this continent. So I think, NATO deserves a lot of credit, but I think the yearning for freedom and democracy is pretty fundamental. NATO has nothing to do with the changes in our own Western Hemisphere, and yet, you're seeing now the emergence of democracies and you're seeing the emergence of free people there. So it's fundamental that people want democracy and freedom, but I think NATO's major contribution has been to keeping the peace, and yet, it's set an example that I think many in Eastern Europe now want to follow. Yes? Q. Mr. President, how do you square the concern over stability in Europe, which is the new purpose of NATO, with increasing signs of instability in the Soviet Union, particularly on the political and economic front, and what can you do to put those two pieces of the puzzle together? A. A very good and very difficult question, because, frankly, one thing we do is stay out of the internal affairs of the Soviet Union. I realize that some think that I'm not staying out of the internal affairs of the Soviet Union when I speak _ speak pleasantly about Mr. Gorbachev. But I think they have to sort it out now. They have to decide what they want, how much of their gross national product ought to go into arms, whether the threat is much less than they have historically perceived. and once they take that decision, then we in the West will stand ready to work very cooperatively with them. But I think the next move, what I'm saying, is up to them. I think they have to make these determinations. and in the meantime, NATO, having seem the changes that have taken place in Eastern Europe and the predicted changes in terms of force levels, can go forward with what I think people will view as an historic document. Excuse me, I did tell you I'd get over here. Q. Thank you very much. Me? A. Yes, sir. Q. How conditional is the proposal to remove nuclear artillery from Europe? Are you actually saying that you will not do this unless the Soviet Union does likewise, are you saying it should be part of negotiations, or are you actually merely inviting the Soviet union to withdraw their nuclear artillery?

DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.06 percent this week, down from 10.15 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.46 percent this week, up from 8.45 percent the week before. DOC.HEAD: Soviets Dominate in Piano; U.S. Vocalists Strike Gold at Tchaikovsky
DOC.TEXT: Soviets dominated the piano section of the ninth international Tchaikovsky music competition, while Americans swept the gold medals in the vocal division, officials announced Friday. Akiko Suwanai of Japan took first place in the violin section of the contest, and West Germany's Gustav Rivinius won the gold medal for cello. In the piano division, Soviets Boris Berezovski took the gold medal and Vladimir Mishchuk won the silver. Three competitors shared the bronze medals: Anton Mordasov of the Soviet Union; Kevin Kenner, an American living in West Germany, and Johan Schmidt of Belgium. Deborah Voigt of New York City won the gold in the female vocalist division and Hans Choi, of Flushing, N.Y. won the gold in the men's division. Alyssa Park, a 16-year-old violinist from Lexington, Ky., who charmed Soviet audiences and won a huge ovation in the finals, took the bronze medal, and also was honored with two more medals: most talented and most artistic. The competition, which began June 14, drew 335 competitors from 51 countries. It took on special significance because this year is the 150th anniversary of Tchaikovsky's birth. The gold medalists will perform at a special concert Saturday night, and the runners-up will play on Sunday. ``I feel totally exhausted,'' Voigt, 29, said Friday. ``It was a grueling and grinding experience.'' The soprano and former apprentice with the San Francisco Opera Company celebrated with champagne, and plans a U.S. concert tour starting in Chicago. Choi, a baritone and former student at the La Scala opera company of Milan, Italy, had said his biggest problem was language. ``I must sing in six languages, and I must sing perfectly in six languanges, because the judges come from so many countries.'' Suwanai, 18, of Tokyo, told the Tass news agency she was happy to win a first prize after coming in second at contests in Genoa, Brussels and Japan. She said some credit for her victory had to go to Tchaikovsky. ``He is not just my most favorite composer. Possibly, there is no other composer who is so close to me spiritually.'' Park, a junior in high school who also studied at the Cincinnati Conservatory of Music, won the bronze for her renditions of works by Tchaikovsky, Paganini, Mozart and Bartok. In an interview after the winners were announced, she said: ``I was very honored, but also very puzzled,'' because the international jury awarded her the medals for the most artistic and most talented, but only ranked her third overall. Park, the youngest of the 65 violinists who entered the competition, admitted feeling some tension, ``but I just tried to treat it as a concert and play.'' Berezovsky, a 22-year-old student of the Moscow Conservatory, won for his performance of works by Tchaikovsky, Chopin and Liszt. The international jury also awarded two fourth prizes to pianists Rolf Plagge of West Germany and Stephen Prutsman, of Los Angeles. Ten Americans were among the 48 finalists who competed Thursday night. For the first time since the competition began in 1958, foreign funding was used for organizing the contest. The hard-pressed Soviet hosts turned to Pioneer Electronics of Japan to contribute a $4,000 stereo set for each category winner as well as subsidizing hotels and transport for visiting musicians. Each winner also wins 5,000 rubles, a non-convertible currency that cannot be taken from the Soviet Union.
