DOC.HEAD: Highway Haircuts and Sinead O'Connor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 10th graf, `I don't...,' to CORRECT name of station from KULZ to KQLZ. Lowercase LP title in 13th graf, ``But all the,'' is cq. Jonathon in 21st graf, ``It gets worse,'' is also cq. ^By HILLEL ITALIE
DOC.TEXT: Sinead's coming to town _ O'Connor, that is. She's hot. The kids love her. Critics, too. The album's gone platinum. Her concerts sell out everywhere. And that look. Her shaved head is as distinctive as the Beatle moptop was in 1964. That's what Joe Poggi is thinking. He's the marketing director at KNRG in Houston. He needs a gimmick, a way to get more listeners. Something outrageous if necessary. He's got it! Madonna was just in town, one stop on her ``Blond Ambition Tour.'' Why not play off that, and go one better. Take O'Connor's name and shout it from the highest rooftops _ literally. ``We had our afternoon jock get on the top of the Summit, which overlooks the Southwest Freeway,'' explained Poggi, referring to the city's sports arena. ``On the marquee we had them put ENERGY 95 presents the `Bald Ambition Tour.' ``You see, the show sold out and we had a pair of front row tickets. But you had to be the first person to come there and let professional stylists cut your hair. ``We had a person show up at 3:15 with hair down to his shoulders. He's a swim coach and we put him up on the marquee. And at 4:30, just when rush hour's really good, we started cutting his hair. People were laughing and honking; some pulled over and watched.'' Highway haircuts and rush-hour remotes may not seem the most dignified way to greet the best-selling author of songs about dead boyfriends and police brutality, even if she does shave her head. But this is hit radio, and a new look plus a platinum LP means gold for the happy-happy world of morning zoos and celebrity wake-up calls. ``I don't think we did it to make fun of her,'' said Mark Todd, operations manager for KQLZ in Los Angeles, another ``Shave Your Head'' promoter. ``People are fans and we did it out of fun. We weren't doing it to put her down. We play her records constantly. It's basically intended to let the listeners participate in something. It makes for good radio.'' ``When it was discovered she was coming into town for a concert, our phones were screaming,'' said Cris Dockett, assistant promotion manager at WMMS in Cleveland. ``Anybody willing to shave their head recieved tickets, plus we gave them cash. They were willing to do it. One of them even brought her own hairdresser into the studio.'' But all the hype has caused much sorrow for the 23-year-old Irish performer, who toured North America from May 1 to June 11. O'Connor, whose ``I do not want what I haven't got'' album quickly topped the charts, was especially upset when she learned that a San Diego radio station had taken to the airwaves to track down her hotel. ``In America people are obsessed,'' the singer complained in a phone interview from Austin, Texas. ``It's really, really shocking. It's so frightening. They follow you around and it freaks you out. Anything could be happening. What am I supposed to do?'' ``It's all been a rude surprise for Sinead,'' said O'Conner's publicist, Elaine Schock. ``She's used to walking the streets. When I would go to see her in England, she'd greet me at the subway. Intellectually, she understood that becoming famous would change things, but in her heart she was hoping it wouldn't.'' Many promoters can sympathize but insist O'Connor will have to get used to it. It's all part of being in the limelight, they say. Rock 'n' roll stars are fair game, as are all celebrities, they argue. Sell a million records and you'd better bring a pair of sunglasses and keep the phone off the hook. ``We can do stuff like that with anybody,'' said producer Telephone Tony of WHTZ in New York, another station on the ``Shave Your Head'' network. ``When Prince was out, he had the same type of thing, and Michael Jackson, too. We had sightings for Madonna around Central Park. We were having listener reports. It was great. ``I'm sure it probably bothers her,'' the producer said of O'Connor. ``I've listened to her album and it's a really serious, artistic piece. But the fact that she has short hair and the fact she's very unique opens up the joke pile.'' Mike Novack, program managerdirector at KFMB in San Diego, Calif., said his station has a group of people they call ``hotel weasels'' who let them know where celebrities are staying. And it gets worse, much worse. In Chicago, WLU and operations P morning host Jonathon Brandmeier likes to greet visiting luminaries with wake-up calls _ LIVE wake-up calls. Jonathan Winters pretended he was Bob Dell, in town for a plumber's convention, when he was called. Robert De Niro hung up. Steve Martin threatened legal action. Brandmeier was broadcasting from Los Angeles in June and switched from ringing phones to ringing doorbells, sending a producer for surprise early-morning visits to such stars as George Burns, Peter Falk and Gene Kelly (none of whom ever came to the door). ``It's all done for for the sole purpose for garnering ratings for the radio station,'' said Carey Curelop, program director of WLOS in Los Angeles. ``Some people have more scruples air controllers lost contact with the aircraft a few minutes after it took off. It was earlier thought that the plane may have crashed, and government planes and helicopters searched for the aircraft Thursday and Friday. The three passengers who deboarded were arrested by Colombian police on Friday when they could not produce identification papers at a checkpoint, Bennet said. They were on a bus traveling from Viterbo to Medellin when they were arrested, Bennet said. He said the passengers were taken to Bogota, the Colombian capital, for questioning.

DOC.HEAD: Snyder Remembered as Man Driven To Help the Downtrodden
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 7th graf pvs, bgng: Police said, to CORRECT spelling of Carol
DOC.TEXT: Mitch Snyder, whose personal demons apparently overwhelmed his fierce commitment to the nation's homeless, was remembered Friday as ``a man of justice'' who worked tirelessly to assist the downtrodden. Jesse Jackson told a memorial service at Bible Way Church that Snyder was a man who heard and answered a ``moral call'' to help the homeless. ``The fact that birds have a home, foxes have a home, and yet men and women, veterans of foreign wars, mothers and fathers, working poor people, have no place to lay their head _ he found that to be a moral disgrace,'' Jackson told about 600 mourners. Snyder's body was discovered Thursday hanging from an electrical cord in his private room at the Washington shelter he founded. A police statement called the death ``an apparent suicide.'' Dr. Georges Benjamin, the city's public health commissioner, said Snyder's death was the result of ``asphyxiation by hanging.'' Benjamin said investigators cannot pinpoint when Snyder died. The death has not yet been ruled a suicide, but Benjamin said there is no evidence of foul play. Police said a note containing ``suicidal references'' was found near Snyder's body, and law enforcement sources said the note outlined personal problems Snyder was having in his 15-year relationship with fellow homeless advocate Carol Fennelly. The two had said last month that they would be married in September. At the memorial service, Jackson described Snyder's dramatic efforts to draw attention to homelessness, which included hunger strikes and sit-ins. ``Mitch was a little eccentric, Mitch was a little off,'' Jackson said to appreciative laughs from the mourners, many of whom live at Snyder's shelter. ``But he was a man of justice. There's something to be said about being a little off.'' A close friend of Snyder's who spoke with him Tuesday described him as ``very down, very despondent.'' ``We talked for about an hour,'' said the friend, who asked not to be named. ``He was very upset about his relationship with Carol, very down in the dumps.'' Snyder's friend reflected on their conversation and then repeatedly called Snyder back to invite him to dinner. ``He didn't return calls Tuesday, or then on Wednesday, which I found strange,'' the friend said. Fennelly declined to discuss the situation after the memorial service. ``This just isn't the time,'' she said. A funeral is scheduled for Tuesday outside the shelter, which is located in a run-down neighborhood just half a mile from the U.S. Capitol. Jackson will preach at the service, and organizers said they are hoping that the Rev. Phillip Berrigan also will attend. Snyder credited Berrigan and his brother, Daniel, also a priest, with helping him turn his life around. Snyder met the Berrigans in a federal prison in 1973 while serving time on auto theft charge. The Berrigans were jailed for burning draft cards in anti-war protests, and quickly made Snyder a convert to their methods of social activism and non-violent protest. That commitment led Snyder first to the anti-war movement, and then to the cause of homelessness after he moved to the nation's capital in 1973. The gray, three-story building where Snyder's body was found symbolized the cause in which he achieved national prominence and the tactics he used in his fight. His group _ the Community for Creative Non-Violence _ was given the government building by the Reagan administration only after Snyder staged a hunger strike in 1984 to demand federal aid and publicize the plight of the homeless. Snyder once described President Ronald Reagan as a nice man who had ``mean-spirited'' politics. Mark Weinberg, the former president's spokesman, said from Los Angeles on Friday: ``President and Mrs. Reagan are saddened and extend their sympathy and prayers to (Snyder's) family and friends.'' After winning the government building, Snyder took his combative tactics to the national stage to publicize the problems of homeless. In 1986, officials in Santa Barbara, Calif., backed away from plans to ban sleeping in public places after Snyder threatened to lead a march of homeless people into the city. But Snyder had suffered defeats in recent months, particularly when the District of Columbia Council, citing budget pressures, scaled back a comprehensive law providing emergency shelter to all who requested it. He was also criticized for his attempts to prevent U.S. Census Bureau workers from interviewing homeless people. Snyder described the efforts of Census workers as ``government grandstanding.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-NATO-Summit Rdp
Summit Stage Moves To Houston
DOC.TEXT: The summit stage moved Friday to President Bush's hometown, where leaders of the world's seven largest industrialized nations will turn their attention to the economic configuration of the post-Cold War world. Houston was turned out in the summit nations' colors; flags sprouted on downtown skyscrapers and at the Rice University summit site. Painters hurried to put the finishing touches on spruced-up buildings. Last year's summit in Paris adjourned early when the leaders ran out of things to talk about. That's not likely to happen next week. Questions of direct economic aid to the Soviets, a contentious fight over farm subsidies and problems of global pollution were expected to dominate the negotiating sessions and working dinners, which get under way Monday. On many of the issues, the United States found itself at odds with the other summit countries _ Japan, West Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada. In many ways the Houston meeting will be a continuation of the talks Thursday and Friday at the NATO summit in London. Of the seven leaders, only Japan's Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu did not participate in the NATO meeting. As his first order of business, Bush was to hold private talks with Kaifu on Saturday. Officials said that in addition to briefing Kaifu on the outcome of the NATO meeting, the two leaders would cover the various economic issues coming up in Houston. High on the economic agenda will be the question of whether the West should supply a $15 billion to $20 billion aid package to bail out Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's floundering economic reform effort, an idea being pushed by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand. Bush repeated his objections to such aid on Friday, saying he has ``big problems'' in giving U.S. assistance as long as Moscow is spending billions of dollars annually in support for Cuba. But he appeared to open the door slightly to the possibility of extending some types of financial credits to the Soviets. Diplomatic sources said that Gorbachev had written an appeal for economic aid to British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who like Bush is against the proposal until the Soviets do more to reform their economy. Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney predicted the economic summit would make ``substantial progress'' in resolving the Soviet aid dispute. However, the most likely outcome was a vague statement of support which would not commit any specific amounts of money but would allow countries such as West Germany to offer their own aid packages. Bush has told reporters that his top priority at the economic summit would be breaking a logjam on agriculture trade which has deadlocked an effort to reform the rules governing world trade. The United States is pushing for agreement to phase out all trade-distorting farm subsidies over the next 10 years. But that idea has drawn strong opposition from European countries, whose leaders contend that such a proposal would cost the jobs of between 2 million and 3 million European farmers. The trade liberalization talks, known as the Uruguay Round for the country where they were launched in 1986, are scheduled to conclude in December, but U.S. officials fear they could falter without agreement on the agriculture question. The world leaders are also expected to consider a European proposal to cut back on ``greenhouse'' gases, forms of pollution which scientists fear are trapping too much heat from the sun and causing global climate changes. The U.S. position is that more needs to be known about the possible threat before committing billions of dollars to cleanup efforts. Before all the serious talks begin, the world leaders will be treated to a taste of Texas on Sunday night, complete with a rodeo, barbecue and a performance by the Grand Ol' Opry. Houston, a city that suffered through hard times during the oil price bust of the 1980s, raised $10 million in donations and assembled an army of volunteers to showcase Houston's economic resurrection for the expected 3,000 reporters from around the world. On Friday, painters were still at work in one of the meeting rooms to be used during the three days of talks at Rice University, a 4,000-student private university five miles from downtown. In deference to Houston's notorious summer weather, the outdoor arrival ceremony on Monday was shortened and a special platform was constructed to pipe cool air underneath the dignataries' seats.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes At Bus Terminal, Injures 27
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded Friday at a crowded black bus terminal, injuring 27 people in what appeared to be the work of right-wing extremists, authorities said. The bombing was the most serious of six explosions in the past week in Johannesburg. White extremists claimed responsibility for the previous blasts, but there was no such claim following Friday's explosion. ``The ultraright and neo-fascist forces ... are on the rampage,'' said the African National Congress, the country's largest black opposition group. ''The ANC demands that authorities disarm and disband the ultra-right groups.'' The bomb went off in the city center during the morning rush hour in an area where buses used by blacks let off and pick up passengers. Thousands of blacks from townships outside Johannesburg pass through the area every day. Police said the bomb hidden in a trash can sent pieces of concrete and debris hurtling through the air, hitting people standing in bus lines and passersby. Doctors said most of the injuries were relatively minor and just two of the 27 blacks treated at a local hospital were required to stay for additional treatment. Police said the blast looked like the work of right-wing white extremists. No arrests have been made. Three black mini-buses were were riddled with debris and about 15 other vehicles suffered lesser damage, witnesses said. ``We just heard a big noise, everyone scattered, people in the taxis got out and ran away,'' said Nhlandla Mbatha, who was waiting in a bus line when the bomb went off. ``There were rocks flying into the air. There was blood everywhere. People (were) screaming and crying.'' Some of the injured were buying food in nearby shops when they were hit by flying debris, witnesses said. ``Everything was clouded with smoke. I saw about six people running toward me with shredded clothing and some with no shoes,'' said shopkeeper Isha Charassi. Police cars and ambulances with wailing sirens rushed to the scene of the blast, the most serious since the bombing campaign began a week ago. Right-wing whites have expressed outrage at President F.W. de Klerk's stated plans to end apartheid and share power with the country's 30 million blacks. At present, the 5 million whites dominate politics and the economy. The previous bombs were aimed at whites involved in efforts to end apartheid, but caused no injuries and only minor damage. A shadowy group calling itself the White Wolves claimed responsibility. In other developments Friday: _ Police searched the home of Robert van Tonder, leader of the right-wing Boer State Party. No one was arrested, but police said they confiscated documents from the home outside Johannesburg. ``If they (the government) carry on this way, they can expect violence to escalate,'' an angry van Tonder said. _ Police said they arrested three ANC guerrillas allegedly planning to attack black rivals in the eastern province of Natal.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiations Set on New U.S.-Singapore Defense Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Negotiations will resume next week on final details of an agreement expanding U.S. access to military facilities in Singapore, the Pentagon said Friday. The proposed deal would not give the United States its own military base in Singapore, but it would greatly expand U.S. military activity in the Southeast Asian city-state, said Lt. Cmdr. Edward H. Lundquist, a Pentagon spokesman. Lundquist said no U.S. planes or ships would be based there permanently, but a small contingent of American military personnel _ probably fewer than 200 _ would be stationed at the Singapore facilities to keep them ready for U.S. use. Lundquist stressed that the proposed use of Singapore military facilities would not be a substitute for the larger U.S. forces at Clark Air Base and Subic Bay Naval Base in the Philippines. A military bases agreement between the United States and the Philippines expires next year, and the Bush administration is seeking to negotiate some form of continued use of those facilities. If the Singapore deal is concluded, U.S. F-16 fighter planes based elsewhere in Asia would be allowed to conduct occasional training missions in Singapore, and Navy ships could use Singapore's strategically located port, Lundquist said. The negotiations began early this year after Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew offered to permit greater U.S. access to his country's military facilities. The Los Angeles Times reported in Friday's editions that it was possible that a final agreement would be signed when Secretary of State James A. Baker III visits Singapore in August. Lundquist said he could not say how close the two sides were to final agreement, but that the remaining issues were mainly legal technicalities. He said a new round of talks was scheduled for next Wednesday through Friday in Washington. Lundquist said the main outstanding issue was the legal status of American military personnel who would be stationed in Singapore under the agreement. One open question, he said, was what rights the Americans would have in the event they were arrested on criminal charges. Singapore authorizes the death penalty for convicted drug traffickers. Singapore has one of the world's largest harbors. It lies in the strategic waterway through which Japan and South Korea get most of their oil from the Persian Gulf. Singapore is a member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, a regional organization whose other members are Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia and Brunei. The Philippines is the only ASEAN member hosting a permanent U.S. military base.

DOC.HEAD: A Taxing Tax Form
DOC.TEXT: One of the city's newest tax forms would tax even the kindest English teacher. Form D-1120 contains numerous misspellings and grammatical errors. The two-page form asks ``coproprtions'' to itemize ``deducations,'' to provide ``a list of address'' showing business ``locations(s)'' and to figure their total income subject ``ot'' tax. ``When we discovered the errors, it was too late in the procedure to do another printing,'' said Finance Director Bella Marshall. Kathy Wendler, president of the Southwest Detroit Business Association, said the form reflects poorly on the entire city. ``The way we handle the language is in some way perceived as a reflection of our ability to handle other situations,'' she said. ``Obviously, we all want to come off as looking good and competent and being able to do our jobs well.''

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Platform to Vote For Gorbachev and Hold Congress
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
LaserPhoto MOSB4
DOC.TEXT: Reformers of the minority Democratic Platform fraction said Friday they would vote to re-elect Mikhail S. Gorbachev as Communist Party leader, but they still planned to consider leaving the party in the fall. Considering ``all variations, we will have to support Gorbachev,'' Dmitri Karualov, a Democratic Platform member from Leningrad, told a news conference at the end of the fifth day of the 28th Soviet Communist Party Congress. Karualov said Alexander Yakovlev, a Politburo member and close adviser to Gorbachev, refused a Democratic Platform proposal to dispute the top party job. Left without any alternative, Democratic Platform, a radical pro-reform group within ther Communist Party, decided to support Gorbachev. Karualov said, however, he believed Gorbachev would likely become a ``hostage of the bureaucracy,'' unable to carry out further economic and political reforms. Democratic Platform had threatened to walk out of the congress, an act that would have caused the first split in the party since 1921. Karualov said the group would hold a congress in the fall to consider its future. He did not provide a date or any further details. The entire Democratic Platform delegation, however, still must make a final decision about whether to break away. Democratic Platform members are to meet with Gorbachev late Friday. Vladimir Lysenko, a faction leader, said he didn't expect any deep answers from Gorbachev and the meeting was unlikely to be a ``big spectacle.'' The movement, formed in January, has only about 100 of the 4,600 congress delegates, but its members say they have the support of 40 percent of the party rank-and-file. Democratic Platform supports calls for the party to divest itself of its massive wealth, an appeal that is unpopular with orthodox Communists. It also wants the party to give up its cells in the army and KGB. Leaders of the movement told reporters they were disappointed by the congress, the main task of which Lysenko said was to preserve status quo. ``These events don't make me very happy,'' Lysenko said. Vyacheslav Shostakovsky, another Democratic Platform leader, agreed: ``For me, nothing has been explained, nothing is happening, just as we predicted.'' He voiced concern that the party's conservative wing was gaining strength and could endanger perestroika, Gorbachev's reform program. He said the conservatives were drawing support from the party apparatus. Lysenko told a news conference that it was necessary to leave the Communist Party in its current form and to create a new political structure, but he gave no details.

DOC.HEAD: NEA Wants to Restructure Teacher Education
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the nation's largest teachers union focused attention Friday on ways to improve the training of America's future educators. Don Cameron, National Education Association executive director, said a teacher education reform initiative will begin in November to link universities and colleges of education with local school districts so innovative curriculum ideas and teaching techniques can be tried out in classrooms. ``Too often, teacher education programs seem rooted in the rarified air of academia rather than in the realities of the classroom,'' he said. Cameron said negotiations are under way with several colleges and universities, including the University of Maryland, Eastern Michigan University, the University of Delaware, several traditionally black institutions in the South and three colleges in Tennessee. Many school districts are enthusiastic about the idea, said Cameron. The program will be coordinated by Sharon Robinson, director of the NEA National Center for Innovation. She said the center will see that teacher education programs make sure future teachers can effectively use new classroom technologies, such as computers, and that their training includes the latest findings in educational research. ``Future teachers must be better prepared to help all their student think for themselves,'' said Cameron. ``Almost everybody agrees students must be better taught to analyze, synthesize and use knowledge.'' The announcement came one day after the 8,100 NEA delegates abandoned opposition to so-called alternative or non-traditional teacher certification and agreed to allow scientists, mathematicians and other mid-career professionals to teach while receiving the training needed to obtain a license. ``The initiative will not seek to impose any one particular model for teacher preparation on schools of education,'' said Cameron, pointing to Thursday's action as proof ``there can be many roads to licensure without the sacrifice of high standards.'' Arthur Wise, president of the National Council for the Accreditation of Teacher Education, said about 200,000 teachers are hired each year and the reform initiative should strengthen their preparation for the classroom. Wise said many of the criticisms of current programs are that they do not adequately prepare teachers academically and fail to provide rigorous teacher training or classroom methods. Before wrapping up its convention in Boston this week, the American Federation of Teachers announced a similar program. Officials selected Los Angeles, Minneapolis and Rochester, N.Y., as sites for helping educators determine the best ways for student teachers to learn new skills that can be adapted to restructured schools. Each site, selected from among proposals submitted jointly by teachers' unions, school districts and universities, will receive a one-year grant of about $30,000 from the Exxon Education Foundation for planning and preparation.

DOC.HEAD: Whitey Herzog Resigns as Manager of St. Louis Cards
LaserPhoto Planned
DOC.TEXT: Whitey Herzog resigned Friday as manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, saying he was embarrassed by a baseball team that he'd turned into one of the best of the 1980s. Herzog, who took the Cards to the World Series three times in his 11 years as manager, made the announcement at a news conference in San Diego, where his team was playing the Padres. ``I made up my mind in San Francisco,'' Herzog told reporters. ``I was totally embarrassed by the way our team played. I just feel very badly for the ballclub, the organization and the fans.'' The Cardinals, who won the World Series under Herzog in 1982 and were National League champions in 1985 and 1987, are 33-47 this season and in last place in the National League East, 14{ games behind the Pittsburgh Pirates. They beat the Padres on Thursday night 4-1. ``I am the manager, and I take full responsibility,'' said Herzog, who has won 822 games, second only to Red Schoendienst's 1,028 on the team's all-time list. Only Tommy Lasorda, who has managed the Los Angeles Dodgers since 1977, has been with the same team longer than Herzog among active managers. The team's top officials, president Fred Kuhlmann, general manager Dal Maxvill and executive vice president Mark Sauer, flew to California for the announcement.

DOC.HEAD: Cypriots Show Treasures From Famagusta
DOC.TEXT: Representatives of the government of Cyprus open an exhibit Saturday of old treasures from the neighborhood of Famagusta, a port city now held by Turkish Cypriots with the support of Turkish troops. Among the exhibits are 1,400-year-old Byzantine mosaics from the church of Panayia Kanakaria in the village of Lythrangomi. The show's catalog says the mosaics were removed from the church, taken to Europe and brought back there by the Cyprus Department of Antiquities for return to the island. Other mosaics from the same church came into the hands of a dealer in Indianapolis, Ind. Their future is still in the hands of U.S. courts. The show includes finds that go back more than 3,600 years: statues, paintings, jewelry, pottery, swords, coins and other objects. It will continue until Thursday at the Washington hotel that is the site of the 30th biennial Clergy-Laity Congress of the Greek Orthodox Diocese. It has been seen earlier on the Greek island of Rhodes and in London. No other U.S. stops have been announced. The exhibit has had invitations from West Germany, Sweden, the Soviet Union and other countries. The Turkish army invaded the northern part of the island in 1974. Greek-speaking Cypriots, usually barred from the area, say most of Famagusta has been deserted since 35,000 Greek speakers fled the city.

DOC.HEAD: Military Says Officer Accused of Cover Up Detained
DOC.TEXT: The military said Friday it had detained an officer accused of covering up the murder of six Jesuit priests, but the court that ordered his arrest said he had not been turned over. San Salvador's 4th Criminal Court ordered the arrest of Lt. Col. Camilo Hernandez on June 26. As late as Thursday, he was still in command at his elite infantry battalion. An armed forces spokesman on Friday said Hernandez had been detained. By law, he must be turned over to the court for arraignment. A spokesman for the court said that had not been done. ``Lt. Col. Hernandez has not been brought here, and we have not been advised of his arrest,'' said a court official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Hernandez is accused of burning of military log books that could have shed light on movement of troops implicated in the Nov. 16 murder of six Jesuit priest-educators, their housekeeper and her daughter. Hernandez denied the allegation in sworn testimony before the arrest warrant was issued. Armed forces spokesman Maj. Mauricio Chavez Caceres said the warrant for Hernandez' arrest was executed late Thursday. He said he did not know where the officer was being held. As a military officer, Hernandez will get special treatment after arraignment. Instead of being sent to prison to await trial, he will be confined to an apartment at the headquarters of one of El Salvador's police forces. All three police forces are part of the Defense Ministry. Though international human rights groups blame the armed forces or military-linked death squads for the abduction and murder of up to 30,000 suspected government opponents during a decade-old civil war, no officer has been convicted, or even tried, for human rights abuses. The priests were killed Nov. 16 during a major rebel offensive in the capital. The slayings provoked an international outcry and calls from some quarters in the U.S. Congress for a cut in American aid to El Salvador.

DOC.HEAD: Police Defend Violent Arrests; NAACP Wants Federal Probe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `She' in 6th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Black leaders on Friday called for a federal probe of the violent arrests that ended a Haitian protest. Police defended their actions and blamed the confrontation on well-organized agitators. Fifty-eight Haitian were arrested Thursday outside a Cuban-owned store when club-wielding police waded into demonstrators who had refused orders to disperse. Fourteen demonstrators were hospitalized but all were released by Friday. The crowd was protesting the alleged beating of a Haitian shopper by store employees in a dispute over a pair of pants last week, a sign of heightened tensions between blacks and Hispanics since Nelson Mandela's strife-ridden visit here. The local National Association for the Advancement of Colored People joined Haitian exile leaders at a boisterous news conference in Miami's Little Haiti neighborhood Friday to criticize the arrests and call for a Justice Department civil rights investigation. The NAACP was ``simply outraged by ... the excessive use of force that has been committed on our brothers and sisters,'' said local leader Johnnie McMillian. ``We do not want to see them treated as second-class citizens.'' She said the violence should be seen as an attack on all blacks, not just Haitians. Haitian exile leader Rev. Gerard Jean-Juste called for a boycott against the store where the beating allegedly occurred and, more broadly, against any business that treated Haitians poorly. ``The demonstrations in the Haitian community were initiated precisely because there has been an unfortunate pattern and history of violence directed against Haitians by Hispanic shopkeepers in our commnity,'' Jean-Juste said. ``This pattern of violence cannot and will not be tolerated.'' Ms. McMillian said the situation was aggravated by the decision of police to transport 32 of the people arrested to the Krome Avenue Detention Center run by the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service. Most were released, but seven remained there Friday facing possible deportation for lack of legal residence papers. The Krome center is a source of frustration for Haitians, who say that while Cuban-Americans are granted instant freedom when they arrive, Haitians are turned back at sea or confined in the detention camp. Miami city officials have kept a low profile since the first protests over the June 29 altercation at the Rapid Transit Factory Outlet clothing store. Although Cuban-born Mayor Xavier Suarez was elected with widespread black support, his snub of Mandela over the South African anti-apartheid leader's praise for Fidel Castro outraged many blacks. Only black Police Chief Perry Anderson has spoken publicly about the demonstrations, trying initially to calm Haitians. But on Friday he was defending his officers, saying police had simply been pushed too far. ``We begged, we pleaded, we negotiated'' before moving in, Anderson said. He accused some protest leaders of acting in bad faith. ``It's well-organized, and we're aware that some of the people doing this are bent on creating disturbances and creating a larger, blown-up situation,'' the chief said. All was calm at the shopping plaza housing the store Friday afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Jets Strike Two Palestinian Guerrilla Bases
DOC.TEXT: Israeli warplanes on Friday pounded two bases in Syrian-policed north and east Lebanon used by a radical Palestinian guerrilla faction, wounding at least eight guerrillas, police said. Police said the fighters from the Libyan-backed, Damascus-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command were wounded in simultaneous air attacks. In Israel, the military confirmed it raided two bases and said its planes returned safely. The four Israeli jet fighters targeted a base on the southern edge of the town of Sultan Yacoub in the eastern Bekaa valley and a base near the Palestinian refugee camp of Nahr el-Bared in northern Lebanon. Both regions are controlled by Syrian troops. Security sources in the south, speaking on condition of anonymity, said before the attacks, three Israeli warplanes flew patrols over southern Lebanon, dropping more than 1,300 flares to illuminate the sector that borders Israel. A police spokesman said three guerrillas were wounded in the raid on the base at Sultan Yacoub and five in Tal Hayat. The base at Sultan Yacoub housed an ammunition depot, a guerrilla training camp and a communications center, said the spokesman, who cannot be further identified in line with regulations. The base at Tal Hayat housed a naval command center. He said the jets scored direct hits on the bases, inflicting severe damage. The ammunition depot at Sultan Yacoub was set ablaze, generating a chain of explosions. The warplanes also dropped three delayed-action bombs at the Sultan Yacoub base, the latest of which exploded at 10:30 a.m., three hours after the air attack, the police spokesman said. He said no one was hurt in the later blasts, which went off after Lebanese Red Cross rescuers evacuated the wounded guerrillas. ``One of them is in critical condition. Another guerrilla lost a leg ... and the third has shrapnel wounds all over his body,'' he said. Palestinian guerrillas opened fire at the raiding jets with twin-barrelled 23mm anti-aircraft guns, but no hits were observed, the police spokesman said. The guerrilla group, led by Ahmed Jibril, has been blamed for a series of raids, including the Nov. 27, 1987, hang-glider attack on a northern Israeli army base that left six Israeli soldiers dead and eight wounded. Sultan Yacoub is about 24 miles north of the Israeli border. Nahr el-Bared is more than 100 miles north of Israel. Friday's air attack was Israel's 13th raid on Lebanon this year. By police count, 16 people were killed and 31 wounded in the 12 previous Israeli air strikes.

DOC.HEAD: Powell to Visit Mideast; Cheney Cuts Short Overseas Trip
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Colin L. Powell, the nation's top military officer, on Friday announced plans to visit five Mideast nations. In another development, the Pentagon said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was cutting short his current European trip. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, leaves Saturday from Andrews Air Force Base, Md., for Morocco and also will visit Tunisia, Egypt, Jordan and Israel for talks on regional security issues. He is scheduled to return to Washington on July 13. No other details of the trip were made public. The Pentagon said Cheney would skip planned visits to Spain and Portugal in order to return to Washington on Tuesday to participate in budget deliberations. Cheney was in Crete on Friday and was scheduled to travel to Greece on Sunday and Turkey on Monday before heading back to Washington on July 10. He originally was scheduled to return on July 14 after visiting Madrid and Lisbon. The Pentagon announcement said Cheney hoped to reschedule the Spain and Portugal visits for this fall.

DOC.HEAD: Task Force Says No Evidence Dealers Sold Stolen Pets
DOC.TEXT: An Agriculture Department task force reported Friday that licensed dog dealers the government has investigated in the Midwest have not knowingly engaged in selling stolen animals to research laboratories. But two dealers may be prosecuted for falsifying records, said James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service. ``After tracing many cases of sales of dogs to dealers, no evidence was found to indicate dealers were knowingly buying stolen animals,'' Glosser said. ``However, the task force did find evidence indicating that two dealers may have falsified records and that 29 individuals were dealing in the wholesale movement of dogs without the required license.'' The agency ``is considering prosecution of these licensed dealers'' and has issued warnings to those without licenses, he said. No names or locations of the animal dealers were released by the agency. The investigation began in April in response to allegations from private individuals, human groups and pet organizations that stolen pet dogs in the Midwest were being sold to research institutions through USDA-licensed ``Class B'' dealers. Those include dealers who buy and resell animals for regulated purposes. Although the investigation began with licensed dog dealers in Missouri and Arkansas, additional dealers were added in Illinois, Indiana and Tennessee for possible investigation, Glosser said. The task force also contacted state police and county sheriffs' offices for possible leads on stolen dogs, he said. Federal law _ the Animal Welfare Act _ requires every federal licensed or registered business, institution or agency to record the name and address of every person from whom it buys a dog or cat. Each dog and cat must have an identity number and description. Newly acquired animals must be held for five business days to facilitate tracing lost or stolen animals.

DOC.HEAD: Nurse Testifies Gang-Rape Victim Was Still Fighting at Hospital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents in 9th graf, `Bello also...'
DOC.TEXT: The Central Park jogger who was gang raped and beaten was fighting and thrashing so much when she was brought to a hospital she had to be restrained, an emergency room nurse testified Friday. Thomas Bello, 26, the nurse in charge of Metropolitan Hospital's emergency room when the woman was brought in around 2:30 a.m. on April 20, 1989, also gave the first testimony indicating the jogger was the victim of a sex attack. ``The patient was agitated,'' Bello said. ``She was fighting _ in a fighting response. She was swinging her arms and kicking her legs.'' Prosecutors estimate the jogger was attacked by a marauding gang of teen-agers five hours earlier, around 9:30 p.m., while running in the northern end of the park. The nurse said that as he and others began treating the woman, they wrapped gauze around her arms and legs and tied them to the bed. Despite her thrashing, the woman did not respond to voices or to being shaken, Bello said. ``She would only respond to deep pain,'' he added, such as a needle being pushed into her arm. The woman was covered in mud and blood and there was a deep gash in the back of her head, Bello said. He said he washed the victim's dirt and blood encrusted hair and her face as best he could. Bello also said there was swelling in her genital area. ``I also noticed there was debris'' around the genitals, the nurse said. Dr. Robert Kurtz, the surgeon who supervised the jogger's treatment at Metropolitan, testified Thursday that she had semen in her vagina, but he did not suggest there had been forced sex, and he was not asked about that. Bello also said he saw a 3-inch-long abrasion along the left inner thigh. After stabilizing the jogger, a doctor did tests to look for evidence of rape, Bello said. Samples were turned over to police. Bello was the 22nd prosecution witness to testify in Manhattan state court at the trial of Antron McCray, 15, Raymond Santana, 16, and Yusef Salaam, 16. All three are charged with attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, assault, robbery and riot in the attack on the woman and two male joggers, John Loughlin and David Lewis. The female jogger, an investment banker who is now 29, was gang-raped, savagely beaten and left near death. She survived, but suffered brain damage and has no recollection of what happened to her that night, the prosecutor has said. McCray, Santana and Salaam are on trial in an adult court, but if convicted they will be sentenced as juvenile offenders and receive up to 10 years in prison. Three other youths accused in the attacks are to stand trial on the same charges later this year.

DOC.HEAD: Wine Consumption Drops for Second Year
With AM-Wine Consumption-List
DOC.TEXT: New Hampshire bucked a national trend and was the only state to show a gain in wine consumption last year, according to a survey. Americans last year drank 2.11 gallons of wine per capita, the lowest consumption of any major wine-producing nation and a 5.8 percent drop from 1988, according to figures released Thursday by the trade publication Wines & Vines. By comparison, Americans over age 21 drank 33.7 gallons of beer, 2.16 gallons of distilled spirits, and about 35 gallons of coffee. Adult-only wine consumption was 3.03 gallons per capita. It was the second straight year wine consumption declined; in 1988 consumption dropped 5 percent from 1987 figures, Wines & Vines. Mississippi drank the least, a mere half-gallon per capita in 1989, and consumers in the District of Columbia the most at 5.55 gallons for every man, woman and child. Drinkers in California, New York and Washington, the top three wine-producing states, drank more wine than the average per capita intake. Reflecting a national trend against alcohol consumption, individual states posted figures showing as much as a 19.5 percent drop from 1988. That distinction went to Arizona, where a half-gallon less of wine was consumed last year than in 1988. Domestic table wines, still wines not over 14 percent alcohol, fell 2.6 percent while production of domestic champagnes dropped 6.3 percent. Last year marked the fourth straight year of decline for foreign champagne sales in this country; they were down 7.8 percent to 12 million gallons. In 1985, champagne imports to the United States hit a peak of 15.8 million gallons, almost all of it from Italy, France and Spain, which together produce more than half of the wine consumed in the world. California wines accounted for 72.8 percent of all wine consumed in the United States, while the other 42 wine-producing states held 12.6 percent of the market. The rest of the market, 14.6 percent, were imports. Wines & Vines blamed the market drop on the continuing loss of ground of generic or jug wines, nearly all of it produced in California's San Joaquin Valley, and a 16.7 percent dip in wine cooler sales. It was the second double-digit loss in two years for the coolers, sales phenomenon of the early 1980s that literally rescued California wine for several years. In 1988 and 1989, cooler sales fell 33.3 million gallons, falling from 21 percent of wine market share to 17 percent last year. Still, the coolers _ mostly cheap white wine, fruit juice and carbonated water _ represented one of six gallons of wine sold in this country last year. U.S. wine exports were up again in 1989 as foreign sales increased to a miniscule 22.1 million gallons in 1989 from 16.9 gallons in 1988. The top two markets are Canada, 5.7 million gallons, and Japan, 5.5 million gallons.

DOC.HEAD: Complaints Against Airlines At Record Low
DOC.TEXT: Consumer complaints to the government about airlines hit a five-year low in May, the Transportation Department said Friday. The department received 689 complaints for the month compared to 826 in April and 805 in May 1989, the department said. It said the peak of 7,280 came in August 1987 and the trend since then has been downward. Federal officials believe the trend reflects improved performance by the airlines, said department spokesman Hal Paris. Reports of mishandled baggage, however, were up slightly. The May average was 5.92 complaints for every 1,000 bags handled compared to 5.85 for April. The most common complaints concerned cancelled or delayed flights. May statistics showed 80.8 percent of all flights operated within 15 minutes of their scheduled time, compared to 82.2 percent in April. Delays caused by mechanical problems were not included. Southwest Airlines had the lowest complaint rate among major carriers for May, with 0.47 per 100,000 passengers. TWA had the highest with 4.62. America West was first in on-time arrivals, with 91.8 percent, followed by Alaska, Eastern, Pan Am, Southwest, Northwest, USAir, Delta, American, United, Continental and TWA. The department took over the job of counting complaints in 1985 from the now defunct Civil Aeronautics Board. The only complaints counted are those telephoned or mailed directly to the department in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Official: Bush Will Wait To Unveil Anti-Poverty Program
DOC.TEXT: President Bush probably will not make a final decision this year on the development of an anti-poverty program, an administration official said Friday. ``It could well go into next year before any final decisions are made,'' said a White House official, who spoke only on condition of anonymity. The news drew differing reactions from two experts asked by the White House to offer suggestions for shaping a federal anti-poverty policy. Isabell V. Sawhill of the Urban Institute said the administration ``went through a lot of effort and came up with a mouse'' in its slow approach to dealing with poverty. But Douglas J. Besharov of the conservative American Enterprise Institute, defended the administration, saying Bush was ``just not coming forward and saying, `I have a new program that will solve all the problems.''' Besharov and Sawhill were among outside experts summoned to the White House in September for a meeting on the poverty issue. Thirty-two million Americans live in poverty, as defined by the government. The issue had been studied by an inter-agency group convened last year and more recently by the administration's Domestic Policy Council. The official who spoke anonymously said, ``You may see in the shorter term some decisions that give an indication of the direction we are headed in, but there will be no final decisions for quite some time.'' Deputy White House Press Secretary Stephen Hart confirmed that Bush is waiting before deciding how to structure a program. ``Certainly no final decisions on what options should be considered by the president have been made. This is a long-term process,'' he said. Sawhill said, however, that she was ``frankly quite disappointed that they could not agree on an overall strategy. ``There were a lot of good ideas put forward, both from people who were consulted externally, and also ... within the administration,'' she added. ``I think it was a serious and worthy effort, but it seems to have fallen victim to some combination of ideology and budgetary pressures.'' But Besharov said that while some people might be disappointed by the administration's position, he believes the administration is ``in the process of a long-term examination of what could be done'' and waiting to unveil a program ``is probably the wisest thing to do at this point.'' He added, ``What is important is to improve the programs that are in place.'' Besharov said a number of proposals were considered during the administration's deliberations. They included: _ Having the government help residents of poor areas establish ``management corporations'' that would fight crime, attempt to improve schools and repair housing. _ Allocating a larger share of federal aid to high-poverty areas. _ Providing financial subsidies to job contractors to help them match up applicants from high poverty areas with job openings.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Science Couple Must Take Their Children To a Doctor
DOC.TEXT: A judge Friday placed a Christian Science couple on 10 years' probation for denying medical care for the dying son, and ordered periodic medical examinations for their other children. The couple, convicted of manslaughter in their son's death, said they would comply the order. ``We always tried to obey the law ... and we'll try to obey the judge's instructions,'' David Twitchell said after he and his wife, Ginger, were sentenced to 10 years' probation by Suffolk Superior Court Judge Sandra Hamlin. The Twitchells, lifelong Christian Scientists, were convicted by a jury July 4 of recklessly and wantonly causing the death of their 2{-year-old son Robyn by relying solely on prayer to heal the boy. Robyn died April 8, 1986, and an autopsy showed he suffered from a congenital defect that had caused a bowel obstruction. On Friday, Hamlin placed the Twitchells, who faced up to 20 years in prison, on 10 years' probation and said that they must take their three children to periodic health checkups under guidelines for children set by the American Medical Association. She said a doctor should be called at ``any signs of serious illness'' in the children _ Elias, 9 months old, Brian, 2 years old, and Jeremy, 8. Hamlin asked to receive monthly reports and said she would call for an immediate hearing if there were any violations of the conditions. Hamlin denied a defense motion to stay the sentence pending the outcome of an appeal, which was filed Thursday. Defense lawyer Steve Lyons said Friday the defense would appeal that denial next week. In a brief statement after the sentencing, Twitchell said that while he would obey the judge's order, he would ``always pray first'' for his children's health. ``We have never ruled out medical care. We just feel prayer, God's power, is a lot better,'' he said. Special prosecutor John Kiernan had asked for a ``very lengthy'' period of probation for the Twitchells, who now live in Brentwood, N.Y.; periodic medical checkups of their children; and that the couple perform community service ``designed to benefit young children.'' Suffolk County District Attorney Newman Flanagan said that the commonwealth decided to prosecute the Twitchells ``with the single intention of protecting the rights of children from neglect.'' The trial attracted national attention, in part because it was held in Boston, headquarters of the Christian Science Church. The church teaches that sickness and disease can be healed by spiritual means alone. Church officials have said the case represents an attack on their religion and expressed confidence it would be overturned on appeal. ``The decision to go forward with this case may not been considered a popular one,'' Flanagan said after the sentencing. ``However, we proceeded with this case in the hope that parents of all children, no matter what their religious beliefs, must be held responsible and accountable for providing their children with proper medical care.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Plant Explosion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The explosion that leveled an area the size of a city block at the Arco Chemical Co. plant Thursday night in Channelview, Texas, was heard twenty miles away. Here are some quotes from plant workers and others:

``We heard the explosion and started running,'' said Marlene Fiscus, who was working for a cleaning service at the plant. ``There was black smoke and flames in the unit right behind us. Had we been another 10 feet back, the explosion would have blown us away.''

``I seen a big flash cross in front of my eyes. I looked over to my left and I saw a big ball of fire. It looked to me like a tank run off, you know, like a rocket just took off,'' said Mike Zugel, a truck driver.
``I saw a circular red flash like an atomic bomb went off. The lights flickered, and then I heard a loud explosion,'' said Glenn Dickey Jr., who lives about a mile from the plant.

``In my 32 years with Arco Chemical Company, I can't remember any single accident of this dimension where we've had multiple loss of life to the extent we had here,'' said Jack Johnson, president of Arco Chemical of North America. ``It certainly is a time that all of the employees and myself grieve the loss of fellow employees. One loss of life is not acceptable.''

DOC.HEAD: Woman Claims She Repeatedly Sold Crack Cocaine to Mayor
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 9 grafs witness saying she brought cocaine to mayor at city building with job application; picks up 5th graf pvs, bgng ``He would; edits below to tighten
DOC.TEXT: An admitted cocaine addict testified in Marion Barry's drug and perjury trial Friday that she supplied crack cocaine to the mayor ``about 25 times'' in three months and brought it to him once along with a job application. Lydia Pearson, testifying with immunity from prosecution, said she delivered cocaine to Barry once at the office of Barry campaign manager Anita Bonds. ``He gave me the money'' for the crack and ``I gave him the'' application, she testified. Bonds was not there at the time. Pearson eventually did get a city job as a contract representative in public housing, but said she recently left it. Pearson, supporting statements by Rasheeda Moore, the former model who cooperated in the FBI undercover sting against Barry, said she supplied cocaine to the mayor from July-September of 1988 and lent the mayor her home for drug-smoking trysts. She said Barry would usually phone ahead from his official limousine to say he was coming. ``I would let him in the house,'' she said, I would give him a bag and he gave me money.'' She also delivered crack to Barry at two hotels after the mayor called her, she said. She said she usually brought three $30 bags, because ``that was his usual.'' ``He would give me $100, a lot of times he would give me the $10 change,'' she said. ``What did you do with the change?'' asked Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Roberts asked. ``Buy some crack,'' said the witness, who described herself as a recovering drug addict. Pearson said she never saw Barry using drugs. Moore testified earlier in the trial she and Barry used drugs more than 100 times, and that she got cocaine from Pearson for the mayor. Barry, 54, is facing trial on 10 charges of cocaine possession, one count of conspiracy and three felony charges of perjury. In another development, U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson reversed his earlier ruling and said Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan and Bishop George Stallings may attend the trial as long as they ``observe the proprieties of the court.'' Stallings sat with Barry's wife, Effi, in the second row of spectators on Friday. Farrakhan was not in court. Jackson reversed himself after an appeals court said spectators cannot be barred merely because they advocate a particular political or religious point of view. Pearson, a lifelong friend of Moore's, said Moore first brought Barry to her home in February 1988. On three occasions, she said, the mayor and Moore spent about an hour in the bedroom. ``Did you ever get high with the defendant?'' asked Roberts. ``No,'' she said. ``Did you ever see him get high on crack cocaine?'' ``No.'' Ms. Pearson said Barry came to her house for drugs when Miss Moore stopped coming in July 1988. The prosecution also introduced telephone records showing calls made from the mayor's limousine to Ms. Pearson's home. In other testimony, Barry's lawyers sought to cast doubt on the FBI's physical evidence, including laboratory tests and the pipe taken from the hotel room after Barry's arrest. An FBI laboratory technician testified that after Barry's arrest, his blood showed an alcohol content of only .005 percent, one-twentieth of the legal standard for intoxication. A videotape of the sting shows Barry's glass was refilled with alcohol at least three times. And FBI agent Frank O. Steele testified that investigators could not find critical evidence for 90 minutes after the Vista Hotel undercover sting. Steele said agents scoured the room for the pipe the mayor used to allegedly smoke crack cocaine and overlooked some of the cocaine used in the operation. Barry attorney Robert Mance played, again, the videotape of the sting operation, seeking to portray a clumsy search of the hotel room where Barry was arrested. ``There was concern that the crack pipe could not be located and to find it as fast as possible,'' said Steele, who said he learned of anxiety among FBI superiors over the pipe's location. Steele was in charge of evidence the night the three-term mayor was arrested. Steele said that in searching for the pipe, he went through the mayor's pin-striped suit jacket and did not notice what was later identified as cocaine in an inside pocket. He testified he finally found the pipe in an eyeglass case placed in a dresser drawer by Moore.

DOC.HEAD: Crackdown Forces Two Prominent Kenyan Lawyers Into Hiding
DOC.TEXT: Two prominent attorneys went into hiding during a growing government crackdown on critics of the one-party state, the lawyers' associates said Friday. The U.S. State Department asked the government not to persecute its opponents. It said it was ``distressed'' by the detentions of at least 11 people Wednesday and Thursday, according to the statement released by the U.S. Embassy in Nairobi. The two lawyers, Gibson Kamau Kuria and Paul Muite, disappeared Thursday after police detained four of their associates, the sources said on condition of anonymity. Kuria is an internationally known human rights lawyer, and Muite has joined in the call for multiparty democracy. Thursday's detentions brought to at least 11 the number of people seized since Wednesday in the crackdown. For months, the government had been criticizing those calling for reform. Associates said Kuria and Muite planned to spend the next few days organizing their personal and business affairs before either surrendering to police or allowing themselves to be arrested. Kuria's wife, Scholastica, said she had urged the men to seek asylum at the U.S. Embassy in Nairobi, but that they rejected the suggestion. ``They feel that if there is any fight, they should fight it here,'' she told The Associated Press in a telephone interview. Since the beginning of the year, a loose coalition emboldened by the changes in Eastern Europe has repeatedly accused the ruling Kenya African National Union party of intolerance, corruption and election-rigging. However, the government has rejected any move toward allowing other parties. President Daniel arap Moi says that multiparty politics would create ethnic strife among Kenya's 40 tribes and lead to tribal warfare. He had threatened arrests, vowing to hunt down advocates of multiparty democracy ``like rats.'' This week's arrests came amid rumors of plans for a pro-democracy rally on Saturday. The government has promised to prevent such a demonstration. Those detained include Raila Odinga, son of Kenya's first vice president; Gitobu Imanyara, a lawyer who edits a magazine critical of the government's human rights record; and two former Cabinet ministers, Kenneth Matiba and Charles Rubia. Matiba and Rubia have been at the forefront of the pro-democracy campaign. The government is holding them for up to 14 days without charge under public security statutes.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Policy Makers Believed Allowing Lower Interest Was Dangerous
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve policy makers concluded in their May meeting that inflation posed too great a danger to allow interest rates to decline, minutes of the meeting released Friday show. The 8-week-old records were made available amid signs that the policy makers decided at their most recent gathering on Monday and Tuesday to shift their policy and stand ready to nudge interest rates lower if the economy weakens further. Unidentified government officials were quoted by The Wall Street Journal Friday as saying they believed the directive adopted earlier this week allows a relaxation of the tight credit policy if additional signs of economic sluggishness emerge. Analysts were split over whether the June employment report released Friday by the Labor Department provided such evidence. The unemployment rate slipped from 5.3 percent to 5.2 percent, but non-farm job growth was a weaker-than-expected 40,000. In May, members of the Federal Open Market Committee voted 10-1 to maintain the existing credit policy and directed central bank officials to be equally ready to raise or lower rates, depending on developments on inflation and economic growth. Members agreed that ``current information on business conditions pointed on balance to relatively moderate but sustained economic expansion.'' At the same time, the members ``generally agreed that the prospects for significant reductions in inflation pressures during the quarters immediately ahead were not promising.'' Lee Hoskins, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland and a prominent advocate of a tough anti-inflation policy, voted against the directive. He argued for a tighter credit policy ``to help assure that progress would be made toward a reduced rate of inflation.'' Hoskins said tighter credit would ``enhance the credibility and effectiveness of monetary policy in countering the persisting strength of inflationary pressures,'' according to the minutes. Other members, who were not identified, went along with the directive but said ``the need to contain and ultimately to reduce inflation might well require a firming of policy at some point.'' The Federal Reserve has been fighting inflation with higher interest rates since early 1988. In mid-1989 it began nudging rates down amid concern the economy might topple into a recession. However, since late December, the Fed has held steady. The federal funds rate, the interest charged among banks for overnight loans, has been 8.25 percent since then. In recent weeks, Bush administration officials, who are counting on continued economic growth to bolster Republican chances during the November congressional elections, have stepped up public pressure on the central bank to lower rates. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told reporters Thursday that the Fed should not wait for a budget deficit reduction agreement between the administration and Congress, but should lower rates now to counter any dampening effects of higher taxes and less government spending. ``It seems to me that it's not a wise idea to emphasize an undying, forever, attack on inflation if it jeopardizes growth in this country,'' he said. The open market committee, comprised of the seven Fed governors and five of the system's 12 regional bank presidents, meets in secret eight times a year to formulate monetary policy. Minutes are released about six weeks later, a few days following the next meeting. There was one vacancy among the governors at the time of the May meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says U.S. May Call for Ban on Drift Net Fishing
DOC.TEXT: The United Nations should move to ban drift net fishing in the open seas if the practice continues to kill fish, sea birds and dolphins at the rate shown in a study, a U.S. official said Friday. The deaths ``from high seas drift netting continue to be of great concern to the United States,'' said William Fox, assistant administrator for fisheries at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. ``I believe we need the statistically reliable sampling that a program to be conducted this year will give us. But I also believe that if the trend shown in last year's pilot program continues, the United Nations must insist on an immediate moratorium of this practice,'' said Fox. NOAA released a preliminary report summarizing figures for catches reported by nine U.S., five Canadian and 32 Japanese observers aboard high-seas drift net vessels from June to December of last year. The study was conducted by agreement between the United States, Japan and Canada, he said. The Commerce Department agency reported 59,060 albacore tuna, 58,100 blue sharks, 9,173 sea birds and 914 dolphins were captured incidental to fishing operations. Rep. Jolene Unsoeld, D-Wash., said the numbers ``confirm my worst fears _ wholesale destruction of our marine resources.'' ``Perhaps most distressing, this new data has been withheld from the public and Congress for the past six months while the administration negotiated with these foreign countries to conduct more studies,'' she said. ``We don't need more studies. We need to ban high seas drift nets.'' The agency said the pilot project covered only 4 percent of the Japanese commercial squid drift net fishery and did not include vessels from South Korea or Taiwan and so is not conclusive for the entire fishery. The program is scheduled to expand this year to cover the Korean and Taiwanese drift net fleets and to have additional observers in the Japanese fleet. Altogether, the agency said, there will be three times as many observers as in the pilot program last year. The United Nations, with U.S. support, has already recommended a ban on large scale open sea drift net fishing beginning in mid-1992. Drift nets of up to 30 miles long have been used increasingly by Japan, Taiwan and South Korea in recent years to catch squid. The incidental catch of other species, especially salmon that originate in the United States, has caused protests from the American fishing industry. In 1987, Congress required the Commerce Department and State Department to negotiate monitoring and enforcement agreements with nations engaged in drift net fishing in the North Pacific. Agreements for a two-year phased monitoring program were signed last year. The nets are invisible to sea life as they float from a cork line, scooping down as deep as 50 feet. Sen. Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska, said earlier that the NOAA data was based on reports from observers who boarded only 32 boats in the 460-boat Japanese fleet. The House has approved a bill that would ban drift net fishing and a similar measure has cleared the Senate Commerce Committee. Tina Harper, a director in the Washington office of the Environmental Investigation Agency, a London-based conservation group, said that organization's study showed 100,000 dolphins killed every year in drift nets. She said an analysis based on a U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization report indicated the figure could be between 300,000 and a million.

DOC.HEAD: Iliescu Resigns from Ruling Party
DOC.TEXT: President Ion Iliescu resigned Friday from the National Salvation Front, the party that was swept to power by the December revolution and led to victory by Iliescu in the May national elections. The Front, under the charismatic leadership of Iliescu and Prime Minister Petre Roman, has dominated government since December's violent ouster of communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Iliescu resigned from the party to conform with a temporary electoral law enacted by the former provisional parliament that stipulates that the president cannot be a leader of a political party. Although the law does not apply to ministers, Foreign Minister Adrian Nastase joined Iliescu in resigning from the party Friday. A communique issued by the Front said the party will be led by its five vice presidents until a congress expected in September, when a new party president will be chosen to replace Iliescu. The five are Bogdan Patrascu, N.S. Dumitru, Sorin Vornicu, Claudiu Iordache and Constantin Costescu. Patrascu said the party would be willing to ``discuss Iliescu's readmittance'' if he should ever again wish to run for national president. Although bitterly opposed by many intellectuals and accused by opposition members of being a neo-Communist, Iliescu received more than 80 percent of the vote in the race for the national presidency. In another development, the Romania Libera daily newspaper ran a front-page appeal for concrete steps leading towards the reunification of Soviet Moldavia and Romania. The communique, signed by six organizations favoring reunification, also called for free movement across the frontier. The Soviet Union occupied Bessarabia, then a part of Romania in June, 1940, and annexed it as the Soviet Republic of Moldavia. Demands for the return of the region have increased since the ouster of the communists and a corresponding rise in nationalism. The government has been cool to the idea of reunification, but the media have increasingly promoted the concept.

DOC.HEAD: Deadline Nearing For Drought-Hit Farmers To Refund Advances
DOC.TEXT: Time is running out for farmers to refund up to $400 million in advance crop subsidies they received from the federal government in 1988 and 1989 when they were hit by drought. The oft-delayed deadline for giving back the advance deficiency payments is July 31, and no change in the repayment date is likely this time. The deadline already has been put off three times, and Sen. Kent Conrad, D-N.D., tried unsuccessfully this spring to get Congress to forgive the debt for some farmers who faced drought again this year. ``It's something Kent tried very, very hard to accomplish but wasn't able to do so,'' said Conrad's press secretary, Laurie Boeder. County offices of the Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service are to send notices later this month to the farmers who owe the refunds, said ASCS spokesman Ray Wagoner. Each spring, the Agriculture Department will advance to farmers 40 percent of the deficiency payments they expect to receive that year for wheat, corn and other crops in the government farm program. However, if market prices rise during the year, as they did during 1988 and 1989, and the deficiency payments are smaller than projected, the farmers are required to refund the overpayments. USDA estimates that farmers who lost crops to the 1988 and 1989 droughts owe $403 million in refunds. Corn growers owe $210 million and wheat producers owe $89 million. Conrad, who believes the total is more like $200 million, tried twice in May to amend an emergency appropriations bill to write off the $30.8 million in refunds he predicted would be owed by farmers who are likely to go through drought again this year. The forgiveness would have applied only to advances that farmers received for crops that were never produced because of the drought. Farmers would still owe refunds on crops they produced. ``Many of these people virtually have no opportunity to pay back the advanced deficiency payments which they have received,'' said Sen. Tom Daschle, D-S.D., during one of the debates. In arguing for his amendment, Conrad said there probably would not be another bill that could reach the president's desk in time to beat the deadline. ``He's still looking for a vehicle that might get through the process in time,'' Boeder said this week. Although the deadline is July 31, USDA will not charge interest on the amount it is owed for 30 days, Boeder said. For the next 90 days, the government will charge 9 percent interest. After that, the rate goes to 12 percent, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Won't Make Mayoral Endorsement
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry said Friday that he will endorse none of the five Democrats vying for his job and urged his loyalists to back whatever candidate they choose. ``What I've decided to do ... is not make any public endorsement,'' Barry told about 100 supporters gathered outside the federal courthouse where his drug and perjury trial is being held. ``Those (supporters) who feel compelled to move on can do so.'' Top city government sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the mayor realized that his shrinking number of supporters already were making their own choices. ``He knows that his organization is already beginning to slip away,'' said one of the mayor's top political advisers. ``At this point, he doesn't have much to deliver anyway.'' Barry refused to rule out the possibility of making an endorsement in the future, but said that for now, ``I am busy with my trial in the courtroom here.'' Barry announced on June 13 that he would not seek a fourth term while battling the criminal charges. The 54-year-old mayor has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. Five candidates are seeking the Democratic nomination. Since his January drug arrest, Barry had said he hoped to play a role in picking his successor if he decided not to enter the race. But as Barry's drug trial _ with its allegations of cocaine use and sexual promiscuity _ has continued, candidates have distanced themselves from him. At the same time, several of Barry's top loyalists have begun talking on their own with other campaigns, sources close to the mayor's camp said. Rank-and-file precinct workers have also jumped to other campaigns in recent weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Fireworks By Mother Nature
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell over the central part of the nation Friday, and hot weather snapped temperature records up to 88 years old in the Southeast. Showers and thunderstorms extended over Illinois, Missouri, Kansas, Iowa and Nebraska, from east-central Texas to the upper and central Texas coast, and in Montana, Washington state and New Mexico. Showers and thunderstorms also were scattered over southern Florida, Arkansas and Louisiana, and from Tennessee into South Carolina. Heavier rainfall during the 6 hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included about an inch at Grand Island, Neb., and Vichy, Mo. The temperature climbed to 104 degrees in Augusta, Ga., breaking the record for the date of 102 that had stood since 1902. It was 99 in Charleston, S.C., where the old mark of 96 was set in 1980. The low for the Lower 48 states was 29 degrees in Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 58 degrees in San Simeon, Calif., to 104 in Columbia, S.C., and Needles, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Gov't Will Ease Measures Against Palestinians
DOC.TEXT: Israel's new defense minister intends to reduce the military's presence in the occupied lands in an effort to break the stalemated peace process and avoid talks with the PLO, a report said Friday. The Hebrew-language daily Yediot Ahronot said the move by Defense Minister Moshe Arens is also aimed at avoiding a possible cutback in U.S. aid that is feared if the peace process does not progress. Defense Ministry spokesman Dan Naveh refused to confirm or deny the newspaper report. If confirmed, the relaxation would be a major departure from pledges by the new right-wing government to increase military measures to combat Palestinian unrest in the occupied territories. The plan is being prepared by Arens as it becomes apparent that the U.S.-supported idea of preliminary Israeli-Palestinian peace talks in Cairo has failed, wrote Ron Ben-Yishai, a respected military commentator. Israeli hard-liners have rejected the American proposal, fearing it would mean negotiations with PLO representatives. Israel views the Palestine Liberation Organization as a terrorist organization but Palestinians insist the PLO is their sole legitimate representative. The Bush administration has shown an increasing impatience with Israel's reluctance to begin the preliminary talks. Bush, speaking Friday at a press conference at the conclusion of the two-day NATO summit in London, urged Israel to take action. ``There has got to be talks ... and we have got to go forward,'' he said. I'd like to think that Israel would now move forward again.'' The newspaper report said Arens wants to bypass the talks and PLO participation by initiating a series of confidence-building measures in the occupied territories that would culminate in municipal elections. Arens reportedly said he hopes to then enter into direct negotiations with elected city officials over Israeli proposals to grant Palestinians limited autonomy, Ben-Yishai said. According to Yediot, the confidence-building measures include a partial troop pullback from Palestinian population centers, a long-standing demand by Palestinian leaders. Naveh said such a pullback was not ruled out. ``Our prescence in towns and refugee camps is contingent on the level of Palestinian violence,'' he said. Late last month, Arens ordered troops redeployed along main roads in the occupied territories, emphasizing travel security for Jewish settlers at the expense of patrols in Palestinian towns. He has made a number of other good-will gestures in recent weeks. Two colleges were opened by the army last month, and two others are due to open next week. The army closed Palestinian universities and colleges shortly after the start of the 30-month uprising, contending they were hotbeds of unrest. In other developments, two Palestinians suspected of collaborating with Israeli authorities were discovered dead in the occupied territories.
