In a village near the occupied West Bank town of Tulkarem the body of 45-year-old Khaled Mustafa Toubeh was discovered, Arab reporters said. They said Toubeh had been kidnapped by masked Palestinian activists in May and was slain on suspicion of cooperating with Israeli authorities. The army said it was checking the report. In the occupied Gaza Strip, 22-year-old Fadi Abu Aziz, was found dead Thursday, the English-language Jerusalem Post newspaper reported. The paper said he was killed on suspicion of cooperating with Israeli authorities. The deaths raise the number of suspected collaborators killed by fellow Palestinians to 232. At least 721 Palestinians have also died of Israeli gunfire during the uprising, and 45 Israelis have been slain.

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Police Attack Demonstrators; Asylum-Seekers Jam Embassies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with additional demonstration, new quotes by Communist chief, higher figures for asylum-seekers. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FRA9
DOC.TEXT: Police attacked demonstrators Friday in Albania's capital near the embassy district, where up to 4,000 asylum-seekers jammed diplomatic missions. Albania's Communist boss offered no ``generosity'' for defectors. About 10,000 Albanians gathered in a central square, following earlier protests demanding that leaders of the last hard-line Communist nation in Eastern Europe adopt major reforms, according to a sketchy report from Tirana by the Austria Press Agency. This rally remained silent, however. Some demonstrators on its periphery scattered when police charged, only to regroup, according to the Austrian agency, which reported no injuries. The APA reporter _ one of the few foreign correspondents in Albania _ witnessed no other attacks. The clash occurred in Skanderbeg Square, not far from a sealed-off area of Tirana containing embassies that became havens for Albanians last week. Diplomats said more than 2,300 Albanians were holed up inside more than a dozen embassies. One Western diplomat contacted in Tirana from Athens put the number at up to 4,000, and reported grave food and water supply problems. At a crisis meeting of the Communist Party Central Comittee, party leader Ramiz Alia assailed the refuge-seekers and made clear Albania's Communists were not thinking of yielding power. ``What is of fundamental importance is the fact that the masses should be led by the party,'' said Alia, in comments reported by Albania's state ATA news agency. ``There is no room for generosity'' in dealing with those who refused to leave the embassies, he said. ``The aims and actions of these destructive, anti-democratic and anti-Albanian forces go too far. We may be poor, undoubtedly we have difficulties and shortages, but the foreigner has never solved our troubles.'' Under 45 years of hard-line Communist rule, travel for average Albanians has been virtually impossible as the country's late leader, Enver Hoxha, steered his 3.2 million people into increasing isolation. But under Alia, who took over after Hoxha's death in 1985, the country has increasingly sought ties abroad and has begun implementing some cautious reforms. Alia has given no hint the leadership was considering any form of political plurality of the kind now in place in formerly monolithic Communist countries in Europe. Alia pledged continued reforms Friday but said only the Communist Party could ``realize the genuine democracy, the human rights, the country's progress and the defense of its freedom and independence.'' He promised a new election law, but strongly implied it would not affect the Communist Party's monopoly on power. The meeting will continue Saturday. The rush on the embassies continued Friday, even after the government repeated a pledge to issue travel documents for everyone seeking to leave the country. Many Albanians with passports and exit visas were seeking entry visas from the various embassies. Some came and left during the day; others, mistrustful of their government's pledges, joined those already holed up for days, said diplomats. The diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said conditions were getting worse inside some of the embassies. West German officials in Bonn said well over 1,000 asylum-seekers were in their Tirana embassy. An employee of the Italian Embassy in Tirana said the number there had grown to 700 by evening. Other officials said the French Embassy held 400 and the Polish and Czechoslovak embassies about 50 each. Authorities have rebuffed attempts by foreign governments to send supplies. Refugees began fleeing into the West German Embassy on Sunday night. Albanian guards shot and wounded two of them that night, the Bonn Foreign Ministry said. It said from 30 to 40 asylum-seekers were injured Monday night as they crashed their truck into the West German compound to gain entry. An Italian Embassy employee reached from Rome described the situation on the crowded embassy grounds as ``more tragic than comic. ... This is an embassy designed for 10 people, you can imagine what conditions are like.'' APA said embassies were growing short of food and medicine. A Hungarian diplomat, describing the situation in the neighboring French mission, said it was jammed, with many sleeping in the embassy garden. The sometimes violent rush to the embassies follows last year's exodus of East Germans to embassies in other East European countries shortly before the fall of East Germany's hard-line government. The Albanian Foreign Ministry on Thursday promised to grant passports to those who have sought refuge in foreign embassies in a desperate attempt to flee their homeland. Hundreds more continued to gather outside embassies and gained entry to embassy compounds. West German and Hungarian diplomats said police were not preventing people from approaching their embassies and were allowing relatives to talk to the refugees through embassy compound fences. A package of new regulations, entitling all Albanians over the age of 16 to own a passport for foreign travel, took effect Tuesday. It did not check the flow of asylum-seekers. Most of the Albanians who fled to foreign embassies before Thursday entered in a rush during rioting that began Monday under fire from Albanian security forces. Diplomats said at least three people were wounded. ATA denied there were casualties.

DOC.HEAD: Cleaning Crew Had More Workers to Chemical Plant During Explosion
With AM-Plant Explosion Bjt
DOC.TEXT: More people than normal were at work in a section of a chemical plant that exploded into flames, killing 17 people, because a contract cleaning crew was on the job. Some terrified workers at the Arco Chemical Co. plant were able to flee to safety. ``We were running through the mud just as fast as we could get out of there,'' said Tommy McBridge, a plant worker who survived the blast late Thursday. ``We knew what it was.'' ``We just heard a big explosion and everybody said `Run!' and we all took off,'' said Marlene Viscus, another plant worker. A one-block area of the Arco plant exploded and burned for four hours before firefighters doused the flames. Ordinarily, only about five of the 50 Arco employees working at the plant at that time would have been in the area of the explosion, manager Earl McCaleb said. The others were contract cleaning workers from Austin Industrial Inc., who were in for work done sporadically at the plant. ``We use some contract workers in the plant for certain operations,'' said Earle Bradford, vice president of public affairs at Arco Chemical's headquarters in Newtown, Pa. He said he was unaware of any problems occurring when contract workers were used. The Oil, Chemical & Atomic Workers union has been critical of petroleum companies' use of contract workers. Last year, a Phillips Petroleum Co. plant in nearby Pasadena exploded, killing 23 Phillips and contract workers and injuring 130 others. Union officials said the use of contract workers, unfamiliar with operations, contributed to safety hazards at the plant. The plant, Arco Chemical's largest, produces intermediate chemicals used in the manufacture of seat cushions, bedding, paints and urethane packaging and gasoline additives, Bradford said. The plant provides about 560 million pounds of propylene oxide, a ``building block'' chemical used to make seat cushions and bedding, and 1.3 billion pounds of styrene monomer used to make drinking cups and automotive parts each year. In addition, the plant produces about 20,000 barrels a day of methyl tertiary butyl ether, a gasoline additive used as an octane enhancer. Arco is the world's largest producer of MTBE, said Al Greenstein, spokesman for Los Angeles-based Arco, parent company of Arco Chemical. ``It's not the only MTBE plant, but we are the world's largest manufacturer of MTBE and this is obviously a major plant for MTBE,'' Greenstein said. The plant originally was built as Oxirane Chemical Co., a joint venture between Arco Chemical Co. and Halcon International, in 1974 with production beginning in 1977. Halcon sold its interest to Arco Chemical in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Hearing Adjourned On Nazi Rocket Scientist
DOC.TEXT: An immigration hearing for Arthur Rudolph, an 83-year-old U.S. rocket scientist and alleged Nazi war criminal, was postponed Friday after a dispute over who could attend the hearing. The hearing is to determine whether Rudolph can remain in Canada as a visitor. Rudolph, who was chief coordinator of the U.S. space agency's Saturn V rocket program that put the first man on the moon, was detained on his arrival Sunday from West Germany and ordered to appear at an immigration hearing. Rudolph left the United States in 1984 in a deal with the U.S. government. He renounced his U.S. citizenship and admitted his complicity in war crimes, according to the U.S. Office of Special Investigation. That allowed him to keep his pension from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. He went to West Germany, where a government attempt to prosecute him for war crimes failed to turn up enough evidence. Rudolph now says he was coerced into the agreement to leave the United States and wants to return to clear his name. Rudolph appeared before Anthony Iozzo, an adjudicator for the Canadian immigration service. But in nearly three hours of debate, the only topic was whether the news media and two Jewish organizations would be able to attend and who would get the 14 chairs reserved for spectators in the tiny hearing room. Rudolph's attorney, Barbara Kulaszka, moved for adjournment, citing her client's fatigue and her need to study documents just given to her by the three federal attorneys presenting the government's case at the hearing. The next session was set for Wednesday. On advice from his lawyer, Rudolph refused to speak to reporters, as did his wife and daughter. U.S. immigration officials had accused Rudolph of working thousands of slave laborers to death to building V-2 missiles for the Nazis during World War II. Rudolph, a former Nazi party member, says he did not persecute laborers during his work on V-2s.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Leader Ousts Ex-Communists, Pleads for Restraint
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS two grafs for final graf to UPDATE with three of four nominees approved; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Faced with complaints from Lech Walesa and other critics, the prime minister Friday expelled three ex-Communists from his Cabinet and pleaded for political calm. But Tadeusz Mazowiecki failed to soften the attacks on his government, which is struggling to introduce a market economy and complete the transition to democracy. Even members of the prime minister's Solidarity camp said they expected bolder moves to restructure his 10-month-old Solidarity-led government. Mazowiecki accepted the resignations of five of 24 Cabinet ministers, including three of the four former Communists who were included in the government last year as the price for Solidarity taking power. The most prominent former Communists who departed were Interior Minister Czeslaw Kiszczak and Defense Minister Florian Siwicki. The prime minister used most of his parliamentary address to warn against ``party quarrels and struggles for personal ambitions at the expense of the state.'' He said they could rob Poland of its ``priceless stability.'' The remarks appeared to be a reference to Walesa, the Polish labor hero who led the fight against the old Communist regime. Many people now believe Walesa would like to succeed President Wojciech Jaruzelski, another former Communist, as leader of Poland. In his speech, Mazowiecki declared: ``I see danger on the peaceful Polish road to democracy. ``The sense of responsibility for the country is getting weaker in political life. ... An opponent who should be defeated through argument is treated as an enemy to be destroyed,'' he said. ``These are occurrences that cannot be tolerated even in the most democratic country. I appeal for self-control. Poland needs wisdom, peace and law-abidingness.'' The prime minister appeared to be responding to criticism by Walesa in ousting the ex-Communists and calling for parliamentary elections ``much earlier'' than spring 1991, when they have been scheduled. Walesa had no comment on Mazowiecki's nationally broadcast speech. The Solidarity chairman has struck a populist chord with his attacks on Mazowiecki. He has urged faster replacement of Communists in the government and state-run industries, new elections to remove Communists still in the parliament, and quicker privatization of state enterprise. Legislators kept up their attacks on the government after Friday's speech. Sen. Jaroslaw Kaczynki said he was only ``30 percent satisfied with the changes.'' Kaczynki is a Walesa ally. ``The changes are much too small. He should have reconstructed the whole government,' said Deputy Jan Litynski, a Mazowiecki supporter. Litynski and other deputies interviewed urged fully free parliamentary elections as soon as possible. Mazowiecki's Cabinet made history Sept. 12 when it was seated as the East bloc's first non-Communist government. But it has been beset by difficulties. The government has faced a major rail strike, used police to break up two farm protests and defended itself against a steady stream of criticism from Walesa. The Cabinet changes finally take the police and military forces out of the hands of former Communists. Gen. Kiszczak's departure ends a 10-year career as interior minister. He oversaw the imposition of martial law to crush Solidarity under Gen. Jaruzelski in 1981, and he served as a chairman of the 1989 talks that made Solidarity legal again. Gen. Siwicki, another Jaruzelski loyalist, had been defense minister since 1983. The third ex-Communist to be ousted was Transport Minister Franciszek Wieladek. Also resigning were Agriculture Minister Czeslaw Janicki of the Peasant Party and Telecommunications Minister Marek Kucharski of the Democratic Party. The prime minister nominated four replacements. Parliament accepted Krzysztof Kozlowski, a Roman Catholic editor who has been serving as deputy interior minister, as head of that ministry; Rear Adm. Piotr Kolodziejczyk, the Navy chief, as defense minister; and Ewaryst Waligorski, a longtime Solidarity activist and deputy to the transport minister, as the head of that ministry. Artur Balazs, the minister of rural life and co-founder of the farmers' union Rural Solidarity, was nominated for agriculture minister, but failed to win committee approval because of Peasant Party demands that the post go to their group.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes in Central London, None Injured
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded in a garbage can near a busy thoroughfare in central London Friday morning, and a second device was found and disarmed, Scotland Yard said. No injuries were reported. The Irish Republican Army, which has bombed British targets as part of its campaign to drive British troops out of Northern Ireland, issued a statement saying it had no connection with the incidents. The morning explosion was reported outside a bank near Waterloo Bridge at 7:15 a.m. The explosion was about a mile east of Lancaster House, where heads of state of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization were concluding a two-day summit meeting. Commander George Churchill-Coleman, head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch, was at the scene and a spokeswoman for Scotland Yard confirmed that there was ``some kind of explosive device.'' ``There was a minimal amount of damage. I am told there was no damage to buildings and no casualties,'' said the spokeswoman, speaking on condition of anonymity. The second bomb was discovered in a household matchbox behind an office of El Al, Israel's national airline, and next door to a fur shop, police said. Bomb disposal experts defused the bomb.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslavia Warns Republic To Retract Declaration of Autonomy
With AM-Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: The nation's leadership Friday warned the republic of Slovenia to abandon its declaration of regional autonomy, saying it threatens Yugoslavia's federation. The country's eight-member presidential council said it ``will take all measures ... to protect the integrity and sovereignty'' of Yugoslavia, the state news agency Tanjug reported. However, the announcement did not elaborate. Slovenia's new, freely elected legislature proclaimed its autonomy on Monday. The move was viewed as a further challege to Yugoslavia's fragile Communist-ruled federation. The authority of the federal leadership has effectively been crippled since non-Communist, center-right parties won elections this year in Slovenia and Croatia, another liberal republic. It was the first free balloting in Yugoslavia in 50 years. Slovenia and Croatia are demanding a looser national confederation. The current federation of six republics and two autonomous provinces already allows each region to run its own government and Communist party structure. The decentralized system of government was devised by the late national leader Josip Broz Tito in the 1974 constitution. The arrangement was intended to prevent one republic from gaining sway over the others, but ethnic and economic differences are again threatening the country's unity. In its statement Friday, the presidencial council said the Slovenian declaration jeopardizes ``collective Yugoslav interests and the country's position in the world.'' The Slovenian declaration calls for the establishment of an independent legal system that would take precedence over federal laws. It also says Slovenian authorities should assert control over all armed forces stationed on the republic's territory.

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopian Boy Found Two Days After Jumping Off Ship
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Abrehem'' cq
DOC.TEXT: A teen-age stowaway who three times jumped ship in a bid to remain in the United States swam two miles to a Navy cargo ship and apparently boarded by climbing an anchor chain, officials said Friday. He was sent right back to the ship that is his unwilling host. Abrehem Selemon, 14, of Ethiopia, had been reported missing Wednesday after he jumped from the merchant ship Pearl while it was anchored 3{ miles off Morehead City. A Coast Guard search was suspended when no sign of the youth was found. He was discovered early Friday aboard the Navy cargo ship Major Stephen Pless, which had been anchored 2 miles from the Pearl when Selemon jumped into the Atlantic. ``I don't want to speculate, but the only thing that could have happened is that he swam to the ship and climbed up the anchor line,'' said Coast Guard Ensign Charles Murphy. Selemon and a companion have been traveling the world at the expense of a ship that doesn't want them. Selemon and Melles Aklilu Kassa, 30, have been on board the Pearl, off and on, at least since before it left Syria loaded with oil on May 22, said Bill D'Andrea, an agent with Curz Moran Shipping Agents in Philadelphia, the firm that contracted for the ship's visit to that city. ``As each port of call was reached, the captain went through the motions of trying to get them off,'' said D'Andrea. ``They tried sending them ashore in Trinidad; Gibralter; Naples, Italy, and some other ports, but they didn't succeed.'' Under U.S. immigration law, stowaways are the responsibility of the ship on which they are found, said Immigration and Naturalization Service agent Charles Van Der Miller. Where, when and why the two boarded the Pearl was a mystery. But Selemon was back on the ship Friday after being transferred from the Pless. ``He is in safe custody aboard my vessel,'' Glenn Pereira, captain of the Pearl, said Friday in a ship-to-shore telephone interview. He would not elaborate about the teen-ager's condition. ``That's all the information I can give you,'' he said. ``I'm not permitted by management to give any statements.'' INS officials declined to disclose Selemon's reasons for seeking asylum, citing confidentiality regulations. Selemon had jumped from the Pearl, a Norwegian-registered merchant ship managed by a Hong Kong firm, June 17 when it was docked in Philadelphia, INS officials said. An INS hearing was held in which Selemon asked for political asylum, said Van Der Miller, in Philadelphia. The request was denied and Selemon was ordered returned to the Pearl. Selemon jumped from the ship again when it was docked in Wilmington, Del., and he was caught in New Jersey, Van Der Miller said. No other details of that incident were available. Where the voyagers are headed next is unknown. Pereira said he was awaiting orders from the ship's owners regarding his next port of call. D'Andrea was sympathetic _ but for the Pearl's captain. ``I feel sorry for him,'' D'Andrea said. ``He had a real busy voyage up here and things like this only make it more difficult.''

DOC.HEAD: First 10 Acres for Super Collider Project Purchased
DOC.TEXT: The state bought its first 10-acre parcel of land Friday for construction of the superconducting super collider, a mammoth $8 billion atom smasher. More than 16,000 acres still have to be acquired from more than 700 Ellis County landowners just south of Dallas for the world's largest scientific instrument. The collider will be a 54-mile underground ring, in which protons will be accelerated to nearly the speed of light while superconducting magnets force them to travel a circle. Two groups of protons will be smashed together; scientists hope the resulting wreckage of subatomic particles will offer new clues to the fundamentals of matter. The first parcel was sold by retired banker E.R. Tut Morris and his wife Tommie Morris of the Dallas suburb of Balch Springs for $45,000. The Morrises drew applause when they removed a ``Contract Pending'' banner from a sign, revealing ``Contract Sold'' underneath. ``I think it's a good thing for the history of the U.S. and for Ellis County and Dallas County,'' said Morris. ``We're very pleased with the price.'' The land was purchased for the state by the Texas National Research Laboratory Commission, which proposed the Ellis County site for the collider to the U.S. Department of Energy. Ownership eventually will be transferred to the federal government. The government is expected to spend $40 million to $100 million for 10,000 acres of land and rights to the land underneath an additional 7,000 acres. Acquisition is expected to be completed in 1992. Phillip Stafford, associate director for site development, said the commission hasn't yet encountered landowners unwilling to sell. ``The process anticipates that there will be those who may not be a willing seller,'' Stafford said. ``Our commission and other state agencies or federal agencies have the power of eminent domain to ensure the project is not held up for those reasons.'' Hoyt Gaston, who owns 100 acres, says he'll be willing to sell ``if the price is right.'' ``I'll be satisfied if I get a deal as good as (Morris) got,'' he said. Gaston is expecting an appraisal on his land in about a month. In May, the House voted to build the collider and limited the federal government's share in the giant science project to $5 billion. Costs above $5 billion would be left to Texas, which has pledged $1 billion, and other sources, including foreign investors. The collider, scheduled to be completed in 1998, is expected to provide 4,500 jobs during construction and 2,500 permanently.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion at Texas Chemical Plant Kills 17
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, ``Assistant U.S.,'' with 2 grafs to update with arrival of assistant labor secretary, comments; picks up 9th graf, `People as ....' SUBS 17th graf, `Henry Kelley ...,' with two grafs to UPDATE with all injured released from hospitals, CORRECT name to Austin Industrial, sted Austin Industries; picks up 18th graf, `The plant ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HTX1, HTX112, LaserColor HTX101, LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: An explosion that could be heard 20 miles away leveled an area the size of a city block at a chemical plant, killing 17 people and injuring five others, authorities said Friday. ``It looks like a bomb went off in there,'' said Richard Bailey, chief investigator for the Harris County Sheriff's Department Arson Division. A tank exploded at about 11:30 p.m. Thursday at the plant about 15 miles east of Houston. The resulting fire was out by dawn. Company firefighters sprayed the area as other workers pulled bodies from tons of twisted pipe and debris. ``In my 32 years with Arco Chemical Company, I can't remember any single accident of this dimension where we've had multiple loss of life to the extent we had here,'' said Jack Johnson, president of Arco Chemical of North America. ``It certainly is a time that all of the employees and myself grieve the loss of fellow employees. One loss of life is not acceptable.'' Assistant U.S. Secretary of Labor Gerard F. Scannell arrived at the plant Friday afternoon to lead a federal investigation of the accident. Scannell said the Occupational Safety and Health Administration would conduct a comprehensive inspection. ``I'm concerned when there is any loss of life. We are concerned with what's happening in the petrochemical industry,'' Scannell told reporters. People as far as 20 miles away reported hearing the blast at the plant, which has more than 350 employees. ``I seen a big flash cross in front of my eyes. I looked over to my left and I saw a big ball of fire. ... It looked to me like a tank run off, you know, like a rocket just took off,'' said Mike Zugel, a truck driver. ``I was in a trailer and I was sitting down about to get up, and it sounded like a car ran into the side of the trailer,'' said Tommy McBridge, who was working at a janitorial service not far from the plant. ``When we went out of there, it was like a nuclear explosion _ just orange flames.'' ``It sounded like somebody was breaking the house in,'' said Deborah Baumbach, who lives six miles from the blast site. Plant Manager Earl McCaleb said two tanks that collected waste water and chemicals exploded for an unknown reason. The larger tank held 900,000 gallons, he said. The company had no capacity figure for the smaller tank. ``They were not cleaning out the tank,'' McCaleb said. A truck of the sort used to remove wastes was in the area of the tanks but it was not immediately known if it had anything to do with the explosion, McCaleb said. One body was discovered in the cab of the truck, officials said. Kathryn Cox, a member of the plant cleaning crew, said she and several fellow workers had just finished their jobs when they heard the explosion. ``We didn't look back,'' she said. ``We just started running and we just kept running.'' The body found in the truck was that of an employee of a contractor. Of the other bodies found by midday Friday, five were Arco Chemical employees, and 11 were employed by a contractor, Austin Industrial Inc. of Houston. All five of the injured were treated at hospitals and released, Johnson said. Henry Kelly, president of Austin Industrial, said his company had 150 workers at the plant for maintenance and construction. He said it has had an excellent safety record during 5{ years working there. The plant had one safety citation, received in 1988 for a death at an off-site fire training building, McCaleb said. Initially, authorities described Thursday night's blast as relatively minor and said no injuries were reported and no evacuations necessary. McCaleb said there was no attempt to withhold information. It was the second major loss of life at a Houston-area petrochemical plant in nine months. On Oct. 23, a Phillips Petroleum Co. plastics plant in Pasadena was hit by series of explosions that killed 23 workers and injured 130. On June 8, two people were injured in a spectacular explosion and fire at a chemical packaging plant in Pearland, south of Houston. Arco Chemical, which is based outside Philadelphia, has been running the Channelview plant since 1980, three years after it went into operation. The plant produces 560 million pounds of propylene oxide, used to make flexible foam for seat cushions and bedding. The substance also is used for cleaning compounds, according to a company brochure. The plant also annually produces 1.3 billion pounds of styrene monomer, used for insulation, foam drinking cups, packaging materials and automotive parts, and 1.7 billion pounds of methyl tertiary butyl ether, a high octane blending component used as a replacement for lead in gasoline. McCaleb said four of the injured workers were treated at a hospital and released. One was admitted to a hospital in nearby Baytown.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Valdez to Return to Service As `Exxon Mediterranean'
DOC.BYLINE: With PM-Oil Tankers, Bjt ^By DAVID SEDENO
DOC.TEXT: The tanker Exxon Valdez, source of the nation's worst oil spill, is headed back to sea after repairs to its shredded hull. But it won't be going back to Alaska and its name will be changed, officials said Friday. The vessel that spilled nearly 11 million gallons in Alaska's Prince William Sound will be called the Exxon Mediterranean when it returns to duty, due next month, said Exxon Shipping Co. President Gus Elmer. ``Due to declining Alaskan crude oil, the vessel will enter foreign service, most likely loading crude in the Mediterranean or the Middle East. It is consistent with our policy that the vessels be named according to their location,'' Elmer said. He declined to say that the environmental disaster in Alaska 16 months ago was a major factor in renaming the vessel and changing its use. ``It is strictly an economics decision,'' he said. Alaska environmental commissioner Dennis Kelso, however, said he believes the name change is due as much to public relations as economics. ``I think the key question is what kind of tankers do we have operating worldwide?'' Kelso said. ``The accident happened here, but it could have happened in Puget Sound or San Francisco Bay _ wherever tankers transport crude or its byproducts. ``What broke down here was the system and the tanker was part of it.'' Former Exxon Shipping Co. President Frank Iarossi acknowledged concerns that the ship's association with the disaster may make it unwelcome in Alaskan ports. He said last summer that the tanker might be renamed and possibly put to work elsewhere. The tanker ran aground on a reef on March 24, 1989, ripping the bottom of its hull open and spilling oil that polluted hundreds of miles of coastline and killed scores of animals. The 987-foot ship has been undergoing $30 million in repairs since August in a National Steel and Shipbuilding Co. dry dock in San Diego. The company built the ship in 1986. ``The ship's ready. She's going smoothly,'' said National Steel spokesman Fred Hallett. ``We're finishing the painting on it right now and we're doing some work in the machinery room.'' A Coast Guard inspector, Lt. Bill Uberti, said National Steel is scheduled to begin two weeks of trial runs after it is floated out of dry dock on July 20. ``If there's a problem, they'll have to fix it before it can go out into service, but I don't anticipate any problems,'' Uberti said. ``The only damage to the ship was structurally, and that's all been fixed.'' The repair work included installation of 3,000 tons of new, inch-thick steel hull plates on the 30,000-ton tanker. The ship had a single hull, meaning only one layer of steel stood between its cargo and the open water. Exxon officials declined to retrofit the ship with a double hull because it was not feasible from an engineering standpoint, Exxon spokeswoman Carrie Chasin said in March. But Hallett said the ship could have been fitted with a double hull. ``The question is the cost and the time,'' he said. Kelso said he favors double hulls. ``The fact the Exxon Valdez is being reassigned _ I expect it will always be known by its former name and bottom _ leads to the question, do we have vessels operating worldwide that have all the protection they should have?'' the Alaskan official said.

DOC.HEAD: NEA Theater Panel Denounces Rejection of Grants
DOC.TEXT: A National Endowment for the Arts advisory panel has denounced the agency's rejection of four grant recommendations, and is urging reconsideration of the decision, the panel chairman said Friday. ``I think it is really an issue of censorship,'' said Phillip Arnoult, founder and artistic director of The Theatre Project, a performing arts center in Baltimore. The panel that advises the NEA on financing solo performing artists met by conference call Thursday, and plans to issue a statement Wednesday in New York. Arnoult had originally asked the NEA to reconvene the panel so panel members could resign in protest if they chose. No panel members have quit so far. Arnoult refused to discuss the statement the panel plans to issue, but he said at least two of those whose recommended grants were vetoed would be present. The NEA accepted the panel's recommendation of 14 other grants. In protest of the rejection of the four grants, one recipient, Rachel Rosenthal, refused her grant for $11,250 last week. Arnoult said he did not know if any of the other 13 would renounce the money. They may follow New York performance artist Richard Elovich's suggestion that each of the grantees donate part of their money to the four, Arnoult said. The rejection of solo performance grants, announced June 29, has created a furor in the arts world and prompted calls for the resignation of NEA Chairman John E. Frohnmayer. Some critics contend that Frohnmayer vetoed the grants to try to pacify Congress members outraged by the federal financing of provocative works. Congress is scheduled to debate NEA's funding this month. Some lawmakers are calling for the agency's abolition. Jessica Andrews, director of the endowment's theater program, declined to comment Friday. Frohnmayer also had no comment. The four artists who did not receive grants recommended by the advisory panel are Karen Finley, Holly Hughes, John Fleck and Tom Miller. The grants ranged from $5,000 to $11,250 each. Miller, Finley, Hughes and Fleck all deal with political and sexual issues in provocative ways. Fleck urinated or appeared to urinate onstage during one performance. Finley, whose work has been singled out for criticism by many conservatives, in a recent series of performances disrobed, placed alfalfa sprouts in her crotch and denounced conservative Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., among others. Helms leads the drive to control NEA funds. He was instrumental in the adoption of anti-obscenity restrictions attached to NEA's 1990 appropriation, which was approved amid protests over works such as Robert Mapplethorpe's homoerotic photography and Andres Serrano's crucifix submerged in urine, both of which received federal funds. Arnoult said Frohnmayer's action overturned a 25-year tradition of peer review, and described past awards of grants as ``statesmanlike.'' ``While I'm deeply concerned about the careers and reputations of these four artists ... I'm also very concerned about the moral center of the endowment which has worked for 25 years _ which represents a massive amount of public service in the field,'' Arnoult said. According to endowment records, in seven years before 1989, the chairman has reversed advisory panels' recommendations on only 35 of 33,700 grants. ``The process is so clearly being politically manipulated and that's just wrong. It censors some of the most talented artists in the country,'' said William George, producing director of Touchstone Theater in Bethlehem, Pa., and a member of the panel chaired by Arnoult. ``You kind of feel a little helpless.''

DOC.HEAD: Honduras To Pay Families of Disappeared
DOC.TEXT: The government will pay $700,000 to the families of two victims of rightist death squads, President Rafael Leonardo Callejas said Friday. Callejas, who took office on Jan. 27, said the payments were obligations from the past that must be honored. ``These situations are disagreeable and you have to forget about them,'' he told The Associated Press. ``They are things of the past and now we are facing the challenge of the future.'' The legislature approved $625,000 for the family of Manfredo Velasquez Rodriguez, a 28-year-old economist, and $75,000 for the family of Saul Godinez Cruz, 32, an elementary education teacher, the amounts ordered by the Inter-American Human Rights Court in Costa Rica. The court, created by the Organization of the American States, ruled both died at the hands of killers ``acting under the protection'' of the government. The case was brought by the Honduran Human Rights Commission, which blamed the murders on military death squads who preyed on suspected leftists. Velasquez Rodriguez was last seen being arrested on Sept. 12, 1981. He had recently graduated from the National University, where he was a student leader. Godinez Cruz was last seen being picked up on July 22, 1982. They were among at least 300 people who human rights organizations say died at the hands of death squads between 1979 and 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Precede LONDON
Bush Basks in Historic NATO Summit Declaration
With AM-NATO Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 8 grafs new to reflect Bush arrival, comment; pickup 7th graf pvs: ``NATO has
DOC.TEXT: President Bush arrived in his adopted hometown with a smile Friday night after ushering his ideas for reshaping the Western military alliance to quick and easy approval at the NATO summit in London. Aboard Air Force One enroute to Houston and another round of summitry, this time with the leaders of the seven most industrialized nations, Bush boasted that the ``London Declaration,'' the communique issued earlier in the day by the NATO leaders, ``was the United States draft.'' And ``that shaped the new direction for NATO,'' he said. In London, it was Bush who announced at the conclusion of the two days of talks among the 16 allied leaders that ``I'm pleased ... that my colleagues and I have begun a major transformation of the North Atlantic Alliance, and we view it as a historic turning point.'' The president's design for a remodeled Western alliance gained unusually easy approval, but he remained in the minority opposed to direct financial aid to the Soviet Union. Most European NATO members say such aid would help stabilize a deteriorating Soviet economy and send a positive political signal. Bush, for his part, ruled out any direct assistance pending changes in Soviet military spending and its huge support for Cuba, but he indicated the United States might be willing to accord the Kremlin some trading credits. The Soviet aid question is bound to be a major topic at the Houston economic summit. During the 10-hour flight, Bush was informed that Eduard Shevardnadze, the Soviet foreign minister, had said that NATO's ``decisions ... move in the right direction and pave the way to a safe future for the entire European continent.'' The president said of that reaction: ``That's very interesting. And very positive.'' Bush confided he had received a recent communication from Soviet Leader Mickhail S. Gorbachev himself. But he merely winked and smiled when asked to describe its contents. In London, Bush achieved his goal of preserving _ at least for now _ a NATO that is the main instrument of U.S. influence in Europe while pushing it toward changes that could make it more acceptable to the Soviet Union. ``NATO has set a new path for peace,'' Bush said. ``It's kept the peace for 40 years, and today charted a new course for stability and cooperation in Europe.'' France in particular has promoted the idea of diluting the influence of both military blocs _ NATO and the nearly dead Warsaw Pact that the Soviets dominated throughout the Cold War. Paris wants a pan-European organization such as the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to play a bigger role. Bush said the London meeting reaffirmed that NATO would survive, and that while it would relax its military stance it would continue to rely on the U.S. nuclear arsenal. ``This is indeed a day of renewal for the Atlantic community,'' Bush said. For more than 40 years we've looked for this day ... and now that day is here and all peoples from the Atlantic to the Urals, from the Baltic to the Adriatic can share in its promise.'' The president managed to overcome initial skepticism from Britain on his idea of modifying NATO's nuclear strategy and declare that nuclear arms are ``weapons of last resort.'' But he remained at odds with West Germany and France on the question of whether to provide direct financial aid to the Soviet Union. ``I have big problems with that one,'' Bush said, adding that he did not think the American public would accept sending money to Moscow as long as Soviet defense spending remained high and the Kremlin continued underwriting Fidel Castro's government in Cuba. Bush added, however, that he would not stand in the way of other NATO countries that wished to aid the Soviets, whose economy is in a shambles. West Germany has suggested a $15 billion Western aid package for Moscow. The matter is expected to be discussed in more detail at the Houston economic summit. ``If the Germans decide they want to do that, that's their business, but I have made very clear to those who have spoken to me about this at this juncture, we have some serious problems and I have not been under any false colors about that at all,'' Bush said. Bush also acknowledged that he faced growing opposition in Congress to keeping a large U.S. troop presence in Europe. He said the NATO reforms adopted at the London meeting could help him persuade his critics that the troops are necessary. ``I view it as my responsibility to make clear to the American taxpayer why it is in our interest to help keep the peace. And that's exactly what these forces are engaged in,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Fang Lizhi Accuses U.S. of Double Standard on Human Rights
DOC.TEXT: Fang Lizhi, the Chinese dissident who took refuge for a year in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing, said the United States has a double standard on human rights. In an interview with NBC News, he said the United States was less demanding of China on human rights issues than of other countries, but added, ``Of course, they are better than before.'' The West generally has less knowledge about China's human rights record that it does of Eastern Europe's and the Soviet Union's record, he said. The interview, conducted Thursday in London, was broadcast in part on Friday's ``NBC Nightly News.'' Fang, an astrophysicist and China's best known dissident, and his wife _ fellow dissident and physicist Li Shuxian _ took refuge in the embassy after the Chinese army put down pro-democracy demonstrations on June 3-4, 1989, killing hundreds, perhaps thousands, of people. Chinese authorities accused them of encouraging the protests and issued a warrant for their arrest, but finally allowed them to leave on June 24 for England, where Fang will be a visiting fellow at Cambridge University. Bush, speaking Friday at a news conference in London during the NATO summit there, was asked about Fang's remarks alleging a double standard. ``I don't agree with that. I notice some of my critics in the United States Congress say that, and I think they are just as wrong as they can be,'' Bush said. He said the United States had taken the lead in condemning the abuse of human rights in the suppression of the pro-democracy movement in China. Fang also spoke Friday with CBS News after his son, Fang Zhe, an undergraduate at Beijing University, arrived in London from China. Now that all of his family members are out of China, Fang, who has another son attending Wayne State University in Detroit, felt free to speak out. In an interview scheduled for broadcast Sunday on NBC's ``Meet the Press,'' he said he expects democratic change in China within the next decade. China's leadership wants economic openness, but is trying at the same time to ``resist the worldwide trend toward democracy and freedom,'' Fang said. Fang said the world is ``getting smaller and mutual influences are getting progressively stronger,'' and so the democratic reforms under way in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union are certain to affect China.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Share of Education Costs Drops
With AM-Teachers
DOC.TEXT: The federal government's share of public school costs dropped by one-third the last decade, the nation's largest teachers' union said Friday. A report by the National Education Association showed the federal government paid 6.3 percent of the total dollar for public elementary and secondary schools this year, compared to 9.2 percent in 1980. With the declining federal support, the report noted that state and local governments in 1989-90 added all but about $500 million to the $11 billion growth in school revenues over 1988-89. According to the report, school revenues are reaching the $200 billion mark. The 5.9 percent increase is the lowest since 1983 and leaves virtually no room to meet the costs of school reform and restructuring because it nearly matches projected expenditures, the report showed. Also, the report said there will be about 3.5 million additional students by the end of the decade. Local school districts picked up 56 percent of new school revenues in 1989-90. The states developed almost 40 percent of new school revenues while the federal government contributed 4 percent, said the report. ``The history of the relative federal contribution to school support is on the decline throughout the 1980s. Congressional action to reduce the national deficit will likely exert a continuing downward pressure on the federal government's share of public school finances and therefore increase pressure on state and local governments to meet the expanding financial needs of public education,'' the survey said. Local revenues, mostly from property taxes, account for 50 percent or more of school revenues in 20 states. A breakdown by percentage includes 89.6 in New Hampshire, 70.8 in Nebraska, 66.9 in Oregon, 63.4 in South Dakota, 60.6 in Virginia, 59.3 in Nevada, 59 in Michigan, 58.2 in Vermont, 57 in Colorado and 56.8 in Wisconsin. Also, 56.4 in Missouri, 56.3 in Maryland, 54.7 in New Jersey, 54.4 in Illinois, 53.2 in Massachusetts, 51.8 in Rhode Island, 51.7 in New York, 51.6 in Connecticut, 51.5 in Kansas and 50.2 in Arizona.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Gets 27 Year To Life for Murder of Daughter's Alleged Supplier
DOC.TEXT: A mother was sentenced Friday to 27 years to life in prison for the murder of a man she claimed was providing her daughter with drugs. Superior Court Judge Margaret Grignon imposed the maximum sentence possible on Belita Fox, 41, for the Aug. 29 shooting of Kevin Furman, 23. Ms. Fox was convicted June 7 of first-degree murder. Deputy District Attorney Robert Foltz argued that Ms. Fox was dangerous and should be imprisoned for as long as possible. Ms. Fox's attorney, Vincent James Oliver, said he would appeal. Furman's mother, Jean Furman, said even the maximum penalty dissatisfied her. ``Belita Fox is where she belongs,'' she added. ``However, nothing can satisfy me. That's the most that she can get. But she's left a lot of hurt behind. ``It's not over. I'll never have my son back.'' During the trial, Ms. Fox testified that she shot Furman because her daughter, Cheryl Wilson, then 17, had a heart murmur that could be aggravated by drugs. The night before the murder, Ms. Fox was seen drinking in bars and told friends that she planned to kill a man who was supplying drugs to her daughter. Early the next morning, she picked up a .38-caliber revolver at her home and drove to Furman's home. She argued with a woman at the home, then shot Furman three times. Ms. Fox then called her daughter from Furman's bedroom and later dialed 911 to report the murder.

DOC.HEAD: Argentina to Resume Interest Payments on Foreign Debt
DOC.TEXT: The government will begin monthly payments of $40 million to creditor banks that have lent the country 1,000 times that sum, the president of Citibank in Argentina said Friday. Two-thirds of Argentina's foreign debt of $60 billion plus $6.5 billion in overdue interest is owed to commercial banks. The largest creditors include Manufacturers Hanover, Chase Manhattan and Citibank. ``Sometime before the end of the day it (payment) will take place,'' Citibank's local president, Ricardo Handley, told the independent Radio Mitre. The announcement coincided with the arrival Friday of Michel Camdessus, director-general of the International Monetary Fund. The last payment was made in May. That $40 million was the first interest payment in two years. The government of President Carlos Menem wants to negotiate a debt reduction, lower interest rates and new funds with its creditors. Central Bank President Javier Gonzalez Fraga plans to fly to New York in late July to resume talks on those issues. A steering committee representing private banks has insisted that significant payments be made on overdue interest before debt reduction or fresh loans will be considered. A director of another U.S. bank, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the banks want payments of $100 million a month. He added that the banks believed Argentina is capable of such payments. Central Bank director Roque Fernandez said Thursday that foreign reserves, which were little more than $100 million when Menem was inaugurated in July 1989 now top $2.1 billion. The government on Friday reported the cost of living rose by 13.9 percent in June and a total of 716 percent for the first six months of this year. The monthly rate was a disappointment to the government, which had hoped to hold the cost of living increase to a single digit for the first time since November. The government has committed itself with the IMF to reduce monthly inflation to 2 percent by December. Argentina has suffered triple-digit annual inflation in 15 of the past 16 years. Last year, inflation soared to 4,924 percent. Also Friday, Argentina and Brazil pledged to remove all barriers to bilateral trade by Dec. 31, 1994. Trade between South America's two largest countries amounted to $2 billion in 1989, with Argentina posting a $401 million surplus. Trade in 1988 totaled $1.7 billion, with Brazil posting a $364 million surplus.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Carrier Departs Japan With Protesters Following It
DOC.TEXT: Greenpeace protesters in a yacht Friday shadowed the U.S. aircraft carrier Midway to publicize claims that the Navy covered up the cause of an on-board fire that killed two crew members, an activist said. Navy officials have said the June 20 blast occurred as a fire-fighting crew opened a hatch to investigate smoke in an emergency equipment room. They said the room is near pipes carrying steam for the ship's plane-launching catapult system. But Faith Doherty, a spokeswoman for the Greenpeace environmental group, claimed the U.S. military had not satisfactorily answered citizens' questions about the cause of the fire. Some Japanese was worried about the fire because of concerns the ship might be carrying nuclear weapons. Under U.S. policy, U.S. officials refuse to comment on what craft is carrying such arms. The protesters followed the 67,000-ton carrier Friday in a 35-foot yacht as the ship left its home port of Yokosuka, near Tokyo. Senior Chief Petty Officer Gary Gunderson, a Navy spokesman, said the carrier was leaving for routine operations in the Pacific. He said the cause of the explosion was still under investigation. Ms. Doherty said she and six other protesters from the United States and other countries met the Midway in their yacht at the mouth of Yokosuka bay, near Tokyo. She said they displayed displayed anti-nuclear signs. She said their actions were intended to protest both the Navy's handling of the fire and the transport of nuclear weapons into Japan.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs. LEADS with 4 grafs with House vote, Senate now expected to vote on override; picks up 3rd graf pvs, `The measure ...' Restores byline.
DOC.TEXT: The Louisiana House on Friday night voted to override Gov. Buddy Roemer's veto of the nation's strongest state abortion bill, which contains no exceptions for rape or incest. The vote was 72-30, two more votes than needed for a House veto override. The state Senate was expected to vote later Friday on overriding the veto Roemer issued earlier in the day. If the Senate also voted to override, it would be the first time a Louisiana governor has had a veto overridden this century. The measure would send doctors who perform abortions to jail for up to 10 years and fined them up to $100,000. It was written for the purpose of challenging the 1973 Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion. Also Friday, anti-abortion activists in Michigan filed petitions with more than 330,000 signatures to initiate a bill that would require girls to have a parent's consent before obtaining an abortion. Roemer signed the veto Friday morning, according to his staff attorney, John Kennedy. In his veto message, Roemer called the issue ``one of the most wrenching and divisive issues to be faced by this Legislature.'' He also responded to charges by backers of the bill that he has changed his position on abortion since he was a congressman, running for governor, in 1987. ``As a member of Congress, I consistently voted to curb abortion on demand and to protect the life of a fetus,'' Roemer wrote in the veto message. ``I initially voted for the exception to save the life of a mother, but over the years of struggling with this issue I became acutely aware of the need to except those instances where conception occurred because of rape or incest. ``Women cannot and should not be forced to bear the consequences of these traumatic, illegal acts.'' Roemer has repeatedly said he sides with anti-abortion forces but cannot allow a bill without rape and incest exceptions to become law. At an afternoon news conference, the bill's author, state Rep. Woody Jenkins, cited statistics showing that of more than 15,000 abortions performed in Louisiana in 1987, only one was done to end a pregnancy that resulted from rape. ``He's for killing 15,000 unborn children a year in Louisiana just to make sure that one child conceived in rape is also killed,'' said Jenkins. Robin Rothrock, leader of an abortion rights coalition, said earlier she remained confident that the Senate would sustain Roemer's veto. ``In the Senate we believe that we still have the 15,'' Rothrock said, referring to 15 senators who voted against the measure when it passed the Senate with 24 votes. An override requires a two-thirds vote in each chamber _ 26 in the Senate and 70 in the House. The House passed the bill last week with 74 votes. In Michigan, the Legislature will have 40 days to pass the veto-proof measure, once the petition signatures are validated. Failure of the measure would put the issue on the November 1992 statewide ballot as a public referendum. Lawmakers passed a similar measure earlier this year but couldn't override Democratic Gov. James Blanchard's veto. A majority of House and Senate members signed the petitions, said Michigan Right to Life president Barbara Listing. The bill would require girls 17 and younger to have a parent's consent for an abortion or to ask a judge for a waiver on the grounds that she is mature enough to make her own decision or the abortion would be in her best interest.

DOC.HEAD: Angry Motorist Arrested After Ramming Capitol Barricades
DOC.TEXT: Police on Friday arrested a suburban Virginia tennis instructor who became irate over being searched and ticketed and rammed his car between concrete barriers in the Capitol driveway. George C. Heflin Jr., 33, of Falls Church, Va., was charged with malicious destruction of government property and three counts of assault with a deadly weapon. Capitol police spokesman Dan Nichols said Heflin appeared to aim the car at three officers but they were unharmed. He said the car shoved aside two of the large, planter-style barriers, damaging them slightly, and came to a stop 30 feet beyond, a total wreck. Nichols said Heflin suffered slight injuries in the incident. Earlier, police had intercepted Heflin after he left his car running and ran up the Capitol steps. They searched him and found only ``religious-type pamphlets,'' Nichols said. His car was ticketed because the motor was left running, Nichols said. Each of the four felony charges carries a maximum of ten years in jail and a $10,000 fine.

DOC.HEAD: Charred Rubble Remains of Chemical Plant Tanks
With AM-Plant Explosion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A small mound of crumpled steel was all that remained Friday of a three-story storage tank after a fatal explosion ripped through the Arco Chemical Co. plant. The roof of the 900,000-gallon tank loaded with wastewater and flammable hydrocarbons blew off in the initial explosion late Thursday and landed 100 yards away in the parking lot of an administration building. The blast shattered windows in the building and left sheets of rumpled steel from the tank throughout the area. The rest of the collapsed tower was spread over a block-wide area in the southern end of the 564-acre complex. Two vehicles, a vacuum truck from Waste Processors Industries Inc. and a tractor-trailer, stood on their wheel rims at the north end of the area, their tires melted into gooey globs of tar. Nearby, blackened rubble remained of a portable air compressor the size of a boxcar. ``I've been to a lot of fires at plants. But this was a hot fire,'' Dennis Calhoun, an Arco employee, said during a tour of the area Friday afternoon. Arco investigators were sifting through the twisted black metal in hopes of finding the cause of the explosion that claimed the lives of 17 workers, including the driver of the vacuum truck. A mesh of overhead pipes that led into the area resembled a toppled Erector set. Six cooling towers for a nearby co-generation plant stood idle under gray cloudy skies after the explosion ripped off panels. Firefighters used foam to extinguish the blaze that could be felt as far as 20 miles away, Calhoun said. A holding basin adjacent to the wastewater tank contained a black, watery liquid spewing from the tanks and helped curb the blaze, Calhoun said. The liquid will be tested before it can be disposed, he said. A smaller tank next to the one that exploded remained standing, but was scorched and completely blackened.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Lower in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold fell 14 cents ounce on Hong Kong markets Saturday, opening at $361.04. It closed at $361.18 Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Three Silver Spring Monkeys Put To Death
DOC.TEXT: Three crippled monkeys, the subject of court fights by animal rights activists for nine years, were humanely put to death Friday after final experiments involving sensory perception, officials said. The three monkeys were among seven remaining animals seized from a Silver Spring, Md., laboratory in 1981. They were part of a study of stroke and spinal cord injury rehabilitation financed by the National Institutes of Health. Researchers had cut the sensory nerves to the animals' left arms. The Silver Spring monkeys have been kept at Tulane University's Delta Regional Primate Research Center since they were seized by the government. The way for the final experiments was cleared Tuesday when a federal appeals court in Washington rejected attempts by the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine to save them. Each monkey was put under deep surgical anesthesia, said Tulane Medical Center spokeswoman Debbie Grant. While asleep, electrodes were inserted in their brains to monitor signals produced when parts of the body were touched. It was the same as the experiment performed on another Silver Spring monkey in January to test a theory that parts of the brain that are no longer used for one function might take over other functions. The nerve endings to the monkey's arms were severed nine years ago in a study of stroke and spinal cord injury rehabilitation. The researchers wanted to know whether the part of the brain that was no longer used to sense feeling in the arms would start responding to stimuli on other parts of the body. In the January experiment, the unused part of the brain was found to respond when other parts of the body were touched. The results of Friday's experiments were not immediately known. After the experiment, while the monkeys were asleep, they were put to death by lethal injection. Ms. Grant said no pain was involved. Conducting the experiments were Tim Pons of the National Institutes of Health and Preston Garraghty of Vanderbilt University. The decision for euthanasia was made because of the monkey's physical condition, Ms. Grant said. Unable to feel pain, they had bitten and otherwise injured their arms, sometimes severely. The monkeys had been at the center of controversy since an animal rights group claimed they were being mistreated in experiments sponsored by the NIH. That led to the Silver Spring raid and charges of animal cruelty against Dr. Edward Taub, whose conviction was overturned on appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Wildfires Spread to About 400 Square Miles; Town Still Threatened
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Tok still threatened, winds easing, Coast Guard station with power restored, number of firefighters now at 1,200; picks up 9th graf, `The blazes ...'
DOC.TEXT: Wildfires charred about 400 square miles of Alaska forests and tundra by Friday, and still threatened the town of Tok, where firefighters kept up a house-to-house battle against wind-driven flames. ``We're afraid the fire will blow back down in a different direction,'' said Rob McWhorter of the Bureau of Land Management in Tok, a crossroads town on the Alaska Highway 80 miles from the Canadian border. The gusty winds that fanned flames around Tok in recent days eased and the fire's growth slowed, but officials told residents to remain prepared to evacuate. The fire, which grew to more than 53 square miles, leaped trees and fire lines Thursday to come within a quarter-mile of some homes before sweeping northwest of town. When the flames got that close, some 300 of the town's 1,200 residents evacuated; most returned to their houses Friday, McWhorter said. Firefighters widened fire lines Friday but the blaze remained close. ``In some cases there are some spot fires on the edge of town left over from yesterday,'' McWhorter said. ``It's not under control but the fire quieted down overnight,'' said Sue Mitchell, a spokeswoman for an interagency fire center in Fairbanks. ``The fire created its own lightning storm which dropped a little rain on the area. It wasn't much, but it helped a little bit.'' A report Thursday that Tok's Coast Guard navigational station burned was incorrect. It only lost power. The station was back on line early Friday after the seven crewman stationed there returned to the unit. ``Our priority for today is to continue to defend the community, to rebuild and expand lines on the flanks of the town,'' McWhorter said. Statewide, an estimated 1,200 firefighters were deployed as 37 new fires Friday brought to 184 the number burning out of control across Alaska's interior, said Pat Flowers, an interagency spokesman. The blazes consumed at least 253,500 acres, or 396 square miles, Flowers said. Gov. Steve Cowper declared a statewide emergency, and called on the Alaska National Guard to help fight the fires. Most of the fires were blamed on near-record heat, low humidity and lightning strikes. Hot, dry conditions were forecast to continue across Alaska's midsection, stirring up afternoon thunderstorms with unpredictable wind. ``The winds are highly variable, swinging like 90 degrees on the compass within a 60-second period,'' McWhorter said. ``That's one of the most dangerous combinations for firefighters you can possibly dream up.'' The fire burned mainly black spruce, birch, aspen and brush on the flat terrain around Tok, where some residents wore masks to filter out smoke. ``What's bothering us the most is breathing. There's burnt spruce needles falling out of the air,'' said one resident, Mellie Terwilliger. ``You can see but you go around with your lights on.'' Authorities closed two main roads Thursday, but traffic resumed early Friday. Tok is about 260 miles northeast of Anchorage at the junction of the Glenn and Alaska highways. The Cassiar Creek fire, 52 miles north of Fairbanks, charred about 2,000 acres by early Friday and threatened several structures. None were threatened by another fire, covering about 47 square miles near Beaver, 110 miles north of Fairbanks, or by the 780-acre Pedro Dome fire, also north of Fairbanks.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian Airliner Hijacked to Colombia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with police speculating plane was hijacked to use for drug trafficking, co-pilot saying passengers are safe. CORRECTS spelling of Bennett. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A domestic airliner with 10 people aboard was hijacked and flown to neighboring Colombia, where some passengers and a co-pilot were let off before the plane took off again, an official said Friday. The destination was not known. The small Twin Otter aircraft belonging to Panama's domestic Aeroperlas airline was hijacked Thursday by five of the eight passengers aboard, said Capt. John Bennett, director of civil aviation. The hijackers _ three men and two women _ then ordered the crew of two to fly to a clandestine airstrip in Viterbo, a small town in Colombia near Medellin, a center for Colombian cocaine trafficking and headquarters of the Medellin drug cartel. The Viterbo strip is used by drug traffickers, which has led Colombian police to believe the hijackers may have belonged to one of the drug cartels, Colombia's national radio network Caracol reported. Police speculated that the hijackers may have taken the plane to use it to transport drug shipments. At Viterbo, the hijackers let out three passengers and the co-pilot and took off with the aircraft's pilot, Warren Lam, for an unknown destination, Bennett told a news conference. The hijackers first boarded the plane Thursday at Colon, at the northern end of the Panama Canal, using false identities, Bennet said. Flight 147 had been bound for Panama City, about 50 miles away. He said air controllers lost contact with the aircraft a few minutes after it took off. It was earlier thought that the plane may have crashed, and government planes and helicopters searched for the aircraft Thursday and Friday. Bennett said co-pilot Sergio Ortiz, 26, called authorities in Panama City Thursday afternoon and said the three passengers were safe and in good condition at a Colombian military barracks in the small town of Pereira. He said they will be taken to Bogota on Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Shreveport, La., Businesses Evacuated in Extortion Hoax
DOC.TEXT: Police evacuated two banks, four dozen businesses and a day-care center Friday in what turned out to be an extortion hoax. ``The bundles that looked like dynamite ... are railroad flares,'' said Fire Department spokesman Pat Bradford. Officials had said all day that they did not know any motive for bomb threats against City Bank & Trust and Commercial National Bank. But Fire Chief Gordon Routley said Friday evening that the man who called City Bank that morning said he would blow it up if he didn't get money. A city bomb squad member, peering through binoculars from a perch 50 feet up on a hook-and-ladder truck, had said Friday morning that bundles of tubes at the bank's entrances appeared to be dynamite. Officials, including the FBI and the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, decided to call in explosives specialists from the Army's Fort Polk. When one of its members got a closer look Friday evening, he said it was a hoax. Seven bundles and several bottles full of an unidentified liquid were found outside City Bank & Trust's main office, and two more bundles were found at a Commercial National Bank branch, said Bradford. He said a Fort Polk demolition expert and one from the Fire Department's bomb squad had to deal with them because a bomb demolition robot failed to work. Suited up in about 65 pounds of bulletproof head-to-toe armor _ the soldier's olive drab and the fireman's black _ in case the bombs were real after all, they went in and took Polaroid photographs of the bundles. After a close look at the photographs, they put a rope and net around the devices, sheltered behind a car across the street and pulled out the bundles, which were kept for evidence.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Strikers Clash, Four Injured
DOC.TEXT: Striking Sandinista workers clashed with pro-government demonstrators Friday, injuring at least four people. Tens of thousands of people maintained a 5-day-old walkout. About 2,000 workers supporting President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro staged a two-mile march to protest the strikes by leftist Sandinista union members. The work stoppages to protest government austerity measures have paralyzed many government services and industries since Monday. The two sides hurled rocks at each other in the clashes Friday evening, injuring a news photographer. The marchers roughed up two journalists from the Sandinista newspaper Barricada. Journalists at the scene saw one clash outside a group of state-owned industrial companies and a second one near the presidential residence. ``We don't want strikes!'' chanted the marchers from the Permanent Labor Congress, which supports Mrs. Chamorro's 14-party governing coalition. ``Out with corrupt government employees!'' they yelled, referring to Sandinista holdovers in Mrs. Chamorro's administration. Her U.S-backed government succeeded the leftist Sandinistas April 25 after it won a popular election. Alejandro Solorzano, a Congress leader heading the march, said the demonstrators also demanded the removal of military chief Humberto Ortega, the brother of former President Daniel Ortega. The strike by the Sandinista National Labor Front has paralyzed dozens of state-owned and private businesses and factories, banks, farm and ranch cooperatives, government offices, and international telephone service. Lucio Jimenez, the Front's secretary-general, claims 90,000 workers have walked off their jobs and says the strikes will spread until the entire country is brought to a halt. Strike leaders are protesting a belt-tightening economic plan by Mrs. Chamorro's administration. She is trying to pare the government's top-heavy bureaucracy by reducing the number of jobs and selling state companies expropriated by the Sandinistas during their decade in power. The strikers are also demanding that union leaders have a say in economic planning and a national minimum wage of $200 monthly. The current minimum is about $50.

DOC.HEAD: Police Break Up Civic Center Encampment, Make Arrests
With AM-Snyder Suicide, Bjt
LaserPhoto FX1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 8th graf, `Some of ...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with judge denying restraining order to stop arrests; picks up 9th graf pvs, `The plaza ...'
DOC.TEXT: More than two dozen police officers rousted some 100 transients out of their illegal encampment across from City Hall before dawn Friday, the deadline for Mayor Art Agnos' eviction order. A few hours after the raid at Civic Center Plaza, where five people were arrested, mothers wheeled their babies on the paths, old men sat on benches, reading newspapers and chatting and kids fed the pigeons there. The plaza's occupation by the homeless for more than two years seemed like it had never taken place. ``I think this is very nice,'' said a broadly smiling Jack Richards, who moved to San Francisco from Ohio 20 years ago. ``This is the way it used to be _ without the conflict, the yelling, the screaming.'' Some of the homeless had lived under the trees in the plaza, one of San Francisco's showplace sites. The liberal mayor, who had been under heavy pressure to restore the plaza to general public use, promised months ago to find housing for the homeless, whether they liked it or not. One man was carried away in his sleeping bag. Keith McHenry of the Food Not Bombs group was arrested and booked on a charge of interfering with police. Other charges included misdemeanor counts of illegal lodging and illegal distribution of food, police said. Some of the hard-core homeless who refused to leave the plaza and ignored the Friday deadline called their home under the trees ``Camp Agnos.'' Five homeless people went to court Friday, asking a judge to order a stop to the arrests. The five claimed that the city law against camping in parks violates due-process rights and that the arrests are cruel and unusual punishment because homeless people have nowhere else to go. Superior Court Judge John Dearman refused without comment their request for a temporary restraining order, but set a July 23 hearing ordering the city to explain why a preliminary injunction should not be issued. The plaza is bounded on the west by City Hall, the north by the earthquake-ruined State Office Building, the south by the Civic Auditorium, and the east by the Main Public Library. As far as 25-year-old Dale Forbis was concerned, life in the middle of San Francisco's seat of government was good enough for him and his wife, Patricia. They moved to San Francisco from Chicago four years ago. ``Life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness,'' Forbis said. ``That's what this country was all about. So why can't I pursue my happiness the way I choose, as long as I'm not bothering anyone?'' He said he has refused to take advantage of two city multiservice centers opened this week. They like living in the streets. Living a hard life often on the edge of violence, many of the homeless said they had formed strong friendships. ``We have a small town here,'' said Oscar Amezquita, 33, who said he fled Guatemala two years ago for political reasons. He said he can't find work. ``We trust each other, feed one another, take care of each other,'' he said. ``We don't want to live in a shelter with people we don't know.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Orders Hawaii-Based Discovery Airline Closed Down
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS new grafs 9-11 with Discovery comments; pick up 9th graf pvs: The administrative ...
DOC.TEXT: The government on Friday ordered Hawaii-based Discovery Airways closed down in one week, accusing the 3-month-old carrier of violating U.S. laws on foreign ownership. The Transportation Department ordered the airline to cancel its flights and inform passengers how to obtain refunds or alternate transportation. The department said it agreed with an administrative law judge that Discovery's officers ``have consistently provided false information and have violated the terms of their temporary operating authority and federal law.'' Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner announced revocation of Discovery's temporary operating authority nearly seven months before it's scheduled expiration. Skinner said the carrier, which operates six planes, failed to show ``any credible inclination'' to correct problems with its ownership and control. Federal law allows U.S. airlines to have no more than 25 percent foreign ownership and requires that they be controlled by U.S. citizens. Discovery is 75 percent owned by Philip Ho, president of the Japanese Nansay Corp.'s Hawaii operations. Other airlines in the area claim that Nansay bankrolled Ho's stake in Discovery. Discovery has operated for three months on several inter-island routes in competition with both Hawaiian and Aloha airlines. Those carriers claim that Discovery is financed by Japanese interests and run largely by an Italian citizen. In Hawaii, Discovery President Don Straight said, ``We do not agree with their evaluation.'' The decision by the DOT appears to run directly contrary to airline deregulation, he said. ``Our primary concern is for our customers, employees and shareholders,'' Straight said. ``Our objective today will be to see if this airline can continue to fly. If that is not possible, we will meet our obligations to our passengers, employees and vendors.'' ``Finally, it is our feeling that the real losers in this decision are the inter-island travelers in the state of Hawaii,'' Straight added. ``Airlines are public utilities which provide a service to the people. This decision by the DOT denies the public an opportunity to choose and is a disservice to us all.' The administrative law judge, Ronnie A. Yoder, declared last month that cancellation of Discovery's permit to operate ``would appear to be a more appropriate action'' than granting the airline a requested extension. Lawyers assigned by the department's Public Counsel section had proposed an arrangement with Discovery that would have allowed it to operate, but Yoder recommended against the settlement. The judge said the carrier had admitted to ``substantial prior misrepresentations'' when it applied for a permit. The judge said the fact that the proposed settlement included sale of a share in the airline to qualify it as a U.S. carrier was an admission that it had ``operated from its inception as a non-U.S. citizen air carrier in violation of the Federal Aviation Act and that its submissions to the department ... were false and constituted misrepresentation in violation of federal law.'' The department gave Discovery until next Friday to end its service. That deadline was set in order to avoid inconvenience to travelers, spokesman Ed O'Hara said. If the airline wants to continue to seek a permanent license, it may proceed with an evidentiary hearing before the law judge, the spokesman said. Skinner said Discovery was given a temporary authority because of the department's policy of promoting new entry and competition in the airline business. But he said the airline failed to establish a voting trust that would have insulated it from possible foreign control. The administrative law judge also cited evidence that Franco Mancassola, an Italian citizen, is effectively Discovery's executive vice president, earning twice as much as its president. Hawaiian Airlines has filed a $9.9 million suit against the new airline, claiming lost revenue because of Discovery's allegedly fraudulent actions.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Damages Nuclear Research Center, No Injuries
DOC.TEXT: A fire at an atomic energy research center early Saturday caused damage but no injuries, officials said. The fire broke out in the biology laboratory of the Democritus Hellenic Atomic Energy Committee in the northern Athens suburb of Holargos, a security official at the building said by telephone. He said the cause of the fire were not known and that an investigation would be held when power was restored to the stricken building. He spoke on condition of anonymity.
