DOC.HEAD: British Airways Places Order for Up to 33 Boeing 747s
DOC.TEXT: British Airways PLC announced today it had ordered as many as 33 Boeing Co. 747 aircraft worth up to $6.9 billion, the airline's biggest-ever investment in new planes. The firm order for 21 747-400s is the fourth largest for Seattle-based Boeing in dollar value. British Airways said it was seeking extra passenger capacity as well as replacements for its older aircraft. Analysts said the airline was placing the order now so it would not have to wait long for new planes amid growing world demand to replace older aircraft. ``All they're doing is protecting their position in terms of requirements. They didn't want to be last in the queue,'' said Dan White, an analyst with the London investment firm County Natwest Woodmac. British Airways said it has placed firm orders for 21 new Boeing 747-400 long-range aircraft for 2.33 billion pounds, the equivalent of $4.15 billion, and has taken an option to buy 12 more for 1.55 billion pounds, or $2.8 billion. Deliveries will start in 1992 and are expected to be completed seven years later, bringing British Airways' 747-400 fleet to 42 aircraft on the basis of firm orders. The company has bought 21 747-400s since 1986 and operates 224 airplanes in all. ``The aircraft will provide extra capacity as well as allowing us to replace older Boeing 747 equipment,'' British Airways Chairman Lord King said. ``Our 747-400s are delivering good performance and proving popular with intercontinental passengers.'' Rolls-Royce PLC won the $1.07 billion contract for the engines, the airline said. Rolls-Royce spokesman Dick Dalton in Reston, Va., said the deal was for 160 RB211-524G engines, including spares. King said British Airways obtained the right to convert any of the orders if Boeing develops a larger version of the 747. Boeing executives have conjectured that in the late 1990s, the company could build a ``747 super.'' The plane would be significantly larger than the model 400, which can carry 412 passengers more than 8,000 miles, and more than 560 in short-range versions. However, company officials have said no decision has been made to actually build such a plane, and Boeing has offered no specifics on how large the plane might be. ``There's nothing in the works at all,'' said John Wheeler, spokesman for Boeing Commercial Airplane Group in Seattle. He said the conversion options negotiated by British Airways are ``just insurance on the part of the airline'' in case Boeing does come up with another jet. Boeing's largest-ever firm order for aircraft was a $9.4 billion deal from Irish leasing company GPA Ltd. in April 1989. So far this year, Boeing has received orders for 240 aircraft, worth a total $25.3 billion. Its firm-order backlog now stands at more than 1,700 aircraft. British Airways also said it would begin a 30 million pound, or $53 million, refurbishment program for its fleet of 747-100 aircraft to keep them operating at high standards until they progressively are replaced by the new fleet. British Airways did not say how it would pay for the new airplanes. Analysts said they expected the airline to own some of the aircraft and obtain leases on others to contain costs. John Lawson, an analyst with Nomura Research Institute in London, said he would not be surprised if the airline sold ownership of some planes to a leasing company and then took out operating leases on them. Such arrangements are known as lease-backs. British Airways has said that it likes to own its aircraft, but that it has used operating leases on a short-term basis in the past to meet peak demand. Aircraft values have held up well, analysts said. British Airways recently capitalized on the buoyant trend by selling some of its 737s and then leasing them back.

DOC.HEAD: Government Approves Small Cut in Producer Rice Price for 1990
DOC.TEXT: Amid U.S. pressure on Japan to open its rice market, the government Friday decided to cut by only 1.5 percent the price it will pay to rice farmers this year. The price cut is the first in two years, but it is much less than some government officials had hoped for to end U.S. criticism of Japan's rice market, which is virtually closed to imports. An earlier plan by the Agriculture Ministry to cut the price paid to farmers for their rice crops by about 5 percent was killed when it was opposed by members of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, who depend heavily on farmer support. The party had requested a freeze on the price. The government regulates and subsidizes the domestic rice market, buying much of the rice crop and reselling it to consumers at lower prices. The subsidy cost the government 311.7 billion yen, or $2.08 billion, in fiscal 1989. The 1.5 percent reduction is expected to help cut the budget by about 9 billion yen, or $60 million. Japanese rice is about four times more expensive than U.S. rice. Japan's rice market is likely to be on the agenda at next week's summit of seven major industrialized nations in Houston, Texas. Producer prices were cut by 5.95 percent in 1987 and by 4.6 percent in 1988. They remained unchanged last year, when the ruling party faced national elections. Japan has been criticized for its rice ban during the current Uruguay round of multilateral trade talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. But the nation has insisted on maintaining self-sufficiency for rice, its staple food. Limited quantities of rice are imported for use in processed foods. Agriculture Minister Tomio Yamamoto is adamantly opposed to opening the rice market. There are signs, however, that some Japanese would welcome a more flexible position on rice imports. The second-largest opposition party recently endorsed easing the ban on imports, and former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita praised the decision as courageous. Last month, the paper published a national survey it conducted of 2,397 eligible voters in May. Some 65 percent of those polled approved of opening Japan's rice market to some foreign imports, and 21 percent favorded full liberalization.

DOC.HEAD: Westinghouse Wins Lawsuit It Would Have Settled
DOC.TEXT: Westinghouse Electric Co., which offered to settle an age discrimination lawsuit two years ago for $35 million, has won the case in federal appeals court. The ruling Thursday, prodded by a recent U.S. Supreme Court decision, ended the court battle that began in 1983 when the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission challenged Westinghouse for forcing laid-off employees to retire prior to age 70 because severance pay was not available. The settlement offer, which would given some 4,000 retirees an average payment of $8,750, was rejected by government lawyers because they believed the workers would get more in court. The 3rd U.S. Court of Appeals last year found Westinghouse guilty of age discrimination on grounds workers couldn't get both retirement and severance benefits when forced to retire prior to age 70. However, the Supreme Court vacated the decision and sent the 7-year-old case back for further review, and on Thursday the appeals court reversed itself, based on the high court's standards set in another age discrimination case that involved employee benefit plans. ``The choice between retirement and unpaid layoff doesn't constitute involuntary retirement where, as here, continued work was not an option for any of the affected employees, and the employees' layoff status was unrelated to age,'' wrote Judge Anthony Scirica. ``Nor do we believe that exclusion from the severance plan caused older employees to retire. Those who retired did so because they were laid off. ``Moreover, after 1982, retirement eligible employees could choose between retirement benefits and severance pay with recall,'' the court said. This was not the government position when it sued Westinghouse. EEOC lawyers claimed Westinghouse violated federal law by forcing laid-off employees under 70 to retire because they would not get severance pay, and also denying those workers a chance to be recalled to work. At the same time, younger workers laid off could lose recall rights only if they took severance.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Lincoln National, Dai-ichi Complete First Phase
DOC.TEXT: Dai-ichi Mutual Life Insurance Co. of Japan has completed the first phase of its agreement with Lincoln National Corp. by acquiring a 5 percent interest in the Fort Wayne insurer, officials announced Friday. The first series of convertible preferred stock was transferred to Dai-ichi for $151.6 million, Lincoln announced. Under the agreement announced June 26, Dai-ichi will purchase a second series of stock, representing an additional 4.6 percent interest, within a year. Both series are worth approximately $312 million, representing the largest investment by a Japanese company in a U.S. insurer. The Lincoln National board of directors has also granted Dai-ichi one right to purchase common stock for each share of the new series of convertible preferred stock. Lincoln National Corp. is the nation's seventh largest multi-line insurance holding company with assets of $25.1 billion and annual revenues exceeding $8.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Suit Alleges Farm Workers Being Cheated
DOC.TEXT: Some labor contractors are cheating migrant farm workers by collecting _ but not reporting _ unemployment and Social Security taxes, an attorney who filed federal suits here alleged on Friday. In many cases, the contractors fail to report any income by the worker, leaving them destitute when the season ends or the worker retires, said James Boon of Florida Legal Services Inc. ``With farm workers, unemployment is a very important benefit because it's a seasonal job, and Social Security is the only pension plan these people are ever going to participate in,'' Boon said. ``It really hurts, and it's a real serious violation of law.'' The suits filed last week allege that farmers in Alabama and migrant labor crew chiefs based in Belle Glade withheld ``thousands of dollars in Social Security and unemployment compensation benefits'' from Palm Beach County farm workers picking Alabama's sweet corn crop in June 1986, June 1987 and June 1988. Most of the workers who filed suits are Haitian immigrants fluent only in their native Creole language and are generally unfamiliar with U.S. and state labor laws, Boon said. He said they are susceptible to abuses by crew chiefs who may try to under-report or fail to report the earned wages of farm workers. Crew chiefs work as contractors, providing the labor to harvest fruit and vegetables and package the crops for shipping. In addition to providing housing and transportation, they distribute the migrants' wages and are responsible for complying with federal labor laws. But Boon said only a small number of investigators police the crew chiefs. ``There is a real big incentive not to report wages, especially if you don't expect to get in trouble for not doing it,'' he said. Boon said under current laws, crew chiefs must set aside $15 for each $100 earned by a worker to be contributed as Social Security, and about $5 for the state unemployment tax. ``The migrants assume the money is sent in, but what happens a lot of times is that nothing is sent and nothing is reported,'' Boon said.

DOC.HEAD: Holdout Strikers Close Major Oil Field
DOC.TEXT: An illegal strike by offshore oil workers forced the Norwegian state oil company to shut down production again Friday, although other strikers were back at work. Morten Wolstad of Statoil A@S said the company halted production for safety reasons when workers continued to defy a government back-to-work order as well as threats of dismissal. He said production had reached a rate of 500,000 barrels earlier Friday, half of Statoil's capacity. ``There just aren't enough people working out there,'' said Wolstad. The strike was in its sixth day on Statoil's Statfjord, Gullfaks and Veslefrikk North Sea fields and ``we aren't at all sure when it will end,'' he said by telephone. Statoil provides the bulk of Norway's 1.6-million-barrel daily oil output. Strikers on most other fields returned to work Thursday, allowing some production to resume. Phillips Petroleum Co. Norway expects flows from its seven Ekofisk area fields to reach normal daily levels over the weekend _ about 220,000 barrels, the national news agency NTB said. Numerous other fields depend on pipelines from Ekofisk to move their natural gas production to West Germany and Britain. About 4,000 offshore workers went on strike last Sunday. The Norwegian Federation of Oil Workers Union and the Norwegian Confederation of Business and Industry deadlocked on wage increases and job protection from automation. The government, saying Norway could not afford the loss, invoked compulsory arbitration Monday and ordered the strikers back to work. Petroleum provides about 25 percent of the national income. About 1,000 oil workers defied the order and continued the strike illegally. Support for the walkout dwindled during the week, leaving about 300 striking at Statoil's fields Friday, NTB said.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Wins City Tax Fight
DOC.TEXT: Cash-starved developer Donald Trump has won a tax fight with the city of New York over his Manhattan real estate, saving $1.2 million on his 1989 taxes. Trump's 56-acre waterfront property on the Upper West Side, assessed by the ciy at $44 million, was instead taxed at a rate $12.5 million lower after Trump made his case before the city Tax Commission. Trump was one of 19,306 taxpayers who won assessment battles with the city for 1989. The full list of winners _ which included the Andy Warhol estate and Alex DiLorenzo, owner of the building that housed the Happy Land Social Club where 86 people died in an arson fire _ was released June 29. Trump, whose cash flow problems have been well documented, saved $1.2 million in taxes with the re-evaluation, the city Finance Department said. But that money went right back to the city Thursday, when Trump made a multi-million dollar property tax payment. Trump shelled out $2.2 million for his undeveloped West Side property, another $1 million for Trump Tower and $900,000 for the Trump Parc condominiums.

DOC.HEAD: Government Say Deal for Portuguese Ford Plant Close but not Confirmed
DOC.TEXT: Government officials on Friday declined to confirm a newspaper report that U.S. auto producer Ford Motor Co. had chosen Portugal for a new leisure vehicle production plant worth about $2 billion. The sum would be the largest single foreign investment in the booming Iberian country. According to the report in the Lisbon daily Publico, Ford has chosen Setubal, a harbor city 30 miles south of Lisbon, for the new plant. The publication said Ford officials met with the Secretary of State for Foreign Trade Antonio Neto da Silva Thursday to discuss financing. ``Everything's going well, we're nearly there ... but there'll be no confirmation until a final accord has been signed,'' said one official at the Ministry for Commerce and Tourism who asked not to be named. Lin Cummins, a spokeswoman for Ford in Dearborn, Mich., declined to confirm or deny speculation about a car production plant for Portugal. ``I've heard no such rumors,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Acura Again Tops Power List
DOC.TEXT: The Acura luxury car division of Japan's Honda Motor Co. Ltd. has topped the J.D. Power and Associates list of cars most satisfying to their owners for the fourth year in a row, the marketing company said Friday. The organization said in a news release received in Detroit that its overall customer-satisfaction index rose about 3 percent to 122 points this year from last year. The survey checks consumer attitudes about a variety of aspects of their vehicles and the dealerships they used. Power surveyed about 100,000 people who have owned 1989-model cars for the last 12 to 14 months. The marketing group refuses to release rankings of vehicles lower than what proves to be the industry average in any particular survey. But automakers with cars ranked high in the survey immediately tout the results in their advertising. The group's Customer Satisfaction Index is one of three principle surveys conducted by the Power organization. Earlier this week, Power released its Initial Quality Survey, which looks into the number of problems reported by consumers during the first three months of ownership. Toyota Motor Corp.'s Lexus Division topped that list and since then, two-page newspaper advertisements have been appearing around the nation. General Motors Corp.'s Buick Division was the highest-ranked U.S. automaker and less than 24 hours after the quality survey was released, television ads bragging about Buick's ranking were on the air. In addition to Friday's Customer Satisfaction Survey and the quality survey earlier this week, Power also produces its Vehicle Dependability Index covering reported problems during the first four or five years of ownership. In the latest survey, Acura was followed by Mercedes-Benz, second last year; Toyota, fourth last year; Cadillac, fifth in 1989; and Honda, which was third.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing to Cut Employment by Another 2,700 This Year
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co. said today it expects to cut its Washington state work force by another 2,700 jobs in the second half of 1990, bringing total job reductions for the year to about 5,600. Boeing, which employs 103,800 people in the state and 161,000 worldwide, had said in January that its work force would be reduced by 5,000 in 1990. Boeing spokesman Paul Binder said the increase was due to defense program cuts that were unknown earlier this year. The forecast could change again due to further defense spending decisions, Binder said. In the first half of 1990, Boeing reduced its state employment by about 2,900 people. Of those, about 2,500 quit or retired and about 400 were laid off, Binder said. Boeing, the free world's largest builder of commercial jet aircraft, has a backlog of more than 1,700 firm orders for jetliners. However, fewer workers have been needed on its commercial side because production of its new 747-400 jumbo jet, which went into service in early 1989, is past the start-up phase, Binder said. Boeing also is working on several defense contracts that have run into opposition in Congress, including the B-2 stealth bomber. Boeing is a major subcontractor to Northrop Corp. for the B-2, and has about 8,000 people working on the bat-wing bomber in Seattle. Dale Shellhorn, Boeing's B-2 program manager, said last month that up to 1,500 workers would be laid off or reassigned because of expected congressional cuts in the bomber program. At the beginning of the year, Boeing employed just under 106,700 workers in Washington and 164,600 worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Production Down This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 106,010 cars and light trucks during this shortened holiday week, down from last week's 230,050, Ward's Automotive Reports said Friday. This week's production is higher than in the same week a year ago, in which 70,173 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 70,022 cars this week, compared with 143,691 a week ago and 40,925 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 35,988, compared with last week's 86,359 and last year's 29,248. Canadian automakers were to build 13,454 cars this week, down from 25,577 a week ago and up from last year's 8,500. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 9,060, compared with 18,577 a week ago and 12,209 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Skid on Improved Weather Forecasts
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices skidded for the second straight day on the Chicago Board of Trade Friday, as more weather forecasters predicted ideal weather next week for Midwestern crop development and winter wheat harvesting. The sell-off extended Thursday's steep losses in the corn and soybean markets as it triggered waves of selling by speculators. Earlier this week, some private forecasters were predicting hot, dry weather for the western and southern reaches of the Corn Belt. But by Friday, meteorologists were near unanimous in forecasting a week of mild temperatures and beneficial showers for the region. The corn crop is nearing its pollination phase, when heat and dryness could reduce yields. ``If you don't get a drought at this time of year, it means the corn crop generally will be developing under favorable conditions,'' said Katharina Zimmer, a grains analyst with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Inc. The forecasts contained nothing that would adversely affect soybeans, which reach their pollination phase in August. And the relatively dry conditions expected in the Great Plains should allow winter wheat harvesting to accelerate. At the close, wheat futures were 5{ cents to 9\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in July at $3.10 a bushel; corn was 4 cents to 7\ cents lower with July at $2.81 a bushel; oats were 4 cents to 4} cents lower with July at $1.31{ a bushel; soybeans were 7 cents to 12 cents lower with July at $6.18 a bushel.

Stock prices rallied in light trading today as traders studied the latest data on employment. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 27.23 to 2,906.44 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 830 up, 546 down and 547 unchanged. Analysts had expected a quiet session in the absence of many traders who were taking time off after Independence Day on Wednesday. The Labor Department reported that nonfarm payroll employment increased by 40,000 in June. Employment data for the past few months have been skewed by temporary hiring for the Census. But brokers said the June data generally lived up to expectations. The figures were seen as confirming sluggish growth, at best, in business activity _ while at the same time probably not signaling enough weakness to prompt any immediate relaxation of the Federal Reserve's credit policy. Gainers among the blue chips included Boeing, up 1{ at 60}; American Express, up | at 32; Philip Morris, up 1[ at 48|; Exxon, up 1 at 47}, and General Electric, up } at 71. Eli Lilly rose } to 87 and Genentech gained | to 29|. A research study published this week reported evidence that a growth hormone produced by the companies can reverse some of the effects of aging in older men. Mack Trucks, traded in the over-the-counter market, added 1\ to 6{. Renault of France, which owns about 44.5 percent of Mack, announced plans to make a $6-a-share bid for the rest of the stock. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.47 to 195.92. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .21 at 358.28. Volume on the Big Board came to 96.62 million shares with an hour to go.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion at Chemical Plant Kills 17; Five Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with toll put at 17; no one still believed to be un accounted for. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Arco said...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HTX1; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: An explosion and fire ripped through a city-block-sized section of a chemical plant ``like a rocket just took off,'' killing 17 workers, authorities and witnesses said. The explosion occurred around 11:30 p.m. Thursday as crews were cleaning waste tanks at the Atlantic Richfield Co. chemical plant in this Houston suburb. The 564-acre complex employs about 350 people. Five workers were injured. ``We're in the process of recovering the victims from the fire,'' Richard Bailey, chief investigator for the Harris County Sheriff's Department Arson Division, said at midday. ``It looks like a bomb went off in there.'' Plant manager Earl McCaleb, his voice breaking, called the explosion and fire ``a terrible tragedy'' and ``an overwhelming sadness, the loss of friends and co-workers.'' Five of the dead were Arco Chemical employees; 11 were employed by an outside contractor, Austin Industrial Inc. of Houston; and one was a truck driver. Officials said they believed they had accounted for all of the missing. Earlier, officials had said there were 15 confirmed dead and one missing; there was no immediate explanation on why the death toll then jumped up by two. Arco said four people were treated for minor injuries and released and one person was hospitalized, but could not give further details. None of the victims was immediately identified. McCaleb said the blaze was not extinguished until more than four hours after the explosion. The blast occurred in a utility area, a remote section that provides cooling, water and steam for plant operations. The explosion involved two tanks containing wastewater and some hydrocarbons, McCaleb said. Officials said there were an unsually large number of people in the area of the plant complex because crews were cleaning the tanks. Authorities had not determined a cause for the explosion. Assistant Secretary of Labor Gerard F. Scannell was en route to Houston this morning, the Labor Department said. ``I seen a big flash cross in front of my eyes. I looked over to my left and I saw a big ball of fire. ... It looked to me like a tank run off, you know, like a rocket just took off,'' Mike Zugel, a truck driver who witnessed the explosion, told Cable News Network. There were no evacuations of people living in the area, according to fire dispatcher Karen Ragsdale. Rose Ann Raupp, an investigator for the Harris County medical examiner's office, said her office was working with plant employees in an attempt to recover the bodies. ``The area is roughly about a city block,'' Jack Johnson, president of Philadelphia-based Arco Chemical of North America, said late this morning. ``It's pretty obvious the explosion at the tank was devastating to that particular portion of the plant. ``It's been a tremendous strain on all of the employees here at the plant. We continue to work to clear the lines and finish the cleanup. We currently are moving that portion of the tank and the bodies.'' McCaleb said the blast involved two tanks, both of which collected wastewater and some chemicals from the plant. The material is pumped from one tank to another before it is disposed of. A vacuum truck, of the sort used to remove wastes, was in the area of the tanks where the explosion occurred but it not immediately known if it had anything to do with the accident, McCaleb said. One body was discovered in the cab of the truck, officials said. Kathryn Cox, a member of the plant cleaning crew, said she and several fellow workers had just finished their jobs when they heard the blast. ``We didn't look back,'' she said. ``We just started running and we just kept running.'' ``We just heard a big explosion and everybody said `Run!' and we all took off,'' Marlene Viscus said. The plant, about 15 miles east of Houston, was shut down today. Initially, authorities had described the blast and fire as relatively minor and said no injuries were reported. Shortly after midnight, Ms. Ragsdale had said that the plant's own firefighters were putting out the fire and added: ``It's not really a big fire.'' The blast is the second major loss of life at a Houston-area petrochemical plant in the past nine months. On Oct. 23, a Phillips Petroleum Co. plastics plant in nearby Pasadena was hit by series of explosions that killed 23 workers and injured 130. On June 8, two people were injured in an explosion and fire at a chemical packaging plant in Pearland, south of Houston. The Arco plant at Channelview has been in operation since 1977 and was acquired by Arco three years later. It annually produces 560 million pounds of propylene oxide, a substance used to make foam for seat cushions and bedding and used in cleaning compounds, according to a company brochure distributed to reporters at the scene. In addition, the plant annually makes 1.3 billion pounds of styrene monomer, which used for insulation, foam drinking cups, packaging materials and a variety of automotive applications; and 1.7 billion pounds of methyl tertiary butyl ether, a high octane blending component used as a replacement for lead in motor vehicle fuel.

DOC.HEAD: Pace of European Monetary Union Quickens
DOC.TEXT: The pace of European monetary union is quickening, bringing closer the day Europe will have a single currency and a ``EuroFed,'' or central bank. The result could merge the 12-nation European Community into one mighty economy with a currency rivaling the dollar in world importance. The benefits are obvious: travelers no longer would have to shuffle lire, pesetas, pounds, francs, guilders and crowns. Businesses would be freed from the paperwork and costs linked to fluctuating exchange rates. Although EC leaders have agreed to pursue economic and monetary union, they now are engaged in an intense debate on how to go about it. Major unresolved questions include whether the currency would be a new monetary unit or a modification of an existing currency; whether it would replace all 12 Common Market currencies or become a 13th, parallel currency; and how much power a central monetary body would have. ``The momentum has considerably increased,'' Bertrand de Maigret, secretary general of the Paris-based Association for the Monetary Union of Europe, said in an interview. Just a year ago, ``people did not dare talk about a single currency,'' he said. ``But now the discussion is full and open.'' The July 1 monetary unification of the Germanys and the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe have spurred monetary integration, experts say. Another boost came last month when Britain dropped its adamant opposition and made a counter-proposal to the main monetary union plan mapped out by EC Commission President Jacques Delors. Experts now say monetary union could happen by the mid-1990s. Peter Ludlow, head of the Center for European Policy Studies, a think tank in Brussels, said use of a single European currency could spread to Eastern Europe and possibly the Soviet Union. ``The dominance of the dollar would be called into question,'' he said in an interview. Karl Otto Poehl, president of the German Bundesbank, or central bank, said in London on July 3 that he believed EC leaders already had reached loose agreement that monetary unity is desirable. A ``decision has already been taken to aim for such change,'' Poehl said, citing an agreement by EC leaders in June to discuss such matters at an intergovernmental conference in December. However, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who strongly opposes giving up the pound and relinquishing control over Britain's monetary affairs, subsequently insisted on retaining the right to keep Britain out of any full monetary union. Delors has proposed a three-stage approach: removing trade barriers and bringing all 12 EC countries into the currency-stabilizing Exchange Rate Mechanism; a transitional period; then full monetary union. He has set no timetable. Britain says it is committed to the first stage and to the EC's plan to remove trade barriers by the end of 1992 and create one marketplace of 320 million people. Britain, Portugal and Greece presently are outside the Exchange Rate Mechanism. Delors advocates using the European Currency Unit, or ECU, a 10-year-old instrument made up of a basket of European currencies, to replace the existing currencies. The ECU already exists but is used mostly for accounting among countries. Poehl said the German mark or some other common currency must be at the core of any eventual monetary unity and that the ``EuroFed'' should control its exchange rates. While he said West Germany might agree to give up the use of the mark under such a plan, he rejected the ECU as a substitute. West Germany also has suggested two-speed monetary union under which it would join France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg in moving quickly toward monetary union, while other EC nations come in later. Delors rejects this. Britain made its counter-proposal on June 21, calling for the current ECU to be turned into a hard currency to be used alongside the existing 12. A new institution called the European Monetary Fund would swap new ECU bank notes for European currencies, thus minimizing any threat of inflation from pumping out new money. The ECU would not be allowed to devaluate against other EC currencies. ``In the very long term, if peoples and governments so choose, it could develop into a single currency,'' says Britain's top treasury official, Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major. Delors and Poehl said the idea should be studied, but continued to press their own positions. One possibility is that the British plan might become a phase toward full monetary union.

DOC.HEAD: Air France Schedule Disrupted by Strike
DOC.TEXT: Air France was forced to cancel more than 60 flights Friday because of a strike by ground personnel at Charles de Gaulle airport outside Paris. The strike for higher wages and better working conditions by hundreds of baggage handlers, hostesses and agents began a day after the end of a disruptive three-day strike by Paris-area air traffic controllers. Air France, which initially said the new strike would cause only minor disruptions, admitted its problems turned out to be severe. It cancelled about half its flights in and out of Charles de Gaulle, including about 50 medium-range flights and a dozen long-range flights. The strike is scheduled to end at midday Saturday, and the state-owned airline said it expected to be able to operate all of its long-range flights that day except one from Paris to Dakar, Senegal. It cancelled 14 medium-range flights Saturday. Most of the flights cancelled Friday were to European cities including London, Frankfurt, Amsterdam and Geneva, which Air France serves with numerous flights each day. It maintained service to these cities on a reduced basis.

DOC.HEAD: VW Boosts Prices for Some '91 Cars and Vans
DOC.TEXT: Average prices for 17 models of 1991 Volkswagen cars and vans will be about 2 percent higher than for 1990 versions of the same vehicles, the automaker said Friday. Volkswagen United States Inc., a U.S. marketing arm for Volkswagen AG of West Germany, said its 1991 base prices will range from $8,895 for the two-door Golf car to $26,085 for the Camper GL Syncro van. Prices for '90 versions of the same vehicles ranged from $8,695 to $25,575. In late 1989, Volkswagen cut base prices of its cars between 6.7 percent and 26.6 percent. Prices for other 1991 Volkswagen vehicles will be announced later, the company said.
Stock prices rallied today, recouping much of Thursday's losses. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 25.49 at 2,904.70.

DOC.HEAD: Beer Industry Tries to Mobilize Opposition to Beer Tax Hike
DOC.TEXT: Beer drinkers are being enlisted in the brewing industry's lobbying effort against potential attempts to hike the federal excise tax on beer. Beer company employees and distributors also have been asked to let Congress know about their oppostion to a beer tax hike while lawmakers were home for Independence Day parades and other festivities. The lobbying offensive comes even though no specific proposal to boost the excise tax on beer has been offered. But brewers, who already have been under attack in the nation's capital for questionable marketing tactics, are fearful that beer will prove a handy target for lawmakers struggling to balance the federal budget. ``When they talk about taxes, the first thing they talk about are alcohol taxes,'' said Jeff Becker, a spokesman for the Beer Institute, a trade group. Brewers say an increase in the tax on beer unfairly would hit middle- and low-income families because they drink most beer. The federal excise tax on beer amounts to $9 a barrel or about 16 cents for a six-pack. The federal rate has not been changed since 1951 although state rates have been raised. Industry executives expect proposals may be made to double the federal excise tax on beer. The Beer Institute estimates doubling the federal tax would cut beer sales volume by 4 percent at retail. The beer industry sold 188 million barrels of beer in 1989, and expectations are that sales will rise less than 1 percent this year. Annual sales growth has been averaging 0.6 pecent to 0.7 percent a year for the past five years, the institute said. The largest brewer, Anheuser-Busch Cos., recently distributed petitions to its 960 wholesalers, which it encouraged to gather thousands of signatures from people who want lawmakers to ``Can the Beer Tax.'' Signatures were collected over the past week at concerts and festivals in several Texas cities. Also this past week, the Connecticut beer wholesaler association hired a plane to carry a banner with the ``Can the Beer Tax'' slogan along the coast. Anheuser-Busch is considering developing radio and newspaper ads that would use the same theme. Company Chairman August A. Busch III encouraged employees last month to buttonhole legislators on the tax issue while the lawmakers were in their home districts for the July 4th holiday and to send letters to their Washington offices so they would be reminded of those views when they returned. ``The next several days are key,'' Busch wrote. Steven Forsyth, a spokesman for Miller Brewing Co. in Milwaukee, said Miller sent letters and packets of information to its employees and suppliers detailing the company's opposition to a beer tax hike. He said they and the company's 700 distributors were also asked ``let congresspeople know that we believe excise taxes are unfair'' and will have little impact on closing the budget defiucit. On Monday, The Beer Institute plans to run ads in 65 newspapers that will show a fancy diamond bracelet and a can of beer above the headline ``You pay more excise tax on the beer.'' The ad points out that federal excise taxes on luxury items such as jewelry were eliminated while beer is taxed at three times the rate of most other consumer goods. ``As one of America's 80 million beer drinkers, tell Congress you don't mind paying your fair share of taxes. But enough is enough,'' the ad says. The ads are being placed in areas represented by senators and House members expected to be influential in the upcoming talks between Congress and the White House on a deficit reduction plan. The ads list a toll-free telephone number and the institute plans to send letters under the caller's name to his or her legislator, expressing opposition to any hike in the beer tax. In his letter to Anheuser-Busch employees, Busch warned a beer tax increase would hurt the company and the industry for years to come. ``No one at Anheuser-Busch is against even-handed efforts to curb the federal deficit. We are all willing to do our part. But excise taxes are anything but even-handed,'' he wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Former Sun-Times Publisher Buys 2 Reader-Written Magazines
DOC.TEXT: Page Group Publishing Inc. has purchased a pair of reader-written magazines in Beverly Hills and Brentwood. Page Group, headed by former Chicago Sun-Times publisher Robert E. Page, bought the Glendale News Press and the Costa Mesa-based Orange Coast Daily Pilot last year. Page said Thursday he paid between $1 million and $2 million for the Brentwood Bla-Bla and Beverly Hills, the Magazine, which are distributed free. The Beverly Hills publication has a circulation of 65,000, the West Los Angeles magazine 75,000, according to their founder and former majority owner, Michael Lobkowicz. The magazines feature prose, artwork, poetry and reviews submitted by readers, published virtually unedited. No payment is given to the authors, who have included such well-known local residents as Zsa Zsa Gabor, Kenny Rogers and Norman Lear. Page said he hoped to build a regional media company when he led an investor group that purchased the Glendale and Costa Mesa papers last year. He purchased the magazines from Metropolitan Media Inc. in West Los Angeles. Lobkowicz will stay on as their publisher and there are no plans to change the editorial content or the staff of 26 people, Page said. The Costa Mesa-based Page Group also owns weekly newspapers in Huntington Beach, Burbank and La Canada Flintridge. Lobkowicz said a third magazine that he launched recently, titled the Prince and the Bear, will be reformulated to appear as a reader-written insert in Thursday editions of the Daily Pilot.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Signs Interstate Banking Bill
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis signed a law Friday that will open Massachusetts' borders to banks from other regions while trying to combat racial bias in lending. The bill ``not only guarantees that every bank in the commonwealth meets the needs of all its customers, but encourages those banks to compete in both national and international financial markets,'' Dukakis said. Interstate banking has been billed as a potential boon to the slumping state economy, as more out-of-state banks could bring new capital to Massachusetts. But analysts and representatives of the banking industry said Friday they did not expect immediate changes. ``I don't see any rush to come here,'' said James Moynihan, a banking analyst with Advest Inc. ``The profitability (of New England banks) is very poor. The companies are not very sought after for now.'' Nonetheless, Robert Sheridan of the Massachusetts Bankers Association said it was important for Massachusetts to make this move. Currently, 26 states allow national interstate banking, and seven more are scheduled to join the ranks within two years, according to the bankers association. Until now, Massachusetts allowed interstate banking only on a regional basis. The bill will take effect in 60 days, but banks can opt out of the provisions until July 1, 1992, if two-thirds of the board of directors agree. The community reinvestment provisions of the law will require the state to publicize the ratings banks receive based on their lending to minorities and low-income people.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: credit policy.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 25.74 to 2,904.95, finishing the week with a net gain of 24.26 points. Advancing issues outpaced declines by about 8 to 5 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 851 up, 540 down and 553 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 111.73 million shares, down from 128.32 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index rose 1.33 to 195.78.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Finishes Mixed In U.S. Trading
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mixed on domestic currency markets Friday after closing higher overseas following the release of a better-than-expected U.S. unemployment report. Gold prices also ended mixed. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery slipped 30 cents from late Wednesday to settle at $361.10 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $360.20, down 30 cents. Despite a continuing slump in the nation's manufacturing and construction sectors, the unemployment rate fell to 5.2 percent in June from 5.3 percent the previous month, the Labor Department reported. Many traders had expected unemployment to shoot up as high as 5.5 percent, a move that could have encouraged the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates to stimulate a flagging economy. The report, however, ``dispelled some anticipation that the Fed might ease,'' said Ronald Holzer, chief dealer at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. Higher interest rates make dollar-denominated securities more attractive, and thereby enhance foreign investors' needs for dollars to buy debt instruments. Non-farm payrolls increased by 40,000 jobs in June, far lower than market expectations. But Linda McLaughlin, a trader at Chemical New York Capital Markets Group, said the fact that the overall unemployment rate fell generated enough interest in the dollar to override the impact of the payroll figure. The dollar rose overseas but turned mixed when trading shifted to the United States. Dealers said, however, that the much-anticipated employment report failed to move the market significantly, and activity was relatively thin. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 150.95 yen, down 0.05 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted higher at 151.00 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 151.70 yen, up from 150.57 yen on Thursday. The British pound rose to $1.7865 from late Thursday's $1.7795. In New York one pound cost $1.7865, more expensive than $1.7815 on Thursday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late rates included: 1.6515 West German marks, down from 1.6517; 1.3983 Swiss francs, down from 1.3998; 5.5435 French francs, up from 5.5430; 1,211.50 Italian lire, unchanged; and 1.1619 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1640. Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with Thursday's late rates included: 1.6540 German marks, up from 1.6497; 1.4005 Swiss francs, up from 1.3990; 5.5515 French francs, up from 5.5357; 1.8595 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8582; 1,213.25 Italian lire, up from 1,210.25; and 1.1630 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1627. Gold in London was quoted at a late price of $361.25 a troy ounce, up from $359.75 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold was quoted at $361.25, up from $359.50. Gold in Hong Kong dropped 21 cents a troy ounce Friday, to close at $361.26. Silver prices were little changed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.866 a troy ounce, down from Thursday's $4.869. In London the metal was unchanged at $4.88 an ounce.

The Russell 3000 index of companies with the largest market value closed at 198.65 Friday, up 0.13, or 0.07 percent, from a week ago and up 1.37, or 0.69 percent, this year to date. The Russell 1000 index of the largest companies, closed at 186.50 Friday, up 0.20, or 0.11 percent, from a week ago and up 1.39, or 0.75 percent, this year to date. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies, closed at 168.20 Friday, down 0.92, or 0.54 percent, from a week ago and down 0.11, or 0.07 percent, this year to date.

DOC.HEAD: Oregon Business, Civic Leader Dies
DOC.TEXT: Harold S. Hirsch, who founded White Stag Manufacturing Co. and was a prominent Portland civic leader and philanthropist, has died in his home. He was 82. Hirsch served as a trustee of Reed College from 1956 until his death from cancer Wednesday. The Japanese Garden in Washington Park plans a living memorial to Hirsch, the Mountain View Garden, which will overlook the city and Mount Hood. ``He was a very dedicated person to the city of Portland,'' said Miles Englehart, president of the Japanese Garden Society, where Hirsch was a longtime board member. ``He used to call me all the time about the garden, even in his last few days.'' Hirsch was a trail blazer in the manufacture of outdoor clothing. In 1929, he used a corner of his family's Hirsch-Weis Co. factory and a couple of its sewing machines to begin making apparel for downhill skiing, a sport then in its infancy in the United States. He had learned to ski on Mount Rainier in Washington and in the hills of New Hampshire, while attending Dartmouth College. He also attended England's Oxford University. His venture grew into a division of his family's company and became known as White Stag. From ski wear, it branched into a broad line of casual sportswear. It expanded from its Portland base to include plants in the South and East and international joint ventures. He was a pioneer in racially integrating his manufacturing plants in the South and in Portland during World War II. Hirsch headed a National Alliance of Businessmen's program to spur the hiring of minority workers. He was also a strong supporter of higher education. In addition to the Reed board, he was a member of the University of Oregon College of Business Administration Advisory Board. He served six years on the university's School of Law's Board of Visitors and was vice president of the Dartmouth College alumni association. He served as president of the Port of Portland Commission and on the citizens' advisory committee for Portland's downtown plan. He is a member of the U.S. Ski Hall of Fame.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Finish Slow Week Little Changed
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices wound up a slow week with mostly minor changes Friday as crude kept to a tight trading range. Volume was extremely light because many market participants took an extended break after the Independence Day holiday on Wednesday. Reports of renewed output disruptions due to an illegal strike by Norwegian oil workers initially inspired crude buying in the energy futures pits on the New York Mercantile Exchange. But the rally fizzled after it became apparent that the bulk of Norway's oil production was resuming. Wholesale gasoline prices firmed on speculation that an explosion and fire at an Arco Chemical Co. plant in Texas could cause a temporary shortage in a gas additive. The plant makes an additive used to upgrade gas to premium. The contract for August delivery of West Texas Intermediate dipped 3 cents to $16.47 per 42-gallon barrel, after slumping 30 cents Thursday. Contracts for delivery during September through November also posted modest losses. Unleaded gasoline for August delivery rose 0.46 cent to 55.41 cents a gallon after sliding 1.14 cents Thursday. The contracts for delivery through November also settled higher. Among other refined products traded on the exchange, wholesale home heating oil for August delivery settled at 48.30 cents a gallon, off 0.03 cent. The contract ended down 0.13 cent on Thursday. The September through November contracts finished mixed. In natural gas trading, the August contract fell to $1.498 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.514 Thursday. Energy broker Andrew Lebow at E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc. said no clear price patterns emerged Friday _ or the entire week _ because activity was so sluggish. He said the Arco chemical plant fire in Channelview, Texas, tended to encourage buying of premium gas on the Gulf Coast.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Skid Further On Weather Forecasts
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices plunged for the second straight day Friday as more weather forecasters predicted ideal weather next week for Midwestern crop development and winter wheat harvesting. On other commodity markets, pork futures fell sharply; copper futures climbed; precious metals slipped; and energy futures were mixed. On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat futures settled 5{ cents to 10 cents lower with the contract for delivery in July at $3.09\ a bushel; corn was 3{ cents to 8\ cents lower with July at $2.80 a bushel; oats were 4{ cents to 5 cents lower with July at $1.31 a bushel; soybeans were 8 cents to 10} cents lower with July at $6.19 a bushel. The sell-off extended Thursday's steep losses in the corn and soybean markets as it triggered waves of selling by speculators. Earlier this week, some private forecasters were predicting hot, dry weather for the western and southern reaches of the Corn Belt. But by Friday, ``they're all saying the weather's going to be mild with good rain in the next week or so, and that is the ball game,'' said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. After the close, the National Weather Service issued a new six-to-10-day forecast predicting normal temperatures and rainfall in the Midwest during the period July 12-16. The corn crop is nearing its pollination phase, when heat and dryness could reduce yields. ``If you don't get a drought at this time of year, it means the corn crop generally will be developing under favorable conditions,'' said Katharina Zimmer, a grains analyst with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Inc. The forecasts contained nothing that would adversely affect soybeans, which reach their pollination phase in August. And the relatively dry conditions expected in the Great Plains should allow winter wheat harvesting to accelerate. Pork futures tumbled on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on selling linked to recent high hog slaughter figures and sluggish retail demand, especially for bacon. The Agriculture Department's hog slaughter estimates of 293,000 head Thursday and 285,000 Friday were both about 15,000 head higher than market expectations. The high slaughter rates have increased supplies of all pork, including the bellies from which bacon is made. The heavy slaughter is not alarming but ``it's enough to put people on edge,'' said Dale Durchholz, an analyst with AgriVisor Services Inc. in Bloomington, Ill. Cattle futures were boosted in part by expectations for rising retail demand for beef. Live cattle settled .12 cent to .63 cent higher with August at 73.65 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .25 cent to .80 cent higher with August at 84.55 cents a pound; live hogs were .28 cent to 1.25 cents higher with July at 61.60 cents a pound; frozen bellies for July and August delivery fell the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound with July settling at 54.17 cents. Other belly contracts were .10 cent lower to .43 cent higher. Copper futures settled 0.7 cent to 2.5 cents higher on New York's Commodity Exchange, reflecting increasing worries about supply availability. A strike at Asarco Inc.'s Ray copper mine in Arizona stretched into its sixth day Friday. Futures also were supported by news that production from the Chilean Copper Co.'s El Teniente mine would drop by 18,000 metric tons this year due to a landslide Thursday. In precious metals trading on the Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled 10 cents to 40 cents lower with August at $362.90 a troy ounce; silver was 0.3 cent to 0.5 cent lower with July at $4.866 a troy ounce. Petroleum futures were little changed on the New York Mercantile Exchange. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 1 cent to 6 cents lower with August at $16.47 a barrel; heating oil was .09 cent lower to .06 cent higher with August at 48.30 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .20 cent to .46 cent higher with August at 55.41 cents a gallon.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices gained ground Friday in the slowest trading of the year, rebounding from Thursday's setback as traders studied the latest data on employment. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 25.74 to 2,904.95, finishing the week with a net gain of 24.26 points. The average fell 32.42 points on Thursday. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 8 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 851 up, 537 down and 566 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 111.73 million shares, down from 128.32 million Thursday and the lightest total since a 77.61 million-share day last Dec. 26. Analysts had expected a quiet session in the absence of many traders who were taking time off after Independence Day on Wednesday. The Labor Department reported that nonfarm payroll employment increased by 40,000 in June. Employment data for the past few months have been skewed by temporary hiring for the Census. But brokers said the June data generally lived up to expectations. The figures were seen as confirming sluggish growth, at best, in business activity _ while at the same time probably not signaling enough weakness to prompt any immediate relaxation of the Federal Reserve's credit policy. Eli Lilly rose \ to 86{ and Genentech gained { to 29{. A research study published this week reported evidence that a growth hormone produced by the companies can reverse some of the effects of aging in older men. Elsewhere in the pharmaceutical sector, Abbott Laboratories rose ] to 41|; Pfizer 1 to 65~; Rorer Group 1] to 74, and Syntex 1\ to 60{. A broad range of consumer products issues also showed strength, benefiting like the drug stocks from investors' search for recession-resistant growth companies. General Mills advanced 1~ to 90{; CPC International 2{ to 82\; Kimberly-Clark 3{ to 78\; Pepsico 2[ to 79~, and Philip Morris 1} to 49\. Other gainers among the blue chips included Boeing, up 1\ at 60{; American Express, up { at 31~; Exxon, up 1 at 47}, and General Electric, up ] at 70|. Mack Trucks, traded in the over-the-counter market, added 1\ to 6{. Renault of France, which owns about 44.5 percent of Mack, announced plans to make a $6-a-share bid for the rest of the stock. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 134.04 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $21.46 billion, or 0.63 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.33 to 195.78. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 3.43 to 422.32, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 2.74 at 358.42. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 1.34 to 460.53. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 358.87, up .38.

DOC.HEAD: Pittston Board Elects New President, Vice Chairman
DOC.TEXT: The board of directors of The Pittston Co. has elected a new president and vice chairman, the company said Friday. Joseph C. Farrell was elected president and chief operating officer, and David L. Marshall was elected vice chairman, the company said. Both had been executive vice presidents. Paul W. Douglas, chairman and chief executive officer, said the promotions were part of the transition plan for his scheduled retirement in September 1991. Pittston suffered a $10 million first quarter loss it blamed on a 10-month coal miners' strike and by poor performance in its air freight business. The Greenwich-based company is engaged in the mining and marketing of bituminous coal through the Pittston Coal Group, Inc. and Pyxis Resources Co.; in air freight services through Burlington Air Express, Inc.; in security transportation through Brink's Inc.; and in home security services through Brink's Home Security, Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Water Commission Recommends New Oil Spill Measures
DOC.TEXT: The Texas Water Commission recommended a 2-cent per barrel fee on crude oil moving through ports on the state's Gulf Coast. The money would help pay for cleanups of future oil spills. The fee would be charged until the balance in the Texas Spill Response Fund is raised from $750,000 to $50 million. The levy would be applied as needed to maintain that balance, the commission said. Approximately 560 million barrels of crude oil pass through oil-loading facilities by tanker along the Texas Gulf Coast every year, the commission said. It said the fee would raise more than $11 million per year. Since several oil and chemical companies have large plants in both Texas and Louisiana, the commission also said the new funding mechanism should be coordinated with Louisiana. Otherwise, shippers might go to Louisiana to avoid the fee. Interest and principal of the fund would be used to finance standby oil spill response contracts and state-owned equipment stockpiles. The money also could pay for a research and development program for new oil spill technology, such as the bioremediation used in the Mega Borg spill. In that process, bacteria was used to eat the oil and turn it into a fatty acid that could be consumed by marine life.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Measures Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Two measures of the nation's money supply rose in late June while a broader money measure fell, the Federal Reserve Board reported Friday. In a report delayed by one day due to the Independence Day holiday, the Fed said the narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose $1.3 billion to a seasonally adjusted $808.8 billion in the week ended June 25 from a revised $807.5 billion in the previous week. The central bank said a measure known as M2 advanced $1 billion to a seasonally adjusted $3,270.5 billion from $3,269.5 billion the previous week. But an even broader measure, M3, dropped $4.1 billion to a seasonally adjusted $4,053.9 billion from $4,058.0 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 4.4 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 was 1.7 percent, which is below the Fed's target range of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,267.3 billion, a 3.4 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,060.5 billion, up 0.5 percent, while M1 rose 3.4 percent to an average of $806.8 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major banks fell 1.3 billion in the week ended June 27, compared with a gain of $1.01 billion a week earlier. _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $430 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $420 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $640 million in the latest two weeks, up from $265 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $306.9 billion in the two-week period ended June 27, down from $309.0 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Shearson To Pay Record NYSE Fine To Settle Stock Trading Allegations
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. has agreed to pay the New York Stock Exchange a $500,000 fine to settle allegations that it violated exchange rules in buying E.F. Hutton & Co. stock in 1986, the NYSE said Friday. Shearson agreed to pay the fine without admitting or denying wrongdoing, the NYSE said. Shearson acquired a 4.9 percent stake in Hutton in 1986, then sold the shares that October after the management of the troubled brokerage rejected a Shearson takeover overture. Shearson, then known as Shearson Lehman Brothers, succeeded in acquiring Hutton the following year. According to the NYSE, Shearson violated exchange rules by failing to announce on the exchange floor as it bought the Hutton shares that they were intended for Shearson's own account, as opposed to a customer's account. NYSE rules require that any brokerage that is an exchange member must announce when it is buying shares for its own account. The rules also require that orders from the public to purchase stock in the same company take priority over a brokerage's order for its own account. The NYSE said in its disciplinary action that ``on at least three occasions, the Shearson floor broker failed to yield priority to public orders for purchases of shares of Hutton.'' The NYSE also criticized the manner in which Shearson sold its Hutton stake. Shearson sold a third of its stake on Oct. 15, 1986, the same day Hutton management privately rejected Shearson's takeover offer. The next day, Hutton announced publicly that it was not engaged in any acquisition discussions with any party, causing Hutton's stock price to plunge in heavy trading. The exchange said neither Shearson nor Hutton ever stated publicly that they were involved in takeover talks. While it did not allege that Shearson violated NYSE rules in selling the stake, the exchange said Shearson consented to findings that it ``engaged in conduct inconsistent with just and equitable principles of trade, and-or engaged in acts detrimental to the interest or welfare of the exchange.'' The sale of the stake, which was concluded over three days, coincided with heavy, volatile trading in Hutton stock fed by rumors that other companies were interested in taking over the brokerage. In addition to paying the fine, Shearson agreed to retain a special lawyer for three years to advise the brokerage on laws and regulations it must follow in trading stock for its own account. ``We determined to settle now rather than go through protracted litigation,'' said Mike O'Neill, a vice president and spokesman for Shearson, whose majority owner is American Express Co. Sharon Gamsin, an NYSE spokeswoman, said the fine was a record for the exchange. With respect to the sale of its Hutton stake, O'Neill said, ``Shearson didn't violate any law or existing interpretation of exchange rules.'' In determining Shearson's penalty, the NYSE said it considered that Shearson consulted with lawyers before selling its Hutton stake. In addition, after exchange officials questioned Shearson's purchase of Hutton shares, Shearson took steps to educate its employees about exchange rules pertaining to purchases for its own account, the NYSE said. The exchange also said Shearson took that action before it learned it was under investigation for its accumulation of Hutton stock. The exchange rules cited in the disciplinary action are based on federal laws governing stock trading, raising the possibility that Shearson could face legal sanctions. It could not be determined whether the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating Shearson over the Hutton stock accumulation. The SEC does not comment on its investigtions. However, a Wall Street source close to the case, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the SEC was not believed to be investigating Shearson.

DOC.HEAD: Renault Seeks to Buy Mack Trucks Stock
DOC.TEXT: Mack Trucks Inc. Chairman Ralph E. Reins said Friday a plan by Renault Vehicules Industriels to buy out Mack's remaining outstanding shares is essential to the truck manufacturing company. Mack announced Friday that Renault, which holds about 44.5 percent of outstanding shares of the American firm, wants to buy all remaining shares at $6 a share. The deal, if Renault succeeds, would be worth about $98.7 million. Reins, who was attending a Mack board meeting in France, told employees he views Renault's tender offer ``to be a very positive development,'' according to Mack spokesman James Santanasto. Renault's financial and operational support is ``crucial to the survival of Mack,'' Reins said. New York business analyst Charles Harris of Oppenheimer & Co. said Mack had been in ``a downward spiral in the last 10 years,'' and said he did not think Mack could survive as an independent company. ``This company is dying on the vine and has to do something,'' Harris said. Mack shares closed at $6.50 in over-the-counter trading Friday, up from $5.25 on Thursday. Santanasto said Renault now owns 13.25 million shares of Mack's 29.7 million outstanding shares and has warrants for an additional 5 million. Renault, which said it would make its offer July 12, also has $50 million worth of convertible debentures. If exercised and converted with the warrant, the French firm's ownership would increase to about 61.1 percent. The Renault offer expires Aug. 9 and is conditioned on enough shares being tendered to boost its interest in Mack Trucks to at least 90 percent of the truck manufacturer's shares. Renault said it was making the offer ``because of the continuing deterioration of the financial condition of Mack'' and the need to restructure the company's debt. Mack, which lost a record $185.4 million last year and $33.9 million in the first quarter of 1990, said it expects a net loss of about $90 million for the six months ended June 30. The Mack board, which includes four representatives of Renault, Friday approved a five-year business plan which projects a net loss of about $130 million for the year ending Dec. 31, 1990. In a news release, Mack officials said they do not expect the company to show a profit before 1992. Mack officials said the company would probably default on its consolidated, three-year revolving bank loans with Citibank of New York and Credit Lyonnais of France after its second-quarter results are announced. Mack Truck's subsidiary, Mack Financial Corp., has obtained a two-week extension and is seeking a long-term extension of the July 8 maturity date of its $350 million revolving credit agreement with Chemical Bank. In the past year, Mack had tried to reduce business costs and conserve cash amid a slowing market for heavy trucks. The effort to stem the company's failing fortunes included the resignation of John Curcio as chairman last October when Mack announced it expected to lose $50 million in the third quarter _ a figure eventually reported at $87.5 million. Curcio was replaced by Reins, who had predicted that 1990 would be a ``transitional year'' for the manufacturer. The company's 1989 net sales totalled $1.75 billion, 17 percent lower than 1988 net sales of $2.1 billion. In June, analysts predicted that Mack's options to save itself from bankruptcy could include closing plants in Winnsboro and Hagerstown, Md., but Santanasto said Friday there were no such plans.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Fugitive Held in Barbados
DOC.TEXT: A former insurance executive accused of defrauding companies and policyholders of more than $50 million has been arrested in his Barbados hideaway and Texas officials have moved to freeze his assets there. The State Board of Insurance said Friday that Robert Walker is facing court action to impound his holdings in Barbados, where he was seized by local police two days earlier on a U.S. warrant. Walker's assets in Barbados could be used for the benefit of Texas policyholders, creditors and taxpayers, the State Board of Insurance said. In Barbados, police spokesman David Bourne said said Walker, 60, was seized at a resort hotel on the Caribbean island where he has been living for the past three months. Walker is wanted in connection with the multimillion-dollar collapse of his Dallas-based National County Mutual Fire Insurance Co. National County Mutual, a property-casualty insurer, was more than $50 million in debt by the time it was taken over by the State Board of Insurance in October 1988, Texas authorities said. ``One of our primary concerns is to enforce the $55 million judgment ... obtained against Mr. Walker in February 1989,'' said board Chairman James Saxton Jr. Thus far, board liquidator Stephen Durish has recovered approximately $2 million in assets belonging to Walker and National County Mutual, the board said in a statement. A federal grand jury in Dallas indicted Walker June 12 on 29 felony counts charging he devised a scheme to defraud the insurance companies and their policyholders in 1987 and 1988. He is also charged with selling policies at a time when the companies did not have the means to pay claims. If convicted, Walker faces a maximum penalty of 145 years in prison and a $7.25 million fine, and he could be ordered to pay restitution.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Plunge on Unemployment News
DOC.TEXT: Government bond prices plunged Friday on news that the nation's unemployment rate dropped in June, making it unlikely that the Federal Reserve will ease interest rates in the near future. The Treasury's key 30-year bond fell 1[ point, or $11.25 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which rises when the price falls, increased to 8.50 percent from 8.40 percent late Thursday. Traders bid bond prices lower in reaction to the Labor Department's monthly unemployment report, which showed that the nation's jobless rate fell last month to 5.2 percent from 5.3 percent in May. William Sullivan, director of money market research for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said the report ``showed a bit more buoyancy in the labor force than the market had anticipated.'' News of a stronger economy makes it less likely that the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates. Lower rates benefit fixed-return investments such as bonds. Gib Clark, chief bond trader for Daiwa Securities Inc., said the unemployment report capped a week of figures that were disappointing to the bond market, including a report showing auto sales were stronger than expected. ``It kind of scotches the thought of Fed easing,'' he said. In addition, Sullivan said, the bond market is under price pressure as it faces the auctions of several major new bond issues next week, including $5 billion worth of 30-year bonds by the Resolution Funding Corp., the federal agency that raises money for the savings-and-loan bailout. Bond prices often soften temporarily as the market anticipates potential difficulty in digesting new issues. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments fell from 7-32 point to 15-32 point, intermediate maturities fell from 19-32 point to 31-32 point, and long-term issues fell up to 1[ points, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 5.56 to 1,157.15. Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 8 percent as the discount rose 9 basis points to 7.75 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 8.08 percent as the discount rose 10 basis points to 7.67 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 8.13 percent as the discount rose 12 basis points to 7.57 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8\ percent, up from 8 percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell 3-16 point to 91 27-32. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.47 percent from 7.45 percent late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Seize $3.15 Million Said Taken Illegally From Failed Thrift
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents have seized $3.15 million that the president of a failed savings and loan allegedly removed from the thrift after it was taken over by the government's Resolution Trust Corp. An assistant U.S. attorney said Friday it was the first time the government has made such a seizure under a law designed to prevent misuse of money from failed thrifts. But no charges were filed against the thrift official, who said the transaction was legal. The U.S. attorney's office in Houston on Monday filed a civil forfeiture complaint in U.S. District Court to seize the money. It alleges that Joe G. Garza, then-president of McAllen-based Valley Federal Savings Association, illegally removed the money from Valley Federal after it failed Oct. 19, 1989, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Mike Clark of Houston. Garza, however, said he transferred the account and several others to various institutions with the approval of the RTC and the Office of Thrift Supervision in Dallas. ``They were fully aware of what we were doing,'' Garza said Friday. ``They encouraged it. They did not want us to have any accounts that were uninsured.'' No charges were filed against Garza. The complaint alleges that Garza transferred the $3.15 million to the NCNB Texas bank in Harlingen, where federal agents this week seized it, Clark said. The money was a certificate of deposit in the name of Inversiones Sagomar Inc., believed to be a Panamanian corporation, the federal prosecutor said. Clark said the account seizure, completed Thursday, was the federal government's first under the Financial Institution Reform Recovery and Enforcement Act of 1989. The act allows for the forfeiture of funds misappropriated by employees of savings institutions which have been taken over by the RTC. Garza apparently was trying to protect the money from forfeiture to the RTC, the federal corporation formed to sell assets from failed S&L's in its effort to bail out the troubled industry, Clark said. The RTC is a branch of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil, Argentina Plan to Remove Bilateral Trade Barriers by 1995
DOC.TEXT: The countries with the biggest economies in South America, Brazil and Argentina, will remove all barriers to bilateral trade by Dec. 31, 1994, presidents Fernando Collor de Melo and Carlos Menem said Friday. Trade between the two countries amounted to $2 billion in 1989, with Argentina posting a $401 million surplus. Bilateral trade in 1988 totaled $1.7 billion, with Brazil posting a $364 million surplus. Trade currently is regulated by lists of products that are subject to quotas and tariffs. During the next four years, the quotas and tariffs gradually are to be reduced. Important items include agricultural products such as rice, beans, powdered milk, apples and peaches; and industrial products such as cars and automobile parts. Among two dozen protocols signed by the presidents, each nation stipulated it may send up to 10,000 cars to the other next year. Tariff-free trade in the automobile sector was projected at $300 million in 1991 and $500 million in 1992, after which tariffs would be removed altogether. The ``common market'' between the neighboring countries and long-time rivals was suggested in 1986 by then presidents Raul Alfonsin of Argentina and Jose Sarney of Brazil. Both were present with Menem and Collor de Melo, whose terms run through 1994.

DOC.HEAD: British Airways Orders Up to 33 Boeing 747s
DOC.TEXT: The day after learning a potentially huge aircraft purchase had been put on hold, Boeing Co. was soothed Friday by its fourth-largest order ever, a deal for up to 33 747 jumbo jets for British Airways PLC. The order, potentially worth $6.9 billion, was the biggest-ever investment in new planes by London-based British Airways, which said it needed extra passenger capacity as well as replacements for older jets. The airline also said it had negotiated the right to buy a larger airplane that Boeing hasn't even decided to develop. British Airways said it placed firm orders for 21 Boeing 747-400s, the world's largest passenger jet, for 2.33 billion pounds, the equivalent of $4.15 billion. It took options to buy 12 more for 1.55 billion pounds, or $2.8 billion. In doing so, it joined a growing number of carriers ordering aircraft nearly a decade in advance to ensure they will have enough passenger seats during the early 21st century. ``All they're doing is protecting their position in terms of requirements. They didn't want to be last in the queue,'' said Dan White, an analyst with the London investment firm County Natwest Woodmac. The announcement came as Boeing increased its forecast of work force reductions this year in Washington state, where most of its plants are located. Boeing said about 5,600 jobs would be cut this year, 600 more than its January estimate, mostly because of uncertainties in defense contracts. Boeing currently has 103,800 workers in Washington and 161,000 worldwide. British Airways is to receive the first of its new planes in 1992 and the 21st in 1999, bringing its 747-400 fleet to 42 aircraft. The company has bought 21 747-400s since 1986 and operates 224 airplanes in all. ``The aircraft will provide extra capacity as well as allowing us to replace older Boeing 747 equipment,'' British Airways Chairman Lord King said. ``Our 747-400s are delivering good performance and proving popular with intercontinental passengers.''
