UAL Corp., the parent of United Airlines, had been expected to announce within the next few weeks the largest commercial jet purchase ever, possibly to include Boeing's proposed new 777 widebody. However, the employees' group seeking to buy UAL and the corporation's board of directors announced Thursday that talks with aircraft manufacturers had been suspended until the employee group could secure loans for the buyout. UAL directors said the aircraft negotiations are on hold until Aug. 9, the deadline for the employees to secure buyout financing. Boeing's largest-ever firm order for aircraft was a $9.4 billion deal for 182 planes by Irish leasing company GPA Ltd. in April 1989. A week later, United placed the second-largest, ordering 180 planes worth $7.1 billion. So far this year, Boeing has anounced orders for 240 aircraft, worth a total $25.3 billion. Its firm-order backlog is for more than 1,700 aircraft. British Airways' order was the third multibillion-dollar purchase of 747-400s in as many months. Japan Airlines ordered 20 planes for $3.1 billion in May, and Korean Air ordered 23 more for $4.8 billion in June. Both those carriers also said they needed more capacity, and likewise are to receive the last of their new planes at the end of the 1990s. King said British Airways obtained the right to convert any of the orders if Boeing develops a larger version of the 747. ``Although no details have been confirmed, we envisage that new 747 variants could provide passenger capacities between 450 and 600 seats,'' he said. Boeing executives have conjectured that in the late 1990s, the company could build a ``747 super.'' The plane would be significantly larger than the model 400, which can carry 412 passengers more than 8,000 miles, and more than 560 in short-range versions. However, company officials have made no decision on whether to build such a plane and offered no specifics on how large it might be. ``There's nothing in the works at all,'' said John Wheeler, spokesman for Boeing Commercial Airplane Group in Seattle. He said the conversion options negotiated by British Airways are ``just insurance on the part of the airline'' in case Boeing does come up with another jet. Rolls-Royce PLC won the $1.07 billion contract for the 747 engines. Rolls-Royce spokesman Dick Dalton in Reston, Va., said the deal was for 160 RB211-524G engines, including spares. British Airways also said it would begin a 30 million pound, or $53 million, refurbishment program for its existing 747-100s, which eventually will be replaced by the new jets. The airline did not say how it would pay for its new airplanes. Analysts said they expected the airline to own some of the aircraft, and obtain leases on others to contain costs.

The nation's unemployment rate edged downward to 5.2 percent last month despite an ongoing slide in manufacturing and overall weakness in job growth, the government reported. Fewer Americans looking for work _ not any rebound in sluggish economic activity _ accounted for the improvement over May's jobless rate of 5.3 percent, analysts said Friday. The economy added just 40,000 jobs to non-farm payrolls in June, the Labor Department said. __ NEW YORK (AP) _ Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. has agreed to pay the New York Stock Exchange a record $500,000 fine to settle allegations that it violated exchange rules in buying E.F. Hutton & Co. stock in 1986, the NYSE said. Shearson agreed to pay the fine without admitting or denying wrongdoing, the NYSE said Friday. According to the NYSE, Shearson violated exchange rules in 1986 by failing to announce on the exchange floor as it bought a 4.9 percent stake in Hutton that the shares were intended for Shearson's own account, as opposed to a customer's account.

The summit stage moved to President Bush's hometown, where leaders of the world's seven largest industrialized nations will turn their attention to the economic configuration of the post-Cold War world. Questions of direct economic aid to the Soviets, a contentious fight over farm subsidies and problems of global pollution were expected to dominate the negotiating sessions and working dinners, which get under way Monday.

The Acura luxury car division of Japan's Honda Motor Co. Ltd. has topped the J.D. Power and Associates list of cars most satisfying to their owners for the fourth year in a row, the marketing company said. The organization said in a news release received Friday that its overall customer-satisfaction index rose about 3 percent to 122 points this year from last year.

A Delaware court paved the way for an investor group to proceed in its takeover attempt of National Intergroup Inc., a Pittsburgh-based holding company of metals and pharmaceutical makers. Vice Chancellor Maurice Hartnett of the Delaware Chancery Court ruled Friday that Centaur Partners Group may proceed with its appeal to the Delaware Supreme Court. The New York investor group is asking the court to decide whether a simple majority of shareholders can vote to expand the firm's board of directors from 12 to 15 members. National Intergroup contends 80 percent of shareholder approval is necessary.

The Bush administration said it is planning to enhance current seafood inspections with a voluntary program financed by companies whose products could earn an official government seal. The new program would use industry controls and government inspections ``to provide additional assurances to consumers that fish and fish products are safe, wholesome and properly labeled,'' officials said Friday.

The government ordered Hawaii-based Discovery Airways closed down in one week, accusing the 3-month-old carrier of violating U.S. laws on foreign ownership. The Transportation Department on Friday ordered the airline to cancel its flights and inform passengers how to obtain refunds or alternate transportation.

A federal judge rejected a request from jurors in the fraud and racketeering trial of three commodities traders that they be allowed to go to the scene of the alleged crimes _ the floor of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The jury said, ``We believe this could be instrumental to reaching a unanimous verdict, if we were to view the pit for approximately 15 to 30 minutes prior to the close of trading.'' But U.S. District Judge Ann C. Williams denied the request on Friday.

East Germany gave communities control of former state-run grocery stores after consumers found eye-popping food prices in their first foray into the free market. Stung by the soaring prices that followed the merger of the German economies on Sunday, Parliament passed a law Friday to break up the state grocery chains that suddenly had become unregulated monopolies.

Stock prices gained ground Friday in the slowest trading of the year, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 25.74 to 2,904.95 and finished the week with a net gain of 24.26 points. The dollar finished mixed on domestic currency markets after closing higher overseas. Bond prices dropped sharply. Grain and soybean futures prices plunged for the second straight day; pork futures fell sharply; copper futures climbed; precious metals slipped; and energy futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Raytheon Said to Lose $100 Million Contract
DOC.TEXT: Raytheon Corp. has lost its bid for a $100 million contract that would have allowed it to enter the lucrative international submarine electronics market, a Rhode Island congresswoman said Friday. Rep. Claudine Schneider, R-R.I. said in a statement that Raytheon had been notified it lost the contract. Raytheon had hoped the contract to build combat systems for two Israeli diesel submarines would provide an entrance to the submarine electronics market, estimated by some to be worth $1 billion. That would provide long-term work and job stability at a time when Defense Department procurement budgets are shrinking. But the contract was awarded to Krupp Atlas Elektronik, a German firm working in conjunction with Loral Corp. of Ohio, according to sources in Washington and Portsmouth. Loral would perform about 60 percent of the work. According to a government official in Washington, the Israeli government has asked that the contract be awarded to the German-American venture. Raytheon officials were unavailable for comment Friday. Spokesman Joseph DeBilio was not in the office late in the day. Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., is a conglomerate that holds the fourth-largest share of U.S. defense contracts. It had courted the contract aggressively. Failure to win it could mean major layoffs at the company's Submarine Signal Division in Portsmouth as early as next week, according to a company source cited in the Newport Daily News in Friday's editions. The facility employs about 2,800. The awarding of the contract was complicated because the program involves U.S. military aid to foreign nations, namely, Israel. Money given under the aid program is to be used exclusively for U.S.- or Israeli-made arms. But because no U.S. shipyards make diesel subs anymore, Israel was allowed to buy the subs from a West Germany company. However, ``It would be unfair for Israel to pay for the German portion of Krupps@Loral system with U.S. taxpayer dollars while Raytheon could build the same system,'' Schneider said. ``This approval would directly conflict with the stated policy.'' Schneider said she wrote to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney Friday asking him to withhold U.S. aid for the contract pending an investigation. Rep. Ronald Machtley, R-R.I. said in June that Israel had asked for a waiver of the aid program to purchase the German systems. An Israeli spokeswoman denied that. At that time, Cheney said an exemption would not be granted. But some officials, including Ohio Sen. John Glenn, a Democrat, had wanted the German-American team to get the contract.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Dial and Greyhound Bus Lines Enter Pact
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Dial Corp. has entered an interim agreement with Greyhound Bus Lines to maintain uninterrupted operation of the bus line while it is involved in U.S. Bankruptcy Court proceedings. Under an agreement announced Thursday, Greyhound Lines will pay Greyhound Dial rent for 15 bus terminals, a maintenance garage in New York and about 2,000 buses leased or subleased to Greyhound Lines. The agreement, filed with a bankruptcy court in Brownsville, Texas, can be canceled by either party with 30 days' written notice. Phoenix-based Greyhound Dial sold the bus line in 1987 to a Dallas-based investor group. Greyhound Dial still owns 22{ percent of GLI Holdings, the parent company of Greyhound Lines. In June, the bus company sought federal protection under Chapter 11 while it reorganized. The filing came after Greyhound Lines workers walked out in a labor action. The strike, started in March, has not been resolved.

DOC.HEAD: Pharmacy Board Member Testifies in Rite Aid Trial
DOC.TEXT: A jury on Friday watched a secretly made videotape and listened to a taped phone conversation in the bribery trial against the Rite Aid Corp. drugstore chain and its president, Martin L. Grass. Grass, 36, is accused of offering $33,000 to a member of the State Board of Pharmacy to step down from that post, thus creating a spot the company could arrange to fill with someone more to its liking. The pharmacy board member, Melvin Wilczynski, 61, testified that he met with Grass in a Cleveland hotel room on April 27, 1989, and spoke with the company president about signing one of six resignation letters prepared by the company. The variously-worded letters were addressed to Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste, who appoints the board members, said Wilczynski, who remains on the board. Grass also handed him a corporate check for $33,249, he testified. Wilczynski said he cooperated with Cuyahoga County authorities and wore a surveillance wire while they filmed the meeting with a hidden camera. The film showed Grass and Wilczynski leafing through papers. On the tape, Wilczynski notes that there are several different resignation letters. The two also speak about health insurance for Wilczynski. There is a knock on the door and then the tape stops. Prosecutors said the arrest of Grass was made at that time. After the arrests, Wilczynski testified, he was so nervous that his shirt was wet with perspiration. ``I asked one of the officers if he could hear my heartbeat,'' he said. The jury also listened to a tape of a phone conversation Wilczynski had on the day before the arrest, in which he set up the meeting with Grass. The trial resumes Monday. Rite Aid, based in Shiremanstown, Pa., has denied wrongdoing and said the check was a legitimate buyout of a consulting contract Wilczynski had with Lane Drug., a division of Peoples Drug Stores Inc. acquired by Rite Aid in April 1989. An indictment unsealed in August charged Grass and Rite Aid with bribery and with possession of a criminal tool, described as a Rite Aid corporate aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Former Thrift Chief Wins $19 Million Reprieve in War With Regulators
DOC.TEXT: Former Columbia Savings & Loan chief Thomas Spiegel won a reprieve Friday from posting nearly $19 million while he fights charges he squandered thrift funds. However, U.S. District Judge Stephen Wilson restricted Spiegel's personal finances until a hearing later this month and ordered him to post a $1 million bond by Wednesday. Spiegel's lawyer called the ruling a victory in his war with U.S. thrift regulators, who had sought to freeze the $19 million in an escrow account Friday and are seeking another $5 million in fines. The $24 million is the largest civil case ever brought against an individual by the regulators. Spiegel has accused the regulators of making him a scapegoat to divert attention from their incompetence. ``He's holding up fine and we're confident that we're going to be able to respond to all the charges against him,'' said Spiegel's lawyer, Dennis Perluss. Regulators say Spiegel wasted Columbia funds on guns, rock concerts, wine, vacations, partnerships and purchases with junk bond king Michael Milken, loans to an auto dealer who provided free luxury cars to Spiegel, and $2.8 million in bonuses he drew even as Columbia was losing money. Spiegel, who earned multimillion-dollar salaries while pouring Beverly Hills-based Columbia's money heavily into Milken's high-risk, high-yield bonds, was charged Thursday by the OTS with improperly diverting the money. Acting on Perluss' request for a temporary restraining order, Wilson temporarily barred the federal Office of Thrift Supervision from enforcing its ``cease and desist'' order requiring Spiegel to put the $19 million in escrow. Perluss argued that the law authorizing such emergency freezes only applies to current directors or officers of a thrift. Spiegel resigned from Columbia at the start of the year; the thrift had lost $591 million during the year due to the sharp drop in the value of its junk bond portfolio. The freeze also would violate Spiegel's right to due process unless a neutral arbitrator holds a hearing on the matter, Perluss argued. Wilson blocked the OTS from forcing Spiegel to put the money in the escrow account until at least July 30, when a hearing will be held before Wilson. But he also ordered Spiegel to use his assets only for reasonable living expenses until then and to give the thrifts office 48 hours notice if he wants to spend more than $5,000 on anything other than living expenses and lawyers. The OTS has the right to challenge any such expenditures in court. Under the direction of Spiegel, a close ally of former Drexel Burnham Lambert junk bond chief Milken, Columbia had the industry's largest portfolio of high-yield, high-risk junk bonds. Columbia is still operating, but analysts predict junk bond losses eventually will force government seizure. The $19 million in restitution, if recovered, would go to the thrift, while the $5 million penalty would go to the U.S. Treasury. Perluss said the conditions imposed by the judge on Spiegel's finances were ``perfectly reasonable.'' ``We certainly expect that Mr. Spiegel will fully perform all of these conditions and be on the conservative side in doing so,'' Perluss said.
